HEADLINE: Beijing Sees U.S. Moves As Plot to Thwart China

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, July 31

 BODY:
Many senior members of China's military and political establishment have come to believe in recent months that the United States is actively conspiring to undermine China politically, economically and militarily, Chinese officials and Western experts say.
In this view, ominous signs are everywhere: The United States is trying to split Taiwan from the mainland, it is blocking China's entry into the World Trade Organization, and it is sending spies like the American human rights advocate Harry Wu to collect evidence in order to fabricate stories about China's penal system. 
 As Secretary of State Warren Christopher prepares to meet Foreign Minister Qian Qichen of China on Tuesday in the sultanate of Brunei, Chinese-American relations are at their worst since the 1989 massacre in Beijing. Although concessions are possible at the meeting, as are polite promises to be nicer to each other in the future, it will be as hard to allay Chinese fears as it will be to make Americans forget about human rights.
The inflexible view that has taken hold in Beijing leaves no easy answers for the Clinton Administration, still struggling to come up with a China policy: Efforts to engage China have arguably achieved little, while threatening diplomatic sanctions would only isolate it more.
With the Chinese Communist Party leadership in a precarious state of transition as Deng Xiaoping, the paramount leader, nears death, analysts believe that President Jiang Zemin is unlikely to take any bold gestures necessary to achieve a breakthrough. Several military officers, a Chinese official said, complained recently that Mr. Jiang had responded too slowly to the American decision to allow President Lee Tung-hui of Taiwan to visit the United States in June.
To military officers, the Chinese official said, the United States is a wily and deceitful enemy that revealed its true nature when it approved Mr. Lee's visit, after promising it would not do so.
To this way of thinking, the United States has pretended for years to support China's aim of reunifying Taiwan with the mainland, but has now bared its true intention to help keep them apart by aiding Mr. Lee, whom the Chinese now accuse of secretly planning to declare independence for Taiwan.
"On Taiwan, there will be no concessions," a senior Foreign Ministry official said. "This is part of our national territory. It is like the American Civil War, when the U.S. Government took a very strong position against the British decision to sell arms to the South."
If this comparison sounds strained, it may be because the Chinese civil war ended 46 years ago. But the Chinese Defense Minister, Chi Haotian, reiterated today that China could use force to "settle the Taiwan issue," and criticized "foreign forces' attempts to interfere in China's internal affairs."
John W. Lewis, a professor at Stanford University, said he learned in recent meetings with Chinese military leaders in Beijing that they have ordered a comprehensive review of China's long dormant military contingency plans aimed at preventing Taiwan from declaring its independence.
"No one wants to go down this path," Mr. Lewis said. "But the United States is forcing them to consider for the first time in decades developing contingency plans for a possible crisis that not only involves Taiwan's independence but United States intervention in the relationship between Taiwan and the mainland."
David Shambaugh, professor of Chinese politics at the University of London, said the emerging hard-line view hangs on four points: The United States is trying to divide China territorially, subvert it politically, contain it strategically and frustrate it economically.
"This consensus is now shared across the spectrum," said Mr. Shambaugh, who added that he was surprised by the uniformity of views he found in meetings with officials and scholars in Beijing last week. "The military has the decisive voice."
This view has not been articulated publicly. Yet it was hinted at in a series of unusually vitriolic official People's Daily commentaries, which are typically issued after an internal consensus has been reached, and which this time accused the United States of colluding with President Lee to work toward a declaration of independence.
"Lee Tung-hui, in an attempt to win the support of the United States for his proposition on the independence of Taiwan, had done his utmost to drive a wedge in Chinese-American relations, and thus made himself a willing card in the hands of the United States," one commentary said. "In the United States there are indeed some people who always follow a policy of opposing and splitting China."
The senior Foreign Ministry official said that "we have received many views" from Chinese officials who see the United States as trying to undermine China.
If it seems obvious to anyone in Washington that the Clinton Administration has no coordinated China policy, Mr. Shambaugh added, China's military sees a clear plan.
"They now see a broad-gauged attack on China," Mr. Shambaugh said. "They're prepared to hunker down and resist the assault, and they frequently compare it with the 1950's, when Mao called the United States its principal enemy."

HEADLINE: White House Lowers Estimate of Budget Deficit for Current Year

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
The White House said today that revised projections showed that the Federal budget deficit for the current fiscal year would now be $160 billion -- or $33 billion lower than previously estimated -- and that President Clinton's plan for balancing the budget in 10 years could probably succeed in 9.
Mr. Clinton pronounced the latest figures good news, and his top aides acknowledged that the revised estimates might help to foster a compromise with the Republicans, who want to balance the budget in seven years with spending cuts that the Administration contends are unrealistically large. 
 "I'm sure somebody will suggest that," the White House chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, said of a possible compromise as Mr. Clinton flew aboard Air Force One to the National Governors' Association meeting in Burlington, Vt.
But the budget director, Alice M. Rivlin, in a briefing at the White House, repeated the Administration's longstanding view that balancing the budget by a certain date was less important than balancing it without damaging programs in areas the President considers most important, like education.
"We are arguing for a specific set of policies, not for a specific date on which to get to balance," Ms. Rivlin said. Among other points, she noted, the Republicans favor far bigger cuts in growth of Medicare spending than Mr. Clinton has been willing to accept and at the same time they want steep tax cuts.
Mr. Panetta attributed the decline in the projected deficit for the current fiscal year, which ends on Sept. 30, to better-than-expected growth in the economy and a spending cut bill signed last week by Mr. Clinton that trimmed $9 billion from current spending.
Officials said they now projected that Mr. Clinton's proposal for balancing the budget would produce a modest surplus by 2004, one year sooner than expected because the effort to balance the budget would prompt lower interest rates than previously anticipated.
For example, by 2005, the rate on 91-day Treasury bills would be 4.4 percent, compared with 5.5 percent without the effects of the President's plan, according to the Administration's budget review. Officials said that drop was comparable to the one projected by the Congressional Budget Office.
Mr. Clinton, speaking to reporters in Vermont, said of the new deficit estimate: "I thought they were a little high before. I feel good about it."
Last month, the Congressional Budget Office estimated that far from balancing the budget, Mr. Clinton's proposals would prompt continued deficits in the $200-billion-a-year range into the next century. Ms. Rivlin acknowledged those differences today, but said they were a result of relatively small differences in assumptions about how the economy would perform, multiplied over the next decade.
"When you compound those differences over 10 years, you get large differences," she said.

HEADLINE: Clinton Vows to Veto Bill on Telecommunications Decontrol

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
President Clinton threatened this evening to veto the bill sponsored by House Republicans to deregulate the nation's telecommunications industries, saying that it would discourage competition.
The bill is aimed at dismantling the regulatory barriers that separate long-distance telephone, local telephone and cable television companies. The bill's Republican backers, Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr. of Virginia and Representative Jack Fields of Texas, contend that deregulation would foster competition. 
 In a statement this evening, President Clinton ran through a long list of objections to the bill. "Instead of promoting investment and competition, it promotes mergers and concentration of power," he said. "Instead of promoting open access and diversity of content and viewpoints, it would allow fewer people to control greater numbers of television, radio and newspaper outlets in every community."
If the bill "is sent to me without a deletion or revision of a significant number of these provisions, I will be compelled to veto it in the best interests of the public and our national economic well-being," he added.
An Administration official said that it was a coincidence that the veto threat came hours after the Walt Disney Company announced plans to take over Capital Cities/ABC. The veto threat "has been in the works for several days, and that was a total surprise to us as it was to anybody else," said the official, who did not wish to be identified.
The House is expected to vote on the bill later this week. Vice President Al Gore is scheduled to address a caucus of House Democrats early Tuesday afternoon to urge them to oppose the bill.
Republicans responded angrily to the President's threat, while denying the President's contention that the bill would foster monopolies. "If President Clinton were to follow through on his threat, he would be vetoing the single biggest job-creation bill of his Presidency, one that will break up the monopolies in local telephone and cable service and unleash the competitive forces that will truly bring the United States into the Information Age," said Mr. Bliley, the chairman of the Commerce Committee.
Mr. Fields is the chairman of the committee's panel on telecommunications and finance issues.
While Administration officials had previously expressed unhappiness with some features of the House Republican bill, President Clinton's statement marks the first time the White House has promised a veto if the bill is not changed. While President Clinton was reluctant to threaten vetoes in the months immediately following the Republicans' overwhelming victory in Congressional elections last November, he has changed tack in the last couple of months and threatened to stop half of the Republicans' spending bills and several other bills.
The current House bill would loosen restrictions on the number of television stations that an individual can acquire, and eliminate restrictions on radio purchases. It would deregulate cable television rates and allow local phone companies to offer long-distance service soon.
Rupert Murdoch, whose News Corporation controls the Fox television network, could be the biggest beneficiary of the House Republican bill because it would allow him to control more television stations.
Administration officials are trying to focus attention on the bill now in part because Mr. Murdoch is scheduled to testify on Tuesday before the House Ethics Committee. Mr. Murdoch will be questioned Tuesday about the $4.5 million advance initially offered to Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia by one of Mr. Murdoch's publishing companies. Under pressure, Mr. Gingrich gave up the advance.
The bill's telephone provisions have been heavily criticized by long-distance companies, which contend they would unfairly allow local phone companies to offer long-distance service long before long-distance companies could challenge the local monopolies. Long-distance phone company lobbyists contend that local phone companies will raise rates for consumers who have no alternative and use the profits to subsidize their new long-distance service.

HEADLINE: CLINTON AND DOLE PRESENT PROGRAMS TO ALTER WELFARE

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: BURLINGTON, Vt., July 31

 BODY:
President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole, his leading Republican rival for next year's Presidential race, presented competing visions of welfare reform to the nation's governors today.
Playing both to the governors and to a broader public widely disillusioned with current welfare programs, Mr. Dole and Mr. Clinton each said welfare must be changed, but they disagreed about the role the central Government should play in fashioning assistance to the poor. 
 Mr. Clinton, seeking to reclaim the initiative on an issue he capitalized on in the 1992 campaign, told the governors that his Administration had just taken action to move more quickly in approving state programs to put welfare recipients to work and would allow states to deny food stamp increases to people who lose welfare benefits for refusing to take jobs.
Mr. Clinton outlined his new executive actions just hours after Mr. Dole described to the National Governors' Association here his own efforts to break a Senate impasse among Republicans over welfare and to build a consensus around legislation that would give each state a lump sum of Federal money known as a block grant to assist poor people.
The reaction among the governors was predictably partisan. Republican governors endorsed Senator Dole's plan and criticized Mr. Clinton for not supporting a complete turnover of control to the states. Democrats said Mr. Dole was advocating a "cut and run" strategy in which the Federal Government cuts benefits and runs from its fundamental responsibility to poor children.
But both men came here to display their concern about welfare to the public, as well as to the governors. Just as Mr. Clinton often promised in 1992 to "end welfare as we know it," Republicans gearing up for 1996 have seized on widespread dissatisfaction with the system as a potent vote-getting weapon.
Mr. Dole, saying that the Great Society programs had failed, announced that the core of his approach was the principle that welfare should be controlled by the states without having to seek approval from the Federal Government. "Governors should not have to play a game of Mother May I," he said, ridiculing the current system under which governors must receive Federal permission, or waivers, to experiment with work programs. "Waivers have led us in the right direction," he said. "Now, let's finish the job. Real change will only occur when you are released from the burden of Federal rules and regulations."
Hours later, Mr. Clinton, in conciliatory remarks, praised Mr. Dole for breaking with conservatives in the Senate who want to require the states to deny cash assistance to unwed mothers and said that was "a very good start for us to work together."
But Mr. Clinton also expressed concerns about flat block grants for welfare with no requirements that states maintain current levels of spending on the poor, asking what would happen in a recession when more people would be seek assistance. If states have to trim benefits, he said, "I do honestly believe that there is a danger that some states will get involved in a race to the bottom," he said. "This program after all is called Aid to Families with Dependent Children not aid to states with terrible budget problems caused by Congress." The governors responded with laughter and applause.
Mr. Dole accused the White House of standing idly by while Senate Republicans debated welfare proposals. But today Mr. Clinton chose the governors' meeting to showcase the power of the President to act even as the Congress remains deadlocked. Mr. Clinton said, "We don't have to wait for Congress to go a long way toward ending welfare as we know it."
Mr. Clinton announced he was directing the Health and Human Services Department to take no more than 30 days to approve state welfare experiments following any of five strategies:
* Require recipients to work but provide adequate child care.
* Limit the amount of time people can collect welfare, provided that jobs are available to those willing to work.
* Require minor mothers to live at home and stay in school.
* Force fathers to either pay child support immediately or go to work to pay it if they are broke.
* Use welfare benefits and food stamp grants as cash subsidies to private employers who hire welfare recipients.
The waiver process now takes 120 days.
Mr. Clinton said he was also ordering the Office of Management and Budget to approve a change in regulations so that food stamp benefits do not automatically rise when a state reduces a welfare grant for someone who refuses to go to work. "If your welfare check goes down for refusal to work, you food stamp payments won't go up anymore," Mr. Clinton said.
And the President announced that he was approving four new state welfare experiments -- in California, Texas, Utah and West Virginia -- bringing to 32 the number of states that have Federal waivers to create their own welfare programs.
The state programs range from California's efforts to establish a cap on welfare benefits for each family so that there is no increase with the birth of a child, to Texas's plan to require parents to prove their children have been immunized or face reductions in benefits.
Mr. Clinton vowed during the 1992 Presidential campaign to "end welfare as we know it" and today he called the issue a "symbol of what divides us." But as President, Mr. Clinton put health care reform ahead of welfare and Republicans claimed the welfare issue as their own after they took control of Congress in the 1994 elections.
Although Republicans and most Democrats favor tying welfare to work requirements, legislative progress on the issue has been stalled for months by a dispute among Republicans, even though legislation approved by the House of Representatives and by the Senate Finance Committee are both tougher than Mr. Clinton's proposals and would set more stringent work requirements.
Mr. Dole has been working to broker a compromise around a measure that would change most welfare programs to block grants. State officials would have more discretion than they have now in decide how to use the money. But poor people would no longer have a legal right, or entitlement, to assistance and the Federal Government would put a cap on total spending regardless of economic need.
But one of Mr. Dole's rival in the Republican race, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, and 23 other conservative Republican senators want provisions to cut off cash benefits to unmarried teen-age mothers and deny additional benefits to welfare mothers who have babies.
Mr. Dole, in an indirect swipe at Mr. Gramm's plan, said, "I will do all in my power to insure that our reforms will not increase he tragedy of abortion in America."
Mr. Clinton similarly noted that abortion rates had been declining and "might turn around and go up again at least among some classes of people, if we pass that kind of rule everywhere in the country."
Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont, the Democrat who heads the governors' association said Mr. Dole's speech was conciliatory in tone, but said nevertheless block grants, because of their inflexibility, "are a terrible threat to the states' taxpayers."
And Mr. Chiles said that the assumption that states would take over welfare programs overlooked the fact that "these programs were started by the Federal Government because children weren't being taken care of."
Several Republicans bristled at Mr. Clinton's support for requirements that would keep states from cutting their own welfare expenditures, as Mr. Chiles predicted some would.
Gov. Fife Symington of Arizona said such requirements would curtail the states' abilities to experiment." He also was skeptical of Mr. Clinton's promise that waiver applications would be handled in 30 days, saying one from his state had recently taken a year. "If you were in my shoes," he said, "you would want to get Washington out of your life as much as possible."
Gov. Terry E. Branstad of Iowa, called Mr. Clinton's speech "the same old thing." He added: "He is talking about more waivers. I remember when he was a governor -- when he was with us."
Governor George E. Pataki of New York, while saying he found Mr. Clinton's welfare goals acceptable, complained about his way of reaching them. "The premise of this Administration is you achieve it by going to Washington." He asked, "Why should we need applications to Washington?"
Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah added the complaint that Mr. Clinton's approach "won't move toward a balanced budget."

HEADLINE: For Stocks, a Dull Session Despite the Disney Excitement

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The stock market muddled through a humdrum session yesterday as concern over economic conditions neutralized excitement over Walt Disney's plans to acquire Capital Cities/ABC in a $19 billion deal.
Popular Wall Street indicators registered minor losses. The Dow Jones industrial average, after drifting at slightly depressed levels for much of the day, ended with a deficit of 7.04 at 4,708.47 despite a solid gain by Disney. 
 Disney was the New York Stock Exchange's volume leader and spurted 1 1/4, to 58 5/8, while Capital Cities/ABC soared 20 1/8, to 116 1/4, also in brisk Big Board trading. A buying frenzy ensued in the entertainment sector; CBS surged 1 7/8, to 77 3/4.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index finished almost unchanged at 301.32, off 0.06, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.87, to 562.06, and the Nasdaq stock market composite shed 4.07, to 1,001.21. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 1.17, to 523.24.
Gainers squeaked past decliners on the Big Board, with a closing tally showing 1,159 stocks up, 1,059 down and 793 unchanged. Big Board volume eased to 289.9 million shares as of 4 P.M. from 311.6 million Friday.
In another takeover development, Wallace Computer Services rose 14 3/8, to 58 3/8 in heavy Big Board volume of more than 2.9 million shares in response to news that it was the target of a hostile takeover bid by the Moore Corporation for $1.3 billion, or $56 a share. Moore fell 7/8, to 22.
USAir was down 1 5/8, to 9 1/2, in heavy Big Board volume of more than 3.8 million shares. The carrier ended talks with its unions on a wage concession and restructuring package and said it would focus on labor cost reductions in collective bargaining.
James River gained 3/8, to 33 3/8, in heavy Big Board volume of more than 3.3 million shares. The company announced last week that it planned to cut 4,400 jobs in North America and Europe to generate savings up to $640 million.
ICN Pharmaceuticals, was up 2 3/4, to 19 5/8, in response to its agreement with Schering-Plough. ICN will receive a $23 million licensing fee from Schering-Plough in a deal that could ultimately lead to $42 million in ICN stock purchases if certain milestones are met. Schering-Plough rose 3/8, to 46 1/2.
Chipcom fell 2 7/8, to 41, in heavy Nasdaq volume of more than 2.7 million shares. Traders were not impressed with the possible bidding war for the computer network equipment maker. Cabletron Systems plans to buy more than $15 million of Chipcom stock, girding for a possible takeveor battle with 3Com, which has offered $39 a share, or about $775 million for Chipcom. 3Com fell 23/16 , to 741/16 .
Lechters was down 19/16 , to 135/16 . The Harrison, N.J., retailer of houseware products said it expected to report a loss of $1.9 million for the quarter ended July 29. That is less than a loss of $7 million a year earlier but still larger than expected.
John H. Shaughnessy, director of research at Advest Inc., said the Disney news reminded investors of "the impressive values in this market," despite the year's steady advance.
Interest rates were also on the minds of investors following release of mixed economic figures. The impact of unexpectedly sluggish data on income and spending was offset by a report on manufacturing activity in the Chicago area, considered a bellwether for the country.
The Commerce Department reported Americans' personal income rose four-tenths of 1 percent in June while spending increased an anemic two-tenths of1 percent last month after advancing nine-tenths of 1 percent in May.
Coming on top of news Friday that the economy barely expanded in the second quarter of 1995 -- turning in its weakest performance in nearly four years -- the income and spending data renewed hopes for interest rate cuts.
But the hopes were tempered by the report from Chicago-area purchasing managers, which showed pockets of strength.

HEADLINE: E. F. Johnson, Retail Analyst, Is Dead at 73

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
Edward F. Johnson, the founder and director of the Johnson Redbook Service, which had grown from a typical brokerage firm analyst's report into an influential retailing research publication, died on Saturday in Brick Township, N.J. He was 73 and was also the Mayor of Bay Head, N.J.
The cause of death was complications related to a brain aneurysm, a spokesman for Johnson Redbook, a division of Lynch Jones & Ryan, a New York brokerage firm, said yesterday. 
 Johnson Redbook provides weekly statistics on retail sales that are widely followed by Wall Street bond traders far beyond Mr. Johnson's own firm as an important economic indicator. Mr. Johnson was known for his blunt and straightforward opinions about trends in retailing, and his service was the only one that provided confidential industrywide statistics. For this reason, Mr. Johnson's weekly reports were viewed as an important sign of the future health of the nation's economy.
Mr. Johnson's service, which got its name from a red notebook that he used to collect data, was founded in 1970. He joined Lynch Jones & Ryan in 1991 and, before that, worked at Prescott, Ball & Turben for more than 20 years. Mr. Johnson's views about retailing trends and about specific companies in the apparel, retail and textile industries were considered influential on Wall Street. As an analyst, he was frequently quoted, especially as the retailing industry was buffeted in the last decade by mergers and bankruptcies.
Mr. Johnson graduated from the Lawrenceville School in Lawrenceville, N.J., and Cornell University. He was an officer in World War II, serving as captain of a B-24 bomber, based in Italy, and an officer of the Korean War. In 1952, he joined the Van Alstyne Noel Company, a brokerage firm, as a partner and later spent more than 40 years as a retailing analyst. He also followed the chemical industry throughout his career.
Mr. Johnson is survived by his wife, Janet Shearer Johnson; six children, Susan Johnson of Ridgefield, N.J.; Keats Landis of Piedmont, Calif.; Kate Johnson of Oakland, Calif.; Kimball Johnson of Denver; David Johnson of Phippsburgh, Me., and Edward, Jr., of Peru, Vt.; four stepchildren, Bari Edwards of Short Hills, N.J.; Gail Shearer of Bethesda, Md.; Mark Shearer of Tokyo, Japan, and Suzanne Whitehorn of Chatham, N.J.; two brothers, Tristam Johnson of Princeton, N.J. and Burgess Johnson, and seven grandchildren.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
The New Negotiations Are Still Languishing In the On-Deck Circle

BYLINE: By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
If anyone thought the past four months of time off from labor negotiations would have changed the climate, nah.
It was four months ago yesterday that Federal Judge Sonia Sotomayor issued the injunction that prompted the players to end their strike and return to work. Negotiators for the players and the owners have not conducted meaningful talks toward a new agreement since, not since the day before Sotomayor's order. 
 In the absence of labor developments, there has been baseball:
Division races, wild-card races; the emergence of the Cleveland Indians, after a four-decade drought, as the premier team in the American League, if not the major leagues; the awesome offense of the California Angels putting Gene Autry back in the saddle again, and the genuine threat of the Colorado Rockies winning a division championship in only their third year of existence.
Then there's the captivating performance of Hideo Nomo, who rivals Toyotas as the most popular Japanese import; the resuscitation of Tim Wakefield and his dancing, darting knuckleballs; the methodically marvelous talent of Greg Maddux; the trades of David Cone, Bobby Bonilla, Jim Abbott and others as contenders bolster themselves for the final two months.
So who needs labor negotiations? The players, the owners and the fans, that's who.
The players and the owners need them to get a deal and assure the fans peace in our time. The fans need that assurance to begin renewing their faith in the game they don't really want to abandon but feel they have to boycott to make some sort of protest or statement.
But the two sides have not met for four months, or more than half the length of the strike. During a hearing on the owners' appeal of the injunction, one of the judges noted that the union had tried to get a meeting scheduled, but to no avail.
Since then, lawyers for the owners and the players have met several times, but they have basically been trying to clean up the National Labor Relations Board charges against the owners, not negotiate a new agreement.
When it was written last week that the owners were not trying to get a new agreement, one of them objected, saying management had been the "aggressors" in trying to set up a meeting. Further, the owner said, union lawyers have told management lawyers they were not ready to make a deal.
Union people who were asked about those claims yesterday quickly disputed the ideas.
"We've been ready to sit down on a full basis since March 30, and they've said the owners don't want to come," one union person said.
As for the suggestion that the union is not prepared to make a deal, the person said: "We'll be glad to hear if they have any ideas. We're still waiting for a response to our proposal from last March."
The owners have decided that when talks resume, only lawyers will attend bargaining sessions. Owners became involved last August and remained in the talks until they broke off March 30. But now the owners themselves don't want to return to the table, even though they are the ones who will dictate management's bargaining position.
Each side, of course, has the right to designate its representatives, but before scheduling a meeting, union representatives said they wanted to discuss the format -- who would attend and how they would proceed with the talks.
Whatever has been resolved or left unresolved, the two sides are scheduled to revisit the critical economic matters soon (remember salary caps and luxury taxes?). "We're going to start talking economic issues with them as early as this week or next week," the owner said.
As of now, the lawyer lineup will be Stanley Jaspan of Milwaukee and Rob Manfred and Frank Coonelly of Washington for the owners and Lauren Rich of New York, Michael Weiner of Hackettstown, N.J., and Steve Fehr of Kansas City, Mo., for the players.
Bud Selig, the No. 1 management man, has talked of adding a new lawyer to the team, and the newest name to surface as a possibility is Randy Levine, who currently is New York City's commissioner of labor relations. When he was in private practice, Levine represented George Steinbrenner and the Yankees, often attending owners' meetings for the club.
If Levine is hired, given his present position, it would possibly not be as just another lawyer but as head of the owners' labor committee, last headed by Richard Ravitch.
A new person joining the talks in a critical position would need time to catch up, but if the rumors players hear are true, Levine or any new person would have more than enough time.
Players hear that the owners don't want a deal before the season ends. Considering their economic state and the ready-made excuse for lowering salaries, the idea goes, the owners don't need an artificial salary inhibitor. They could pay players as little as they want in many cases and use that strategy to force the players to accept whatever position they adopt.
If the owners were to pursue that strategy, they would do so with the belief that the players would not strike again. Indeed, the players prefer a new agreement to a new work stoppage, but they are unlikely to accept a deal at any cost.
Better to go back to the division races. They offer a much brighter outlook.

HEADLINE: Squaring Off on Welfare

 BODY:
Two clever politicians, anticipating next year's Presidential election, addressed the nation's governors yesterday on a subject of sure-fire appeal -- welfare reform. Both Senator Bob Dole and President Clinton called for more work and less welfare. But only Mr. Clinton addressed the needs of the poor.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole, the Senate majority leader, tried deftly to navigate the tricky political challenges they face inside their parties. Mr. Dole's proposals seemed tough enough to win the support of Congressional Republicans, yet were not nearly as punitive as those advanced by Senator Phil Gramm, a rival Presidential candidate. Mr. Clinton also offered stiffer welfare rules. But he pledged to help liberal Democrats preserve the safety net that guarantees Federal help to every poor family. 
 Speaking first, Mr. Dole said he would turn the money that Congress now spends on cash assistance, child care and job training over to the states in block grants with virtually no Federal strings. States could even choose to run the food stamp program themselves. In a stroke, he would gut a 60-year-old pledge that Washington will assist poor families no matter where they live.
Meantime, he cleverly countered Mr. Gramm's challenge from the right. Mr. Gramm and others have proposed Federal rules that would prohibit states from paying benefits to unwed teen-agers or raising benefits to parents who give birth while on welfare. Mr. Dole doubts he can win majority support for either idea. He therefore opposed them with the tactically clever argument that Mr. Gramm's restrictive rules could compel teen-agers to seek abortions.
Mr. Dole's attempt to solve another intra-party fight over spending formulas might also work. Northern states want block grants to mirror current formulas favoring high-income states. Southern states want block grants that would send extra money to states with rising populations. Mr. Dole proposes to preserve current spending patterns in the short term, but spend almost $1 billion more over the next seven years to help fast-growing states.
Mr. Clinton criticized Mr. Dole's block-grant proposal because it would lead to a "race to the bottom" as states, freed from Federal requirements, slashed benefits and services. Mr. Dole suggested that states could be trusted to protect the poor. He is wrong. Over the past 20 years, cash assistance, which is set by the states, has fallen by about 40 percent, after accounting for inflation. Food stamps, whose value is set by Congress, did not fall.
Mr. Clinton outlined an attractive fallback if the Republicans fail to pass comprehensive reform. He vowed quick administrative approval of state experiments that, for example, require recipients to work or limit how long they can collect benefits. But he insisted that to win Federal approval for such welfare-to-work proposals, states would have to help parents find affordable day care and, if necessary, jobs. He also vowed to help states enforce tougher standards by eliminating automatic increases in food stamps for recipients whose cash benefits have been reduced because they violated state rules. That may not sit well with liberals, but the proposal is true to Mr. Clinton's pledge to back state experiments.
The President's incremental ideas might be the best option in sight. His proposals would preserve the Federal entitlement of cash assistance and food stamps. They also provide time for the states to figure out how to institute time limits and other welfare-to-work reforms. Recent studies show that well-run experiments in Michigan, California and Atlanta have cut welfare costs by more than 20 percent and welfare rolls by more than 15 percent.
That may not be ending welfare as we know it. But it puts more parents to work and costs taxpayers less -- without removing the Federal safety net and thereby punishing children on the backs of ideological fervor and Presidential campaigning.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Victory Over the Stupids

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
The commandants of the gulags of the world and their security-ministry masters have two things in common, in whatever country they operate. They have a taste for torture, and they are very stupid.
Perhaps part of the combination comes from genetics. Some people seem to be born to fight for freedom and others to draw blood from them. 
 But the stupidity comes from a particular environment -- the totalitarian environment. The guardians of the gulags never have to test their minds against those of free men and women. So, in time, they move from the mental inferiority that drew them to their line of work to becoming truly mentally handicapped -- unable to understand that to free, inquiring minds they are panes of glass revealing instantly all their actions, motives and maneuvers. Their stupidity is the belief of the gravely dim-witted that they can manipulate and fool their intellectual betters.
The first such individual I encountered was a Governor of Goa when it was a Portuguese colony in India. He gave me permission to tour his prison to show me that the people for whom I was searching -- Indian Socialists who had crossed the border carrying freedom flags -- were not in his custody. He led me down a cell row leading left from a main corridor; large, sparsely occupied cells, Socialist-free.
As he showed me out, of course I walked to the right. The cells were packed with prisoners who had just been jammed into them, my Socialists. They held up arms livid with cigarette burns. The Governor looked at me in astonishment that anyone would ever think of turning in an unauthorized direction.
In the Soviet gulag a commandant was stunned that a visitor shown an isolation cell glistening clean white would smell the walls and discover they were damp with fresh paint.
Lord, Lord, how dull these people are. But for impenetrable stupidity I have rarely known anything like the film the Chinese made and sold to Western news organizations. This film is supposed to show that Harry Wu confessed that his reports are false.
My Harry, your Harry, the Harry of all who admire those who put their lives on the line for freedom. Harry Wu spent 19 years in Chinese slave-labor camps. After he was freed he made his way to America. But he kept returning to China to get even more information to spread before the world about slave-labor exports that support China's military establishment. And he has reported about organs taken from executed Chinese prisoners, then sold to sick, rich Chinese and foreigners who do not inquire whether the prisoners are guilty or of what.
Of course, Harry Wu was heard confessing to nothing except maybe some editing errors by a BBC editor of his own organ documentary. The gulag film really shows how hard Mr. Wu resisted, not that they had broken him.
The U.S. hopes that the film means the Communists are getting ready to release Mr. Wu. But there is as good a chance that the police apparatus will demand continued imprisonment.
American diplomats are doing their personal best to help Mr. Wu. But if he is released it will not be because of irresistible U.S. Government pressure.
There has been none applied that Beijing would recognize -- raising of tariffs, barring China from the World Trade Organization or blocking a World Bank loan. By breaking his promise to apply pressure for human rights in China and Tibet, President Clinton made himself the prisoner of Beijing.
Political apologias will not work, nor will the journalistic variety. I am thinking of the fellow on The New Republic who wrote a nasty little piece about how snatching salable organs from executed criminals was really not that bad. And I am thinking of the house liberal on the McLaughlin show who revealed much too much about herself by saying that after all we had to understand that the Chinese regarded Mr. Wu as a spy.
The only realistic hope is that some Chinese foreign-service officers who are not brain-dead will be able to overrule the security police, who gave Mr. Wu and his fully documented reports world recognition by arresting him instead of stopping him at the border and sending him back.
Harry Wu has won his victory. The only way China can now cut its losses and save face is to set him free. May God bless Harry Wu.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities In Price Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were higher in modest trading yesterday as the market awaited new supply and an important economic report.
As many traders stayed on the sidelines, waiting for Friday's report on employment in July, data released yesterday were mixed. Personal income and spending showed gains that were lower than expected, and a manufacturing report was stronger than expected. 
 The Commerce Department said June income was up four-tenths of 1 percent, compared with estimates of as much as six-tenths of 1 percent. Spending rose two-tenths of 1 percent, compared with estimates of as much as five-tenths of 1 percent.
While the increases were less than expected, the report also suggested that the economy was recovering at a pace fast enough to dissuade the Federal Reserve from lowering short-term interest rates anytime soon.
"The gap between personal income and personal spending does not suggest that there exists more room for consumption in the second half of the year," said Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation in Columbus, Ohio. "Given the fact that consumption grew by a fairly robust 2.5 percent in the second quarter, any acceleration beyond this growth rate is bound to cause some concern for credit markets and present a potential stumbling block."
Bond yields, which mirror expectations for inflation and the demand for loans, could be as high as 7.25 percent by Labor Day, Mr. Chan said.
Signs of resilient strength in the economy were also seen in the July report of the Chicago purchasing managers. The managers' index of business activity rose to 49.7 percent, from 47.6 in June. The forecast had called for a rise to 47.5 versus 47.6 percent in June.
"Much of the inventory correction that was long awaited may have taken place a lot sooner than expected," Mr. Chan said.
Mr. Chan said a jump the new orders component of the index suggested that the manufacturing sector was moving toward an expansion. "Such a development, if it persists, may very well push long-term Treasury rates into a new trading range of 7 percent to 7.25 percent within the next two or three months," he said.
The market typically pays attention to the Chicago purchasing managers' report because it is considered as a precursor to the broader report by the National Association of Purchasing Management, which is scheduled to be released today.
Yesterday, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond gained 24/32 , to 10928/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.84 percent from 6.90 percent.
The Treasury's regular weekly bill auction yesterday was solid all around, traders said. The average rate for a three-month bill was down 3 basis points from last week's auction, to 5.44 percent, while the six-month was down 7 basis points, to 5.39 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Market analysts expect that a supply of new securities in the coming weeks will likely limit any gains for the week. The Treasury will announce its quarterly borrowing requirements tomorrow. Corporate issues are expected to remain light as a result of the heavy economic calendar that will keep buyers somewhat at bay.
"A record $46 billion in municipal coupon and redemption proceeds are schedule to roll in this month," said Michael S. Appelbaum, senior vice president of investments at Paine Webber Inc. He said investors seeking reinvestment strategies should note the attractive municipal to Treasury yield ratios prevailing in today's fixed-income markets.
"Certain technical factors show the muni market in a slightly oversold condition," Mr. Appelbaum said, "and while it's not posible to predict whether municipal securities will be less expensive in the near future, the current attractive relationships should not be overlooked."
Municipal bonds were steady yesterday as investors focused on today's $1 billion sale of New York City bonds. According to Bloomberg Fair Value analytics, the bonds are expected to yield as much as 6.55 percent for a 30-year bond, or 17 basis points higher than similarly rated city bonds.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Steady as Traders Assess Credit Union Problems in Japan

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed in lackluster, thin trading yesterday as traders sorted through the suspension of operations at a large Japanese credit union and fresh signs of a revival of the American economy.
The dollar spent the day trading in a tight range, a condition likely to remain "until we see something to focus on," said Lynn Tierney, a foreign-exchange vice president at Shawmut Bank in Boston. She said many traders were awaiting the report Friday on July employment in the United States. 
 In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar slipped to 1.3845 German marks from 1.3856 marks on Friday. The dollar edged up to 88.32 Japanese yen from 88.11 yen. The British pound rose to $1.5975 from $1.5960.
In Asian trading, the dollar surged against the yen after anxious investors of Cosmo Shinyo Kumiai, the largest credit union in Tokyo, withdrew about 60 billion yen, or $680 million, 14 percent of its 439 billion yen in deposits.
The credit union was closed and the Bank of Japan poured several billion yen into the institution in hopes that foreign investors would be reassured to see a swift Government response to a financial crisis.
The quickness of the response led some traders to speculate that Japan might become more aggressive in its monetary policy, perhaps by lowering interest rates.
"I think the market was trying to figure it out," whether the Bank of Japan would ease, Ms. Tierney of Shawmut Bank said.
A Bank of Japan governor, Yasuo Matsushita, however, later ruled out the possibility of an immediate cut in rates.
The dollar was also supported yesterday by a report that showed strength in American manufacturing. The Chicago Purchasing Management Association said its index of area business activity rose to 49.7 percent in July from 47.6 percent in June. The increase was greater than expected.
The report helped the dollar because it showed the economy was more robust than previously thought, reducing the prospects that the Federal Reserve would lower interest rates, said Kevin Lawrie, foreign-exchange manager at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
Lower rates would make American assets less attractive to investors and create less demand for dollars.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
For one mutual fund company, memorable mayhem replaces more mundane images.

BYLINE: By Anthony Ramirez 

 BODY:
MOST advertising for giant mutual funds is baby-boomer pabulum: generic displays of Frisbee-catching dogs, handsome couples and grinning college graduates. As mutual funds proliferate -- there were more than 6,000 at last count, more than double the number of companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange -- their advertising seems to appear more and more alike.
But not at Alliance Capital Management, one of the largest American mutual fund companies, with more assets under management than the gross domestic products of Greece and Ireland combined. 
 With the help of Gary Weis, the cult documentary director who made quirky short films for "Saturday Night Live" in the 1970's, Alliance has put together a startlingly tongue-in-cheek series of new TV commercials that say, in effect, investing in stocks is complicated, so don't try this at home.
"The thing that rankled us was all these no-load mutual fund ads that said it was dumb to hire a professional," said John Carifa, president of Alliance Capital Management, a New York-based unit of the Equitable Companies unit of AXA S.A. of Paris. Alliance funds have $136 billion in assets under management and charge a sales fee, or load.
In the commercials, three cocksure Everymen plunge into ever more complicated tasks, certain they can cut hair, pull teeth and, most startlingly, perform do-it-yourself brain surgery. The ads run on such cable-television shows as "Crossfire" on the Cable News Network and "Biography" on the Arts & Entertainment network.
The new ads, which began last month, grew out of the "Mutual Funds Without the Mystery" theme that was developed in 1994 by Ferrell Calvillo Communications Inc. of New York, which is directing the $5 million ad campaign. Curiously, the new ads seem to contradict Alliance's ads from last year.
Last year's commercials poked fun at stock experts. In one commercial, for example, an increasingly confused man is sandwiched between two other subway riders discussing mutual funds in jaw-breaking jargon. In another, a Gypsy fortune teller spouts the similarly impenetrable babble of stock-market technical analysts.
Neither John Ferrell, president of Ferrell Calvillo, nor Mr. Carifa of Alliance sees much contradiction in the approaches. Picking the right experts is the key, they say.
The new Alliance commercials get much of their deadpan comic sensibility from Mr. Weis. ("Yeah, yeah, it's one S," was the first thing he said upon picking up the phone.) Mr. Weis, who also created the wry, slice-of-life commercials for the Ikea furniture chain, is one of the busiest commercial directors around and one of a small group that specializes in comedy.
"What we like about Gary is that his characters are funny, but still recognizably real people," said Mr. Ferrell, who hired Mr. Weis as the commercials' director.
Despite the Alliance commercials' hilarity, Mr. Weis likes to exercise his own sense of self-restraint. "You don't joke the joke," he says frequently.
But in one critical respect, he did turn up the volume. When Ferrell Calvillo hired Mr. Weis, the agency gave him two situations: a man giving himself a haircut and another man performing do-it-yourself dentistry in his den.
"They were funny," Mr. Weis said from his Santa Monica, Calif. production company, 1/33 Productions Inc. "But if that's the idea, maybe the darker, the funnier."
Mr. Weis suggested a third commercial to Ferrell Calvillo, who agreed to it as long as it didn't cost too much.
Not to worry. Rocket science might require too many effects, so why not brain surgery? Mr. Weis hired a friend, a stand-up comic, Wayne Federman, dressed him in pajamas and had him lie on his back on a table. The camera, which did not move, shot from overhead.
The first image of the commercial is an X-ray of a skull held up against a desk lamp. "Oh yeah! This is not a problem," says Mr. Federman, off screen.
The next shot is of Mr. Federman, a tape measure around his head and dishwashing gloves on his hands, as he lies next to a tray with a pizza slicer, a gavel, a hand drill and calipers. Mr. Federman holds up a book titled "Brain Surgery Made Easy."
"In mutual funds, as in life, a little knowledge can be a dangerous thing," intones the disapproving announcer.
A blithe Mr. Federman measures his forehead with the calipers and says, "Well, that's close enough."
The announcer continues, "And while investing isn't brain surgery, a professional could help avoid complications."
Then, a puzzled Mr. Federman switches a mallet from his left to his right hand. "Ah! It's this hand!"
Mr. Federman next puzzles over a picture of a baboon, fiddles with an old-fashioned, hand-cranking drill and then practices moving a hacksaw across his forehead. "Too medieval," he says, with a shudder.
The last image is of a chain saw, shot from the patient's point of view. "All right, it's show time!" Then the roar of the chain saw.
The only production dilemma in the commercial, Mr. Weis said, was whether Mr. Federman should be seen starting the chain saw. "But, oh boy, I had nightmares about safety on that, so we decided no," Mr. Weis said. "Unseen is funny. Noise is funny."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A scene showing do-it-yourself brain surgery is one in a series of a tongue-in-cheek TV commercials for Alliance Capital Management's mutual funds directed by Gary Weis. The point: Turn to a professional. (Ferrell Calvillo Communications)

HEADLINE: Report Says American Incomes Rose in June

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
Helped by higher wages, the incomes of Americans grew modestly in June, rebounding from a decline in the previous month, the Commerce Department said today. Consumer spending rose slightly.
The Commerce Department said income increased four-tenths of 1 percent in June after having fallen two-tenths of 1 percent in May, the first decline since January 1994. 
 Consumer spending increased two-tenths of 1 percent in June, slowing from May's increase of nine-tenths of 1 percent, the biggest gain in nine months. May's increase was revised upward from the gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent reported originally.
Consumer spending represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, and analysts said the figures were consistent with an economy that seemed to have hit bottom in the spring and might already be moderately reviving.
"I think we were heading into the third quarter with a little more momentum than we thought," said Joel Prakken, an economist at Laurence H. Meyer & Associates, a St. Louis forecasting firm.
On Friday, the Government reported that the economy expanded at an annual rate of only half a percentage point in the second quarter, the weakest performance in nearly four years. Given that, today's figures were not a great surprise.
Analysts said some parts of today's economic report were encouraging. Private wages and salaries increased in all major parts of the economy. Spending on costly durable goods, an indicator of consumer confidence, was relatively strong.
Outlays for big-ticket durable goods like cars and appliances rose 2.6 percent in June, in contrast to increases of two-tenths of 1 percent for both services and nondurable goods like food and fuel.
"The underlying level on the demand side is pretty good," said Raymond Worseck of A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc., an investment firm in St. Louis.
The Commerce Department said that disposable income -- income after taxes -- rose just three-tenths of 1 percent in June following a gain of eight-tenths of 1 percent the previous month. Higher tax payments in April, required by a 1993 law, followed by smaller payments in May explained the increase in disposable income in the latter month despite the overall drop in pay.
The combination of incomes and spending meant the savings rate, or savings as a percentage of disposable income, remained at 4.1 percent in June. Before May, the savings rate had not been that low since November, when it was also 4.1 percent.
Private wages and salaries, the most closely watched component of income, increased at a $19.6 billion annual rate in June, in contrast to a $23 billion decline in May. Personal income also includes income from such sources as dividends, interest and businesses.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. Trade Negotiator Urges Shift in Approach on Japan

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 31

 BODY:
In a sign that the United States might be seeking a new approach to trade relations with Japan, a senior Clinton Administration official repudiated the confrontational tactics employed by the two nations and called instead today for a new framework based on cooperation.
"A relationship between the world's two biggest trading nations that is characterized by one trade confrontation after another seems as anachronistic as the old gunboat diplomacy," Jeffrey E. Garten, the Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, said in a speech here. 
 Mr. Garten's speech came only a month after Washington and Tokyo reached an agreement on trade in automobiles and auto parts, ending one of the nastiest disputes between the two nations after two years of negotiations.
The Clinton Administration has hammered hard at what it sees as Japanese trade barriers. The new call for peace could reflect frustration with the auto talks, especially because the resulting agreement did not yield what Washington wanted in terms of quantifiable commitments by Japanese car manufacturers to purchase more American parts.
Mr. Garten, who was one of Washington's two lead negotiators in the auto talks, said the trade framework signed by the two countries in 1993 was fine for governing negotiations aimed at reaching specific trade agreements and would be maintained. But he said a much broader framework was needed to cover discussions about such issues as the role of the World Trade Organization and different systems of business competition in each country, which is becoming a major trade issue.
"Amazingly enough, these kinds of 'policy planning' discussions almost never happen now," he said in his speech to foreign correspondents. "Virtually all of our time is spent in contentious negotiations."
Mr. Garten said his proposal "isn't meant to be a policy announcement as such, but certainly we in the Administration would like to see a new environment in our relationship with Japan."
A Japanese Government official who has been involved in trade talks with the United States reacted with caution to Mr. Garten's proposals, but he was mildly positive.
"Basically, I think it's a relubrication of the dialogue mechanism," the official said. "I don't sense he has anything very concrete in mind." He added, "I don't think this is official U.S. policy."
But the Japanese official, who spoke on the condition he not be identified, said Tokyo also believed that there should be more discussions about trade that were not aimed solely at negotiating the latest agreement. "It's a shared kind of sense that we should talk to each other more," he said.
Mr. Garten, who is in Japan on what is seen as a fence-mending mission after the combative auto talks, said that forging a new cooperative relationship would not be easy and that the old pattern of confrontation might continue.
For a cooperative approach to work, he said, Japan must vigorously deregulate its economy and both countries must strive to make existing agreements work. In addition, business executives in the two nations must take a more active role in resolving problems, he said.
Mr. Garten's proposals were not all new. Groups of Japanese and American executives have already been established to try to solve trade problems. The United States has also long pressed Japan on the issue of competition policy, urging, for instance, that Japan's Government be more assertive in enforcing antitrust laws against such practices as bid rigging and exclusionary relationships between Japanese distributors and manufacturers.
While Mr. Garten said the 1993 trade framework was too narrow, it was proclaimed to be very broad on the day it was signed. It was also intended, as President Clinton said at the time, to put the trade relationship "on a footing of mutual respect and mutual responsibility," and to end fruitless confrontations.

HEADLINE: We're Creating Jobs In the Third World

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Bob Herbert's "Sweatshop Beneficiaries" (column, July 24) misses the mark on the beneficiaries of United States companies sewing clothing in the Caribbean and Central America. Our company, like many of our competitors, has been manufacturing brassieres in the Dominican Republic, Jamaica, Haiti and Colombia for the past 25 years. 
 Our wages are comparable to the other sewing factories in these areas, and like many of them, we provide breakfast and medical care for our employees. In addition to the sewers who earn between 75 cents and $1.25 an hour, these factories have local supervisors, who earn between $100 and $400 a week.
The real unemployment rate in these countries approaches 50 percent and these jobs are eagerly sought. In addition, the United States imposes a duty that amounts to a dollar on every dollar we pay the sewing operators in these countries. In this competitive environment we would not sell a single bra if our price was not reflective of labor cost.
The presidents of the Gap and J. C. Penney do not earn their large salaries because they promote bras made with what Mr. Herbert calls exploited labor. They earn them because they are good merchants. There are plenty of retailers who have gone bankrupt and who are now out of business even though they carried these same garments made in the same factories. Until Mr. Herbert can find a better income source for these people, he should not criticize those who provide these jobs.
 
RAYMOND GOLDBERG
President, New Age Intimates
Long Island City, Queens, July 27, 1995

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: We're Creating Jobs In the Third World;
A.I.D.'s Role

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Sweatshop Beneficiaries" (column, July 24) outlines difficult worker conditions and low wages in several developing countries. The Clinton Administration has taken an active role in addressing the issues Bob Herbert raises, insuring that taxpayer dollars go to develop new markets for United States products while creating jobs in the United States. 
 The Free Trade Zone program has not been funded since 1992, and no taxpayer dollars have gone to support such trade zones since that time. Under a law passed in 1992, the financing of these trade zones was prohibited in the Foreign Assistance Appropriations Act of 1993.
Brian Atwood, Agency for International Development Administrator, took this further in 1993 by issuing stronger guidelines prohibiting the use of all A.I.D. funds, regardless of the year appropriated, that might promote the "export of U.S. jobs."
A.I.D. works in developing countries around the world to insure that worker rights are protected. In El Salvador it has worked with the Government to bring labor codes in conformity with internationally recognized standards of workers rights. A.I.D. has maintained dialogue with the Salvadoran Government and with the A.F.L.-C.I.O. to institute proper enforcement mechanisms for these newly established codes.
As Mr. Atwood said to Congress last year: "We feel very strongly that we should not be exporting American jobs, period. We ought to be exporting American goods."
The policies we have established promote this, while working to protect worker rights in these countries.
 
KELLY KAMMERER
Counselor to the Agency
for International Development
Washington, July 26, 1995

HEADLINE: Clinton Lashes Out At Congress, Citing Pollution and Guns

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Declaring that "this Congress is on the wrong track," President Clinton lashed out today at the 104th Congress as the captive of polluters and gun lobbyists. And he threatened to veto the bill that pays Congress's administrative expenses unless it makes faster progress in passing Federal spending bills to his liking.
At the same time, Mr. Clinton repeated his hope that he can yet find "common ground" with the Republican majority on Capitol Hill on welfare overhaul, campaign finance reform and a balanced budget, and said that the challenge of doing so has "not been debilitating, it's been invigorating." [Excerpts, page A12.] 
The President delivered his mixed message in an informal news conference called to denounce the House's passage on Monday of a bill that would limit the Environmental Protection Agency's ability to enforce pollution laws -- a measure the President derided today as a "polluter's protection act."
But Mr. Clinton quickly broadened his attack, raising or renewing veto threats against a handful of other bills working their way through Congress on issues from telecommunications to ending American participation in the United Nations arms embargo on Bosnia. He noted that the limits on environmental regulation were restored to a spending bill just days after a bipartisan coalition had voted to block them on the ground that they would allow increased pollution, and he said the turnabout came because an army of lobbyists had gone to work.
"You can see who's in control in this Congress," the President said, citing the environmental bill, as well as Speaker Newt Gingrich's pledge to the National Rifle Association earlier this year, reported today in The Washington Post, that no gun-control legislation would come out of committee in his tenure. "And it's not good."
Aides said Mr. Clinton's threat was intended to show that while he wanted cooperation with Congress, he would not accept it at any price.
"Part of encouraging cooperation is holding out your hand," one senior White House aide said. "But there are times when a rolled up newspaper on the nose has its uses." Another aide described the President's remarks as "a 2-by-4 across the eyes."
Predictably, Tony Blankley, the spokesman for Mr. Gingrich, had another view.
"Having read the President's screed, I am struck by the fact that he now seems to be intoxicated with his own political impotence," Mr. Blankley said. "He seems freed from any sense that his words have any meaning whatsoever, and he roams around the landscape saying things he knows are not true." Mr. Blankley was referring to the effects of the environmental bill.
"I think he's trying to get attention," Mr. Blankley added. "It's what minority parties who don't have any power often do."
Mr. Clinton's latest threat -- to veto the bill that pays the costs of running Congress and entities under its control, like the Library of Congress and Congressional Budget Office -- amounted to a virtual declaration of war with the legislative branch. Not since Woodrow Wilson in 1920 has a President vetoed an appropriation for the legislature's workings, and only then as part of a broader veto of spending for all three branches of Government, according to the Senate Appropriations Committee's staff director, J. Keith Kennedy.
"I don't think Congress should take care of its own business before it takes care of the people's business," Mr. Clinton said, complaining that House and Senate negotiators had agreed on the terms of their own appropriations while continuing to wrangle over most of the rest of Government spending. "If the Congressional leadership follows through on its plan to send me its own funding bill before it finishes work on the rest of the budget, I will be compelled to veto it."
But House and Senate aides noted that the administrative appropriation to run Congress is always among the first spending bills passed, precisely because it does not involve controversial policy questions or programs dear to constituents, and that Mr. Clinton signed it promptly last year. The bill for the fiscal year that starts on Oct. 1 would cut spending by about $200 million, to $2.1 billion from $2.3 billion.
"There is nothing controversial about the legislative appropriations bill," said Representative Robert L. Livingston, the Louisiana Republican who heads the House Appropriations Committe. "It shows that Congress is committed to cutting itself first. The President has no substantive grounds for a veto."
A veto would have little immediate effect, because the legislative appropriation would not take effect until the new fiscal year begins on Oct. 1, and it would ultimately get caught up in the dispute over the other spending bills, anyway.
White House aides said the Republicans had abrograted the genteel non-aggression pact that has traditionally prevailed between both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue on such matters by threatening to shrink or abolish White House agencies like the Council of Economic Advisers or the Office of Drug Control Policy.
"The point the President is making is that this is an important point of leverage in getting them to think more seriously about the larger budget issues," said the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry.
It now appears possible that the legislative appropriation may be the only spending bill to reach Mr. Clinton's desk before the vacation recess later this month. Vetoing it would let the President make the point that he is pressing for agreement on other spending bills, while accusing Congress of trying to force him to accept its priorities or risk shutting down the Government when the fiscal year ends.
Despite Mr. Clinton's repeated vows to veto legislation like the E.P.A. spending bill, the leaders of several major environmental groups said today that they did not trust him to follow through.
At a breakfast with reporters, the environmentalists condemned Mr. Clinton for signing a spending bill this week that contained a provision overriding all existing environmental laws in order to encourage increased logging on Federal lands when they are endangered by fire, pests or drought.
"His moral compass is swinging so wildly that it is impossible to know where the Administration will end up," said Carl Pope, executive director of the Sierra Club.

HEADLINE: ALLIES EXTENDING SHIELD TO PROTECT ALL BOSNIA HAVENS

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 1

 BODY:
The NATO allies today extended the protection of Western air power to all the so-called safe areas in Bosnia, including Sarajevo, warning that attacks on the enclaves would meet a "firm and rapid" bombing campaign.
The decision to broaden the Western threat against rebel Serbs' aggression reflected a growing sense among the allies that the recent show of Western resolve may be succeeding. 
 Since NATO agreed on July 21 that it would send warplanes if the Bosnian Serbs persisted in their threat to one protected area, Gorazde, Bosnian Serb forces have halted their advance against that enclave and directed their soldiers elsewhere.
Under today's agreement, United Nations military commanders in Bosnia could call in air attacks in case of a concerted assault on Tuzla in eastern Bosnia, on the capital, Sarajevo, or on Bihac, to the west, without having to seek approval from United Nations civilian authorities in New York or Zagreb, diplomats in Brussels said.
"Military preparations which are judged to represent a direct threat to the U.N. safe areas or direct attacks upon them will be met with the firm and rapid response of NATO air power," said NATO's Secretary General, Willy Claes.
The allies also threatened a countrywide campaign of air strikes against Bosnian Serb air defenses and other military targets if the Serbs pressed attacks on the protected enclaves, but such a broad campaign would require the approval of the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali.
After many weeks in which the allies seemed plagued by indecision and disarray, they have now united in a gamble: Any further attack on the safe areas will oblige NATO to make good on its threat to bomb the attackers or suffer one of the worst ever setbacks to its credibility.
NATO did not publicly spell out what would constitute an "attack," but the allies appear to mean a massing of forces or a frontal assault like the ones the Bosnian Serbs used to seize Srebrenica and Zepa last month. The threat would have to go beyond the shelling and sniper fire that are daily miseries in Sarajevo, or the fierce skirmishing that has swirled around the Bihac region without directly menacing the safe area.
Explaining that NATO's initial warning against an attack on Gorazde had been heeded, Mr. Claes said the intention now was to "underpin the search for a political settlement."
"We urge all parties both in Croatia and in Bosnia to exercise restraint and to desist from military action," he said after a three-hour meeting of alliance ambassadors today. "We call on them to enter into serious negotiations to achieve a lasting peace throughout the former Yugoslavia."
But while recent military offensives by Bosnian Serbs -- and by neighboring Croatia, which has joined the fight against Serbs near the Bihac enclave -- have drastically changed the situation on the ground this summer, the prospects for a negotiated solution to keep war from spreading are still clouded by disagreements among the major powers.
All parties to the conflict have different reasons to think that they have more to gain on the battlefield than at the negotiating table in the next month or two, these diplomats say, and disunity among the Western allies and Russia about what a negotiated outcome should look like has undermined the effectiveness of diplomacy.
"The Muslims in the Government won't negotiate seriously as long as they think they can still get NATO and the Americans involved on their side," a European diplomat said. Today's vote in the United States House of Representatives in favor of breaking the arms embargo on Bosnia would encourage such a view in Sarajevo, the diplomat indicated.
The current basis for peace negotiations is a plan backed by the United States, Britain, France, Germany and Russia last year that would give the Bosnian Muslims and Croats 51 percent of Bosnian territory and the Serbs 49 percent, as opposed to the more than 70 percent the Serbs now hold. Despite pressure from Serbia to accept the plan, the Bosnian Serbs were the only party to the conflict to reject it last winter.
That plan, by the countries referred to as the contact group, envisioned an eastern corridor for the Muslim Government from Sarajevo through Gorazde to the Muslim enclaves of Zepa and Srebrenica. The Bosnian Serbs took the last two enclaves by force last month, and NATO and the United Nations have threatened them with intense bombing if they attack Gorazde.
France's Prime Minister, Alain Juppe, and its Defense Minister, Charles Millon, are now openly suggesting that the peace plan's map should be revised to reflect changes in the situation on the ground.
"The French, the British and the Russians would be only too happy to accept the Serbs' redrawing of the map in the eastern half of the country and press for a realistic settlement that would leave Sarajevo and central Bosnia in Bosnian Government hands, but the United States and Germany won't accept it," a European diplomat with negotiating experience in the conflict said.
Dr. Philip H. Gordon, a senior research fellow at the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London, said, "The contact group plan obviously has been rendered out of date by events."
"You can still imagine a diplomatic deal being done to trade off Gorazde to the Serbs and leave the Government with Sarajevo, as part of an overall settlement," Dr. Gordon said in a telephone interview. "But it's much harder to see the tradeoff in Bihac."
One contact group official said today: "The eastern enclaves were always just bargaining chips for Sarajevo, though we could never say so. But last month they became pawn sacrifices without anything in return."
The European Union's peace negotiator, former Prime Minister Carl Bildt of Sweden, flew to Washington today for meetings with American officials on Wednesday after consulting with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany and President Jacques Chirac of France this week.
Diplomats said they expected Mr. Bildt to argue for American acceptance of a long-sought deal under which the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, would recognize Bosnia and Croatia within their existing borders in exchange for lifting economic sanctions.
"We think that Carl Bildt has made some progress, and we continue to support his negotiating efforts, but they have not yet reached the point where we see an equitable solution," Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke said in a telephone interview from Washington.
American officials said the United States wanted the agreement to provide for strong international monitoring of the Serbian-Bosnian border to insure that Serbia is true to the commitment it made not to supply the Bosnian Serbs with weapons and soldiers to carry on the fighting.
After the Muslim Government called on Croatia for help in Bihac, Croats advanced a good part of the way over the weekend toward creating the enlarged Government-controlled enclave at the western tip of the country that the contact group's plan envisions.
Many Europeans believe that the security of both Sarajevo and Bihac would have to be guaranteed by a United Nations force even after a settlement, Mr. Gordon said.
But first the Muslims, Croats and Serbs would have to agree to one. The last time their representatives talked together was Feb. 12, 1994.
Some international experts on the war say recent fighting, including attempts by Croatia to reclaim its Krajina region from Croatian Serbs, have only complicated prospects for peace.
Croatian Government and rebel Serb negotiators agreed, however, to meet in Geneva on Thursday, according to the United Nations, but the United Nations envoy, Yasushi Akashi, warned, "The danger of a full-scale war is increasing."
