HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Westinghouse and CBS Agree to $5.4 Billion Deal
Westinghouse has agreed to pay $5.4 billion, or $81 a share, for CBS, the last independent television network and once the crown jewel of broadcasting.
Westinghouse has decided to borrow heavily to bet on broadcasting, its most profitable operation. The deal would create a company with 15 television stations and 39 radio stations, with access to more than a third of the nation's households. [Page A1.]
 
Laurence A. Tisch's venture into media ended up tarnishing his reputation. That, according to many of his friends, is a bitter pill for a man who took the top job at CBS to enhance his power and broaden his legacy. [A1.]
 
Roger C. Altman, the investment banker turned Deputy Treasury Secretary whose Washington career fizzled last year, is the lead adviser to Westinghouse, and that has Wall Street buzzing. [D7.]
 
Conventional media companies, though in demand now, still face a challenge from new media technologies, analysts say. But it may take longer than once expected. [D5.]
 
Auto Sales Edged Up in July
Sales of cars and light trucks in July drifted below June's moderate pace, but appeared narrowly to beat the results of July 1994 because of hefty rebates. [D3.]
 
Economic Reports Show Strength
The National Association of Purchasing Management index rose more than expected in July, to 50.5, while construction spending increased nine-tenths of 1 percent in June, the largest increase in nine months. [D2.]
 
The strong reports showed a rebounding economy and pushed the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond up to 6.90 percent. [D18.]
 
Digital in a Profitable Year
Digital Equipment posted fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of $159.8 million, or $1.01 a share, its third consecutive profitable quarter. The company also reported its first annual profit since 1990. [D8.]
 
Analysts' Files Subpoenaed
The records, files and personal notes of five securities analysts who specialize in tobacco stocks were subpoenaed by a consortium of law firms as part of a giant class-action against tobacco companies. [D2.]
 
Banking Legislation Delayed
House Republican leaders have agreed to postpone any banking legislation until at least late September or October. [D2.]
 
Tokyo Credit Union Gets Loans
The Bank of Japan issued special loans to rescue Tokyo's largest credit union. Its troubles had threatened to spark turmoil in the nation's banking system. [D4.]
 
Official's Trade Speech Disavowed
The Administration disavowed a Commerce Department official's call on Monday for a less confrontational and more cooperative trade relationship with Japan. [D4.]
 
Interim Head for Labor Group
Thomas R. Donahue became the interim president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., but whether he can keep the job depends on how rapidly he can bring change to the shrinking federation before the election of a permanent president in October. He promised to begin pouring millions of dollars immediately into helping unions enroll new members. [A9.]
 
F.T.C. Accuses Car Dealers
The Federal Trade Commission accused the a California car dealers Association of conspiring to restrain trade and deprive "consumers of truthful information" by withdrawing advertising from The San Jose Mercury News. Advertising. [D3.]

HEADLINE: Monday's Speed Demon Is Tuesday's Law Abider

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: SUFFERN, N.Y., Aug. 1

 BODY:
Kevin Carrol was plodding along the highway at 55 miles per hour in his Jeep this morning when he came upon a road sign that shook him up just a bit.
"It said 65 miles per hour!" said Mr. Carrol, marveling at his discovery on Interstate 84. "As soon as I saw it, I just hit the gas, boom, and passed a bunch of cars." 
 Thousands of drivers across New York State were free to burn a little more rubber -- an additional 10 miles per hour, to be exact -- today after the new speed limit of 65 m.p.h. took effect on 1,100 miles of highway in the less populated areas north of New York City.
The switch, which makes New York the 46th state to raise its speed limit above 55, came with little fanfare or celebration. Most people greeted it with the same sort of silent pleasure that they experience over the extra hour of sleep that comes each fall when clocks are set back.
"It's nice to have the ability to get somewhere a little quicker without worrying about getting a ticket," said Mr. Carrol, a business consultant who drives up to six hours a day to visit clients around the state. "I took advantage of it right away."
Motorists seemed to be complying with the new limit. By late yesterday afternoon, the state police reported no speed-related accidents on highways where the change took effect.
"From outward appearances, we've had a positive response from the public," said Maj. Gregory Sitler, who heads the Division of Traffic Services for the state police. "I wouldn't anticipate anything out of the ordinary today."
Under the old law, most drivers understood that troopers would rarely make a speeding arrest for anyone driving under 70. But the state police have vowed to vigorously enforce the new limit.
Still, the switch did not suit everyone, and the cautious were wary. John McFeeley of Staten Island refused to drive his van faster than 55, even though he was holding up his two-van caravan on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway.
"I'm happy with the 55 miles per hour," Mr. McFeeley said as he and his companions stopped at a service station here on their way to the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown.
"It's a safe speed," continued Mr. McFeeley, who would feel at home in the four states -- Connecticut, New Jersey, Delaware and Hawaii -- that have not raised their limits to 65 m.p.h. "It's a speed limit that you can still control the car if, God forbid, something goes wrong."
The driver of the other van, Tony Diprima of Brooklyn, did not see it that way. "I figured with the new speed limit, we could have cut at least a half hour out of our trip," he said. "But he's driving a half hour behind me. I had to tell him to speed it up."
John Tomasulo, who drives a bus that shuttles people from New York City to a Sullivan County resort, felt the switch was overdue because many drivers had long ignored the 55-m.p.h. limit.
It was a situation that he found particularly frustrating, because he usually observed the old speed limit, given the harsh penalties bus drivers can face if they start accumulating speeding tickets.
"I was afraid of losing my license," said Mr. Tomasulo, saying that bus driving was his sole means of income. "But it was a real problem to be blocking the flow of traffic on the road all the time. I almost always had to stay in the right lane."
More than a few people figured the change would spare them time on the road, only to have their hopes dashed by -- what else? -- traffic.
Jimmy Davis said he was making great time at 65 m.p.h. on his drive back home to Tarrytown after spending a few days in the Catskills.
Then road construction funneled cars, buses and trucks into a single lane of crawling traffic. Once that cleared up, the highway clogged up again, this time because of a tractor-trailer accident.
"I thought I was going to save at least a half hour off my total trip," Mr. Davis said, who had no such luck.
Most people considered the new speed limit in terms of their own narrow interests. But at a ceremony today in Clifton Park, Gov. George E. Pataki looked at the bigger picture. He said the change should help the state's economy, making it more attractive to the trucking industry.
News of the change had not reached everyone.
Vienna Anderson, driving on Interstate 87, began to panic the moment she spotted a police cruiser in her rear-view mirror and realized she was traveling well above 55.
"I saw the policeman behind me," she said. "I said, 'Oh, no. I hope he's not coming after me.' I thought he caught me."
Ms. Anderson, who was on her way to Washington, added: "Isn't that silly. I didn't even know they had raised the speed limit."
Kurt Sachno, a truck driver, had heard all about the change. But his company, Baxter Healthcare Corporation in Montgomery, N.Y., has not lifted the 55 m.p.h. restriction it keeps on its drivers.
The company keeps track of the drivers' speed by equipping each truck with a computer. "There's talk that they'll change the policy now that there's a new speed limit," Mr. Sachno said. "I hope they do, because it's a hazard to be driving 55 when everyone else is flying by you."

HEADLINE: Excerpts From President's News Conference at White House

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the question-and-answer portion of President Clinton's news conference at the White House today, as recorded by Reuters and the Federal Information Systems Corporation, a private transcription service:
 
Opening Statement
 Looking over the last few days, it is clear that this Congress is on the wrong track. I began the year hoping to make bipartisan progress on balancing the budget, on reducing paperwork, reforming regulations and welfare. And therefore, I was very pleased last week when a bipartisan majority voted to reject the extreme anti-environment provisions adopted in the House committee. That was the right thing to do.
But then the lobbyists for the polluters went to work. They got the leadership of the House of Representatives to call the bill back up, and last night in a remarkable exercise of special interest power, the House voted to gut environmental and public health protections. It was a stealth attack on our environment in the guise of a budget bill.
The bill would effectively end Federal enforcement of the Clean Water Act and the Clean Air Act, a bill that my Republican predecessor said was his proudest legislative achievement. It allows poisons in our drinking water, raw sewage on our beaches, oil refineries to pollute, and limits a community's right to know what chemicals are toxic which are released in their neighborhoods. It would be bad for our children, our health and our environment.
This is Washington's special interest politics at its most effective and at its worst. Even before these 17 special interest provisions were added, the bill had already dramatically undercut environmental protection by cutting environmental enforcement in half.
You don't need to damage the environment to balance the budget. Our budget demonstrates that, and the budget the American people get out of this session of Congress ought to demonstrate that.
In the past few days, a battalion of lobbyists has swarmed Capitol Hill, exerting enormous pressure to save these loopholes. I said I would use the power of my office to help people, not polluters. I believe we can protect the environment and grow the economy.
So on this so-called environmental bill, my message to the American people should be very, very clear. Don't worry. We'll make common sense reforms, but the minute this polluter's protection act hits my desk, I will veto it.
One of the most interesting things that has received not too much notice in the last few days is that while Congress has been taking care of the special interests, it's also taking care of itself. It is way behind schedule on virtually every budget bill in the hope, apparently, of enforcing a choice at the end of this fiscal year, between shutting the Government down and adopting extreme budget cuts, which will be bad for our country, bad for our economy, and bad for our future.
Apparently they don't even plan on letting the American people see their planned Medicare cuts until the last possible minute. But one bill, wouldn't you know it, is right on schedule. The bill that funds the Congress, its staff and its operations. I don't think Congress should take care of its own business before it takes care of the people's business.
If the Congressional leadership follows through on its plan to send me its own funding bill before it finishes work on the rest of the budget, I will be compelled to veto it. I want to work with Congress to pass a balanced budget to protect the health and security of the American people. A balanced budget that strengthens our economy and raises the incomes of our people and the future prospects of our children. . . .
 
Q. Mr. President, your policies and your judgment calls appear to be under siege on Capitol Hill; Waco, Whitewater, Bosnia, social programs, and so forth. How debilitating has this been on you personally, on your administration, on the country? And obviously you're whistling in the dark if you think you're going to have common ground.
 
A. I disagree. It's not been debilitating, it's been invigorating. And I wouldn't be so surprised. There are two significant things that I would say, big issues that have become clear in the last few days. One is, you can see who's in control in this Congress. Who's in control of the people that compel this unusual revote on the environmental issues.
You see the story on the N.R.A. today. No gun control will be voted out of committee or on the floor of the House. I'm sure glad we got the Brady bill and the assault weapons ban first. And I still think we ought to have a ban on the cop-killer bullets. You see, we're investigating -- this Congress -- is investigating the A.A.R.P. and letting the N.R.A. run one of its own investigations. So you see who's in control. That's the first thing you see.
The second thing you see is more hopeful. There were, after all, 50 Republicans who broke ranks in the House and said that they would put the environment ahead of party. Senator Dole, yesterday, said that in Vermont at the Governor's Conference that he wanted to pass a welfare reform bill free of the extremist provisions which the members of his caucus, some of them, had demanded that he put on a welfare reform bill. And so we may be moving toward finding common ground in welfare reform.
So you see two things: you see who's in control, and it's not good. You see some people feeling uncomfortable about it and we may be able to make some progress. . . .
 
Q. Speaking of special interest, do you feel that the Speaker is dragging his feet on the bipartisan campaign finance reform commission, and what else are you willing to do to make sure that that happens?
 
A. Dragging his feet is an apt but inadequate description of what has happened. I mean, we shook hands on that in New Hampshire. I thought it was a fairly simple deal. The man said that the gentleman asked this question. He said, why don't you guys do a base closing commission? We said O.K. Five days later I wrote a letter to the Speaker, I didn't get an answer. Five weeks later, I wrote, I said again, O.K., here are two people that are the counter people that I would put on this commission and I would like for them to get with someone you designate and we'll set it up. . . .
 
Q. Mr. President, we know that you have just met with the leadership to try and make your, your veto of the Bosnia arms embargo lifting stick. But in the event that it doesn't and not knowing as we speak what the size of the margin is going to be, what is the next step? What else would you look to do?
 
A. Whatever the vote is, we still might sustain a veto. But I was encouraged by a few people who told me that they had decided on reflection that it was not the thing to do now. The Rapid Reaction Force, after all, is showing some strength there. And I would remind you that the only thing that has ever worked in the last two and a half years is when the Bosnian Serbs thought the United Nations would permit NATO and the Americans who are working with NATO, to use air power to stop the aggression so that there would have to be a negotiated settlement.
And in the last several days, the last couple weeks in Gorazde, you know we've gotten five convoys through, there has been no assault on it. And I think that this new strategy will work if we can hammer out a negotiated settlement and there is a new effort there. . . .
 
Q. Can you tell us, first of all, why you want to veto the telecommunications bill? I understand that you're concerned about concentration of media power. And in regard to that, can you comment on the merger yesterday between ABC and Walt Disney and the proposed merger, it may happen today, between CBS and Westinghouse, and whether you see this concentration of power happen?
 
A. Well, I think first of all, you have to take on these mergers under our law, and as a matter of economics, you have to take them case-by-case and analyze them. And all I know about the proposed mergers is what I read this morning when I woke up. So I can't comment on that. I do think it would be an error to set up a situation in the United States where one person could own half the television stations in the country or half of any of the media outlets and we don't have a Fairness Doctrine anymore and we don't have----.
Particularly if we took the Federal Government out of, all the Federal agencies out of any kind of maintenance of competition, or maintenance of competitive environment, taking the Justice Department out of it, for example.
I would remind you that we have the most successful telecommunications operations in the world, partly because we have had the proper balance between a highly competitive environment and an openness to new forces and new technologies and new entries in it from all around the world. I want very badly to sign the telecommunications bill. We tried to pass one, this Administration did during the last session of Congress. . . .

HEADLINE: Grand Opening in Texas: The First Edison School

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: SHERMAN, Tex., Aug. 1

 BODY:
An Apple computer for every child to take home. An E-mail system and a computer "chat room" allowing schoolchildren, their parents and their teachers to communicate at any time of day. A school day that is an hour and a half longer than the national average, and a school year that is 30 days longer. Special classes in everything from dance to personal finance to character and ethics. Spanish for everyone.
These were just a few of the things offered when pupils arrived at George Washington Elementary School today for the first day of classes. George Washington is the first school in the nation to open in partnership with the Edison Project, an ambitious venture whose mission is to provide a superior education at prevailing public-school costs and make money for its investors at the same time. 
 The opening of Washington today and of three other Edison-run schools in the coming weeks, in Kansas, Michigan and Massachusetts, is a far cry from the original vision of Edison's founder, Christopher Whittle, who once talked of raising $2.3 billion to build hundreds of new profit-making schools from scratch.
Nonetheless, Edison officials, including the venture's president, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., former president of Yale University, suggested that the partnership here and with other existing public schools could yet become a touchstone in a transformation of how Americans think about the estimated $280 billion spent yearly on American public education.
And educators in this manufacturing city near the Oklahoma border were clearly dazzled, especially by Edison's promise to speed George Washington's pupils (kindergartners through fourth graders) -- and their parents -- into the high-technology age.
"Can you imagine what this means if you're home sick?" said a beaming Sherman School Superintendent, Dr. Bob Denton. "The teacher can just put stuff in the student's E-mail, and that afternoon, if you're feeling better, you can call up your homework and do it. There's no place to hide anymore!"
In truth, opening day of the new school year at the two-story beige-brick school was little different in many respects from that in any other American public school. Most of the computers remained packed in boxes for now -- pupils will not get to take them home until they complete a training course -- and some teachers said that even they did not yet have a password with which to log on.
But within weeks, George Washington will become "the most high-tech school in America," Mr. Schmidt pledged in an interview.
Every teacher will have an Apple laptop to use throughout the day. And Dr. Denton said parents would be encouraged to use the computers as well, to communicate messages to teachers and to call up, say, announcements about coming meetings or tips on parenting.
Many parents seemed perhaps even more thrilled than their children at the prospect of becoming computer-literate.
"Definitely in our world, you've got to get into computers if you're going to go anywhere," said Reatha Abshire, the mother of Spencer West, a third grader.
The opening of the partnership school was preceded by a deluge of applications from outside the immediate neighborhood; 140 children transferred in and swelled George Washington's enrollment to about 500. Only 15 or so pupils asked to be transferred out, Dr. Denton said.
For the standard per-pupil cost of a given school district -- around $4,500 annually at the elementary school here -- Edison pledges to dramatically improve education and test scores, in part by providing a computer in every home, lengthening the school day (to eight hours for elementary students), extending the school year (to 205 school days) and giving teachers monthlong training sessions, or "institutes," in the summer.
What remains utterly unclear is just whether the Edison Project can make money. Mr. Whittle, the maverick entrepreneur whose extravagant personal spending habits and mixed financial success in several other projects have generated devastating publicity in the last year or so, unabashedly insists that the venture will prove profitable.
Edison has spent about $45 million on research and development of a curriculum and school model, and earlier this year obtained $30 million more from investors, including Mr. Whittle, money that is allowing it to open schools here and in Mount Clemens, Mich., Boston and Wichita, Kan., this year and 7 to 10 more schools next fall.
"We're not making money right now, and we won't for another two to three years," Mr. Whittle said. "We will begin making money when we have a relatively large system."
The average American school district operates just six schools; operating hundreds will allow Edison to achieve economies of scale that will both pay for the educational extras and generate profits, said Mr. Whittle, who has spoken of investment returns ultimately reaching 10 percent.
That is Mr. Whittle's theory, anyway. Some educators have dismissed it out of hand. "It's la-la land," Sandra Feldman, the president of the United Federation of Teachers in New York City, told a conference on privatization of the schools last year.
But some experts are not skeptical at all. One who thinks Edison could ultimately prove profitable is Michael Moe, an analyst with Lehman Brothers who tracks the venture and the handful of other private companies trying to run public schools for profit.
"I think clearly when you look at the amount of money that is spent on public education in this country, the possibility of bringing some rationalization to the services provided and still enhancing the quality of the services is very, very real," Mr. Moe said in a telephone interview today. Mr. Moe noted that half the money spent on education went to purposes outside the classroom. "There is not another service business in the world," he said, "where 50 percent of the money is allocated outside of where the service is rendered."
At the ribbon cutting today, in front of a huge sign that read, "Welcome to an Awesome Learning Adventure," Mr. Whittle and Mr. Schmidt were given a hero's welcome, and Sherman's Mayor, Julie Ellis Starr, gave them keys to the city. Rick Tichenor, the vice president of the school board, said, "In Texas, I think we hit the Lotto jackpot winner."
While the computers generated by far the most attention, Mr. Whittle urged teachers, parents, and schoolchildren to focus on other aspects of the curriculum as well. He cited the longer day and year, the immersion in foreign languages and the character-and-ethics component, in which, among other things, students are urged to make their own trading cards depicting their personal heroes and including vital statistics and history.
"The computers are only 10 to 15 percent of what we're doing here," Mr. Whittle said in an interview. "There are much more important things going on that you don't see right now."

HEADLINE: Thomas E. Morgan Dies at 88; Was Congressman for 32 Years

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Dr. Thomas E. Morgan, a longtime Democratic member of Congress who had championed bipartisanship as head of the House Committee on International Relations for 18 years, died on Monday in Greene County Memorial Hospital in Waynesburg, Pa. He was 88 and lived in Fredericktown, Pa.
For much of his 32-year tenure, Dr. Morgan was the only practicing physician in Congress. His medical skills came into play on March 1, 1954, when four Puerto Rican nationalists, firing from a spectators' gallery, sprayed the House chamber with bullets, wounding five members. "Doc" Morgan, as he was affectionately known, applied bandages and in one case a tourniquet to the victims. 
 An imposing figure, he was 6 feet 4 inches tall and weighed 240 pounds. After retiring from politics in 1976, he continued to practice medicine until he was 80 in Fredericktown, a community of 1,237 people in southwestern Pennsylvania, where he maintained a large house "with 67 doors" overlooking the Monongahela River.
Dr. Morgan became interested in politics when he was a youth. He served on the Fredericktown City Council in the 1930's but quit when it interfered with his medical practice. When the Democratic leadership for Pennsylvania's 24th Congressional District asked him to run for Congress in 1944, he accepted and won handily; he was re-elected to each succeeding Congress until he retired.
Dr. Morgan was named chairman of what was then called the House Foreign Affairs Committee in 1958 at a time when that committee was overshadowed by its Senate counterpart, the Foreign Relations Committee. He had a reputation of supporting the Administration's foreign policy, whether the President was a Democrat or a Republican. But in his latter years he opposed President Richard M. Nixon's policy of involvement in Vietnam and President Gerald R. Ford's intention to provide assistance to anti-Communist forces in Angola.
Thomas Ellsworth Morgan was born on Oct. 13, 1906, in the small Pennsylvania mining town of Ellsworth, one of eight children of William and Mary Morgan. His father, an immigrant from Wales, was a coal miner. As a boy he worked in the mines, cleaning lamps and picking slate.
The lessons of this heritage were reflected decades later in his Congressional career, when he promoted legislation to grant Federal assistance for the retraining of thousands of unemployed miners and to sustain President Harry S. Truman's stance on maintaining liberal immigration policies.
He received a bachelor of science degree from Waynesburg College in Pennsylvania in 1930 and a medical degree from Wayne University in Detroit in 1934.
He met his future wife, the former Winifred Strait, while interning at Grace Hospital in Detroit, where she was a nurse. They married in 1937.
Besides his wife, he is survived by a daughter, Mary Ann Youngwood of Potomac, Md., two grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thomas E. Morgan (Associated Press, 1961)

HEADLINE: Reclaiming A Lost Zone;
One-Man Drive Helps Tenants Battle Drugs

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC 

 BODY:
Lee Morgan, a 58-year-old woman living in one of Brooklyn's most crime-wracked neighborhoods, scoffed at the young man with the leather eye patch and the tinted-blond braids when he made his pitch about restoring decency to the building she calls home.
"I wasn't interested in anything he was going to do with this building," said Ms. Morgan, describing her view of Lyndrew Nesmith. To her, he was just another tenant-organizing quack talking as if he could summon Jesus himself to cast out the drug addicts infesting the hallway of her four-story East New York walk-up, wash away the urine and graffiti and sweep up the empty crack vials that crunched underfoot in the stairwells every morning. 
 Now, 10 months later, the crack vials, the graffiti and the urine stench are gone. A new outside door with a $1,500 magnetic lock keeps the drug rabble out. And members of the tenant association that Mr. Nesmith formed in the building argue over elementary buzzer tactics aimed at keeping things that way.
The city-owned building, at 673-675 Miller Avenue, at Riverdale Avenue, is just one of 20 in the neighborhood in which Mr. Nesmith, 35, has persuaded tenants to form associations over the last year, creating a sense of community among apartment dwellers who barely exchanged hellos before locking their deadbolts.
With the charm of a preacher and the tactics of a military campaigner, he has spearheaded an alliance of police officers, housing workers and two nonprofit groups -- the East New York Urban Youth Corps and the Cypress Hills Local Development Corporation -- that has reversed, at least temporarily, the buildings' downward slide. Mr. Nesmith receives a $24,000 salary from the two nonprofit groups, which are government-financed. The 20 buildings were considered among New York City's worst, abandoned by their owners to crack and decay before the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development took them over in foreclosure proceedings.
Eleven of the buildings have been rid of the dealers and addicts who haunted the hallways and the abandoned apartments and often preyed on passers-by, Mr. Nesmith said. Residents of the other buildings, including Ms. Morgan's, are still trying, pressing in some cases for eviction of tenants who feign cooperation but use their apartments for drug playgrounds.
"They used to call this the dead zone," said Mr. Nesmith, referring to East New York's murder rate, for years the city's highest. "Now we call it the resurrection zone. Our goal is to take back the neighborhood, building by building, street by street."
Martin Dunn, executive director of the East New York Urban Youth Corps, said his organization invests $150,000 of its $1.8 million budget on tenant organizers like Mr. Nesmith.
"Its just a small slice of the budget," Mr. Dunn said, "but it makes a lot more sense to be out there organizing buildings to save them from deteriorating than to have the places torn down and their residents put in shelters."
The organizing effort in city-owned buildings, which officials say is being carried out by 109 nonprofit organizations citywide, has coincided with a police campaign to combat the drug trade by having officers arrest suspected dealers for loitering, consuming alcohol in public and other once-ignored "quality of life" peccadilloes.
Both campaigns have coincided with a citywide decline in crime. In 1993, East New York's precinct, the 75th, recorded 126 murders, a city record, said the former commander, Inspector Joseph P. Dunne. The toll dropped to 87 in 1994, but the precinct still ranked worst in the city. By mid-July, there had been 27 slayings this year.
"Without community involvement we have nothing," said the present commander, Deputy Inspector Edward Mezzadri. "We've always had some cooperation. But when people start seeing results, they thrive on it. And it turns around an area that is barren."
The police concede that the drug trade in East New York has by no means been eradicated. In some cases, officials say, drug dealers have simply moved to other locations. "We make arrests over there all the time," said Officer Robert Hockenjos. "It keeps on rolling."
But the officer also echoed the thoughts of many residents, who said Mr. Nesmith and his organization have helped make a difference on some of the city's worst streets.
As an organizer, Mr. Nesmith uses direct tactics. He infiltrates a drug-infested building, recruiting collaborators willing to risk joining a patrol to stop trespassers from using front entrances that often have been stripped of their doors. Second, he warns street dealers that the tenants are banding together and advises them to move on.
"The next step is to establish a secure perimeter with new doors and locks," said Mr. Nesmith, who learned tenant organizing in his native Philadelphia before moving to New York in 1991. In some cases, the perimeter includes locked metal cages that city housing workers put on the entrances to basement passageways used by drug dealers.
Residents are urged to provide the police and housing officials intelligence to support evictions of neighbors who deal in drugs or who might allow drug users and sellers to use their apartments.
The final element is perseverance, Mr. Nesmith said. "If I'm not there often, there can be problems," he said. "They have in-house fights, maybe someone says something bad, maybe someone spits on someone, little things that just escalate. Then I have to let them know what the ultimate consequences will be: that the city agency won't invest in rehabilitation."
In that sense, Mr. Nesmith comes well prepared for the job. Living with his mother and brother in the projects of Philadelphia, Mr. Nesmith said he sometimes tried to mediate gang fights.
"I once stepped out in between two gangs and started giving a speech about brotherhood, and they stopped fighting," he said. "That experience with the gangs helped me with what I do now. It made me not afraid. Most people are afraid to go into these buildings."
The East New York tenements on Williams Avenue between Riverdale and Livonia Avenues were once one of the city's bloodiest drug bazaars; now they have been cleaned up and the addicts locked out. Daily sidewalk gatherings of dozens of pushers have dwindled to a few stragglers as police informers recruited from among the tenant associations created by Mr. Nesmith have helped city housing officials evict traffickers.
"The next block used to be a supermarket for heroin, and you were hearing bullets coming out of nowhere for anything," said 37-year-old Larry Wilkerson, who said he helped run a Williams Avenue drug ring before going to jail on a weapons charge. "I haven't heard a gunshot in months, and the drugs aren't being sold on the block anymore."
The drop in crime has stunned the officers of the 75th Precinct and residents, who caution that the area's social and economic weaknesses make reconquered buildings susceptible.
Once the home of German, Jewish and Irish immigrants, East New York suffered from the white flight of the 1960's and the drug contagion of the 70's and 80's, which wiped out 20 percent of the housing stock and left many of its 170,000 people in poverty. A quarter of the current households earn less than $10,000 a year, and half of the adults failed to finish high school.
Ms. Morgan's walk-up is typical of the buildings that could easily decline again if tenant unity collapses in petty quarrels and renewed apathy. The building is at a crossroads exploited by drug dealers for its convenient access by customers from outside the neighborhood and easy escape routes.
The building at 673-675 Miller Avenue, opposite a house that officers called a drug outlet store, has seen more than its share of drug-related deaths. Last September, a woman with stab wounds to the chest and duct tape over her mouth was tossed to her death from the roof. Three months later, a wealthy suburbanite, Barry Bernstein, was found dead of an apparent drug overdose, his head resting on the baseboard of the fourth-floor landing.
After another killing this spring, Inspector Mezzadri said: "I went there myself and told people on the stoop that we weren't going to put up with it. They don't want people hanging around selling drugs and wreaking havoc in the community. I got very good info."

The children, from left, are Juan Questell, 8; Miguel Questell, 5, and Juan Questell, 11.; Lyndrew Nesmith is trying to restore decency to what once were drug-infested apartment houses. HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Signs of Economic Strength Send Treasury Prices Down

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities tumbled yesterday after stronger-than-expected reports on manufacturing and construction showed a rebounding economy.
The reports bolstered the market's view that the Federal Reserve was unlikely to reduce short-term interest rates soon. The data also revived fears that inflation could creep up if the economy continued to accelerate. 
 The slide in Treasury prices, while sharp, could have been worse had it not been for the reluctance of traders to sell too heavily in advance of the report on employment to be released Friday.
Woodrow Wilson once said, "The man who is swimming against the stream knows the strength of it." That was more or less how some traders described the plight of buyers in yesterday's market.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 26/32 , to 109 3/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction to the price, rose to 6.90 percent, from 6.84 percent on Monday, returning it to Friday's levels.
Buying was restricted further by investor concern about an overabundant supply ahead of the Treasury's quarterly refunding of its borrowing needs next week. The Government will announce today the size of the refunding package. Carroll J. Delaney, director of research for Stires, O'Donnell & Company, said there was growing speculation that the Treasury would reopen for sale the current 6.50 percent 10-year notes to relieve their scarcity value in the so-called repo market, where investors sell securities, agreeing to buy them back at a specified price on a given date. He also said he thought the Treasury might announce an odd-date maturity for the long bond, like 30 1/4 years.
"It's too early to hypothesize auction yield levels at this point, but this week's substantial dose of economic news will be critical to the process," Mr. Delaney said.
Bond prices fell after a report that the National Association of Purchasing Management index showed a stronger-than-expected reading of 50.5 points for July, up from 45.7 in June. Some analysts had expected a reading of 48. The strength in the manufacturing part of the survey easily overrode the positive impact of a sharp drop in the price components to 58.3 points from 65.6 in June.
A separate report, on construction spending in June, was also stronger than expected. The Commerce Department said construction spending rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in June, to an annual rate of $520.4 billion, driven by building of factories and highways.
Anthony Dwyer, chief market strategist at Josephthal Lyon & Ross, said evidence was mounting that the economy was no longer slowing as sharply as it was in the second quarter. "Therefore, the hope for another Fed easing over the short term is diminishing," he said. In the municipal bond market, prices followed Treasury securities lower. New York City sold $972 million in nontaxable debt at higher-than-expected yields, traders said. The city still has not priced $260 million in taxable, variable-rate debt, which will probably be sold with very low yields, close to rates for commercial paper. The issue will probably be priced around mid-August.
The yields on the nontaxable debt were as much as 10 basis points higher than those on existing, similarly rated bonds. A basis point equals one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Analysts said money managers demanded higher compensation for the bonds amid concern that the city's finances were not improving. On July 10, the Standard & Poor's Corporation cut the city's long-term debt rating to BBB+ from A-. Drew McCullagh, who manages about $1 billion at Voyageur Asset Management, told Bloomberg Business News that if the credit rating had not been cut, the bond price might have been at least 10 basis points lower.
J. P. Morgan Securities, a unit of J. P. Morgan & Company, tentatively priced the bonds, consisting of serial bonds whose maturities run from 1996 through 2025, to yield a maximum of 6.65 percent for an issue due in 30 years. Shorter maturities were priced to yield from 4.25 percent in 1996 to 5.30 percent in 2000, 6.15 percent in 2005, 6.50 percent in 2010, 6.60 percent in 2015 and 6.625 percent in 2019.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Bank of Japan Rescues Troubled Cosmo Credit Union

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Breaking a longstanding taboo, financial authorities rushed in with funds today to rescue a Japanese credit union whose troubles had threatened to spark turmoil in the nation's banking system.
It was the first time in three decades that the central bank, the Bank of Japan, had issued special loans, this time to prevent a run on Tokyo's largest credit association, the Cosmo Credit Corporation, from alarming jittery depositors at other financial institutions. 
 The scare, which developed suddenly over the weekend, has become a test for Japanese regulators and bankers who are eager to demonstrate to investors and financiers around the world that Japan can manage a crisis and prevent it from spilling over into the global financial system. Just last week, Robert E. Rubin, the United States Treasury Secretary, expressed concern about Japan's banking crisis.
The nation's banks are saddled with at least $570 billion in bad loans, and many financial experts say the debt load is hobbling the economy and roiling the stock and property markets.
Cosmo's depositors have withdrawn about $915 million in cash, or nearly one-fifth of total deposits, over the last two days. Today, officials at the credit union prominently displayed cartloads of money to assure depositors that cash supplies were ample.
There appeared to be little risk that the credit union's troubles would have an impact abroad because Cosmo turned to depositors, rather than the money market, to finance its lending activities. Analysts have expressed concern that if a full-blown banking crisis did develop in Japan, some of the nation's banks would be unable to meet commitments on the international money markets.
Still, Tokyo share prices fell today, with the Nikkei index of 225 stocks declining 318.96 points, or 2.1 percent, to close at 16,358.57. Shares of financial institutions led today's retreat.
Government officials were coy about saying whether the special loans from the central bank represented a use of public funds. That is a sensitive issue because many in Japan hold the nation's wealthy bankers responsible for creating a speculative economic bubble that has burst, producing the country's worst economic problems in decades.
Nonetheless, if today's measures did not actually presage the use of public funds to aid banks, they did at least elevate the public debate about pouring such money into failing institutions. Financial regulators and Government authorities have said they do not want public funds to go into saving poorly managed, bankrupt institutions, but they also recognize that taxpayer money may be necessary at times to prevent bank runs from exploding into a nationwide panic.
Officials at the Ministry of Finance and central bankers tried to distinguish today's loans from public funds.
"It is funding from the Bank of Japan, and not normal lending by the bank," said Yukio Yoshimura, a spokesman for the ministry. "There is no strict definition of public funds." An official at the Bank of Japan said the loans were "different" from public funds.
The central bank declined to disclose precisely the amount of today's loans, but various financial officials suggested that the amount was between $170 million and $215 million. On Monday, the National Federation of Credit Cooperatives, an industry association, lent about $700 million to Cosmo.
Runs on banks in Japan are extremely rare, and the Government almost never lets lending institutions go bankrupt. Even today, lines at Cosmo were orderly and people waited patiently to withdraw their deposits.
Sampachi Taido, Cosmo's president, resigned, and authorities said that Cosmo probably would be merged into another bank. Authorities suspended Cosmo's operations on Monday, forbidding it from taking any new deposits and making any new loans, but depositors are still allowed to withdraw funds up to a limit of about $1.1 million, regulators said.
Cosmo lent heavily to real estate speculators during the bubble economy of the 1980's and now is saddled with a large bundle of bad debts. Ministry officials said Cosmo had nearly $2 billion in bad loans, representing about 35 percent of its loan portfolio.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. Not Embracing Call for a Shift on Japan

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said today that one of his top aides was not speaking for the Administration when the aide called for a less confrontational and more cooperative trade relationship with Japan.
The aide, Jeffrey E. Garten, the Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, did not put his speech, given Monday in Tokyo, through the interagency review process and was expressing his personal views, Mr. Brown said in a telephone interview this afternoon. 
 The speech angered some senior Administration officials, who worried that it eroded the White House's carefully cultivated and politically advantageous image of being tough on Japan.
While Mr. Brown said that he retained confidence in Mr. Garten, the incident appeared today to have weakened Mr. Garten's standing within the Administration while strengthening his rivals at the Office of the United States Trade Representative, a separate agency.
Mr. Brown said that Mr. Garten had long advocated tough action toward Japan and that his speech simply indicated a hope that the relationship could be more cordial even as the United States continued to try to open the Japanese market. "All of us at the Commerce Department, Jeff included, ought to have absolutely unassailable credibility on the Japan issue; we were the tough guys," he said.
Mr. Brown also contended that Mr. Garten had indicated that his views did not represent a shift in Administration policy. "Clearly, he was not speaking for the Administration, as he acknowledged," Mr. Brown said.
Mr. Garten said that his proposal was not "meant to be a policy announcement as such, but certainly we in the Administration would like to see a new environment in our relationship with Japan."
But Mr. Garten made the speech as a senior Commerce Department official, and the department had distributed his speech widely to reporters. In it, he took a much less aggressive tone than other American officials in discussing efforts to open the Japanese market.
"We have a good opportunity now to initiate a more positive phase in the trade and economic relations between the U.S. and Japan, one in which the tone becomes more cooperative and more oriented towards the common goal of building a world economy in which our two countries are not pictured as antagonists but as close partners," Mr. Garten said, according to a text of the speech released by his office.
He went on: "Such an environment will not evolve from soothing words, but from some very hard work on both sides of the Pacific. Achieving it will be a difficult challenge for both Washington and Tokyo. I believe it can be done, however."
The speech gave the appearance of undermining Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative. Mr. Kantor took a very confrontational approach in auto trade talks with Tokyo a month ago, only to forgo trade sanctions at the last moment and strike a deal that some American critics of Japan have labeled as inadequate.

HEADLINE: Activity Rises In Construction And Industry

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Two reports released yesterday signaled renewed strength in the economy, as an index of manufacturing activity rose more than expected in July while construction spending increased in June by the largest amount in nine months.
The statistics helped send stock and bond prices lower because investors believed that the numbers would make it less likely that the Federal Reserve would act soon to cut interest rates. 
 Yesterday's figures indicated that the threat of a recession has receded "further and further into the background, and a soft landing is becoming the dominant theme," said Robert Dederick, an economic consultant at the Northern Trust Corporation in Chicago.
In one of yesterday's reports, the National Association of Purchasing Management said its manufacturing index rose to 50.5 last month from 45.7 in June. Before declining in May and June, the index had increased for 20 consecutive months. An index reading of 50 or more means manufacturing is expanding, while a reading below 50 signals a slowdown.
Economists had expected the index to rise to only 46.5, according to a Bloomberg Business News survey. The July reading of 50.5 may indicate that the economy has recovered from the weakness of the spring and early summer.
"It looks like the economy is rebounding much more quickly and with more vigor than people thought," said Mark Zandi, chief economist for Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa.
As for construction spending, the Commerce Department said yesterday that it rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in June, to an annual rate of $520.4 billion, driven by building of new factories and highways. The increase was the first in three months; in May, spending fell 1.5 percent.
Analysts surveyed by Bloomberg Business News had expected a June increase of one-tenth of 1 percent.
The numbers could remain strong in the months ahead as "nonresidential building permits continue to be strong," analysts at Mitsubishi Bank said before yesterday's report was released. Permits for new projects are considered a gauge of future construction starts.
Spending on commercial projects like factories, warehouses and motels rose 3.5 percent in June. Spending on plant and equipment has been a source of strength for the economy and is likely to remain healthy for the rest of the year, the National Association of Business Economists said last week.

HEADLINE: Keeping Wages Down

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Can Merger Save the Unions?" by Michael Weinstein (Editorial Notebook, July 31): When Mr. Weinstein writes, "Competition from abroad and a 20-year slowdown in productivity have stripped unions of their power to raise wages," he couldn't be more wrong. 
 Productivity per labor-hour in the sector embracing the three unions in question, auto workers, steel workers and machinists, has risen at least 40 percent in the past 20 years.
Wages have stagnated because the huge overhang of unemployed and underemployed workers deprives all workers, not just the unions, of bargaining power.
The unions have no hope of reducing that overhang unless they attack the source: the Federal Reserve Board's paranoid delusion that the economy cannot grow faster than 2.5 percent a year without serious inflation.
 
ROBERT ZAGER
Stamford, Conn., July 31, 1995
 
The writer is retired vice president for policy studies of Work in America Institute.

HEADLINE: World News Briefs;
State Department Plan Is Put on Hold in Senate

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
A Republican plan to reorganize the State Department, already facing a veto threat, was put on hold in the Senate today when solid Democratic opposition kept backers from bringing it to a vote.
The author of the bill, Jesse Helms, the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee and a Republican of North Carolina, reacted angrily to the defeat, saying that "if the Administration wants to play hard ball," he will make sure that no ambassador nominations or treaties get through his committee. 
 The delay also puts in limbo an attempt by the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, to link American participation in a United Nations women's conference in Beijing in September with China's release of Harry Wu, a Chinese-American human rights advocate.
Senator Dole, Republican of Kansas, pulled the bill and moved to other legislation after failing twice to get the 60 votes needed to end debate and set a timetable for final action. Both votes were 55-45, with all but one Democrat, Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, opposing cloture.
The bill would eliminate three major agencies -- the United States Information Agency, the Agency for International Development and the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency -- and cut 10,000 employees by the end of the decade. It would also make changes in aspects of American foreign policy, including requiring the President to notify Congress 15 days before casting a vote on peacekeeping operations in the United Nations Security Council.

HEADLINE: Mayor Gives Final Approval For East Harlem Supermarket

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
After months of bitter debate over a proposal to build a Pathmark supermarket in East Harlem, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that he had given final approval to the project, clearing away the last obstacle to building the store.
The $13 million supermarket has been planned since 1991 for a desolate lot on 125th Street, but construction has been held up because of opposition from Hispanic merchants in the neighborhood. Construction could start next spring, Mr. Giuliani said. 
 To appease the opponents, the Mayor said the city would become a partner in the deal and would hold a minority stake in the enterprise until a Hispanic partner could be found to take it over.
In exchange for providing the land on which the store will be built, the city's Economic Development Corporation, the nonprofit agency responsible for development projects, will get a 49 percent stake in the project. Mr. Giuliani said the city would later transfer that ownership to "an appropriate community group that would reflect the community in which the supermarket is being located." No group has been selected yet to assume the city's share in the plan.
The majority stake will be held by the original developer, a consortium of nonprofit groups known as the East Harlem Abyssinian Triangle, which includes the nonprofit development arm of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, Harlem's best known black congregation.
Under the plan, Pathmark, after paying off any debts, will pay rent to the Abyssinian group and the city; later, the Hispanic group selected will take over the city's share of that money. The money Pathmark pays to the city and the Hispanic group would be used for new housing and other neighborhood projects. The Abyssinian group also plans to use its share of the money for community development.
Pathmark is expected to pay about $50,000 a year for the first 10 years. That amount is expected to rise as debts are retired.
The Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church and one of the original developers, said: "I'm happy that the Mayor has finally seen the benefits of this project, even though it has taken him a long time to deal with this matter. I'm glad the project is going through, and Harlem will have a new supermarket.
Originally planned as a straightforward development measure for an economically depressed area, the East Harlem Pathmark project became embroiled in bitter political and ethnic passions. East Harlem small-market owners, most of them Hispanic, denounced the 53,000-square-foot project, complaining that it involved no Hispanic community groups and that the large supermarket would hurt their business.
At the same time, however, surveys suggested that a majority of residents, both black and Hispanic, wanted to see the store built, both for the shopping convenience and for the 200 jobs the supermarket is expected to generate.
For Mr. Giuliani, the project presented delicate political problems because Hispanic small-business owners have been important supporters of the Mayor. Even after the project received the other necessary government approvals, the Mayor gave no indication of his position for many weeks.
When Mr. Giuliani finally announced his decision today to reporters in City Hall, he was flanked by three of the four deputy mayors who had helped restructure the plan.
Mr. Giuliani said: "The deal that was worked out will benefit everyone: local businesses, members of the communities, shoppers, workers and the city of New York. East Harlem. I think East Harlem takes a giant step forward today."
Not everyone agreed. Adam Clayton Powell 4th and Antonio Pagan, the councilmen from Manhattan who have opposed the plan because of its potentially negative impact on small merchants, said they still objected because the project's developers will receive $1.1 million in Federal and state grants, a low-interest mortgage loan and tax abatements.
"This is corporate welfare of the worst kind," Mr. Powell said.
Mr. Pagan said he also objected because the project still had no Hispanic group involved. "The original sponsors are still in control," he complained. "This was supposed to be a compromise. But who compromised? There's been no communication between the Mayor and the opponents."
Mr. Giuliani has long vowed to make economic development more attractive to corporations. Administration officials acknowledged that the Pathmark debate was being watched by other corporations as a indication of the difficulty involved in doing business in New York City.
In April, Pathmark had tried to placate the opposition by pledging $25,000 a year, in addition to the money the Abyssinian group had expected to receive, for a minimum of five years, to create an economic development fund for East Harlem, presumedly to assist Hispanic-owned businesses. The company, based in Woodbridge, N.J., said the money would be held in escrow in an East Harlem bank and administered by a community-based organization.
But Mr. Giuliani, suggesting that such an agreement would have a chilling effect on any company seeking to do business in New York, strongly asserted yesterday that the earlier offer was null and void. "No such payment will take place," he said, "and that will be set forth in writing."
"That's inappropriate," Mr. Giuliani said. "There's no reason to exact additional taxes from businesses that want to do business in this city. That's a way to discourage business."
That seemed to be a reference to an arrangement struck between Pathmark and Councilwoman Juanita Watkins on a proposed Pathmark store planned for the Springfield Gardens section of Queens. Under that plan, the company will donate more than $400,000 during the next 20 years to other merchants in the area. The money will be dispersed by a seven-member advisory panel chosen by Ms. Watkins.
Mr. Giuliani declined to discuss his position on the Springfield Gardens supermarket project directly. But he said arrangements like that "should be part of the past of New York City, not the future, where businesses are expected to make side payments and side deals."
Administration officials said the biggest problem in arriving at the current plan had been the search for a Hispanic developer to become a partner. In the end, they could not find one they judged suitable.
The Mayor said, "Just because one doesn't exist now, doesn't mean that one won't exist a year, two or three years from now, until that community group is developed."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 3, 1995, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about mayoral approval of a plan to build a Pathmark supermarket in East Harlem misstated the terms of the deal. The city's Economic Development Corporation and a private investment group will build the supermarket, rent it to Pathmark and use the profits from this arrangement -- estimated at $50,000 a year for the first 10 years -- for community development projects. The $50,000 does not represent Pathmark's total annual rent, which will actually be about $1 million.

HEADLINE: Plunging Life Expectancy Puzzles Russia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Life expectancy in Russia, already lower than in any other developed country, has plummeted again this year, and scientists and public health officials say they cannot explain the continuing steep decline.
For the last several years health statistics here have been hard to believe: no country that reports to the World Heath Organization has a life expectancy as low. Life expectancy for men born in Russia this year is lower than in India, Egypt or Bolivia. 
 Epidemic rates of heart disease, cancer and accidents account for much of the problem, which has caused death rates to more than double in the last decade. But none of that explains why Russia has become the first country in history to experience such sustained reversals in its health statistics.
"There is no historical precedent for this anywhere in the world," said Judith Shapiro, an economist who specializes in health demographics at the University of London, referring to the drop in Russian male life expectancy from 64 to 57 in the last four years. "Obviously nobody can quite figure it out. But it is a mystery that needs to be solved soon."
It is also a mystery that has profound implications for a country trying to restructure its society and economy after years of despotic rule. Despite the common belief that the world is overpopulated and that fewer people are usually better, no country can afford a trend in which its most productive citizens die in huge numbers while they are in their prime.
But that is just what is happening here. Deaths are now almost twice as common in Russia as births, while infant mortality has risen 15 percent in each of the last two years.
While the numbers are bleak, nobody attributes the change to inaccurate or incomplete statistics. Instead, experts here and in the West have in the past routinely written it all off to the fragile state of Russia itself: economically stressed, psychologically damaged, its health care system in ruins.
All of that makes sense. But it is not enough, specialists now acknowledge, to explain the demographic catastrophe spreading across the nation. Mortality figures released by the Labor Ministry here last week showed that if current conditions persist, nearly 50 percent of today's Russian youth will not even make it to the retirement age of 55 for women and 60 for men.
Last year the death rate reached 15.6 for every 1,000 people, an increase of nearly 10 percent over the previous year and nearly 30 percent since 1992. By contrast the birth rate fell to 9.0 per thousand from 9.4 the year before. In the United States last year the birth rate was 16.1 and the death rate was 9.0. Life expectancy for American men is 72 and for women 79. It is 71 for Russian women.
While death rates soar, birth rates here are lower than in any other country. Only 1.4 million children were born in Russia last year, less than half the number of recorded abortions. For the first time last year the population shrank in every one of Russia's 79 regional districts. But what frightens researchers here most is the condition of those children who are born. More than 10 percent have serious birth defects, 50 percent of all school children suffer from chronic illnesses, and these rates are growing every year.
Frustrated by explanations that don't quite add up, scientists are looking more closely at the history of Soviet ecological abuse for answers -- decades of open testing of nuclear weapons, chemical plants spewing deadly toxic materials into the country's most important rivers, generations of factory workers and farmers exposed to huge doses of dangerous pesticides and harmful chemicals.
What they are finding -- tentative and preliminary though it may be -- is not reassuring. Congenital abnormalities among children are among the most vivid examples of the impact of pollution. In 1990, 388 of every 10,000 children born died in their first year of life as a result of serious birth defects, more than four times the rate of the United States. In 1993, the figure was 407 per 10,000 children. And last year, according to the Ministry of Health, the rate reached 436. Those are just numbers for defects serious enough to kill.
"What we have here is a disaster," said Dr. Aleksandr Chuchalin, a member of the Russian Academy of Sciences, who has been researching the link between the health of children and the state of the environment. "But the reasons are just incredibly hard to pin down. Obviously, it's is not enough any more to say that our life style accounts for these numbers. No life style could account for all of this."
Dr. Chuchalin and colleagues are beginning to examine the hypothesis that radiation produced by decades of nuclear irresponsibility -- at places like the Chernobyl power station but also at waste dumps and test sites across the country -- is a major factor in the surge in illnesses and birth defects. But such links are never easy to demonstrate.
"It was surprising that we could not seem to observe the genetic effects of what happened there," said Dr. David Hoel, chairman of the department of biometry and epidemiology at the Medical University of South Carolina, and an expert on the effects of radiation in populations. "Everyone assumes the connection. But it takes many years of careful study to be sure."
Whatever the cause, it is frequently asserted that the nation's genetic heritage could be in danger.
"Back in the early 1960's our eminent geneticists warned about the genetic damage to the Russian population," Aleksei V. Yablokov, chairman of the National Security Council's committee on ecological health and safety said in a well-publicized speech earlier this year. "No one believed them. Now congenital deformities are increasing faster than any other health problem. As a biologist I think we have to look not so much at the conception of children by drunken couples, but at the chemical and radioactive contamination of the environment."
He may be right. But there are other more obvious causes, like failure to vaccinate the population against preventable illnesses. Some illnesses, such as rubella, can lead to the passing of genetic mutations from mother to child. The relationship between potential birth defects and women who become ill with rubella during pregnancy is well known throughout the world, as the Georgetown University demographer Murray Feshbach has pointed out in his recently released "Environmental and Health Atlas of Russia."
In the years between 1985 and 1989, the United States -- where rubella vaccinations are common -- averaged 427 cases a year, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. During the same period, the former Soviet Union, with about 15 percent more people, averaged 564,000 cases a year. In 1993, in Russia alone the figure was 128,000. Last year it almost tripled to 360,470. If half of those people are women, and only 5 percent of them are fertile women that means more than 25,000 potential infections for pregnant mothers.
"The question is how long are we going to accept these numbers," said Marina Cherkasova, director of the Russian Socio-Ecological Union, an advocacy group that works mostly on health issues. "Are we going to sit here for another 50 years and wonder whether the incredible rates of disease we have can be prevented, or are we just going to keep moving backward in time?"

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about plunging life expectancy in Russia referred imprecisely to a remark by Dr. David Hoel, an American expert on the effects of radiation in populations. When he said, "We could not seem to observe the genetic effects of what happened there," he was referring specifically to radiation's effects on Hiroshima, not to Russia.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: THE BUSINESS -- Broadcast Networks Come Back Strong;
An Old Medium Holds New Luster for Buyers

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER 

 BODY:
Only a short time removed from persistent predictions of their imminent demise, the broadcast networks have become the hottest properties in the media marketplace.
Many analysts predicted that yesterday's $5.4 billion deal by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation for CBS Inc. was only a prelude to a bidding war for that network. And coming just a day after the Walt Disney Company agreed to take over Capital Cities/ABC for $19 billion, the Westinghouse move was widely interpreted as part of a sudden hunger for network acquisition. 
 "There is a frenzy going on in this business," John Reidy, a media analyst for Smith Barney, said.
Analysts and network executives cited numerous reasons:
*The elimination or reduction of Government regulations that have hampered networks in producing and owning programs and limited the number of stations they could own.
*The increased desire for program producers to control systems of distribution, the better to create value for the programs they generate.
*A boom in advertising revenues for traditional network television.
*The still murky possibility that coming changes in the way television signals are delivered may greatly increase the number of channels a broadcaster can transmit into American homes.
Another factor, of course, is the consolidation of power in the entertainment industry among a few big cost-conscious companies. "The reason it is all happening now is the rise of corporate conglomerates, coupled with rising program costs and the end of Government regulations," said Larry Gerbrandt, senior partner of Paul Kagan Associates, a firm that tracks media companies. "The Disney deal was made for program distribution and the Westinghouse deal for station market share, but both deals are about economies of scale."
Indeed, Disney executives emphasized on Monday that owning ABC meant the company's programs would have a reliable distribution base, and Westinghouse executives said yesterday that a merger with CBS would give the new company the strongest lineup of television stations in the country.
The Disney deal for ABC is widely considered to be far superior to Westinghouse's for CBS, both because of ABC's far more valuable assets and because that network recently has had much better ratings and owns far more profitable stations than CBS.
Still, analysts said the two deals were part of a larger reassessment of the value of broadcast networks. "There's a re-recognition of the different things you can do with a network," Mr. Reidy said.
But one senior executive with long network experience said that at least part of the reason for the network fire sale was purely emotional: "There's a nervous frenzy among a lot of these guys running these big companies. They don't want to be left out of what's going on."
The same executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity, noted that only five years ago Michael D. Eisner, the Disney chairman, disdained networks, saying he not only didn't want to buy one, he was glad he didn't own one.
That was at a time when the broadcast networks were being widely written off as yesterday's medium. Cable channels talked of expanding to 500 channels. There was the prospect of video-on-demand, where viewers could choose to watch what they wanted when they wanted. The idea of delivering shows by a single channel on a rigid weekly schedule was being described as the TV equivalent of the icebox facing off with a Frigidaire.
At the same time the advertising market for television had gone so soft that many industry executives predicted there would not be enough revenue to support much more than two networks.
NBC, the network with the most programming woes at the time, was so unwanted that its parent, the General Electric Company, was said to keep it only because no buyer would pay enough to insure that G.E. would not incur a severe loss.
In the years since, the Government has removed restrictions that kept the networks from taking a financial interest in shows they broadcast; has allowed the networks to syndicate shows, and is considering raising the percentage of the nation's television households a network can reach with the stations it owns, from 25 percent to 35 percent.
Thus, the business climate has changed from one in which networks were of little interest to buyers because they were shackled with regulations for being too powerful to one in which the networks -- now unshackled because their competitive power was waning -- are very desirable.
Mr. Reidy said that Rupert Murdoch, chairman of the News Corporation and its Fox broadcasting network, had set the standard that other studios now seek by using his network to create value for shows Fox owned.
"The networks are becoming program owners and not just mere conduits," Mr. Reidy said. "Only a network can create value by making a program a hit. Even if you don't have very good ratings, you can still showcase a program and then sell it in Bulgaria or some place."
The international market is becoming increasingly lucrative for American program producers, and Mr. Eisner cited it as an area where the new Disney/ABC would look for extra revenue.
Mr. Reidy also said that the boom in advertising sales for all the networks was making them more attractive to bidders.
CBS, he said, "lost their president, Howard Stringer, they've had all this slippage in ratings, yet the advertising market is so frenzied that CBS is going to see an upswing in cash flow in the fourth quarter."
In going billions of dollars into debt for the honor of owning a network, neither new prospective owner cited the possibility that some time in the next decade they may be able to expand their channel capacity without having to make deals with the cable industry.
In the fall, the Federal Communications Commission will begin considering plans to change the system of delivering television signals. Under a new digital system, stations with one channel may eventually be able to deliver five or six into each home in their viewing area.
The plan faces enormous technological complications and political maneuvering. But Mr. Gerbrandt said that any expansion of channel capacity would help the networks.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 7, 1995, Monday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day on Wednesday about the businesses of the four leading television networks, their corporate parents and merger partners characterized the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's relationship with two cable television channels incorrectly. The company's Group W unit manages the business affairs of the Nashville Network and of Country Music Television; Westinghouse does not own Nashville and holds only a one-third interest in Country Music. The Gaylord Entertainment Company owns the Nashville Network and the remaining two-thirds interest in Country Music Television.

HEADLINE: Stock Prices in Retreat, With Dow Dropping 8.10

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Stocks stumbled yesterday after a sharp decline in bond prices raised concern that interest rates, and corporate borrowing costs, were headed higher.
The selloff in bonds followed the release of two unexpectedly strong economic reports. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 26/32 , driving its yield up to 6.98 percent, from 6.84 percent on Monday. Higher rates threatened to hamper corporate earnings growth, which has driven the market's recent rally. 
 All three major averages were down yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial index closed at 4,700.37, off 8.10 points. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed at 559.64, off 2.42 points, and the Nasdaq composite index closed at 991.11, off 10.10 points.
"The stock market appears to be settling into a tight trading range," said Alan Ackerman, senior vice president of Fahnestock & Company. "There is no breakout at hand, nor does it appear that a breakdown is in process."
Still, the reports that spooked the bond market pointed to an economy that could now be rebounding. The manufacturing index of the National Association of Purchasing Management rose in July for the first time in three months. And the Commerce Department reported that June construction spending, led by starts of new factories and highways, notched its largest advance in nine months.
Declines on the New York Stock Exchange exceeded advances by 1,290 to 969. Big Board volume increased to 332.9 million shares, from 289.9 million shares Monday.
The decline in the market was tempered by a surge in takeover activity. Shares of Disney rose 2 7/8, to 61 1/2, a day after announcing its $19 billion deal to acquire Capital Cities/ ABC. Shares of Capital Cities climbed 3 1/4, to 119 1/2, after jumping 20 1/8 on Monday.
Yesterday's announcement that Westinghouse Electric planned to purchase CBS lifted Westinghouse shares by 1 1/4, to 14 7/8. But CBS was unchanged at 77 3/4.
Profit taking weakened many technology issues, particularly the semiconductor stocks. dropped 5, to 151 1/4; Micron 2 1/8, to 60 1/4, and Cyprus Semiconductor, 2, to 50 3/4.
Airlines also wound up on the down side, as traders showed concern about higher oil prices for much of the day. AMR, the parent of American Airlines, closed at 74 3/4, off 1/4; , the parent of United Airlines, closed at 48 1/2,, off 7/8, and Delta Air Lines closed at 78 7/8, off 3/8.
Georgia-Pacific spurted 1 7/8, to 88 1/8, after stating that it would begin a stock repurchase plan. I.B.M. finished on the plus side in a weak technology sector, rising 3/4, to 109 5/8, following a meeting that its management held with security analysts on Monday. And SunAmerica, which has been enjoying strong sales of annuities, jumped 2 3/4, to 60.
