HEADLINE: Real Estate;
In downtown Los Angeles, a former department store will have new life as state offices.

BYLINE: By Morris Newman 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
A GOVERNMENT partnership is buying a historic department store building in a neglected section of the downtown here as part of a larger effort to revive the area.
The building, the 450,000-square-foot former Broadway Department Store, will house state offices. It was purchased for only $1.8 million by the Los Angeles State Building Authority, a partnership of the State of California and the Los Angeles Community Redevelopment Agency. The seller was the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency entrusted with selling the assets of insolvent savings and loan associations. 
 The partnership agreed to buy the property in June and expects to complete the purchase in October.
The state plans to spend an additional $61.5 million on the building, a 10-story structure built in 1918. Much of the money will go toward reinforcements against earthquakes, as well as other safety features to help the building meet current city codes.
The building, which is expected to reopen in 1999, will gather 1,700 state employees from 41 sites in the Los Angeles area.
The purchase is a "major set piece in the revitalization of the Broadway-Spring Street area" of downtown Los Angeles, said Daniel Garcia, chairman of the redevelopment agency's board of commissioners. The area, also called the historic core, is just east of the new high-rise financial district.
The deal stems from an executive order from Gov. Pete Wilson to consolidate state office uses in downtown areas of Los Angeles and other cities, including Oakland and San Bernardino. The Broadway store project will help the state meet a goal of consolidating 750,000 square feet of government office space in the historic core.
In addition to being a partner in the purchase, the redevelopment agency assisted in the deal by forgiving part of the building's property taxes, so the money could be reinvested in the structure.
"The old Broadway building was a critical issue for us, as a means to shore up the public investment the state already had in the area," said Kevin Eckery, Deputy Secretary of the State and Consumer Services Agency.
Chief among the state's assets in the historic core is the 825,000-square-foot Ronald Reagan Building, a state office building built in 1989 two blocks south of the Broadway building, amid dilapidated buildings at the edge of the city's Skid Row section.
The former Broadway store, with 45,000 square feet of space on each floor, is well suited to office use, Mr. Eckery said. He added that the building would encourage the use of mass transit; a station of the city's new Metro Rail subway system is a block west of the building.
The purchase also meshes with ambitions of the city's redevelopment agency to introduce new uses and new tenants into empty buildings of the historic core, which was the city's financial center from the turn of the century until the 1960's. The area is prized by preservationists as a collection of handsome old office buildings, banks and a group of flamboyant movie palaces. But many of the buildings are considered obsolete for modern office use. Since the 1960's, most downtown office tenants have moved to newer towers.
The void left by big companies in the historic core was quickly filled by retail businesses, created largely by immigrants from Mexico and Central America. Broadway has become an intensely busy shopping street for the Hispanic community, and storefront properties command some of the highest retail rents in the city. In many buildings, however, the upper floors sit empty.
But after years of failed and struggling projects, investment is focusing again on the historic core. Mr. Garcia, the redevelopment agency chairman, cited several projects for the area, including the renovation of the upper stories of the Million Dollar Theater and the Grand Central Market, both on Broadway, into apartments and office space.
The agency has approved a plan to renovate the Broadway Spring Arcade, a retail and office building. The Archdiocese of Los Angeles is planning a $150 million complex, including a new cathedral, on the site of the existing St. Vibiana's Cathedral.
"The area is showing a spark," Mr. Garcia said. "Three or four of the big pieces are falling into place."

HEADLINE: A 'Frontier' Land of Ancient Rivalry

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, Aug. 2

 BODY:
The mood of diplomats and United Nations officials here trying to avert a wider war between Croatia and rebel Serbs ranges from "not optimistic" to "very pessimistic." Should their fears become reality -- which may be known within the next few days -- the conflagration over a crescent of territory called Krajina will not be a new one.
On the contrary, it will be a resumption of a brutal war that was begun in 1991 and was largely over before the siege of Sarajevo and the horrors and ethnic cleansing in neighboring Bosnia began in 1992. And the history of struggles for the land stretches back centuries. 
 Fearing, with good reason, that renewed fighting between Croatian Government troops and the rebel Serbs will lead to a even broader Balkan war, Washington and other Western Governments, and the United Nations, are trying to broker a peaceful resolution. Representatives of the parties are to meet in Geneva on Thursday, but it is hard to find a diplomat who thinks either side is willing to engage in serious negotiations.
The signs that compromise is a hopeless notion continued to pile up.
Croatia, which has an estimated 100,000 troops ready for war, warned the Serbs in a letter today to give up or be attacked. Croats assaulted Serb-populated villages along the border with Bosnia today, closed main roads that the military might need and sent out broadcasts to the Serbs to overthrow their leaders.
Responding to the threats of violence, Lufthansa canceled all flights into Croatia.
Both the Government and the rebels have legitimate grievances and claims, diplomats say. The Government invokes the principle of territorial integrity and the economic imperative to integrate the Krajina, which sits astride vital oil, rail and road networks. The Krajina Serbs talk about protecting the right to self-determination and the rights of a minority.
Whose land the Krajina is depends on how far back in history one goes and who the historian is.
"It is our land," one Croatian woman said adamantly, explaining why she wanted her Government to go to war to take it back.
Knin, for instance, is claimed by the rebel Serbs today as the capital of an independent republic. But a Croatian King, Tomislav, was crowned in Knin in the 10th century, and for the next several centuries Croatia and neighboring kingdoms were carved up by the various empires of the day.
By the end of the 17th century, Serbs dominated the region. The Hapsburgs and Hungarians moved in vast numbers of Serbs because they wanted the Orthodox Christians to serve as buffers against the Ottoman Turks. The word "krajina" means "frontier" or "border lands."
By race and language, Serbs and Croats are one ethnic group, according to most anthropologists. What divides them is religion: the Croats are Roman Catholics, the Serbs Eastern Orthodox.
Still, Serbs and Croats "lived together in relative contentment," and they would not have "dreamed it possible that Croatian soldiers would massacre innocent Serbs, while Serbian fighters would mutilate innocent Croats," Misha Glenny, a journalist-historian who has chronicled the disintegration of Yugoslavia, has written.
But that is precisely what happened once strident nationalists gained ascendancy.
In Belgrade, President Slobodan Milosevic, a Serbian hard-liner, had designs for a "Greater Serbia" that would include the "krajinas" in Croatia. Croatian nationalists had dreams of a greater Croatia, which would include Croat-populated regions of Bosnia.
The Croats voted overwhelmingly for independence in May 1991 in a referendum boycotted by most of Croatia's Serbs. Civil war erupted between the Yugoslav Army and the fledgling Croatian military. It was a war in which neither side gave any quarter, villages were "ethnically cleansed" by both sides and some 10,000 civilians were killed.
In early 1992, the United Nations negotiated a cease-fire, and the first peacekeepers arrived in the Balkans to supervise the withdrawal of the Yugoslav Army and the demilitarization of the Krajina.
But the area's political status was left unresolved.
The Krajina Serbs were adamantly against being part of Croatia. Part of their fears went back to World War II, when Croatia was ruled by the Ustashe Government, which supported the Nazis and killed thousands of Serbs. In 1991, when Croatia gained its independence from Yugoslavia, the Government fueled the Serbs' fears by adopting traditional Croatian symbols that had also been used by the Ustashe.
Nationalists from Serbia proper also came around to stir up trouble.
For the most part, the cease-fire held, and after months of strenuous efforts, in January of this year, the American Ambassador here, Peter W. Galbraith, working with his Russian counterpart and United Nations negotiators, came up with a proposal on the Krajina's political status. It would remain part of Croatia, but it would have considerable autonomy, including its own flag, parliament, police force and even currency.
The Krajina Serbs refused to even look at the proposal, sparing the Croatian Government from rejecting it, which diplomats say it surely would have done, for it had no intention of granting autonomy.
Though there have been changes in the Krajina Serb government and some moderates, thought to be willing to negotiate, are in key positions, the self-proclaimed republic is headed by Milan Martic, who was indicted last month by the international criminal tribunal in The Hague for crimes against humanity.
Currently, the estimated population of the Krajina is 150,000 Serbs; the Croats have been driven out. There are about twice that many Serbs in the rest of Croatia, most of them living peacefully, telling evidence that not all Croatian Serbs side with the rebels.
On the Croatian side, the strategic determination not to allow the Krajina to secede is driven by economics as well as nationalism. Tourism is the backbone of the Croatian economy, and the best routes to popular tourist spots on the Adriatic like Split and Dubrovnik run through the Krajina.
Before the war, tourism brought in about $10 billion a year; last year revenues were down to $2 billion, and this year, the fear of war has reduced it to less than $500 million.
One of the great unknowns now is what Mr. Milosevic will do for the Krajina Serbs in the event of war. He will be under pressure from Serbian nationalists to come to their aid. At the same time, however, he is desperate to have economic sanctions lifted, and Western diplomats here believe that he may be willing to sacrifice the Krajina.
The land itself is of marginal value. But in the Balkans today, where irrational nationalism reigns and bitterness has destroyed brotherhood, the Krajina Serbs and the Croatian Government are ready to fight over it.


GRAPHIC: The Balkan wars have embroiled three of the countries involved in the split-up of the old Yugoslav Federation. Fighting first flared in 1991, after Slovenia and Croatia, two of the republics in the six-member federation, declared independence.
Chart/Map: "The Balkan Conflict: Where Things Stand"
The Yugoslav Government , which had come under the domination of nationalist elements of the federation's largest ethnic group, the Serbs, allowed Slovenia to leave without serious opposition. But Serbs living in Croatia, a large minority fearful of the Croatian nationalists, rejected secession and, with military support from the Serbs of Yugoslavia, seized control of its homeland region. Fighting was halted by a United Nations-monitored cease-fire in early 1992, but flareups continue, and many see an imminent Croatian offensive to regain control of its Serb-held territories.
Fighting in Bosnia began in 1992, following the Croatian model: the election of a nationalist Government (this time Muslim-dominated, not Croatian), its rejection by a strong Serbian minority, a declaration of independence from Yugoslavia, a Serbian revolt backed by the arms and men of the Yugoslav Government, and the Serbian seizure of large swaths of territory. Three years of fighting has produced an estimated 200,000 deaths, more than a million refugees and a military stalemate.
 
WHO THEY ARE
 MUSLIMS -- Mostly Slavic, Serbo-Croatian speakers who adopted Islam under Ottoman rule. Some families have some Turkish or Arabic ancestry.
 CROATS -- Slavic, Serbo-Croatian speakers of the Roman Catholic faith whose ancestral lands were part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire.
 SERBS -- Slavic, Serbo-Croatian speakers of the Orthodox Christian faith whose ancestral lands were part of the Ottoman Turkish Empire.
 
WHERE THEY LIVE
 BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
 Capital: Sarajevo.
 Population: 4.6 million.
 Ethnic profile: Muslims nearly half, Serbs one third, Croats one fifth.
 President: Alija Izetbegovic, who heads a Muslim nationalist party but professes a commitment to an multiethnic country. Receiving Croatian military support, and benefits somewhat from the presence of United Nations peacekeepers.
 CROATIA
 Capital: Zagreb.
 Population: 4.8 million.
 Ethnic profile: Croatian majority; Serbs one eighth.
 President: Franjo Tudjman. Despite its nationalist leanings it has forged close ties with the West, especially the United States and Germany. Uneasily allied with Bosnia against the Serbs.
 SERBIA
 Capital: Belgrade.
 Population: 9.8 million.
 Ethnic profile: Serbian majority; Albanian and Hungarian minorities.
 President: Slobodan Milosevic. Technically part of Yugoslavia, which includes Serbia and Montenegro, but the Milosevic Government thoroughly eclipses that of the Yugoslav Federation. Milosevic once championed the notion of gathering all Serbs into one political entity. But after the United Nations slapped an economic embargo on his country, Milosevic ended assistance, overtly at least, to the Serbian militants in Croatia and Bosnia.
 
THE UNITED NATIONS
 Originally, U.N. peacekeepers were to go to former Yugoslavia to patrol the truce in Croatia. By summer 1992, their roll had broadened to include insuring aid deliveries to millions of needy, especially in Bosnia. The U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees has been the principal deliverer of aid on which millions depend in Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia.
 Peacekeepers -- There are approximately 23,000 peacekeepers in Bosnia, and just over 12,000 in Croatia. There are another 12,000 people at Zagreb headquarters and scattered through the mission area, and some 1,000 peacekeepers in Macedonia.
 The Arms Embargo -- The embargo was imposed on all of former Yugoslavia in September 1991. Despite the ban on trading arms, Croatia and, to a lesser extent, the Bosnian Government have acquired arms that they say help redress the Serbs' advantage in heavy arms, inherited from the Yugoslav Army.
 U.N.-Designated "Safe Areas" -- Six Muslim enclaves have been designated for protection by the United Nations. Sarajevo, the capital; Tuzla in north central Bosnia; Bihac in northwestern Bosnia; and the eastern enclaves of Gorazde, Zepa and Srebrenica. Zepa and Srebrenica both have fallen.
 
NATO
 By agreement with the United Nations, NATO is responsible for patrolling a U.N.-declared no-flights zone over Bosnia. NATO air strikes have been called when U.N. commander on the ground, their civilain chief and NATO commander agree on them.
 Last month, U.N. Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali delegated his authority to the U.N. commander in former Yugoslavia, meaning military men will now decide whether to engage in more vigorous air strikes.
 
Map shows the current areas of control in and surrounding Bosnia and Herzegovina.
 
Chronology: "Recent Developments"
 May 24 -- U.N. orders Serbs to return heavy weapons to U.N. control and remove all heavy weapons around Sarajevo.
 May 25 -- Serbs ignore U.N. order. NATO attacks Serb ammunition depot. Serbs respond by shelling "safe areas."
 May 26 -- Serbs take U.N. peacekeepers hostage. Eventually more than 370 seized.
 June 8 -- NATO approves new rapid reaction force to bolster U.N. peacekeepers in Bosnia.
June 15 -- Bosnian Government launches offensive to break seige of Sarajevo. Serbs step up shelling of Sarajevo and other "safe areas."
 June 18 -- Last of U.N. hostages released.
 July 11 -- Serbs overrun Srebrenica "safe area" and seize more U.N. hostages; Muslim refugees and peacekeepers tell of Serbian atrocities. The "safe area" of Zepa is overrun over the following two weeks.
 July 21 -- NATO threatens air strikes if the nearby Gorazde "safe area" is attacked.
 July 28 -- Croatia sends thousands of troops across the border into Bosnia, where they cut Serbian supply lines and threaten a widening of the war.
 Aug. 1 -- NATO extends its threat of air strikes against rebel Serbs to protect all remaining "safe areas" in Bosnia -- Sarajevo, Gorazde, Tuzla and Bihac. House of Representatives follows Senate on defying arms embargo, sending measure to a certain Presidential veto.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

MCI to Dismiss 2,500, Even as Earnings Rise
 MCI, even while announcing a 21 percent rise in earnings, said it would restructure the company, dismiss about 7 percent of its work force -- 2,500 to 3,000 employees -- by year-end and write off obsolete assets. It expects to take a $600 million to $800 million write-off. 
 The move was one in a flurry of announcements intended to make the company more attractive to investors. MCI also said it might issue stock tied to parts of its business and said it had concluded alliances that would allow it to offer cellular telephone services to most of the country. The stock rose 62.5 cents, to $24. [Page D3.]
 
Del Laboratories to Settle Sexual Harassment Suit
 Del Laboratories, a Long Island cosmetics and pharmaceutical company, agreed to settle sexual harassment complaints brought by 15 women against its chief executive in what was called the largest monetary settlement that the E.E.O.C. has ever obtained. [A1.]
 
More Signs of Growth
 More evidence that the economy is perking up emerged as the Government's main forecasting index posted its first gain of 1995, rising two-tenths of 1 percent in June. Also, sales of new houses were at the briskest pace since late 1993, rising 6.1 percent to about 728,000 units. [D3.]
 
Microsoft and Digital in Pact
 Microsoft and Digital Equipment announced an agreement aimed at helping both companies capture a bigger share of the corporate market for computers and software. The agreement also included a plan to cross-license their patents. [D2.]
 
F.A.A. Grounds Markair
 The F.A.A. has grounded Markair, a cut-rate airline serving cities like New York, Chicago, Los Angeles, Dallas and Atlanta, because of maintenance problems. [A17.]
 
Prodigy Scales Back Plan
Prodigy has decided not to move half its staff from White Plains to New York City; instead, it will open a 13,000-square-foot office in SoHo staffed by about 50 employees. [B4.]
 
Orange County Plan Vetoed
 The recovery plan of Orange County, Calif., took another blow as Gov. Pete Wilson vetoed a bill that would have allowed the county to shift $70 million a year earmarked for transportation to help pay its huge debts. [D2.]
 
Shuttle Venture Formed
 Rockwell International and Lockheed Martin agreed to form a joint venture in an effort to meet NASA's goal of using a single contractor for the space shuttle program. [D3.]
 
Where the Power Lies in TV
 A small takeover fight for Outlet Communications helps illustrate where a lot of the real power in broadcasting lies: with the owners of individual stations that can deliver viewers. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D5.]
 
Isuzu Ads Evocative of Spielberg
 The new commercials for American Isuzu Motors contain hints of many Steven Spielberg movies. And since the campaign was stepped up this summer, sales of some Isuzu models have surged. In July, the company sold more than 6,000 Rodeo sport utility vehicles, a record. Advertising. [D5.]
 
Another Shift at Times Mirror
 Times Mirror named Efrem Zimbalist 3d president and chief executive of its magazine division, in a move aimed at increasing the unit's profits. [D4.]
 
After Apartheid, Jobs for Blacks
 With apartheid behind them, many South African companies are rushing to hire blacks, wooing them with salaries that are 20 to 50 percent higher than their white counterparts. But many of the jobs turn out to carry little real authority. [A1.]

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Tokyo Acts in Unusually Direct Manner

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 2

 BODY:
The Japanese Government took the financial markets by storm today, introducing a package of measures meant to bolster the dollar and backing up its words with cash.
The Government's actions -- announcing the measures, which were aimed at increasing Japanese investment abroad; intervening in the currency market during the Japanese trading day, and then intervening again when trading began in the United States -- were part of a cooperative effort with the United States, and the dollar rallied. 
 But economists and analysts in Tokyo were skeptical that the euphoria would last. Still, the move also comes a day after Government officials reacted quickly to a run on a large credit union.
And in contrast to their usual style of leaking bits of a plan before an announcement, the authorities today surprised the markets with their detailed package, which was buttressed by the interventions.
"Japan needs to invest and lend more abroad to reverse the strong yen," Masayoshi Takemura, the Finance Minister, said at a hastily called news conference. When Japanese institutions invest in foreign securities and assets, they must sell yen and buy dollars and other currencies, weakening the Japanese currency. So by making foreign investment easier, the ministry hopes to push down the yen.
The strong yen has battered the Japanese economy because it makes Japanese exports more expensive in terms of other currencies and reduces the amount of Japanese currency produced by transactions denominated in other currencies.
In recent months, economists and analysts have criticized the authorities for introducing economic measures that lacked substance. Today, however, the text was quite specific.
"This package has more guts, more numbers, more targets than we've seen in previous packages, and that's helped to enamor people," said David Atkinson, a financial analyst at Goldman Sachs (Japan) Ltd.
The plan loosened restrictions on some banks, allowing them to take more aggressive positions in foreign exchange trading. It also eased curbs on loans made by insurance companies that are denominated in yen and foreign currency.
Accounting rules covering foreign bonds held by Japanese companies were loosened, allowing the companies flexibility in stating the value of the bonds and in reporting losses caused by currency fluctuations. The Government hopes that with more choice in how to account for foreign bonds, companies will buy more. But analysts noted that accounting changes were unlikely to encourage large flows of capital.
The plan also removed restrictions on purchases of Euroyen bonds by Japanese institutions. However, Japanese investors have evaded such limits in the past, and in any case, Japan had already promised the United States that it would take the step next year. (A Euroyen investment is denominated in yen but held outside Japan.) The Government hopes that by promoting the Euroyen market, it will increase liquidity of the yen abroad -- in essence internationalizing the yen -- to ease demand for yen in Japan and thereby weaken it.
Finally, the Government said it would promote investment and lending abroad by its official institutions.
Buoyed by the package and the market intervention, in which the central banks of Japan and the United States sold yen and bought dollars, the dollar rose above 90 yen for the first time in about four months. Mostly because of the dollar's strength, Tokyo stocks rose, with the Nikkei average of 225 stocks closing with a gain of 362.18 points, or 2.2 percent, to 16,720.75.
Still, financial experts in Tokyo said the measures were unlikely to have a lasting effect because while they were specific, they were rather cosmetic. In some cases, the measures merely supported guidelines already in effect or accelerated deregulatory steps previously planned.
Most important, the analysts said they doubted that the measures would alter the basic sense of risk aversion that now shapes the outlook of Japanese institutions.
Japan's insurance companies, at which most of today's measures were aimed, were riding high in the 1980's, when soaring stock and real estate values gave them the confidence to invest in riskier assets abroad. Now, with Japan's stock and property markets depressed, the institutions are struggling, and some are not even able to pay dividends.
"Unless you change their risk aversion, they're not going to jump into investments abroad," said Rie Ota, a financial analyst at Baring Securities (Japan) Ltd. "They don't have as much of a cushion as they used to."
Moreover, Japanese institutions, which poured money into dollar-denominated assets in the last decade, are still smarting from the effects of the strong yen.

HEADLINE: Book War: Shops vs. Superstores;
As Chains Grow, Struggling Small Stores Stress Expertise

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
Like a captain going down with the ship, Encarnita Quinlan stood among the half-empty shelves of Endicott Booksellers and gazed bravely at the bargain hunters picking over the remains of her store, which is closing after 14 years in business on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. A sympathetic customer approached and asked, "Heartbroken?" Ms. Quinlan threw an arm across her chest, struggled for the right word, and settled for "yes."
There is quite a bit of heartbreak among New York City's independent booksellers these days. With the arrival of Barnes & Noble superstores, places like Endicott's are finding themselves up against the wall, unable to offer the discounts or carry the number of titles found at Barnes & Noble stores, or to serve caffe lattes and flavored iced teas in spiffy mezzanine cafes. 
 Up and down Manhattan, even in Brooklyn and the Bronx, which have no superstores yet, bookstore owners and some serious readers warn of an approaching intellectual ice age, when impersonal superstores will drive out the city's rich array of neighborhood bookstores.
Others, particularly the hordes of customers who pack the aisles of the Barnes & Noble stores, are not so sure. Fans of the stores, including publishing executives, say they have brought a breath of fresh air. The stores are prospering, they say, because they are well run and a pleasure to visit, with a wide selection of titles, many at discounts.
What the future promises, some publishing executives say, is a New York in which many general-interest independent bookstores will be crushed by the Barnes & Noble juggernaut, but the superstores will coexist with specialty bookstores and independents that can diversify or provide a high level of service and expertise.
"There's always a place for a neighborhood bookstore," said Lenny Golay, co-owner of the Corner Bookstore, on Madison Avenue near 93d Street. She plans to open a second store, Lenox Hill Books, in mid-September on Lexington Avenue between 72d and 73d Streets.
What the small store cannot offer are the discounts and the number of titles available at the superstores. Barnes & Noble stores, which carry as many as 150,000 titles (compared with 35,000 at Endicott's), offer 20 percent off all hard-cover titles, 30 percent off hardbacks on the New York Times best-seller list, and 20 percent off paperbacks on the list.
But discounts are only part of the story. With their wide aisles, clubby decorating schemes, lavishly stocked magazine racks and coffee bars, they have become retail destinations -- a place to hang out, meet people and attend readings, children's programs and even concerts.
"When I first walked in here, my impression was, 'This is a cool store,' " said Danessa Atkins, who had traveled from Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, to shop in Barnes & Noble's Chelsea store on Saturday. "You can read whatever you want because they have these lounging chairs and everyone's relaxed."
Uptown, Doris Ogel was shopping for vacation reading at Books & Company on Madison Avenue near 74th Street. She pronounced Barnes & Noble "sort of a hassle." Books & Company was more like it, she said.
"I come here for certain things," she said. "They have a wonderful classical library, and a lot of poetry. Barnes & Noble is trying, but the people who work there are not real book people."
Real book people or not, the company thinks it has found a winner with the superstore concept. Last year, Barnes & Noble recorded sales of $953 million from its 268 superstores across the country, up 32 percent from $614.6 million from 203 stores in 1993.
Nationwide, superstores operated by the four largest book chains accounted for 17 percent of the $9.55 billion in retail book sales last year, up from 11 percent in 1993. That figure is likely to rise as expansion continues. Barnes & Noble, whose first New York superstore opened in Rockefeller Center in 1977, has opened five more superstores in Manhattan, one in Queens and one in Hoboken, N.J., in the last five years. It plans to open three new stores in the city by the end of the year, on 17th Street across from Union Square, on Broadway at 67th Street, and on Austin Street in Forest Hills, Queens.
Forest Hills and Lincoln Center, which has a few performing-arts bookstores only, are more or less virgin territory. The Union Square store will test the downtown market since it is only a few blocks from the Barnes & Noble store on Fifth Avenue at 18th Street, which is itself within hailing distance of the chain's Chelsea superstore.
For independents, the success of the superstore formula means adapt or die. After Barnes & Noble opened a superstore at 86th Street and Lexington Avenue in January 1990, the Burlington Book Shop went out of business. So did Eeyore's and Storyland, children's bookstores that could not compete with the superstore's large children's annex. Eeyore's second store, on the Upper West Side, also closed.
After the Barnes & Noble superstore opened on upper Broadway in April 1993, Ms. Quinlan said, business immediately dropped 25 percent at Endicott's, at Columbus Avenue and 81st Street. That quickly fell to 45 percent and stayed there, even after she cut store hours and reduced the employees from 14, to 10. Before the superstore, she said, business had risen 5 to 7 percent annually. The store's official closing day is Labor Day, but if the stock sells out, it may shut its doors earlier.
"People tell me to add a cafe and sell coffee, but how many cups can you sell?" Ms. Quinlan said. "Besides, if I'd wanted to sell coffee and T-shirts, I would have gone into a different business."
A block down Broadway from Barnes & Noble, Shakespeare & Company carries on. The store, near 81st Street, has opened a second-floor used-book section. Customers who sell books to the store receive store credit. It has also begun selling rare books and remainders. Still, business is down, although management will not say how much. "They haven't done us in, but they're sure making life hard," said Felice Rose, the general manager.
Shakespeare, which has a store downtown on Astor Place, plans to open a third store on Lexington Avenue at 69th Street in the fall.
Many independents say Barnes & Noble is bent on total domination of the New York market. Barnes & Noble executives like to think they are creating new book buyers in a market with room for both superstores and book boutiques. "The overall market is expanding, and our company is in for a larger piece of a larger pie," said Stephen Riggio, chief operating officer of Barnes & Noble.
The big-pie argument has not done much to cheer up hard-pressed independents, however. "None of us see much of a future," said Jenny Feder, co-owner of Three Lives & Company Bookstore in the West Village. "We do special orders, we have a pared-down operation, we don't have high rent, but we're just eking it out."
David Ravel, manager of the Community Bookstore in Park Slope, Brooklyn, said the superstores have already affected buyer behavior in his store. Customers who cannot find a title no longer want to place a special order, he said. Instead, they head to Barnes & Noble. "What the superstores have done, brilliantly, is create the illusion that they have everything, and of course, no one can have everything," he said.
Owners and book buyers at independent stores say the loss of stores like Endicott will mean cultural impoverishment for the city. They say customers enticed by discounts will wake up one day to see they have traded away expertise, personal service and a commitment to small presses, university presses and quality books that require nurturing.
"E. Annie Proulx, who now wins prizes and sells widely, was supported by the independents for years before she made it to the chains," said Stuart Bernstein, the book buyer at Endicott's. "People are no longer going to find the depth of selection, the small-press book, or the odd university-press book. There are books I felt it was my responsibility to take a chance on."
Not everyone agrees. Susan Donnelly, the sales manager at the University of Chicago Press, said that about half of her sales now go through superstores, which have become more willing to stock not only the press's trade books but also its scholarly titles.
"Now at Barnes & Noble, they listen to our presentation of the most scholarly books at the back of the catalog," she said. "This isn't something that the independents particularly like to hear, but it's true."
Lisa Domitrovich, a consultant to and former executive director of Small Press Distribution, said the independents, under pressure from chains, have grown cautious in recent years. "They are no longer the major supporters of the small presses," she said. "The chains are."
Yes, for the moment, say the independents. But what happens when Barnes & Noble has established superstores all over the city?
"The big question is, if they are successful at eliminating the competition, what's their motivation to keep prices down, or to keep 'Epic of Gilgamesh' on the shelves, even if it only sells two copies a year?" Mr. Ravel said. Small-store owners like to point out that a year ago, Barnes & Noble quietly dropped its policy of discounting all paperbacks.
Mr. Riggio, who will not say how many stores Barnes & Noble plans to open, plays down the independents' fears. "Even with our big store opening in Chelsea, there has been an explosion of small bookstores in that area," he said.
St. Marks Books in the East Village is a stone's throw from Barnes & Noble on Astor Place and Tower Books on Lafayette Street. It has defined itself as an alternative by specializing in cultural theory and stocking a large number of poetry and fiction titles from small presses.
On East Seventh Street, See Hear, has carved a niche by carrying hundreds of fanzines -- magazines devoted to a single topic or obsession -- and related books. Ted Gottfried, the owner, is looking for a larger location so he can carry every fanzine being published. "It's the opposite of mass market," he said. "Anyone trying to play the general bookstore game is just going to die."

HEADLINE: Tiny Base May Give Clues to Saving Jobs

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: HEATH, Ohio

 BODY:
Newark Air Force base here is so small that it does not even have a runway, but President Clinton's top advisers are counting on it to solve a big political problem.
The little base amid the cornfields of central Ohio repairs guidance and navigation systems for nuclear missiles and fighter jets. But now it is enmeshed in Mr. Clinton's 1996 campaign hopes in California, where it is touted as a promising, though largely unproven, way of turning Government enterprise into private enterprise. 
 When the Pentagon decided in 1993 to close the Newark base, local residents and the Air Force came up with a plan to keep most of the 1,400 civilian jobs in the town. The idea was to have the workers become employees of a private company that would contract with the Government to do the work.
The military calls the concept privatization in place, and it would like to institute the process at some other bases to be closed to ease the impact on the local economy. This is how California came into the picture.
In theory, private contractors could do the same work with fewer people at lower costs than the Government. The shift would allow the Pentagon to reap the savings of closing the base, keep skilled workers together to perform essential military tasks and avoid the cost of moving equipment.
The Newark base, in this community of 7,500 people 35 miles east of Columbus, is the first where the military has tried to privatize an entire installation. So anxiety reigns at the 70-acre installation, the smallest in the Air Force.
The civilian employees are torn between staying on with a private employer next year or transferring to another Pentagon maintenance depot to keep their Federal benefits. "I'm 48 with 18 years in this man's Air Force," said one employee, John Crumpley, a product engineer who wants to move to a Navy depot in Florida, "and I'm not about to give that up to go work for a contractor who'll fire me after a year."
Several large contractors, including the Boeing Company and Rockwell, have bid on the Newark work and have promised to keep most of the jobs here. But the companies do not rule out eliminating some jobs.
One company, the Science Applications International Corporation of San Diego, pulled out of the bidding because of what it said were restrictive contract requirements.
"They were telling us the schedule to mop the floors," said David Berteau, a Science Applications International executive who is a former Pentagon official.
The General Accounting Office, the auditing arm of Congress, says contracting the work at Newark might actually cost $456 million more over the next five years than having the military do it. Even the Air Force says it does not know whether the plan will save money.
"We don't know what it will cost," Col. Joseph M. Renaud, the base commander, said in an interview. He said the winning bid would be announced on Dec. 5.
James F. Boatright, the Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Air Force for installations, said, "The only way to know for sure is to go through the process."
Despite the uncertainty, the Pentagon has said it will try to privatize most of the civilian work at two installations that are much larger and more diverse than Newark, McClellan Air Force Base in Sacramento, Calif. and Kelly Air Force Base in San Antonio. These are two bases the Air Force agreed to close on recommendations by the independent commission on base closings.
Citing Newark as a prototype, Deputy Defense Secretary John P. White said the Air Force would contract the work at McClellan and Kelly to local employers to keep thousands of jobs in the two cities. "We have in place in Ohio a real-live example," Mr. White told reporters. "We're doing this with the private sector."
Defense Department officials acknowledge that no one gave privatization at McClellan the slightest thought until July, when the commission recommended closing that installation, which employs 11,000 civilian and military workers. The Pentagon had recommended that the base remain open.
With all the jobs at stakes at McClellan, Mr. Clinton and his top aides faced a difficult political calculus: Reject the panel's findings and risk Republican accusations that the President was politicizing a nonpartisan process that had worked well since 1988, or do nothing and anger many voters in a state that is crucial to Mr. Clinton's re-election hopes.
"One cannot deny there was political pressure," a senior Defense Department official said. "The question was, What could you do to moderate it."
Enter Newark Air Force Base, which is so small that a visitor can easily walk from the front gate to the two main buildings: the administrative headquarters and the vast shop, where technicians repair F-16 gyroscopes, measure laser beams and wield 50-ton calibrators in subterranean chambers where temperatures are controlled to one-tenth of a degree.
Pentagon and White House aides express confidence that privatizing civilian jobs will work at the bases in Ohio and California, particularly since McClellan is not scheduled to close for five years. By that time, Administration officials say, they can apply to the larger base the lessons learned from Newark.
Under the Administration's plan, the Pentagon will employ 8,700 civilian workers at McClellan through the year 2000 and about 4,500 with a private contractor after that.
While Air Force officials are scrambling to work out the specific details of the McClellan plan, some experts say it is premature to use Newark as a model for the much larger bases in California and Texas.
"I hope the Newark example works out, but it's a minor effort compared to what's proposed at McClellan," said Paul Taibl, a retired Air Force lieutenant colonel who is director of economic programs for the Business Executives for National Security, a research organization in Washington. "If it's unsuccessful or rocky, it could sour Congress on trying it again."
Even commanders at Newark note the differences between their base and their much larger California cousin. Newark is a small, specialized installation. The Air Force estimated it would be cheaper by fivefold to leave the work in Newark than move it. McClellan, by contrast, is a sprawling complex base that performs a variety of aircraft maintenance work that could be done at other Air Force depots now operating well below capacity.
"They have a much larger operation then we have," said Colonel Renaud, who recently flew to McClellan to offer advice. "They face a challenge of trying to get their arms around this huge operation and decide how to make privatization work. It's going to be a monumental challenge."
California's members of Congress, who fought to keep McClellan open, express concern that the Pentagon may be applying an experimental idea to McClellan before the time is ripe. "Of course, I'm concerned," said Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California. "It's never been tested in a larger way."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Clinton Administration is counting on this little base in Ohio to solve a big political problem: how to close a huge base in California, which is vital to President Clinton's re-election, without the loss many civilian jobs. The Air Force is closing the installation, Newark Air Force Base in Heath, Ohio, while trying to privatize most of the base's 1,400 civilian jobs to reduce the economic impact. (Andrew Gordon for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
$207 Million Deal Is Near At WNYC-TV

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
The ITT Corporation and Dow Jones & Company have agreed to pay New York City $207 million to acquire the city-owned television station WNYC-TV, Channel 31, people involved in the negotiations said yesterday. The companies plan to transform the station into a 24-hour sports, financial news and entertainment service, they said.
The goal is to make what is now a public television station into a superstation, like WTBS in Atlanta and WGN in Chicago, that can be beamed by satellite to cable systems around the country. 
 The station would offer professional sports events including games of the Yankees, Knicks and Rangers, whose broadcast rights rest largely with the MSG cable network, which is owned by ITT and the Cablevision Systems Corporation. Cablevision's Sportschannel service has the rights to some Mets games, as well as those of the New Jersey Nets, the New York Islanders and the Stanley Cup champion New Jersey Devils, and the new station is expected to negotiate for the rights to some of those games -- giving it a potential lineup of seven major-league teams.
Dow Jones is expected to provide business and economic programming, including material from its Asian Business News and European Business News television operations.
The price tag is two to three times what New York City expected to reap when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced plans in March to sell the television station and to turn over the city's two radio stations to a nonprofit foundation. The foundation is to pay the city $20 million over six years, raising the money from listener pledges and other sources.
A sale price of $207 million for WNYC-TV would be a windfall for the Mayor's tightly stretched budget and a vindication for Mr. Giuliani, who was criticized when he first proposed to sell the city's television and radio stations.
"I figured $40 million to $70 million," said Thomas Morgan, who resigned as president of WNYC last year rather than be party to the sale. Even so, Mr. Morgan added, "If they'd waited a few more years they could have gotten more. It had developed into a great alternative TV public station."
When Mr. Giuliani, shortly after his inauguration, broached the idea of selling the city's stations, it was the listeners to public radio who protested the loudest. The deal to sell only the television station quieted many critics, though the foreign-language programmers who lease a large chunk of broadcast time on Channel 31 had appealed in June to retain their access, which they will lose under this deal. English-language programming for immigrants and financial news from Bloomberg Business News are also broadcast on leased time.
The ITT-Dow Jones purchase of WNYC requires approval of the Federal Communications Commission. The partners expect the deal to be cleared within six months.
The key to the ITT-Dow Jones plan is to use programming and resources already in place, rather than spend tens of millions of dollars to develop programming from scratch. Though the price is high for a UHF, or ultrahigh-frequency, station, the anticipated cost of programming is low.
In buying WNYC, the venture will have a local broadcast station that can transmit its signal to a satellite, from which it can be plucked by cable systems around the country. In this type of "superstation" arrangement, the station owner receives no fees from the cable systems but is able to sell a national audience to advertisers.
The alternate approach would have been to market the MSG network nationally, but this would have required the negotiation of thousands of contracts with cable systems.
One executive involved in the negotiations said MSG and WNYC would not show games simultaneously. Instead, the strategy will be to allow viewers without cable television to see some games of local teams on what is now WNYC. Knicks and Rangers games have only been available on cable television except for an occasional game of the week; only 50 Yankees games a year have appeared on broadcast television in recent years, with more games shown on cable.
WNYC is available to noncable viewers in the New York City market, but it can be difficult to pick up without a strong antenna. ITT and Dow Jones are planning to double the power of the station for easier reception.
ITT would also provide programming from its Caesars hotel-casino properties, including concerts, boxing and tennis matches.
Dow Jones would supply financial programming from midnight to 6 A.M., including reports from Asian and European markets that Dow Jones publishes each day in The Wall Street Journal. Domestic financial news and features broadcast from a New York studio would be featured from 6 A.M. to about 5 P.M..
"Dow Jones has a fairly substantial interest in business TV overseas," James Dougherty, a Dean Witter Reynolds analyst, told the Dow Jones News Service. "Owning TV stations is clearly in their future."
The executive involved in the talks said there was not a timetable yet for turning the station from local to national distribution as a superstation. He also said he did not expect that the Yankees, which are owned principally by George Steinbrenner, would be paid more to beam their games nationally.
ITT and Cablevision jointly own the Knicks and Rangers. In the past, Major League Baseball and the National Basketball Association have been sharply critical of superstations like TBS and WGN, saying they reduce the value of the leagues' national TV contracts.
The N.B.A.'s attempt to eliminate Chicago Bulls' games on WGN led to a Federal antitrust lawsuit that eventually allowed WGN to continue to broadcast 30 games a season, though not the 41 games that the superstation wanted to show. The N.B.A. was also allowed by a Federal judge to impose a fee on WGN's telecasts.
The Giuliani administration, apparently annoyed that news of the sale had leaked out before an official announcement could be made, declined to comment yesterday.
"It's too early to talk about," said Colleen A. Roche, the Mayor's press secretary.
In March, city officials had estimated that WNYC would sell for $65 million to $75 million. As the bids came in, however, the increased interest in the station prompted speculation that it could sell for as much as $90 million. But no one at City Hall had predicted that it might sell for more than twice that amount.
WNYC broadcasts from the Municipal Building near City Hall. New York has been the only major American city to operate noncommercial stations, and Mr. Giuliani has said that with its fiscal problems the city has no business continuing to operate them.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Despite some problems, the news from Mexico is mostly good.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
REMEMBER the peso crisis in Mexico? No news, in this case, is largely good news. The much criticized "bailout" has allowed the Government to avoid default on its debts and even begin attracting foreign capital. "The White House should get high points" for preventing panic and helping to minimize the pain that followed the devaluation, concludes Jeffrey Sachs, director of Harvard's Institute for International Development.
But there is still plenty to worry about. For while Mexico's deep recession, engineered to permit exports to regain their competitiveness in world markets, has reshaped the economy faster than expected, Mexico's capacity to achieve Asian-style growth remains very much in doubt. "Financial stability," suggests Rudi Dornbusch, an economist at M.I.T., "has been given the upper hand over a sustainable development strategy." 
 Mexico's devaluation was virtually inevitable because the administration of former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari allowed the peso to rise sharply in the 1990's relative to its purchasing power. Inexpensive imports, the reasoning went, would keep Mexican consumers happy and force long-protected Mexican industry to shape up or shut down.
But once foreigners got the message that Mexican exports were uncompetitive, the torrent of foreign investment that had sustained the overvalued peso stopped and Mexico could no longer pay its bills with borrowed dollars.
Unfortunately, the Government delayed the day of reckoning until after national elections by spending down its nest egg of foreign currency. Thus, when devaluation did come, those who had lent dollars to the Government quite reasonably worried that Mexico would be forced to renege. The "bailout," in the form of a $51 billion line of credit collateralized by Mexico's revenue from oil exports, prevented investor panic and the Government's default.
Lawrence Krohn, a senior economist for the Union Bank of Switzerland, argues that President Ernesto Zedillo then gambled that harsh belt-tightening would permit Mexico to put its financial mistakes behind it in a hurry. And thus far, the gamble seems to have paid off. Populist politicians have not been able to make inroads by promising an end the austerity. Indeed, Mr. Krohn says, "the left has gained no ground,"
Foreign investors, particularly direct investors in no rush to recoup dividends, are coming back. What is more, the overnight reduction in domestic spending has permitted exporters to divert billions of dollars of Mexican goods into world markets, transforming an $18.5 billion trade deficit in 1994 into a surplus estimated at $5.5 billion this year.
This turnaround is far faster than conventional economics would predict. But it does not surprise Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics. "Mexican industry has a tradition of looking abroad for markets when domestic demand is slack," he notes.
With any luck, Mexico's recession will end this year after a drop in economic output of between 3 percent and 4 percent. The Union Bank of Switzerland is forecasting 2 percent growth in 1996. And Mr. Krohn believes that Mexico is capable of achieving sustainable growth of 4 percent.
But don't crack that bottle of tequila just yet. For one thing, Mr. Dornbusch notes, deja vu could happen all over again. Once the economy is out of recession and foreign investors return in force, Mexico may well be tempted to let the peso creep back up to an exchange rate that inhibits export-led growth.
Besides, 4 percent growth (partly offset by 2 percent population growth) would hardly put Mexico in the big leagues with, say, Thailand or even Chile. Mexico and Chile, incidentally, had virtually the same per-capita income in 1986; this year, Chile's will be 80 percent higher.
The heart of the problem, Mr. Dornbusch argues, is Mexico's failure to save enough to finance its own growth. According to the International Monetary Fund, Mexico's savings have averaged just 14 percent of income in the last decade, compared with an average of 20 percent in countries at a similar stage of development. And because Mexico cannot rely on foreigners to make up the difference, growth is ultimately constrained by the willingness of affluent Mexicans to save more and spend less.
Mr. Dornbusch says that institutions are to blame, not the culture. "Mexico does suffer from proximity to the United States," the world's most profligate economy, he jokes. Nonetheless, he argues, public policy could make a big difference.
Mr. Dornbusch has in mind higher taxes that would allow the Government to run a permanent budget surplus. And he would like to see a Chilean-style system of forced savings for retirement, in which a portion of everyone's wages is assigned to the private mutual fund of the saver's choice.
The Zedillo administration has, in fact, acknowledged the savings problem. But with Mexico's decaying ruling party divided on how much and how fast it dares change, serious reform is no certainty.

HEADLINE: Murray H. Finley, Labor Leader For Textile Workers, Dies at 73

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Murray H. Finley, the labor leader who led the final, innovative campaign that forced the J. P. Stevens Company to accept union contracts in 1980, died on Monday at the University of Michigan Hospital in Ann Arbor.
Mr. Finley, who was 73, had moved to Ann Arbor after his retirement as president of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union in 1986. 
 His wife, Elaine, said the cause was leukemia.
A distinctly new-school labor leader who never stitched a seam, Mr. Finley was a lawyer who worked his way up through the administrative ranks of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers Union of America, which represented some 350,000 workers in the men's clothing field.
A year after becoming president of the union in 1972, Mr. Finley presided over what amounted to a dress rehearsal for the J. P. Stevens campaign, an effort orchestrated by a union strategist, Ray Rogers, who used consumer boycotts and corporate pressure to force Farah slacks to accept union contracts at its plants in El Paso.
The stage for the final battle against J. P. Stevens was set in 1976, when Mr. Finley helped negotiate a merger with the Textile Workers Union of America.
The textile workers had been struggling to organize Stevens factories in the South since 1963, but although workers at several factories had voted to make the union their bargaining agent, the company had steadfastly refused to bargain, engaging in blatant intimidation and other illegal tactics.
With Mr. Finley as president of the merged union, the company began to experience some intimidation of its own.
The union organized a nationwide consumer boycott, disrupted the company's annual meeting in New York, mounted noisy campaigns to induce corporate executives to resign from the Stevens board and put pressure on banks that dealt with Stevens to abandon the company.
The company capitulated in 1980, accepting union contracts calling for hefty raises at 10 of its 160 plants. But since then, an economic recession and rampant imports have taken their toll on both textile employment and union membership.
Amalgamated, which had 500,000 members after the 1976 merger, had only 200,000 a month ago, when it merged with the International Ladies Garment Workers Union to form Unite, the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees.
Before he retired in 1986, Mr. Finney, who had begun his career denouncing corporate greed, was speaking out on trade issues in a vain effort to block low-cost imports.
Mr. Finley, whose father was an engineer, was born in Syracuse and grew up in Flint, Mich., where, his wife suggested yesterday, the struggles of the United Automobile Workers at the local General Motors plant helped make him a lifelong union man. He joined the U.A.W. when he worked at a machine gun factory before serving with the Army in World War II.
Mr. Finley graduated from the University of Michigan with a degree in economics in 1946. Then, after receiving his law degree from Northwestern University in 1949, he went to work for the old Amalgamated, serving in various capacities in Detroit and Chicago, where he supervised the creation of a vast array of union social programs, from low-cost housing to day care and health clinics.
After his retirement Mr. Finley taught at Harvard University and the University of Virginia.
Besides his wife he is survived by two daughters, Sharon, of Exeter, N.H., and Susan, of Cortez, Colo.; his wife's niece, Jolynne Miller of Manhattan, whom the couple reared after her mother's death, and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Dollar Surges as U.S. and Japan Act Jointly in Markets

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2

 BODY:
The dollar soared to its highest level against the yen in nearly five months today after the United States and Japan sold about $1 billion of yen and the Japanese Government moved to make it easier for institutions there to invest their yen abroad.
With international markets flooded with yen, the dollar rose 3.3 percent against the Japanese currency, standing at 90.96 yen in late New York trading, up from 88.04 yen on Tuesday. 
 Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said the moves by both nations were consistent with an agreement made by the Group of Seven leading industrial nations on April 25, which called for an "orderly reversal" of the plunge in the dollar that occurred in the winter. Many currency traders took Mr. Rubin's remark as suggesting that the United States would intervene in the currency markets again, a line of thinking that Administration officials did not discourage.
Economists said the dollar's rise might damp sales abroad of American goods but would still help the overall American economy. By making imported goods slightly less expensive, a stronger dollar could diminish fears of inflation here and make it slightly easier for the Federal Reserve to stimulate the economy by cutting interest rates.
That possibility, as well as a belief that Japanese institutions would step up their investment in the United States, sent the stock and bond markets up sharply, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising as much as 55 points soon after the Fed began its intervention. Later, though, the Dow average gave up all of its gains when traders took profits. [Page D8.]
The stronger dollar and the Japanese Government's move to ease controls on overseas investments by financial institutions could also reduce the odds that Japan's banking crisis will spread elsewhere. Japan's ailing banks and insurance companies have invested huge sums in the United States, and a stronger dollar makes those investments worth more.
The changes in investment rules were announced today in Tokyo by the Ministry of Finance, Japan's bank regulator. The ministry is overseeing institutions with a total of at least $570 billion in bad debts and it witnessed a run this week on Tokyo's largest credit union. By giving Japanese banks and insurance companies more leeway to pursue higher yields abroad, the authorities hope to lower the yen's value; when Japanese institutions invest abroad, they sell yen and buy other currencies.
Mr. Rubin expressed concern last week about Japan's banking crisis and urged the Bank of Japan to do whatever was necessary. But in a statement today, he presented the joint intervention in the currency markets and the Ministry of Finance's policy changes as part of a continuing international effort to reverse the dollar's plunge.
"We welcome the actions taken by the Japanese authorities to remove impediments to capital movements," Mr. Rubin said. "These actions and our joint operations are consistent with the April 25 G-7 communique."
Mr. Rubin's statement left the impression with traders that the United States might take actions to push the dollar even higher. Administration officials nurtured that view today by sticking to their policy of refusing to speculate whether they would intervene again in the coming weeks.
Currency traders said that today's intervention, while not the biggest of this Administration, was particularly effective. They said it worked because it showed strong coordination between Tokyo and Washington and because Mr. Rubin again caught traders by surprise, making them reluctant to resist the Treasury by selling dollars.
"It's the most aggressive thing they've done so far, as far as trying to prevent the deterioration of the dollar against the yen," said David F. DeRosa, the director of foreign exchange trading in New York for the Swiss Bank Corporation.
Kevin J. Lawrie, a foreign exchange manager at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, said that the intervention was successful because traders were partly taken by surprise and quickly joined the Federal Reserve in buying dollars. "This thing seems like a tidal wave; it probably seems like more than it is," he said.
After two unsuccessful interventions in the spring, Administration officials have concluded that the best way to influence currency markets is to ambush them. Today's intervention and two other successful interventions this summer have come when the dollar was already rising and when traders did not see an immediate need for the United States to support its currency.
While traders were applauding the skill of today's move, economists were divided on its wisdom. The dollar's rebound from a low of 79.80 yen on April 19 has made American goods slightly less competitive in foreign markets. But if the dollar's strength allows the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates, most economists believe that will have a much greater effect on the economy than a modest change in exports, which account for only one-eighth of economic output in the United States. And with the Japanese economy stagnant for the fifth year, American companies have had particular trouble expanding sales there.
William R. Cline, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics here, wondered whether the dollar's rise would lead to a widening of the American trade deficit with Japan over the next couple of years and to worsening trade tensions. "It's a mistake," he said, adding, "I think the dollar is properly valued at 85 yen and if the dollar works its way back to 100 yen, then two years from now the United States Government is going to be complaining" that the trade imbalance with Japan is too large.
But Lawrence Chimerine, an economist at the Economic Strategy Institute here, said that a wide variety of business practices in Japan restricted the sale of American goods there and that the trade imbalance was not a reflection of currency movements. "We are so supercompetitive at 90 that you don't need 80" yen to the dollar, he said. "I think they want to send a message to the Fed: a strong dollar, lower import prices, all make it easier to lower interest rates."
Administration officials, following their policy, declined to comment on what the independent Federal Reserve should do about interest rates.
The Fed, acting on the Treasury Department's directions and possibly using money from the Bank of Japan, swapped as much as $1 billion of yen for dollars during four rounds of intervention in currency markets today, Mr. Lawrie said. The Bank of Japan also bought dollars during trading in Tokyo, traders said.
The dollar also gained against the German mark today, rising to 1.3976 marks in late New York trading from 1.3758 marks Tuesday.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Bonds Up on Outlook For More Japanese Buyers

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices surged yesterday in a rally fueled by the prospect of more Japanese investors entering the market to compete for Government securities.
Earlier, the Japanese Government surprised financial markets by announcing measures to ease controls on Japanese financial institutions to encourage overseas investments. The plan heartened traders in New York, who bet that it could mean increased Japanese investment in the Treasury market. 
 "The news added positive uncertainty, in that it created an environment where market participants are now concerned about a new set of buyers entering the market and competing for securities," said Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston.
Mr. Alexy attributed the buoyancy of the market yesterday in part to memories of the market in the 1980's, when Japanese investors were major buyers of Treasury securities.
Hopes of new buyers overcame concerns about new supply yesterday, as the Government plans to sell $42.5 billion of debt securities next week.
"Since Treasury securities yield higher than Japanese Government securities, Japanese investors might be interested in the quarterly refunding next week," said Waldo T. Best, an economist at Barclays De Zoete Wedd Securities.
Treasury prices were also bolstered by a sharp rise in the dollar, which gained after Japan and the United States sold about $1 billion of Japanese yen on foreign exchange markets. A stronger dollar makes American assets like bonds more attractive to foreign investors.
James Hale, a fixed-income analyst in the San Francisco office of MMS International, a market research and analysis firm, noted that as foreign central banks buy dollars "they typically use those dollars to buy Treasury securities."
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond, which had gained more than a point during the session, was up 19/32 by late in the day, to 109 22/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.84 percent, from 6.90 percent on Tuesday.
Traders and analysts said the stronger dollar and the prospect of increased Japanese buying came at a good time as concerns had mounted over the market's ability to absorb a flood of new supply.
The Treasury announced the size of its quarterly auction yesterday, and it was bigger than expected -- or about $500 million more for each maturity. The Treasury said it was selling $42.5 billion of debt securities, including $18 billion of 3-year notes, $13 billion of 10-year notes and $11.5 billion of 30-year bonds. In when-issued trading late yesterday, the 3-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.99 percent. The 10-year note was being offered at 6.43 percent, and the 30-year bond at 6.81 percent.
Traders were encouraged that the market did not become overly concerned about a report that showed a brisk pace in June home sales.
The Commerce Department reported yesterday that sales of new single-family homes rose 6.1 percent in June, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 728,000 from the revised May pace of 686,000.
While the report pointed to an economy recovering at a pace that makes it unlikely the Federal Reserve will lower short-term interest rates anytime soon, the market has already priced in expectations that the Fed will not cut rates.
"There was knee-jerk selling but experienced traders are not selling much based on the homes sales," said Mr. Best of Barclays De Zoete Wedd Securities.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Pair of Aces Has Become A Hot Hand

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
IT is premature, and much too muggy, to call this the pennant race just yet. First things first. Jack McDowell and David Cone need to get on a roll, begin their own friendly run to October within the Yankees' starting rotation. Their arms race will determine how the Yankees do in the divisional race.
"From my Mets' days, we sort of thrived on what we did as a staff," Cone said. "In the short term, we can push each other. Good pitching is contagious." 
 McDowell pitched well enough yesterday into the eighth inning. Then Kevin Seitzer doubled leading off, Buck Showalter yanked him for the struggling Steve Howe and Howe promptly blew up a tied game the Yankees eventually lost, 5-2, to Bud Selig's discounted Milwaukee Brewers. Cone goes tonight, another chance to counter a McDowell defeat with a victory, as he did in Minneapolis Saturday night. He is the early leader in the Yankees' arms race.
These expensive and occasionally weird and wired right-handers -- one clean-cut and cagey, the other scruffy and somewhat shy -- are here to carry a staff that is otherwise too banged up or baby-faced. In other words, the usual, around Yankee Stadium. At least George Steinbrenner, whose last homegrown starter who amounted to much was Ron Guidry almost 20 years ago, has this time gone out and rented as his twin aces the Cy Young Award winners for 1993 (McDowell) and 1994 (Cone).
"An ace is what Tom Seaver was," argued Cone, the one-time aspiring sportswriter and erstwhile tabloid playoff columnist. "That's an ace, not a guy who comes in and does it for two months."
Now that Steinbrenner has apparently abandoned the veneer of being among the budget impaired, maybe this doesn't have to be a one-season stop for McDowell and another brief layover for Cone. If they can carry the Yankees into the playoffs and beyond, there may be more inflationary money for McDowell and Cone, who happen to be working with no more years on their contracts.
"It depends on the direction the team goes," said McDowell, 8-8, a long way from his Cy Young year of 22-10. He shrugged: "Let's wait and see what it looks like at the end."
The word on McDowell, especially after his middle finger snapped to attention as he left the mound two Stadium starts ago, was that he would be gone the minute his guaranteed $5.4 million was paid in full. Not necessarily the case, he claimed.
He may be a West Coast rock guitarist whose favorite tabloid is the Village Voice, but McDowell said he likes the Yankees and New York, too. To prove it, he and his wife rent on the upper West Side. One year, with an option.
Across town, back in the pad he's been renting in absentia since 1992, Cone has no particular inclination, or plan. He has already changed teams five times in a decade, the rate picking up speed as baseball plunges deeper into economic instability. Cone has become so accustomed to his peripatetic life that he's developed a sweet little rationalization speech.
He wanted to know who, exactly, in contemporary sports isn't a hired gun. "Somebody wants you in a pennant race," he said. "That makes you feel good."
If McDowell believes New York overreacted to him last month, Cone will tell him some stories as they lounge in the bullpen some lazy August night. By the time Cone was finishing with the Mets in 1992, he was a regular in the gossip columns, renowned for, among other things, alleged sexcapades. Cone made mistakes, felt the wrath of the city's news media machine. He still didn't want to leave, and would've returned in a matter of months.
That's when Ewing Kaufman, the late Kansas City Royals' owner, won him back to his native state and original team. "He was dying of cancer and he looked me in the eye and said he wanted to rectify the worst trade he'd ever made," said Cone. That dramatic appeal, supplemented by a $9 million signing bonus, whisked Cone from Steinbrenner's grasp.
Back in Steinbrenner's New York, Cone, a loyal union supporter of Donald Fehr, said there is nothing to fear but fear itself. "Win, lose or draw, I'm not going to hide in the trainer's room," he said.
Give this hired gun the ball every fifth day. McDowell, too, has shown the potential to weather this sultry city as the race heats up. The Stadium fans have apparently forgotten his fickle finger. They cheered him again yesterday as he left the mound. The Yankees haven't made the playoffs since 1981. Finally, they appear armed, and ready.

HEADLINE: Forecasting Gauge and House Sales Show Gains

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2

 BODY:
More evidence that the economy is perking up emerged today as the Government's main forecasting index posted its first gain of 1995 and sales of new houses were at the briskest pace since late 1993.
"The signs of rebound are there," said Darwin L. Beck, an economist at CS First Boston. "Lower interest rates help to sell houses," he added, and bode well for sales of cars and other big-ticket items in coming months. 
 Today's figures, analysts said, were the latest of several indicators suggesting that the economy's sharp deceleration during the first half of the year has stopped well shy of recession and that growth, though still restrained by a buildup in inventories, was reviving.
A third report today showed that by one measure the economy actually contracted during the April-June quarter, the first shrinkage since the end of the 1990-91 recession. When calculated according to the Commerce Department's chain-weight process, which considers how changes in prices affect what is produced, the decline was at a rate of two-tenths of 1 percent, following a 1.7 percent rate of expansion during the first three months of the year.
But it was the department's forward-looking index of leading indicators that captured much of the attention today, despite its undistinguished predictive record in recent years and the fact that most of its components have previously been published. The housing number took on less significance when what appeared at first glance to be a sharp jump in home sales in June turned out to mainly reflect a sharp downward revision for May.
The leading index edged up two-tenths of 1 percent in June, after four consecutive monthly declines. (January's reading was unchanged.)
Eight of the 11 components contributed to the increase, the largest being a jump in the M-2 money supply, which includes currency, checking accounts, some savings deposits and money market mutual funds.
The others, ranked by impact, were another surge in stock market prices, a rise in the University of Michigan's index of consumer expectations, lower first-time claims for unemployment insurance, an expansion of the factory workweek, increased issuance of building permits, higher contracts and orders for new plant and equipment, and more new orders to factories for consumer goods and materials.
The three negatives were a deceleration in prices for materials especially sensitive to the business cycle, a decline in backlogged orders for durable goods and a decrease in the proportion of companies reporting slower deliveries from suppliers.
June was the 10th consecutive month in which the prices component rose at a slower pace, according to Deutsche Morgan Grenfell/C. J. Lawrence.
Two companion indexes also gained. The index of coincident indicators, whose components tend to move at the same time as the economy at large, rose three-tenths of 1 percent, after the first back-to-back declines since early 1991.
The index of lagging indicators, which includes the bank prime rate and the inflation rate for services, climbed seven-tenths of 1 percent, the biggest rise since February.
The report on sales of new single-family houses, also from the Commerce Department, showed sales at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 728,000 in June, 6.1 percent above the revised May pace of 686,000. May sales had been initially estimated at a considerably higher 722,000.
The median sales price eased to $132,000 from $133,900, while the stockpile of unsold houses remained at 347,000, a 5.8-month supply at the current sales pace.
The chain-weight measures of gross domestic product, which the department began publishing as an alternative gauge in 1992, will replace fixed-weight data as the featured gauge at the end of this year, when a comprehensive revision of national income and product accounts is scheduled.
The main goal is to correct for what economists call substitution bias, the shifting of demand, and hence output, in response to changes in relative prices.
The bias associated with fixed-weight measures, which assume no response to changing prices, was once considered small enough to ignore, but in the 1980's prices and quantities of the energy and food components began to swing significantly and computer prices fell rapidly while output of them surged.
Illustrating the tendency for output measures using fixed-price weights to produce higher current growth than chain-weight measures, the department reported last week that G.D.P. rose at a pace of five-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter. This compared with the decline of two-tenths of 1 percent calculated under the chain-weight alternative published today.
