HEADLINE: AUTO RACING;
Driven Toward the Bright Lights

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SIANO 

 BODY:
Stock car racing, which is being acclaimed as the new growth sport of the 1990's, faces a problem similar to that of a backwoods guitar picker who suddenly gets discovered by Nashville: how to remain true to those who loved you in obscurity while cashing in on the big time.
Nascar's Winston Cup series, which was featured on the cover of two major national magazines last month, is enjoying record attendance and television ratings as it approaches its new showpiece event, the $4.5 million Brickyard 400 this Saturday in Indianapolis. 
 According to Goodyear, Winston Cup attendance went from 3,127,130 in 1989 to 4,896,000 last year, an almost 64 percent jump. ESPN says ratings for its race broadcasts so far this year are up 27 percent from 1994.
Even so, the Winston Cup series is as geographically imbalanced as a pro football league without a Los Angeles franchise. Ten of its 31 races are at five tracks in a 140-mile stretch from southern Virginia to South Carolina.
A solution that could take the sport to the next level of national popularity appears near. By early 1997, there could be tracks that will eventually have 100,000 seats or more in such sponsor-lucrative markets as Los Angeles, Dallas-Fort Worth, Las Vegas, Nev., and Miami. But to gain access to the bright lights, Nascar may have to pay less attention to the land that sustained it through hard times: the rural Southeast.
But the easiest way to solve the problem -- expanding the 31-event season -- would add too much pressure to the lives of mechanics and pit crews, everyone in the sport admits.
"It looks like we're maxed out on the number of race dates," said Bill France Jr., the president of Nascar.
At the moment, stock car racing's most important economic barometer -- the cost of running a team versus the amount sponsors will pay -- is in balance. But team owners say their expenses are rising, even as demands on sponsors cannot rise significantly.
"You've got places like North Wilkesboro, N.C., and Rockingham, N.C., that the sponsors couldn't care less if we raced there," said Felix Sabates, owner of Kyle Petty's car, which is sponsored by Coors beer. "Right now, I'd be afraid to go to Mr. Coors and say I need another $1 million next year. But I would not be afraid if we had some of these new markets."
Although Nascar tightly controls technology (Winston Cup cars still use carburetors), the creation of new teams has raised salaries for experienced personnel, and teams are free to use sophisticated equipment in private test sessions.
"Five years ago, there were teams operating with $2 million annual budgets," said Richard Childress, Dale Earnhardt's car owner. "Today, teams operate with $7 million to $8 million budgets."
The top 15 teams, Sabates said, get about $4.5 million to $6 million annually from sponsors. The rest must come from prize money, which owners split with drivers. The average Winston Cup race has a purse of between $900,000 and $1.4 million -- a range some car owners would like to see improved.
"I think at some point, you'll have to start setting a minimum purse of $1.5 million to $2 million a race," Childress said. "When they do that, and if some of these places can't bring in enough people to pay that much, then you'll have to start looking at some of these tracks like Texas and Las Vegas."
Most track owners are adding seats, to cash in on sellout crowds and also to meet Nascar's requests for fatter purses and better facilities. But as tracks expand, access roads and parking capacity are strained.
Larry Carrier, who built the half-mile oval in Bristol, Tenn., in 1961, then rescued it from bankruptcy after he had sold it to a new owner, has watched the track grow with the Winston Cup series until it has become a facility with about 75,000 seats today.
Carrier knows he must keep investing money in his track to justify Nascar's decision to give him two Winston Cup races annually.
"It's going to take two Winston Cup dates to survive," he said. "You can't do it with one to keep up with what Nascar wants."
But the way he sees it, Nascar owes him something, too. "It goes back to loyalty," Carrier said last week. "Nascar has always been loyal to us, and we've always done what Nascar wanted."
When the series struggled years ago, Carrier said, he helped buy cars for drivers so other races would have good starting fields. "We kept racing going when it wasn't anything," he said. "Those other people building tracks who want two races, that's their problem. They just got here too late."
O. Bruton Smith hopes he is not too late. Smith built Charlotte Motor Speedway -- with its six-figure trackside condominiums. Through his majority interest in Speedway Motorsports Inc., a publicly held company, he owns Charlotte and Atlanta Motor Speedways and began clearing ground last week for a $100 million speedway northwest of Fort Worth.
"We feel 100 percent confident that when we complete a 150,000-seat, one-and-a-half-mile speedway in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, Nascar won't have any choice but to come running there," said Eddie Gossage, who will run Smith's new Texas speedway. It is scheduled to be completed next July.
But will Nascar grant the two Winston Cup races each year that Smith says he needs to make the track viable?
"We feel we'll be able to get them," Gossage said.
To understand the depth of Gossage's confidence, consider the following:
*Nascar has already promised a 32d race in 1997 to Roger Penske's planned speedway in Fontana, Calif., about 45 miles east of Los Angeles.
*Homestead Motorsports Park, a 1.5-mile speedway about a half an hour south of Miami, opens this November.
*Work is under way at a 107,000-seat oval north of Las Vegas, with completion planned in May.
"I'm sure the traditionalists won't like it," Gossage said, referring to the possibility that some of the smaller tracks will lose one of their two Winston Cup dates to the Texas track. "But the N.F.L. doesn't have the Canton Bulldogs any longer."
An interesting analogy, considering that Gossage's boss, Smith, is half-owner of the Winston Cup version of Lambeau Field. In June, Smith, through Speedway Motorsports, bought 50 percent of the North Wilkesboro track. North Wilkesboro, which opened in 1947 and is the oldest track on the circuit, is also its biggest target for jokes.
As soon as Smith bought into the track, speculation started that he would ask France to transfer race dates to the Texas track. But Smith denied that he would seek a date shift, saying that he would improve North Wilkesboro and keep the two Winston Cup races there.
France, when asked last week whether he would allow a track owner to move Winston Cup dates between tracks, replied: "The dates aren't for sale, per se. But on the other hand, if an owner wants to shut one down and move it elsewhere, we'd be willing to look at something."
When the subject of shifting Winston Cup dates from an old track to a newer, better-located one comes up, the talk must include Bill France. But that's not just because France's father, William (Big Bill) France Sr., founded Nascar, the sanctioning body that the family still owns.
The family also owns 61 percent of the shares -- about a $265 million stake -- of International Speedway Corporation, which controls Daytona International Speedway, Talladega (Ala.) Superspeedway and Darlington (S.C.) Raceway.
The company also has a half-interest in Watkins Glen (N.Y.) International race course, and Bill France Jr. owns a share of Martinsville (Va.) Speedway. Together, these tracks hold nine Winston Cup races a year. And since Smith's Speedway Motorsports Inc. stock came on the market on Feb. 24, France's I.S.C. stock has jumped about 45 percent, from $130 to $190 a share.
France is generally considered a wise and benevolent dictator, with the Winston Cup seen as the best-run, most competitive auto racing series in the world. "Anything we've asked the other tracks to do, such as repaving, or adding more prize money, our tracks have been as much a leader in this as anything," France said.
But none of this stopped Kyle Petty from suggesting, after the most recent event at Darlington, that its infield should be flooded and the track turned into a fish pond. No owners or drivers shouted him down.
There may be another way out for France and Nascar, a solution used by traditional pro leagues: expansion. "We may find one day in the near future we may have an Eastern Division and a Western Division," Smith said. That is, split the Winston Cup series into two divisions, each with 25 to 30 races.
Nascar is considering it, France said. Such a split, if it occurs, is several years away, he said. But it may be the least bloody way to keep the tracks that helped Nascar grow while adding the ones that will help it prosper.

HEADLINE: Gloria Chadwick, 63, Official In U.S. and International Skiing

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD 

 BODY:
Gloria Chadwick, an international ski racing administrator who was especially dedicated to furthering women's cross-country competition, died on Sunday at her home in Lake Placid, N.Y. She was 63.
Her brother, Norman Chadwick of Mount Vernon, Wash., said she died of cancer. 
 In her youth, Miss Chadwick was a downhill ski racer on the United States A team. She had wanted to compete at the Olympic level, but a skiing accident in which she broke her leg sidelined that ambition.
Undaunted, she went on to make her mark in the sport through administrative undertakings, and in 1986, was inducted into the United States National Ski Hall of Fame in Ishpeming, Mich.
She had been director of the United States Olympic Training Center in Lake Placid since 1985, and was executive director of the United States Ski Association from 1961-68. She was also the first national coordinator for Nastar, a racing program for recreational skiers.
For the last decade, she focused her efforts on behalf of women in skiing as chairman of the International Ski Federation Subcommittee on Women's Cross-Country.
Miss Chadwick was born in Philadelphia, but her family moved to Lowell, Mass., when she was a toddler. As a teen-ager from a modest home, Miss Chadwick honed her Alpine skills by skiing regularly at nearby Cannon Mountain, N.H.
She received a bachelor's and master's degree in business from the now-defunct Staley College in Brookline, Mass., and later studied management at Santa Clara University in Santa Clara, Calif.
In a breakthrough for women in the ski industry, she was hired in 1971 by the Big Sky Resort near Bozeman, Mont., to be director of marketing, and later, a vice president.
From 1975 to 1983, she was president and general manager of Burke Mountain, Vt. In 1983, she became commissioner of economic development for the state of Vermont.
In 1985, Miss Chadwick opened the United States Olympic Education Center at Northern Michigan University in Marquette, Mich. Later that year, she also began supervising the $12 million modernization of the Lake Placid training center.
During the last two years, she was in charge of developing the ARCO United States Olympic Training Center in Chula Vista, Calif.
Miss Chadwick is survived by her brother.

HEADLINE: Pathmark: The Right Move

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has now approved the construction of a Pathmark supermarket on a desolate city-owned lot in East Harlem. His decision removes the last obstacle to a store the neighborhood needs. It also means that Mr. Giuliani has chosen to set aside narrow political considerations that might have killed the project. It was the right choice, not least because it sends a reassuring message to other corporations that might want to do business in New York City.
The process has not been easy. Surveys suggest that a majority of the area's residents, both black and Hispanic, want the 53,000-square-foot supermarket and the 200 jobs it is expected to generate. But for months the project has been caught up in an emotional and sometimes nasty turf war that pitted East Harlem's small-market owners, most of them Hispanic, against the black-dominated nonprofit development consortium behind the deal. 
 The project raised delicate political problems for the Mayor. Even after it received the other necessary government approvals, Mr. Giuliani, a man known for strong opinions, delayed weeks in making known his position because he was clearly anxious not to offend Hispanic small-business owners who have been an important element of his political support.
He therefore devised a compromise that saves both the supermarket and, perhaps, his political base. As recast by the Mayor, the deal allows the city to keep a 49 percent stake in the enterprise (a group that includes the nonprofit development arm of Harlem's Abyssinian Baptist Church will own the rest) until a suitable local group from largely Hispanic East Harlem can be found to take it over.
There is some irony in this compromise given the Mayor's disdain for basing any municipal decisions on race and ethnicity. Nevertheless, the city stands to benefit, especially if it helps encourage other development projects in East Harlem.
To his credit, Mr. Giuliani pointedly rejected Pathmark's attempt to defuse local opposition by pledging to contribute $25,000 a year, for a minimum of five years, to create an economic development fund for East Harlem, presumably to assist Hispanic-owned businesses. "There's no reason to exact additional taxes from businesses that want to do business in this city," he said. "That's a way to discourage business."
That is a sound principle on which the Mayor should now educate the City Council. A Council committee recently approved another Pathmark store, for the Springfield Gardens section of Queens, after the company agreed to donate more than $400,000 over 20 years to a slush fund controlled by the local Councilwoman, Juanita Watkins.
New Yorkers, especially poor New Yorkers, need more supermarkets, not more selfish politics as usual.

HEADLINE: Big Deals, With Journalism Thrown In

BYLINE: By Bill Kovach; Bill Kovach is curator of the Nieman Foundation for Journalism at Harvard.

DATELINE: NANTUCKET, Mass.

 BODY:
As the news about the mergers that are reshaping the television news industry continues to tumble out, public affairs journalism seems to have been swept away by America's new mania for corporate bigness.
Few of the early accounts of Disney's deal with Capital Cities/ABC and the sale of CBS to Westinghouse Electric have made more than passing references to the implications for the future of independent news gathering. 
 But there are dangers. Among them is the degree to which the emerging corporate structures will smother what remains of a passion for public affairs coverage in the corporate news divisions.
 There was a breathtaking glimpse of the future on Monday when Charles Gibson, co-host of ABC-TV's "Good Morning America," interviewed Thomas S. Murphy, the chairman of Capital Cities/ABC, and Michael D. Eisner, the Walt Disney chairman -- his present and future bosses. Mr. Gibson tried to raise the question of the impact of the merger with the entertainment giant on the high-quality journalism at ABC-TV.
Mr. Murphy, without missing a beat, asked Mr. Gibson if he wasn't proud to be a member of the Disney family. Mr. Gibson struggled to keep the conversation on an objective level that might be of some real value to the viewers. Mr. Murphy noticed his discomfort with the question and joked about it with Mr. Eisner. Mr. Gibson may have thought his role was that of an objective journalist. His bosses made it clear that their interest tended more toward entertainment than information.
The trend is not new. For the past decade and a half, journalism has been slowly squeezed into a smaller and smaller corner of the expanding corporations that make up the communications industry. The values and norms of journalism have been steadily eroded as corporate managers order news divisions to produce more "infotainment" programs.
This leads to programs like the recent Diane Sawyer interview on ABC's "PrimeTime Live" with Michael Jackson that was tied to the release of a new video with which the network hoped to be associated in the minds of the elusive youth market. Such programming increasingly draws resources away from the discovery and pursuit of important material for the evening news broadcast.
Though the trend is not new, with the Disney-ABC merger the threat to a form of journalism that serves the interests of a self-governing people crosses a new threshold.
Even with the best of intentions, owners and managers are influenced by the fact that they now preside over a corporation that, by the simple act of merger, has drastically reduced the proportionate importance of the news department. An already diluted pool from which the values of journalism will be drawn has been reduced to peripheral importance in corporate decisions. ABC's news division will now have to compete with the enormous energy of Disney's entertainment productions in a company in which ABC's value as an outlet for entertainment is paramount.
One important advantage that television news departments have had is the relatively low cost of production of news compared with entertainment shows. But the marriage of Disney's entertainment production company with ABC's worldwide transmission system changes that relative position.
Because of the opportunity to cycle and recycle Disney's cartoons and movies worldwide, the per unit production costs of these entertainment packages will be substantially lowered. More important, news neither keeps nor travels particularly well, but Mickey Mouse goes on forever and is welcome everywhere.
And there is another force at work, best represented by the proposed merger of CBS and Westinghouse, that should cause worry. This rush to merge mainly entertainment organizations that have news operations with companies deeply involved in doing business with the Government raises ominous questions about the future of watchdog journalism.
Communications companies make up the fastest growing industry in the United States. They have now almost completely ingested the country's news organizations. Because these new communications corporations are so dependent on Government decisions, they are actively involved in lobbying for and buying Government favors.
According to the Center for Responsive Government, the communications industry was the sixth largest contributor to the candidates in the 1994 elections. The industry contributed nearly $10 million directly to political-action committees.
As they seek to buy favorable treatment in law, rules and regulations and to win Government contracts for their manufacturing divisions, these corporations have become supplicants of the very institutions whose behavior they must objectively monitor if their work is to be of any value to the public.
There is a basic fact about the free-market system. The market is governed by the logic of economic self-interest. Public affairs journalism is by definition concerned with the broader interests of a civic society. These latest mergers will drive two more press organizations deeper into a world dependent for its well-being upon the decisions of governments here and abroad. A passion for good old-fashioned journalism could hardly find a more discouraging atmosphere within which to try to survive.
 But in the end, the most important factor that can warm the passion for journalism is the commitment from the top of the news media corporations. The owners of The New York Times, Washington Post and Boston Globe risked Federal prosecution to provide readers with the analysis of the Vietnam War contained in the Pentagon Papers. And there is the example of a few Southern newspaper owners who, at great economic cost, encouraged full and objective coverage of the civil rights movement.
 That is certainly not the sort of message Charles Gibson got when he tried to interview the men at the top of America's biggest new media conglomerate.

HEADLINE: Californians Can Put Civil Rights Back on Track;
To Open Doors

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Glenn C. Loury (Op-Ed, July 26), who claims that the moral high ground on affirmative action is to ignore race and gender in recruiting job candidates and government contractors, suffers from an ivory tower understanding of the real world. 
 The programs subsidized by taxpayers to provide higher education, health care and new roads are dominated by an establishment controlled by white males. In this era of shrinking resources, the old-boy companies that have built costly staffs and facilities are under pressure to maximize every opportunity to maintain them. The single wedge that keeps the door open to those outside the network is affirmative action.
For prime contractors, who now have to share some publicly funded work with minority and women subcontractors, it would be more profitable to perform all the work in-house. But different faces often bring fresh ideas, highly motivated people and lower overhead rates.
Women-owned companies are hiring people of all types at twice the rate of white, male-owned companies. And when times get tough, owners who remain close to their origins are more likely than bottom-line managers to forgo their own benefits to keep staffs off unemployment.
President Clinton has it right when he says: "Affirmative action is good for America . . . Mend it, don't end it."
 
CAROLYN S. KONHEIM
Brooklyn, July 26, 1995
The writer is president of Konheim & Ketcham, environmental consultants.

HEADLINE: Ailing Fishing Industry to Get $53 Million in Aid

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
President Clinton announced a $53 million disaster relief package today to combat emergency fishing problems and put unemployed fishermen to work in New England, the Northwest and Gulf of Mexico.
The biggest share of the money, about $25 million, will go to Northeastern states hit hard by declines in groundfish stocks. About $15 million will go to states along the Gulf of Mexico to assist the industry with uncharted seabed obstructions caused primarily by flooding. 
 About $12 million will go to the Pacific Northwest, extending programs started last year to buy back fishing permits as well as put fishermen to work restoring fisheries and counting fish for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
"I am taking this action today," Mr. Clinton said in a statement, "because fishermen in the Northeast, Northwest and Gulf of Mexico have suffered millions of dollars of losses because the source of their livelihood -- fisheries resources -- has been disappearing."
Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, speaking at a Capitol news conference, said of efforts to buy back fishing permits, "One of the problems is there are too few fish and too many boats being used to catch them."
The money will come from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, which is part of the Commerce Department.

HEADLINE: U.S. Says Iraq Still Violates U.N. Terms for Lifting Sanctions

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration disclosed new intelligence information today in an effort to persuade its allies not to lift economic sanctions against Iraq, asserting that Baghdad still uses terrorism to kill opponents abroad and had developed vast stocks of germ warfare agents.
In a hearing before a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee, Madeleine K. Albright, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, took an unyielding attitude toward easing the sanctions, a move that France and Russia hope the Security Council will approve next month. 
 Sounding like a prosecutor, Ms. Albright ticked off point by point how Iraq continues to flout United Nations resolutions with which it is supposed to comply in order for sanctions to be lifted.
Iraq, she said, has failed to dismantle its weapons of mass destruction, failed to return property stolen from Kuwait, failed to stop supporting terrorism and failed to stop repressing the Kurds and minority groups.
To build her case against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, she showed aerial photographs of Kuwaiti military equipment that Iraq stole after invading Kuwait in 1990, but has not returned, as required by Security Council resolutions.
She also displayed photographs showing that Iraq has expanded a missile research and development installation and built a chlorine plant that she said could quickly be transformed to build chemical weapons.
Ms. Albright condemned Mr. Hussein's recent threats to unnerve the world and stop dismantling Iraq's weapons of mass destruction if the United Nations Security Council does not ease the sanctions in September.
"Baghdad must understand that it is not involved in a negotiation," she said. "It is under an obligation brought on by its own transgressions."
She disclosed that the Administration had concluded that Iraqi security services were behind an automobile crash last summer that killed the son of the late spiritual leader of Iraq's Shiite minority group. She also said that last year, Iraqi intelligence officers killed Talib al-Suhayi, an Iraqi opposition leader in Beirut.
To show that Mr. Hussein and his closest supporters are living in luxury while the Iraqi masses are mired in poverty, she showed the Senators satellite photographs of some of the 50 palaces and luxury residences that she said the Iraqi Government is building at a cost of $1.5 billion.
In her testimony, she asserted that members of Mr. Hussein's family, especially his son Uday, were enriching themselves by importing goods, despite the embargo, and reselling those goods at exorbitant prices. She also said they were involved in exporting oil and using "the proceeds, in part, to line their pockets."
She said Mr. Hussein was so worried about a possible coup by Iraq's military and Republican Guard that he has established a new elite paramilitary group and has given more security responsibilities to Uday Hussein.
Eager to resume commerce with Iraq, both France and Russia have proposed removing the embargo on Iraqi oil once Baghdad provides full cooperation in dismantling and providing information on its weapons of mass destruction.
Ms. Albright said no sanctions should be eased until Iraq comes into full compliance. "Iraq will respond constructively only to a policy of firmness," she said, adding that its compliance "has been grudging, slow, sporadic and insufficient."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Time Warner Agrees To Cable Rate Plan

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Time Warner Cable said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Federal Communications Commission to lower basic cable rates, with offsetting increases in another tier of cable service, and to provide more than $5 million in refunds to customers.
Under the accord, the company will also upgrade its systems and offer free service to public schools. 
 Time Warner Cable will reduce the price of basic cable service by 10 percent. It said the cut would apply to all of its systems, which have a total of 9.7 million subscribers.
The price of this service will be capped, with adjustments permitted once a year for changes in external costs and inflation.
The company, based in Stamford, Conn., will offset the move on basic rates by raising the monthly charge on another tier of service by up to $1 each year. This tier includes some broadcast stations and channels like CNN, CNBC and ESPN.
Time Warner Cable said it would make refunds in the form of bill credits to customers in systems where its rates were subject to refund liability because of rate complaints that followed the re-regulation of the cable industry in 1993.
Refunds will be made in parts of New York City; Syracuse; St. Petersburg, Fla., and other cities.
A spokesman said the refunds would vary greatly, and declined to estimate how many subscribers would be affected by the rate moves.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
India State Government Scraps $3 Billion Enron Project

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

 BODY:
A regional government in India has decided to scrap a $3 billion power plant being built by the Enron Corporation, in a move that threatens to derail the growth of foreign investment in that country.
The cancellation of the power contract was announced yesterday by the nationalist Hindu leaders of the state government of Maharashtra. They are opposed to the policies of the national Government, whose four-year-old commitment to economic change and a more open environment to foreign investors is being tested by the attack on the power project. 
 India is an important emerging market for American companies, one of the few in Asia where they have been able to steal a march on Japan. Clinton Administration officials have brought groups of executives there, and the Energy Secretary, Hazel R. O'Leary, won guarantees last year from Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao for the Enron project and several others.
In New Delhi, a spokesman at the United States Embassy said that diplomats would consult with the Indian Government. "We are deeply concerned," he said.
Enron, in a cautious statement from its Houston headquarters, invited further discussions but threatened to seek the legal enforcement of its contracts. The company has already spent more than $100 million on the project.
But an Enron executive in India, who asked not to be named, called the cancellation "a blow to the country."
After the regional government first proposed scrapping the project in the spring, Enron executives and American diplomats met with officials of the national Government, hoping that the Prime Minister would step in to rescue the project.
The electric power plant was to be India's largest single foreign investment. The project, on the rocky coast of the Arabian Sea 100 miles south of Bombay, was meant to supply more than 2,000 megawatts of power, a huge amount by any nation's standards. The first phase, to be completed in 1997 at a cost of $990 million, would be diesel-fueled. The next phase, costing $2 billion, would be fueled by natural gas.
Enron, the largest natural gas company in the United States, owns 80 percent of the project, with Bechtel Enterprises and GE Capital, the General Electric Company's finance arm, splitting the rest.
The recently elected leaders of Maharashtra have attacked the project, accusing the company of receiving favorable terms from Mr. Rao's Government.
"The project is against the interests of Maharashtra and its people," Manohar Joshi, chief minister of the Maharashtra state assembly in Bombay, told the legislature. "Whatever Enron asked for was granted." He has accused Enron of corrupting politicians to win favorable terms, including high electricity rates, without competitive bidding, an accusation that the company and Mr. Rao's Government deny.
Mr. Joshi and other Hindu nationalists have turned the Enron deal into a noisy national debate, appealing to fears of foreign exploitation that date to India's colonial past. His coalition won state elections in March, and his party is preparing to sound the same themes in a national election that Mr. Rao must call by next spring. Companies like Coca-Cola and I.B.M. were kicked out of India in the 1970's, but Mr. Rao has welcomed foreign investors back.
It remains unclear whether there is any room left for negotiations with Maharashtra's leaders. Having seized the political advantage, the Maharashtra government might still choose to renegotiate Enron's terms, said Marshall M. Bouton, executive vice president of the Asia Society in New York and a former United States diplomat in India.
And electric power is sorely needed in India. Chronic power shortages regularly paralyze factories, offices, hospitals and trains. The Enron plant was to be the centerpiece of India's plan to raise power output by a half by 2000, with 60 percent of the increase to come from foreign projects.
The attack on Enron is bound to frighten other companies, Mr. Bouton of the Asia Society said. "In the foreign investment community, this raises questions of whether deals once done in India will be carried through, and in general whether the forces of economic nationalism are counterattacking after four years of reform," he said.
The CMS Energy Corporation, the parent company of one of Michigan's largest utilities, has already threatened to pull out of two power projects, worth a total of $800 million, if politics kills the Enron plan. Last week, the company president, Victor J. Fryling, spent five days meeting Indian national and state officials to speed the necessary approvals and guarantees.
Although progress has been slow, Kelly M. Farr, a company spokesman, said yesterday, "We're optimistic that we have support from the state and central governments." CMS awaits the central Government's response to Enron, he said, noting that the CMS plants would be in different Indian states.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The nationalist Hindu government of the Maharashtra state in India has canceled the Enron Corporation's electric power plant project. Women from villages near the plant demonstrated against the project on July 17. (Reuters) (pg. D2)

HEADLINE: Judges Use a New Weapon Against Driving Drunk

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
Some drunken drivers are facing a new obstacle: a dashboard computer that detects alcohol on the breath and prevents the car from starting when the driver's alcohol level is too high. As more judges order the devices installed, and the devices become more sophisticated, some traditional law-enforcement functions are being turned over to private contractors and even microchips.
"It's a Big Brother type of thing," said Michael L. Walton, the Court Administrator in Hamilton County, Ohio, where judges have flexibility in ordering the devices use. 
 But Mr. Walton and others say that without the devices, those convicted of drunken driving and put on probation might otherwise lose their licenses, which can be tantamount to a sentence of unemployment. Or they may drive without a license, and still drink, threatening others. Thus, some libertarians say they are not bothered by the basic idea.
"At some point, potential victims have a right to step in and say, 'I simply will not be exposed to this much risk,' " said Roger Pilon, director of the Center for Constitutional Studies at the Cato Institute, a libertarian group in Washington.
One alcohol-detection device, the Sens-O-Lock, has a synthetic voice that demands a breath sample when the driver puts the key in the ignition. The computer then determines if the person is sober; if he or she determined not to be, a microchip wired to the car's electrical system keeps the car from starting. The computer will also note the failed test, and that information may be passed along to the authorities by a technician who periodically downloads the computer's memory.
Although the computers have been around for a decade, they have become more sophisticated: they now can tell whether a child or a balloon, hair dryer or other substitute is being used to give the breath sample in place of an adult, though they cannot tell the identity of the adult. With this new feature, cases like Gregory Cook's can be avoided.
Last September in San Marcos, Tex., Mr. Cook took his 8- and 10-year-old daughters to breakfast and drove drunk into a waste pond at a water-treatment plant. All three were killed. The car had an older alcohol-detection computer, and Mr. Cook regularly had one of his daughters blow into it.
The new computers also ask for a retest at odd intervals while the car is moving, to prevent a drinker from driving sober to a bar, leaving the engine running and going in to drink. If it does not get a retest, an alarm system will go off, usually flashing lights and beeping of the horn.
As computer prices have declined, so has the cost of alcohol detectors. The manufacturer of the Sens-O-Lock, Alcohol Sensors International, foresees a voluntary market for people who know they have an alcohol problem. The company, in Ronkonkoma, L.I., is planning to sell a campus model to nervous parents, for $400 to $425.
But most models now in use were ordered by a judge and lease for $60 or $70 a month, paid by the driver. There are 15,000 to 20,000 of the devices in court-ordered use in about 35 states, with at least seven New York counties using them. Gov. George E. Pataki is expected to sign legislation soon that would permit their use statewide. New Jersey and Connecticut do not have probation for drunken drivers and thus do not use the devices.
Texas, where judges have ordered many motorists to install alcohol-detection devices as a condition of probation for drunken driving, will bring them into a new era on Sept. 1. A law taking effect then will require the computers as a condition of bond for a driver arrested on a charge of drunken driving if he or she had a previous drunken-driving conviction.
Experts say Texas will become the first state to require them as a condition of bond as opposed to probation.
Jay Jacobson, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union of Texas, said that one open question was whether a recorded test failure was the breath of the probationer or someone else who had access to the car keys. Nonetheless, Mr. Jacobson said he did not object to the devices because "my knee-jerk predilection is to be very harsh" on drunken driving.
He said that Federal regulations "require employers to put in all sorts of safety devices." If a person has been known to drive drunk, he said, this device seems reasonable.
Experts say the availability of the computers makes some kind of punishment more likely because judges are often reluctant to suspend a driver's license, considering that sanction equivalent to a sentence of unemployment.
"This technology is an important development, because we lack options, otherwise, for dealing with this," said Dr. Jay Winsten, an associate dean of the Harvard School of Public Health and director of the Harvard University Alcohol Project. "This makes it easier for judges and juries to bring a guilty verdict."
It also prevents a person from driving drunk. As New York and other jurisdictions have discovered, lifting a license does not remove the physical ability to drive.
"Compared to license suspension, this probably reduces the recidivism rate by 90 percent," said Donald W. Collier, a chemist who developed the idea for the computer in 1970 while working for the Borg Warner Corporation.
"You're taking away his car if he's got alcohol in his system," said Dr. Collier, who is a trustee of the National Commission Against Drunk Driving in Washington.
But the technology can, in some cases, put extraordinary power in the hands of technicians. When a judge orders a probationer to get an alcohol detector, the installation is done by a private company; in Delaware, Virginia and West Virginia, for example, the company is a monopoly chosen by the state, while in California, most probationers have a choice of four or five companies.
The driver must return to the vendor at specified intervals, usually 30 to 60 days, so that a technician can plug a computer cable into the device to retrieve the record of the tests. In some states the data are transmitted to the authorities by computer modem, without the technician even knowing what they say. In others, the technician may evaluate the data and decide whether to send them on to the probation department.
For example, at Life Safer Interlock, an alcohol-detection leasing company in Cincinnati, Richard C. Freund, the marketing manager, considers his technicians "case managers." He cited a case in Columbus, Ohio, in which a man had one of the older computers. A girl who came in with her father on a regular trip to have the device calibrated and read, he said, "was remarking to provider about how neat a machine Daddy had, how she had to blow into it to open up his sun roof."
"We reported that to the probation department," Mr. Freund said.

Martello, chief operating officer of its maker, Alcohol Sensors International of Ronkonkoma, L.I. (Thomas Dallal for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Moscow Again, Clubs Cater to 'Members Only'

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Members of Grand Dynamo, a fancy private club in Moscow, have their own way of escaping the daily rat race. At night gamblers, with tumblers of Scotch and score cards in hand, place their bets ($10 minimum) on large trained rats that scurry through a neon-lit, glass-encased race course, prompted by a hand bell rung by a dwarf dressed as an 18th-century page.
"We've always had a lot of rats in Russia," Maksim Malkov, the manager, said with a smirk. "But this is the first time they've been organized." 
 Russia is once again becoming a members-only society. Cash, not Communism, is the criterion for admittance, and as the rich get richer, their tastes are growing less democratic and more decadent.
In a way, the private club scene is a bizarre, through-the-looking-glass reflection of how Soviet society was run in the days when local party bosses created their own lavish preserves, hidden behind iron walls. Only these days, bankers and mobsters pick up the tab for high-level Government officials to hobnob privately in sybaritic style.
"I think we can describe today's Russia as socialism for the elite and capitalism for the people," said Olga Kryshtanovskaya, director of the department of elite studies at the Moscow Institute of Sociology. She has just completed a confidential report on Russian elites in the provinces, ordered by President Boris N. Yeltsin's office. "The political elite gets economic privileges, and ordinary people are free to sell goods in kiosks," she said.
The wild, open-access night clubs and discotheques that mushroomed all across Moscow in the dawning days of capitalism are being replaced by members-only clubs. Mobsters, show business stars, politicians and businessmen all have their own places, though there is considerable crossover among the membership. Snobbery and networking play a role.
Safety is a constant preoccupation. At Grand Dynamo, an African security guard dressed to look like an American marine in helmet, fatigues and an M.P. armband, stiffly salutes arriving Mercedes-Benz and Volvo sedans.
Private clubs from Moscow to Yekaterinburg, Murmansk and Vladivostok offer the rich -- or politically powerful -- casino gambling, gourmet dining, cabaret shows, strippers and a cozy sense of exclusivity.
There are also more sedate establishments, with reading nooks and conference rooms, but even they are more Copacabana than Century Club. The stuffy, plutocratic Moscow Commercial Club, modeled on London's gentlemen's clubs along Pall Mall, also boasts its own casino.
Behind oak doors, there is a 1980's feel to Russia in the 1990's -- the ostentation and inflated egos of bankers and businessmen, the plunder of state industries, and glittery galas and fashion shows.
"Russia is the only place where even middle-aged mobsters take Ecstasy and dance to technopop," said Maximillian Friedman, a 20-year-old American nightclub consultant.
Major banks and former state-owned companies also have their own clubs. Logovaz, the country's largest car dealership and one of the most politically influential companies, spent $2 million to restore a turn-of-the-century merchant's mansion to entertain its top executives and guests.
Friends of the powerful Mayor of Moscow, Yuri M. Luzhkov, belong to Magisterium, a club that was hurriedly created for Mr. Luzhkov after he complained that he had no place to hang out after-hours.
Membership in Grand Dynamo, as in so many of the new, exclusive social clubs of Moscow, costs $3,000 a year. For that, its chosen mill around indigo-lit bars and pool tables, talk business in a foaming Jacuzzi or bet on rodents. All the waiters and waitresses are black, African graduate students from Patrice Lumumba University here.
"They steal less than our people, and they can say 'yes sir' with a respectful tone in their voices," said Boris Y. Mlinov, vice president of the club. "It gives the club some style."
Situated in a secluded corner of the Dynamo soccer stadium, the club has a plush if slightly raffish ambiance. Sixty-two of its 300 members are high-level Government officials, who as honorary members enjoy club privileges without paying the annual dues.
Other businessmen and politicians flock to an oak-paneled social club called the Center for the Liberal Movement, founded by Yegor T. Gaidar, leader of the democratic party Russia's Choice, and Oleg Boiko, a business tycoon. Mr. Boiko left Russia's Choice after Mr. Gaidar attacked the Government's handling of the Chechen war, but both remain members of the club.
The Moscow Commercial Club was the first private club of the Soviet Union, founded in 1989 to serve the country's new millionaires by Vladimir V. Semago, a Soviet functionary who used state money to restore its pre-revolutionary grandeur.
By day, Mr. Semago is a leading member of the Communist faction in Parliament, railing against social injustice. By night, he presides over the club's paneled dining rooms and conference rooms, the portrait of a genial plutocrat in scarlet blazers and a Ronald Coleman mustache.
Moscow boasts a members-only country club and golf course, as well as a private yacht club on the Moscow River. The nightclub Lis's, which opened in the 1989 as the first, cavernous Western-style discotheque of the perestroika era, closed down not long after a suspected organized-crime figure, Valery Dlukach and his bodyguard were shot and killed leaving the disco in 1993.
A little like Los Angeles in the 1920's and 30's, Moscow is a city preoccupied with reinventing itself. Styles and tastes vary, but there is a make-believe, theme-park quality to most of these places, from Logovaz Club, so exquisitely Empire in its furnishings, to Arlekino, a nightclub for children that owes more to Studio 54 than Romper Room.
Opened last May by the owners of a well-known adult nightclub, Arlekino, the kiddie version, features nannies and armed security guards who keep watch as children dance and rough-house in a Day-Glo disco, complete with tiny bar and bar stools, under psychedelic strobe lights and blaring pop music.
In a restroom wallpapered in Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck hangs a gaily painted sign, "No Smoking." The club is open for now to those parents who can afford the $10 cover charge, but the managers are considering making it members-only this fall.
Russia today is awash in strange reversals of fortune, and if the winners can be found toasting one another over Courvoisier cognac in armchairs, many of the losers are sulking in the club's backstairs.
Yuri S. Ananyev, a well-known animal trainer, worked for 30 years at the prestigious, but now impoverished, Durov Animal Circus. These days, Mr. Ananyev trains laboratory rats to race for Grand Dynamo, which pays him $400 a month -- four times what he made at the circus.
Preparing for another rat race, his champions squeaking hungrily in a box at his side, he grudgingly pulled on his tuxedo jacket. "Unfortunately, the only work these days is here," he said, glancing at the velour armchairs and amber-lit bar area with distaste. "It is the problem of our lives. Instead of making art, we have to get involved in gambling."

A1); Peter Litvinenko, dressed in an 18th-century page's uniform, opening glass starting gates and ringing his hand bell to release prize rats into racing tubes for the wagering audience at the Grand Dynamo club in Moscow. Private clubs, like much of Russia, are moving toward becoming a "members only" society. (Heidi Bradner for The New York Times) (pg. A2)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
BILL TO DECONTROL PHONES AND CABLE TIES UP THE HOUSE

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Friday, Aug. 4

 BODY:
House Republican leaders delayed final action early this morning on legislation that would open the nation's telephone and cable companies to freewheeling competition.
The bill is still expected to pass the House of Representatives by a comfortable margin -- though it faces a threatened Presidential veto. But a protracted debate and action on an unrelated appropriations bill ran past midnight, well beyond the time the House was scheduled to take up the telecommunications bill. 
 At 1:15 A.M., the House Majority Leader, Dick Armey, asked that the House adjourn until 8 A.M. today, when it would take up the telecommunications bill. The motion was approved unanimously.
The House's decision to take up the bill during the day comes after several Democrats criticized Republicans for conducting debate on it under the cover of darkness. The legislation amounts to the most radical deregulation of the nation's communications laws in more than six decades, and the first night of debate began Wednesday and stretched past 2 A.M. Thursday.
At that time, opponents of the bill accused its Republican backers of staging a nocturnal assault on consumers.
"After midnight, vampire-like, the communications bill rises each evening to be debated until dawn, when again we return to the regular order on the floor," said Representative John Bryant, Democrat of Texas. "These issues are too important to be debated when America is sound asleep."
Thursday afternoon, Vice President Al Gore reiterated President Clinton's threat to veto the bill, calling it "abhorrent to the public interest and our national economic well-being."
But the bill's backers hailed its changes, saying it would increase investment, create thousands of jobs and, contrary to the opponents' contention, eventually lower telephone and cable rates.
"This legislation is balanced, sweeping and momentous," said its chief architect, Jack Fields, a Texas Republican.
Representative John Linder, the Georgia Republican who was managing the bill on the floor, said, "The American people will be amazed by the wide array of technological changes that will soon be available in their homes."
Mr. Linder also captured the philosophy of the new Republican majority behind the bill. "The most extraordinary development has come in those nations that have put their trust in the power and potential of the marketplace," he said on the floor early Thursday morning. "This bill states that Government authority and mandates are not beneficial to economic development."
It was evident in the visitors' gallery during the evening that the telecommunications measure was no ordinary bill. Visitors there are usually diffident tourists clad in T-shirts and Bermuda shorts. But at 2 A.M. Thursday, a different breed was keeping an eye on the chamber. Dressed in white business shirts and ties, they were riveted to the floor action. This crowd was pleased when, at 12:14 A.M., the House rejected a motion to adjourn, and members rolled up their sleeves for a night of battle.
Democrats suggested that the bill was being rammed through in the middle of the night to keep its contents hidden not only from the public but also from House members, who have just slogged through one of their busiest sessions and have not had time to focus on the details of the complex package.
The House bill, which is similar to one passed by the Senate in June, would make these changes in communications laws:
*Remove regulation of cable rates within six months, except for basic services.
*Allow cable companies to offer telephone service, and telephone companies to get into the cable television business.
*Allow local phone companies to offer long-distance service, provided they open their local monopolies to new competitors.
*Lift limits on the number of television and radio stations one company could own, and allow broadcast companies to own cable systems, newspapers and radio stations in one city.
Consumer advocates sharply criticized the last provision, which goes well beyond the Senate measure. The critics predict that it would lead to media monoliths that quash alternative voices. As evidence, they pointed to this week's one-two punch in which Walt Disney agreed to acquire Capital Cities/ABC for $19 billion and Westinghouse Electric reached a $5.4 billion deal for CBS.
"This is a signal that competition is not going to flow from this bill -- more consolidation is," said Bradley Stillman, the telecommunications policy director of the Consumer Federation of America.
President Clinton has also objected to any relaxing of the limits on media ownership. He said he would not sign the bill unless the House removed these provisions, as well as those that would ease regulation of cable rates and allow the regional Bell companies speedy entry into long distance.
Those changes did not seem to be in the cards. The House was preparing to debate amendments that focus on price controls on cable television, the reregulation of broadcast ownership and provisions for regulation of violence and gratuitous sexual images that could be constrained by technology.
At one point, Representative Michael Flanagan, a Republican from Illinois, rose at his desk in the chamber and produced a plastic trash bag full of mail. It was only one of the four sackfuls that had been arriving daily in his office, and those of practically every other House member, for several days.
The AT&T Corporation, an opponent of the measure, "would have me believe that thousands of people in my district feel so strongly about their corporate profits that they are going to send me thousands of telegrams," he said.
Mr. Flanagan, a first-term Congressman who unseated the once-powerful Dan Rostenkowski, is from Chicago, and he knows something about ballots cast from the grave. So he was suspicious when a deluge of telegrams arrived bearing exactly the same message. He asked his staff to check them out.
Of 200 people who supposedly sent telegrams to Mr. Flanagan, only 75 could be found, he reported on the floor. Of those 75, many did not speak English and only 3 had heard of the telecommunications bill. And they hardly cared enough to rush down to Western Union and wire an "urgent-gram" to Washington. One telegram, he said, came from Casimir, whose last name was not disclosed, who "passed on in March."
"It has been said in Chicago that those who have gone beyond have a tendency to vote," Mr. Flanagan said, "but to send me a telegram is indeed, truly, long distance at its best."
Both sides generated tons of mail, but many members said these particular sacks of telegrams came from a campaign engineered by the chief opponent of the bill, the Competitive Long Distance Coalition, made up of AT&T and smaller long-distance carriers. The coalition once supported the bill. But when House Republican leaders took the highly unusual step of changing the bill after it had been approved in committee, the coalition turned against it and has been spending millions of dollars in an effort to defeat it.
The lobbying effort is headed by Marlin Fitzwater, who was press secretary for President George Bush. He said he did not believe that the coalition's direct-mail company had generated fictitious mailgrams. But, he added, "Anytime you have an '800' number, you're open to anybody calling in and giving contaminated information."
 Mr. Fitzwater said his side had spent $10 million to defeat the bill.
Early this morning, Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan and a ranking minority member of the Commerce Committee, called for a Congressional investigation to determine whether fictitious telegrams were sent to House members.
Expecting the legislation to pass, the other side -- represented by the regional Bell companies, which enjoy the backing of House Speaker Newt Gingrich and other Republican leaders -- has spent about $1 million to promote it.
But for all the millions spent, many members said it had no effect on how they would vote.
Mr. Flanagan supports the bill, and suggested that the sweeping lobbying campaign against it had only hardened his support. The bill, he said, "will provide competitiveness to an industry that has long lacked it," he said.
Similarly, Representative Maxine Waters, Democrat of California, said the mailgrams were "getting on people's nerves."
But the mail was not the only venue for propaganda. In the ornate Speaker's lobby just outside the House chamber, a highly regulated and secure area, one lobbyist had apparently received special permission to install a large easel. On it sat a time-line chart entitled "Trends in long-distance rates and exchange access charges."
Representative Peter A. DeFazio, Democrat of Oregon, was staring at the chart in the wee hours when an irrepressible yawn consumed his entire face. Whichever side wins, he observed, "it will be done in the dark of night because it involves real money."
He added: "The other big thing pending is the Department of Defense bill, the only category of expenditures that is increasing, and that will come up in the very last moments before the recess, and there will be a tremendous rush to get out of here in the hopes that they can preserve the B-2 bomber and their other pet projects. It's all very intentional."
Representative Scott McInnis, Republican of Colorado, commented, "Everything that needs to be said has been said, but not everyone has said it."
Marcy Kaptur, Democrat from Ohio, was aghast at the whole scene, and took the floor to tell the dwindling number of her colleagues just how she felt.
"Here we are in the middle of the night considering the most sweeping rewrite of the communications legislation in the last half-century," she said, adding that she was ashamed of the House. "There has been enough lobbying money spread around on this bill -- over $20 million -- to sink a battleship."
She added, "With a $1 trillion industry, with the rights of free press at stake and competition in every one of our communities hanging in the balance," the constraints on the debate time were like being "forced into a girdle."
She concluded: "I feel sorry for America tonight."
No one took issue with her.

A front-page headline yesterday about the Congressional debate on the telecommunications bill referred incorrectly in some editions to the House action. The issue was not debated Thursday night; the House adjourned early yesterday until 8 A.M. without any further debate or action on it.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

House Delays Final Vote On Communications Bill
House Republican leaders delayed final action early this morning on legislation that would open the nation's telephone and cable companies to freewheeling competition. The bill is still expected to pass the House of Representatives by a comfortable margin -- though it faces a threatened Presidential veto.
But the House adjourned until 8 A.M. after protracted debate and action on an unrelated appropriations bill ran well beyond midnight. The House's decision comes after several Democrats criticized Republicans for wanting to debate the telecommunications bill under the cover of darkness. [Page A1.]

Corporate Profits Surge, Despite Sluggish Quarter
The economy barely budged in the second quarter, growing at an annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent, but corporate profits continued to rise. The operating profits at the companies that make up the Standard & Poor's 500 index rose about 18 percent in the spring quarter, off slightly from the 21 percent rise in the first quarter. [D3.]
 
NBC to Acquire Outlet
NBC has agreed to acquire Outlet Communications for $47.25 a share, or about $311 million. NBC has also settled its dispute with Renaissance Communications, which had a deal for Outlet that came undone. [D4.]
 
Retail Sales Rose in July
Many of the nation's large retailers reported moderate sales gains during July. The heat wave helped them reduce inventories of lightweight clothing and ring up strong sales of air-conditioners. [D2.]
 
Factory Orders Fall
Factory orders declined two-tenths of 1 percent in June, the fourth time in five months orders have fallen, with demand slipping for aircraft and communications equipment. But in a hint of economic strength, jobless-benefit claims took a surprising 51,000 tumble. [D3.]
 
Ford Sales Climb 4.9%
Ford said its car and light truck sales rose 4.9 percent in July, but the increase, added to other auto makers' results, was not enough to lift the industry out of its slump. [D3.]
 
F.A.A. Plans Tracking System
A consortium headed by Wilcox Electric, with Hughes Aircraft and TRW, won a $475 million Federal contract to develop a navigation system that would let anyone from airline pilots to wilderness hikers pinpoint their location to within 21 feet anywhere in the United States. [A10.]
 
Tele-Communications Backs Turner
John C. Malone, the chief executive of Tele-Communications, said his company would do "everything we can to help" Ted Turner obtain a television network. [D4.]
 
Comsat Losing Sleepy Image
Little by little, Comsat has built a portfolio of entertainment assets as diverse as movies and professional sports, and it is beginning to shake its long-held image as a sleepy company. Market Place. [D6.]
 
Campaign Focuses on Hurley
Estee Lauder is reported to be spending $12 million to $15 million on a new ad campaign with Elizabeth Hurley, but it is also completely refashioning its advertising look to suit the actress. Ms. Hurleywas the Woman Wronged in the Hugh Grant affair, and Estee Lauder said the dignified way that she handled the publicity over the actor's arrest might actually help the campaign. Advertising. [D5.]
 
Group Bids for Canary Wharf
Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia said he and a group led by the Canadian businessman, Paul Reichmann, had joined their competing bids for the huge, once-bankrupt Canary Wharf development in London. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Pathmark's Neighbors Learn to Compete

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Along Jamaica Avenue, the commercial heart of the working-class Woodhaven section of Queens, a string of small, mom-and-pop shops opens every morning, providing their owners with a steady, if not always bustling, business.
Just a few blocks away stands a Pathmark supermarket, a hulking 70,000-square-foot presence astride a small strip mall. When the giant supermarket opened 10 years ago most of the other local merchants openly worried that they would be driven out of business. How could they compete with this commercial giant? 
 Today, however, more than two dozen small stores remain open within a one-mile radius of the supermarket -- roughly equal to the number when this Pathmark opened.
Ever since Pathmark Stores Inc. announced plans to build two new, giant supermarkets in New York City -- one in East Harlem and another in southeastern Queens -- the fate of small markets and grocery stores in those neighborhoods has been the subject of intense, emotional debate.
The plans have prompted an outcry from many owners of small businesses and several elected officials, who complain that the new stores will force dozens of small businesses to close.
Merchants on Jamaica Avenue in Woodhaven, as in other areas where large supermarkets have been built, said that they initially had to change their strategies -- and stock. But many contend that once they did, they had no trouble staying in business.
"We were here before Pathmark came," said Young Woo, the owner of Jea & Son Inc., a small market selling snacks, sodas and canned goods on Jamaica Avenue. "We have seen some people go, but we have seen a lot of people come here, too." She explained that the merchandise she carries has not changed much over the years. "People shop differently here than they do at Pathmark. They come here for the quick shopping. That's what we offer, and we're doing O.K."
Down the street, at Produce and Plus, a grocery store with fresh fruit and vegetables in outdoor bins, David Kim said his market has thrived by stocking produce that is particularly attractive to his Hispanic and Asian customers.
"We sell yucca, Brazil yam, plantains and a lot of things that you can't always find in Pathmark," he said. "Plus, our vegetables and fruit are fresher."
The City Planning Commission as well as the Community Food Resource Center, a nonprofit group that focuses on increasing access to food for low-income New Yorkers, have studied the impact of large markets on smaller stores. Each has concluded that the presence of supermarkets has rarely if ever resulted in a decline in the number of smaller stores in a neighborhood.
Their research has also indicated that, in many cases, a large supermarket creates a financial anchor that actually improves business for neighboring stores, no matter their size.
"We found that new supermarkets did not threaten the viability of existing food stores," said Pamela J. Fairclough, who is a project manager with the Community Food Resource Center.
"We looked at the impact in several neighborhoods where large supermarkets were built, comparing the number of smaller stores there before and after," Ms. Fairclough added. "We found that the same number of stores existed before as after."
One reason the small, mom-and-pop stores survive, Ms. Fairclough and city planners said, is that they provide services and products that give them a competitive advantage. Some provide steady customers with lines of credit; others sell ethnic foods rarely stocked in large supermarkets.
"We have done extensive research and the record shows that smaller stores are competing and competing successfully," said Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission. "There is no question that there is beneficial financial impact on the surrounding area when a large supermarket comes in."
Still, many people remain unconvinced. Adam Clayton Powell 4th, a City Councilman from East Harlem who has bitterly opposed the construction of the Pathmark store in his district, vehemently disputes the Planning Commission's findings. Mr. Powell insists that the new 53,000-square-foot store planned for his neighborhood will drive out smaller stores.
"They devastate the local economy," Mr. Powell said. "The big stores can afford to come into a neighborhood and lose money for a time. Once they monopolize the consumer base because of their rock-bottom prices, they are the only store left in town."
Mr. Powell charged that the very prospect of Pathmark coming into East Harlem has created financial hardships for existing small markets, which are now finding it difficult to get lines of credit. One East Harlem business had been unable to refinance its debt because of a skittish finance company, the Councilman said.
In Woodhaven, store owners said that in the initial years after Pathmark came to the area, some owners sold their businesses. But they were taken over by other merchants. Some store owners still there complain that business has not been robust in recent years, but they attribute that primarily to their customers' economic fortunes, rather than to Pathmark.
"For the most part, this is really a convenience store," said Charlie Datta, the manager of a deli and grocery store on nearby Woodhaven Boulevard. "In Pathmark, you have to have a cart, wait in line with a lot of food in the cart. Here, you're in and out.
"People come here for the convenience," Mr. Datta said. "There is enough business for everybody."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Jobless Data Send Treasury Prices Down

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities headed south yesterday, after a surprisingly large drop in the latest weekly jobless claims report sparked fears of rapid growth and rising inflation.
Claims were down to 321,000 for the week ended July 29 compared with the average trade estimates of 371,000 and against a downwardly revised 372,000 the week before. 
 Traders are trying to determine if the weekly number was an aberration or the beginning of a trend. It caused concern that the Fed would avoid making further changes in monetary policy for fear that the economy would accerlate and ignite inflation.
The long bond plunged 110/32 at its worst point, but by late in the day it was down 31/32 , to a price of 10823/32 for a yield of 6.93 percent, up from 6.86 percent on Wednesday.
Shorter-maturity bill rates were up an average of 4 basis points on the six-month and one-year maturities. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The economic data were not the market's only worry; supply also remained an issue, as the Treasury prepared to come to market with more than $67.7 billion in new bills, notes and bonds next week. This includes $25.2 billion in three- and six-month bills that are auctioned weekly, followed by the large quarterly refunding that begins Tuesday with $18 billion in new three-year notes, and $13 billion in 10-year notes on Wednesday. On Thursday the refunding will finish with the sale of $11.5 billion in 30-year bonds.
In when-issued trading yesterday, yields were higher as dealers searched for prices that would begin to attract the most investors. The 3-year was offered at a price to yield 6.09 percent; the 10-year at 6.52 percent, and the 30-year at 6.88 percent, up an average of 6 basis points.
Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist at the PNC Bank Corporation in Pittsburgh, said the bond market was supersensitive to any signs of economic improvement at present.
The drop in the claims report may have been overstated, analysts said, and spooked the market, even though there is little connection between the claims report and payrolls data due today, since the period comes after the July jobs survey.
"Given all the problems with weekly claims data that we know about," Mr. Hoffman said, "today's numbers may not reflect the real picture. Many factories, especially auto plants, shut down in early July, which bloated the claims report. Subsequently claims plummented when these workers returned in late July," he said.
"I would expect a rebound in new claims to the 375,000 level during the next several weeks," he added.
Ford, the last of the Detroit car makers to report sales for July, posted a rise for the month, with truck sales setting records. The report brought the total of domestically produced cars and trucks for all the United States auto makers to 6.6 million for autos, and 5.3 million for trucks, for a total of 11.9 million. The figure was well below expectations, matching the April low for the year.
Michael Strauss, chief economist at Yamaichi International (America) Inc., said, "Government yields were also pressured higher because people were expecting the Japanese to immediatetly respond to a loosening of investment restrictions that prevent them from buying more foreign bonds, and they have not."
Elsewhere, in the municipal bond market prices declined amid a lack of demand, especially from mutual funds. Analysts report, nevertheless, that many investors do not expect prices to fall significantly because issuance is light, down 25 percent from the beginning of the year through July.
Some investors have been reluctant to buy tax-exempt securities because of lingering concern that tax laws could be changed, diminishing the value of municipal securities.
Currently general-obligation bonds maturing in 30 years and rated single-A are yielding about 6.14 percent, or about 88 percent of Treasury bonds, according to Bloomberg Fair Value analytics. Investors generally consider the bonds attractive when they yield more than 85 percent of Treasury securities.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Down Against the Yen As Intervention Seems to End

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against most leading currencies yesterday as currency traders took profits a day after the dollar surged to nearly a five-month high against the Japanese yen.
The dollar rose sharply on Wednesday after the United States and Japan jointly entered foreign-exchange markets, selling about $1 billion worth of yen. In addition to the coordinated intervention, the Japanese Government introduced measures to make it easier for Japanese insurance companies and portfolio managers to invest overseas. 
 Japan wants to weaken the strong yen, which has hindered an economic recovery by making the products of important Japanese exporters more expensive abroad.
Traders said they saw no signs of intervention yesterday, a departure from the practice begun on July 7 when the Bank of Japan followed through on a joint intervention to support the dollar.
"They sort of felt: 'We did our thing yesterday; let's step aside and see how things go,' " said Richard Holbrook, director of global equities at Bailard, Biehl & Kaiser, a money management firm in San Mateo, Calif.
The dollar settled in New York at 90.52 yen, down from 90.96 yen late Wednesday. Earlier on Wednesday, the dollar rose as high as 91.27 yen.
The dollar also slipped to 1.3909 German marks yesterday from 1.3976 marks late Wednesday. The British pound rose to $1.6055 from $1.5997.
While traders took profits, they were also assessing the new Japanese investing rules. Traders questioned whether the plan would persuade Japanese investors, typically conservative and averse to risk, to invest in United States bonds and stocks, thus increasing demand for dollars.
"The fact that the doors are a little more open does not address the economic problems that underline the capital flow imbalance and the state of the economy on both sides of the Pacific," said Lisa Finstrom, a currency analyst at Smith Barney Inc. The United States had a trade deficit of $66 billion with Japan last year.
Other traders noted that bond yields in some European countries were higher than comparable Treasury yields.
Traders will look for clues to the direction of United States interest rates today, when the Labor Department reports on employment in July. They are looking for confirmation that the economy is growing fast enough to prevent the Federal Reserve from pushing down short-term interest rates anytime soon.

HEADLINE: In America;
Buying Clothes Without Exploiting Children

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Readers have been asking what they can do about American companies that sell clothing made by exploited workers, many of them children, in the maquiladora factories of Central America and the Caribbean.
A woman from Montauk, N.Y., wrote, "I simply cannot sit back and watch my two children frolic in their vacation surf knowing that other children suffer to enable my kids to have cute bathing suits." 
 A woman from Berkeley, Calif., wrote: "It makes me want to do something. But what?"
A man from Tulsa, Okla., said: "For the last 20 years or so, I have watched the 'Made in U.S.A.' label grow scarcer and scarcer in the clothing departments of retail stores. Nevertheless, over that entire time I have made a commitment to purchase American-made apparel exclusively. Up to a few years ago this merely resulted in some minor inconveniences: slightly longer shopping trips and increased catalogue browsing. More and more it is turning into a grueling ordeal."
Many readers asked if there were a list of good companies and bad companies, some kind of guide that they could follow.
The questions raised were good ones, sensible and direct, and filled with compassion and a sense of responsibility. Most people do not want to buy clothing made by workers who are treated like slaves, and they find the exploitation of children especially repulsive. But the issue is complex, and the answers at the moment are not very satisfying.
In 1980, 30 percent of all apparel purchased in the United States was made abroad. Today the breakdown is about 50-50, with the balance about to be tipped in favor of imports. Some items -- sneakers, for example -- are hardly made in the United States at all. So, as consumers have found, it is very difficult to simply "buy American."
Moreover, a "made in the U.S.A." label is not a guarantee that the product was made by workers who are treated humanely.
"There is a tremendous proliferation of illegal sweatshops right here in the United States," said Charles Kernaghan, executive director of the National Labor Committee. "We can document hundreds of sweatshops in New York, San Francisco."
On Wednesday, officials raided a garment sweatshop complex in El Monte, Calif., where, according to authorities, nearly 70 Thai immigrants had been held in virtual slavery. The complex was surrounded by barbed wire and spiked fences.
"I never would have believed a situation like this could exist in the United States, and I hope I never see it again," said California's Labor Commissioner, Victoria Bradshaw.
The best thing consumers can do is let American companies know, emphatically, that they do not want to buy goods made by child laborers, or by workers of any age who are exploited. Speak to clerks and store managers. Write to company executives. Ask if garments were manufactured under humane conditions.
"If the consumers would engage the companies on this issue, if they would just enter the debate, it would be a tremendous breakthrough," said Mr. Kernaghan.
Consumers should ask company executives to respond with a letter certifying that none of their products are made in factories in which abusive practices are employed.
Consumer and labor organizations can be contacted for the names of newsletters and groups that track employment practices and boycotts.
It is important also for consumers to write their representatives in Congress, alerting them to their concerns about this issue. Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa has introduced a bill that would block the importation of goods produced by children under the age of 15. A similar bill has been offered in the House.
According to Senator Harkin, as many as 46 million children around the globe make goods for the United States market.
Many apparel companies in the U.S. have adopted codes of conduct that are supposed to insure that the workers who make their products are not abused. But the codes, primarily public relations devices, are widely ignored by the independent contractors who run the factories.
Said Mr. Kernaghan, "As it stands now, no worker in Central America or the Caribbean has ever heard of a code of conduct."
In the headlong rush to dismantle the barriers to trade, enormous efforts are being made to protect the rights and property of the businesses involved. But the workers, the human beings who make the products, are not protected. In the international corridors of power, they are less than an afterthought.
