SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1554 words

HEADLINE: HOUSE PASSES BILL CURTAILING RULES ON PHONES AND TV

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
The House of Representatives approved a bill today that would radically rewrite the nation's communications laws for the first time in more than six decades.
In a frenetic session before breaking for a monthlong recess, House members voted 305 to 117 for vastly reduced regulations on everything from cable television to local and long-distance telephone services. 
 The bill would give local phone companies -- the so-called Baby Bells -- something they have been seeking for years: the right to enter the long-distance market. But in a setback to the television networks, House Democrats curbed some of the legislation's strongest elements of deregulation, winning key amendments to limit media ownership and to mandate that all new television sets include technology that would allow parents to block out programs with violence or sexual content.
But consumer advocates said the amendments hardly made the bill consumer-friendly. They predicted that cable and telephone rates would increase as big communications conglomerates were allowed to become even bigger.
"Congress has reached deep into consumers' pockets, opened their wallets and taken out their money," said Bradley Stillman, director of telecommunications policy at the Consumer Federation of America.
Still, the bill's Republican backers exulted in their victory.
"With this bill, we will break up two monopolies: local telephone companies and cable companies," said Thomas J. Bliley Jr., the Virginia Republican who is the chief sponsor of the legislation.
Republican leaders said the wide margin of victory today, and the Senate's 81-to-18 vote in June approving a similar measure, guaranteed that they could override a threatened veto from President Clinton, who sides with the consumer advocates. To override a veto, both houses must muster a two-thirds majority.
But while the House Republicans marshaled a seemingly veto-proof advantage, both Edward J. Markey, the Massachusetts Democrat who sponsored the amendments on media ownership and technology to block violent programming, and White House officials insisted that they had already corralled about a dozen votes from Democrats who voted for the bill but said they would support a Presidential veto.
Mr. Markey said that the back-to-back ABC and CBS deals announced earlier this week prompted both Democrats and Republicans to vote for stricter ownership limits.
"The members are now much more aware of what could happen if they don't pay attention," Mr. Markey said. A third Markey amendment, which would have limited cable rate increases, did not pass.
In approving the so-called V-chip that would be included in new television sets and allow parents to block programming, the House followed the lead of the Senate. But the House left room for broadcasters to develop an alternative blocking technology. Whatever the technology used, it would be up to the broadcasting and cable industries to develop a rating system.
The debate over the V-chip capped an exhausting and emotional session in which the lawmakers veered from highly arcane discussions of local and long-distance telephone competition to an impassioned debate on how to protect children from violent and sexual programming.
Representative Dan Burton, an Indiana Republican and ardent proponent of the V-chip, broke down in tears after it passed. Before the vote, Mr. Burton had described witnessing domestic violence in his childhood -- behavior that he said was encouraged by the violent images on television.
Although the media and programming issues dominated the House debate, the telecommunications bill will have its biggest economic impact on the telephone industry, where local and long-distance companies will now be allowed to compete head-on.
The long-distance carriers were dealt a significant setback yesterday when the House leaders amended the bill to make it easier for the regional Bell companies to offer long-distance service.
In the original bill, the Bell companies would have had to meet a rigorous checklist of items to gain entry into long distance. Most important, they would have had to open their local markets to competitors and demonstrate that those competitors were offering service "comparable in price, features and scope."
Now, though, the Bell companies can gain entry into long distancmerely by demonstrating that there are competitors in their local markets who offer bxth business and residential service.
Thomas J. Tauke, the chief lobbyist for the Nynex Corporation, said that if the measure approved today, or one like it, was enacted, his company would probably be the first Bell company to move into long distance. He said that process would take 12 to 18 months. Nynex already has deals with cable companies and so-called competitive access providers giving them access to its local telephone network.
Mr. Stillman, of the Consumer Federation of America, estimated that consumers would pay an average of $10 a month more for local phone service in the year 2000 because the Bells would use their monopoly power in local markets to impede new competitors.
Daniel Reingold, a telecommunications analyst at Merrill Lynch, agreed that local rates would increase. But he said that was because state governments from New York to California had already been forcing the Baby Bells to open their markets to competition.
To compensate the Bell companies for this lost revenue, New York, California and several other states have allowed the Bells to raise their rates for basic residential service.
In the long run, several Bell executives said, technology will drive the rates down again. Philip J. Quigley, chairman and chief executive of the Pacific Telesis Group, said the legislation would also offer consumers more choices, since it would accelerate the entry of telephone companies into new businesses like video programming.
Consumers may face a similar trade-off with cable. The House bill lifts rate regulation for basic cable services like CNN and MTV after 15 months. Mr. Markey lost an amendment to scale back that deregulation, and consumer advocates said that the average monthly cable bill would increase by $5 to $7.
Cable executives insisted they could not risk raising rates at a time when they face new competition from direct-broadcast satellite and telephone companies. And they said consumers would benefit from the ability of cable companies to offer telephone service.
"With all these new competitors, is this the time you want to go out and alienate your customers?" asked Brian L. Roberts, the president of the Comcast Corporation, the fourth-largest cable operator.
The networks are losers on several fronts. The original bill would have allowed one company to own television stations reaching 50 percent of the nation's TV households. Mr. Markey's amendment reduces that to 35 percent -- the same level allowed in the Senate bill.
The amendment also prohibits a broadcaster from owning a cable system in the same city -- again the same as in the Senate legislation. Under the original House version, broadcasters would have been able to own newspapers, radio stations or cable systems in the same market.
Martin Franks, the vice president of government relations at CBS, said his network would be handicapped by the new rules. Assembling a powerful group of TV stations was a main motivation for the Westinghouse deal with his network. And while the combined company would still be within the House's ownership limits, the legislation would foreclose it from buying any more big stations.
Jack Fields, a Texas Republican and another architect of the bill, said that Mr. Markey's amendment was crafted to protect big newspaper publishers like The New York Times Company or The Washington Post Company. Newspaper companies would still be able to acquire other media properties in the same market, while broadcasters would not.
The House voted to move its final deliberations on the bill from midnight to later this morning after Democrats complained that the bill was being rushed into law under cover of darkness to avoid scrutiny. The Democrats threatened to tie up the proceedings with procedural motions unless the House leadership agreed to delay the debate by about six hours.
The Democratic victories bring the House legislation closer in substance to the Senate bill. But as both parties look forward to the conference committee, in which the Senate and House bills will be reconciled, Mr. Fields said that several issues still had to be resolved.
Among them: the Senate voted in its bill to make the transmission of pornographic material by on-line services a crime. But the House bill leaves the policing of the Internet, the global computer network, up to the on-line services themselves.
The House must also consider the prospect of a Presidential veto. White House officials said today that President Clinton was pleased with the success of the V-chip and media ownership amendments, but that he still had problems with several provisions of the bill, including the lifting of cable rates and the easier admission of the Bell companies into long-distance service.
"People are kidding themselves if they think there is some magic bullet that will get the President to sign this bill," one White House aide said.


GRAPHIC: Some important effects of the bill approved yesterday by the House, if it becomes law.
 
CABLE TV: The bill would erase limits on cable rates, allow telephone companies to offer cable service, and make it harder for customers to press formal complaints about rates.
Charts: "Changes the Public Would Feel"
Rates would probably rise for most customers, especially in the first few years and in smaller markets where competition is unlikely.
 
PHONE SERVICE: The billj would allow long-distance carriers, cable companies and others to compete with local phone companies and allow Bell companies to offer long-distance service if they meet certain criteria.
 Long-distance rates would probably continue to fall; local rates might also fall where there is competition, but might rise elsewhere.
 
VIOLENCE ON TV: The bill would require new television sets to include a feature that could be programmed to block out material rated as violent.
 
(pg. 1)
 
"The V-Chip: Regulating Violence on Broadcasts"
 
The Chip: The House and Senate telecommunications bills would require new television sets to be equipped with a so-called V-chip that would allow parents to screen out violent television programming. Broadcasters and cable operators have yet to agree on a ratings system that the chips could read.
 
Broadcasting the signal: The same broadcast signal that carries television pictures has room to carry data, like a violence rating for the program that would signal a V-chip to block access. Each frame of a television broadcast is made of 525 lines, of which 483 are used to create the video image. The 42 other lines make up what is called the vertical blanking interval, the black bar that appears on the screen if the image begins to roll. Twenty-four of these lines can be used for other information, like instructions that could activiate the V-chip.
 
(Source: Electronic Industries Association)
 
"Highlights and Open Questions"
 Here are key provisions of the House telecommunications bill passed yesterday, how they differ from the bill the Senate passed in June, and concerns the White House has voiced about some provisions.
 
MEDIA OWNERSHIP
 
HOUSE BILL: Would lift almost all restrictions on the number of radio and TV stations a single company could own, except for three rule: An owner would be limited to two TV stations in any one market; only one of the two could be a VHF station (channel 2 through 13); and all of an owner's TV stations combined could not reach more than 35 percent of the nation's households. A current rule forbidding commong ownership of TV or radio stations and newspapers in the same market would be scrapped, but the Federal Communications Commission could block an "undue concentration of media voices." A ban on common ownership of cable systems and TV stations in the same market would be retained.
 
DIFFERENCES IN SENATE BILL: Would retain the current ban on common ownership of broadcast outlets and the newspapers in the same market, and the current owneership limit of one TV station of any kind in the market.
 
WHITE HOUSE VIEW: Consumers "should continue to benefit from a diversity of voices and viewpoints in radio, television and the print media."
 
LOCAL TELEPHONE
 
HOUSE BILL: In exchange for entry to new markets like cable television and long-distance services, local telephone companies would have to let would-be rivals connect to their networks at prices low enough to make competitive services practical. Small rural phone companies could seek an exemption to this requirement.
 
DIFFERENCES IN SENATE BILL: The F.C.C. would have a role in arbitrating between phone companies and new rivals over issues of access to existing networks.
 
WHITE HOUSE VIEW: State regulators would not be left with enough flexibility to regulate local rates and control the introduction of competition in local phone service.
 
LONG DISTANCE TELEPHONE
 
HOUSE BILL: Local Bell telephone companies would be allowed to enter the long-distance business after six months, provided they meet certain requirements related to network access for would-be rivals, and provided that there is local competition.
 
DIFFERENCES IN SENATE BILL: The F.C.C. would have a role in determining whether it is in the public interest to allow a Bell company to compete for long-distance customers in a market.
 
WHITE HOUSE VIEW: Contrary to sponsors' claims, the House version would not insure competition in either local or long-distance services.
 
CABLE TELEVISION
 
HOUSE BILL: Would remove price controls on cable TV programming and equipment rentals, except for basic service, within 15 months - or sooner if a telephone company begins competing with the cable company. Small cable companies would have all price controls removed, including basic service. More than 3 percent of a cable company's customers would have to complain before the F.C.C. would begin a review of the company's charges.
 
DIFFERENCES IN SENATE BILL: Would deregulate rates only for companies that charge the national average rate or less, with the benchmark average recalculated every two years. The F.C.C. would continue to review rate complaints from one or a few subscribers.
 
WHITE HOUSE VIEW: The bills do not contain enough safeguards against high rates for consumers - especially in small towns and rural areas, where true competition would be unlikely.
 
INDECENT CONTENT ON-LINE
 
HOUSE BILL: Would encourage on-line computer services like Compuserve and American Online to police the content of subscribers' communications for pornographic materials.
 
DIFFERENCES IN SENATE BILL: Would make transmissionof pornographic matgerial over on-line services a crime.
 
WHITE HOUSE VIEW: Has not yet commented on this provision.

HEADLINE: Pain, and Dreams, Greet Christopher in Cambodia

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Aug. 4

 BODY:
The last time a Secretary of State arrived in this poorest corner of Southeast Asia, 40 years ago, Cambodia still had its tragedies ahead of it: two savage wars, the secret bombings, the horror of the killing fields.
Today Secretary of State Warren Christopher landed here to declare that Cambodia had finally "emerged from a cruel darkness," and in small and sometimes unspoken ways, he spent much of the visit atoning for America's role in Cambodia's many miseries. 
 On Saturday, in what is expected to mark the most dramatic moment of his weeklong tour, Mr. Christopher will land in Vietnam and formally establish relations with the Communist Government that it battled for 15 years. It is a visit, he said today, that will "help the United States put behind it the pain of war."
Mr. Christopher's arrival here was the occasion for a meeting of starkly different worlds, as his motorcade, sirens blaring, rumbled down dirt roads past collapsing shanties, flooded rice fields and water buffalo who did their best to appear unimpressed.
From his car window, he could glimpse the warren of junk-strewn back allies that contain some of Asia's deepest pockets of poverty in a country that can only dream of the economic miracles that have so transformed neighbors like Thailand and Malaysia, only an hour's flight away. Nearly half the Cambodian population is under 15, meaning that they have no memory of the terror that destroyed the society.
Throughout the day Mr. Christopher received stunning reminders of how dramatically the nature of America's power in this part of the world has changed. For decades his predecessors viewed Cambodia first as a domino in the cold war, then as a failed state that imploded in genocidal fury, then as a testing ground for the United Nations.
But this morning the two men who share the prime ministership here -- Prince Ranariddh, a son of King Sihanouk, and Hun Sen, who first came to power with the backing of Vietnam after its 1979 invasion of the country -- asked Mr. Christopher to view Cambodia first and foremost as a trading partner.
They spent much of their time urging the Secretary to help them obtain most-favored-nation trading status -- he agreed -- and talking about how to attract foreign capital. Many officials told Mr. Christopher they now fear that American investors will pour into Vietnam, as Cambodia withers.
"It was a remarkable conversion," one of Mr. Christopher's aides said after the meeting. "This is a country that a few years ago had no economy, and whose people scavenged for food," he added, not mentioning that in the countryside here some still do. "And here they were talking about their hopes for future as an exporter."
But as Mr. Christopher reminded the two men, the first requirement for investment is political stability, in short supply here. There was a coup attempt a year ago; Pol Pot, weakened by defections, still stages attacks from the Thai border; corruption is rampant, and there are still 8 million to 10 million unexploded anti-personnel mines buried in the countryside. And the new Government is drifting toward authoritarianism.
In the last few months it has ejected a leading opposition member from the National Assembly, threatened others, and passed a widely criticized press law making it a crime to publish anything "injurious to the state," a term the Government itself will define.
So Mr. Christopher found himself lecturing on human rights, warning the leaders that "elections are not enough" and cautioning that American aid -- about $40 million -- will probably turn on the country's human rights performance.
"Compared to five years ago, things are definitely improved," said Keith Schulz, a legal adviser for the Asia Society who is based here. "Compared to a year ago, they are backsliding."
Everywhere Mr. Christopher went, it seemed, he tripped across the remnants of Cambodia's mind-numbing suffering.
In the morning he spent an hour learning the art of removing mines, watching demonstrations of the painstaking work involved in clearing out the jungles where farmers, children and animals are still regularly blown up. Mr. Christopher used the time to appeal for foreign aid funds. The "de-mining" project, a training program, gets $5 million in Federal grants that may well be reduced to $1 million.
This afternoon he visited the grim prison where Pol Pot's victims were photographed and sent off for execution. The pictures cover the dingy prison walls, eyes bulging out in the terror of imminent death, and Mr. Christopher seemed shaken when he viewed the museum's collection of human skulls.
But bby evening, he was dining in one of the world's most spectacular palaces, the home of King Sihanouk, who has spent millions over the last few years restoring the compound, with its French and Khmer influences, to its original 1870 splendor.
It was in the same place in 1955 that John Foster Dulles, the last Secretary of State to come here, tried to persuade the same King to abandon his neutrality in the growing war in neighboring Vietnam, a war America had yet to enter. The failed effort touched off a long downward spiral in America's relations with the enigmatic King, which reached a low-point when he was overthrown in a coup that brought Lon Nol to power and saw the Vietnam war spill across the border.
Tonight the aging King, who has been treated extensively in China for cancer and appeared thin but rested as he sat with Queen Monique in front of his gold-encrusted throne, was clearly in a mood to set aside lingering resentments. For his part, Mr. Christopher made it clear he had come partly to atone and partly to celebrate Cambodia's re-emergence as a nascent democratic state.
"No doubt with the benefit of hindsight the U.S. could have done many things better in Cambodia," Mr. Christopher said tonight, in words he was clearly rehearsing for his visit Saturday to Vietnam. "None of us is fully satisfied with the role of the U.S. in this period. But what we need to emphasize now is the future."

His plane touched down at Noi Bai Airport, 20 miles north of the capital, at about 9:40 A.M. (9:40 P.M. Friday, Eastern time), and he was met by Deputy Foreign Minister Le Mai, Hanoi's main spokesman on American affairs.

HEADLINE: Religion Journal;
One Man's Life of Virtue Earns the Papal Spotlight

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

 BODY:
If Americans' book-buying habits are any indication, lots of people are curious about what makes up a virtuous life. Just look at the best-seller lists, where "The Book of Virtues," by the erstwhile Presidential prospect William J. Bennett, has ridden high for months.
 Yet to assess the virtuousness of a person's life is essentially a religious matter. In the Roman Catholic Church, to take a prime example, there is the Vatican's Congregation for the Causes of Saints, which examines those lives in which dedication to moral good seems truly extraordinary. 
 Recently, after deliberations by that body, Pope John Paul II declared the Rev. Francis Solanus Casey, who worked for more than 20 years in various New York City parishes, to be "venerable." The title is the church's way of saying that the late Father Casey lived a life of "heroic virtue" and has cleared the first of three steps on the road to sainthood.
 No man born in the United States had ever received that distinction, said the Rev. Michael Crosby, a Milwaukee priest who spent years researching Father Casey's life, preparing the extensive documents on which the church authorities would make their decision.
 Indeed, only three American Catholics have been declared saints: St. Frances Xavier Cabrini, a founder of hospitals, orphanages and convents, who died in 1917 and was canonized in 1946; St. John Neumann, a bishop of Philadelphia, who died in 1860 and was canonized in 1977, and St. Elizabeth Ann Seton, founder of the Sisters of Charity of St. Joseph, who died in 1821 and was canonized in 1975, the first American-born saint.
 But then, the church's investigations into a person's holiness can be rigorous indeed.
 In the case of Father Casey, the process took 13 years and resulted in a three-volume document that runs more than 1,300 pages.
 After the Vatican gave approval to begin the process in 1982, officials in the Archdiocese of Detroit, where Father Casey spent much of his adult life, interviewed nearly 60 people who had known the priest. The interviewers worked from 29 single-spaced pages of questions. The resulting testimony, 800 pages long, makes up one of the volumes of the document.
 But the crucial volume is a careful examination of how Father Casey demonstrated 15 virtues, from faithfulness to God and love of the neighbor to prudence, justice, temperance and fortitude (the four cardinal virtues).
 Father Crosby, who wrote that book, as well as one other dealing with how Father Casey responded to the political and social events of his times, said he supported his findings with well over 1,000 footnotes, some with as many as 10 sources, drawn from the testimony of those who knew Father Casey and from the priest's own letters.
 Still, the bare facts of Father Casey's life are modest.
 He was born in a log cabin in Wisconsin in 1870 to Irish immigrants. Baptized Bernard Casey, he spent a few years as a streetcar worker and Federal prison guard before becoming a Capuchin Franciscan priest. His order gave him the names Francis Solanus. The first Irish-American among the Milwaukee-based, German-speaking Capuchins, he was ordained but never given authority to hear confessions or preach.
 From 1904 to 1924, he worked in parishes in Yonkers, Harlem and the Lower East Side of New York. Except for a few months in Brooklyn in the mid-1940's, he spent the rest of his life in Detroit. He died in 1957.
 For much of his life, Father Casey was popularly known as a man whose relationship with God was considered so profound that his prayers could help heal people, and as a man who had insight into people's futures. The faithful came by the busload to see him.
 "There is a thin line between the gift of prophecy, which Solanus had in abundance, and intuition," Father Crosby said. "He had this uncanny ability to listen. He would look right at you, and he would take as much time with you as you would want." He encouraged those he helped to perform acts of charity.
 Father Crosby, who has a master's degree in economics and a doctorate in theology and who works as an advocate for corporate social responsibility, said he was originally skeptical of efforts to push Father Casey's cause. He said he believed that enough priests and nuns had been canonized and that the church needed more saints who had been laypeople.
 But as he did his research, his views on Father Casey changed. "I really just came to have unbelievable respect for him," Father Crosby said. He was deeply impressed, he said, by the priest's unwavering faith in God and by his bedrock belief in human goodness.
 Toward the end of a telephone interview from the friary where he lives, Father Crosby mentioned in an almost offhand way that he had once met Father Casey. It was the briefest of encounters, not much more than a handshake, the day in 1956 when Father Crosby's brother entered the Capuchins.
 No, Father Crosby said, he did not recall what Father Casey said to him. But he remembered the words of his brother: "My brother Dan says, 'Come and meet Solanus, because he's going to be a saint someday."

HEADLINE: Transit Agency Seeks to Alter Union Contract

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
Seeking sharp reductions in spending, New York City transit officials want to renegotiate the existing contract with subway and bus workers, insisting on work-rule changes or even wage cuts and threatening thousands of layoffs if the union balks.
"We're looking at 2,000, maybe 2,500 positions that would have to go," unless there are major union concessions, said an official of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority who spoke on condition of anonymity. While some reductions could be made through attrition, he said, most would inevitably be made through layoffs. 
 The demand for union "give-backs" would be the latest step by M.T.A. officials in their efforts to piece together a financial package to cope with rising costs, stagnant revenues and declining city, state and Federal subsidies. Early this week, officials revealed that they plan to do away with free and half-fare student transit passes. And on Thursday, the M.T.A. chairman, E. Virgil Conway, proposed raising the price of a subway token from $1.25 to $1.50, and increasing Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North Commuter Railroad fares and bridge and tunnel tolls.
Mr. Conway said that in addition to fare and toll increases, the M.T.A. would have to cut spending by $2.85 billion over five years to balance its budgets. Wresting concessions from transit workers would be the first and perhaps most important part of that campaign.
Because the Transport Workers Union has a year-old contract with two years still to run, management must have the employees' cooperation to make any changes in working conditions or wages, and union leaders made it clear that such cooperation would not be given readily.
"I don't relish the thought of having to take a more militant stand," said Damaso Seda, president of the Transport Workers Union Local 100, which represents 32,000 of the Transit Authority's 41,000 employees, "but if push comes to shove, it will get real ugly."
But management insists that it needs union concessions to make the Transit Authority, whose parent agency is the M.T.A., more efficient and to balance its budgets for 1996 and beyond. And the M.T.A. has at its disposal the powerful threat of layoffs.
The M.T.A. plans to take on the transit workers at the same time that talks on a new contract with Metro-North unions are stalled over the authority's insistence on work-rule changes and its offer of wage increases smaller than the rate of inflation. But if officials are to find economies, the most important place to do so is in the Transit Authority, whose work force and projected deficits are by far the largest in the M.T.A.
M.T.A. officials said that their actions were prompted both by the severity of the authority's financial problems and by the belief that the new, Republican Governor would back them in taking a harder line than in the past. In negotiating new contracts last year with L.I.R.R. and Transit Authority workers, the M.T.A. at first took a tough stand on wages and work rules, but later backed down. In the L.I.R.R. talks, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo forced a settlement after a two-day strike.
The M.T.A. official who spoke on condition of anonymity would not say what specific demands will be made of the transit union, but he cited as possibilities a wage freeze or reduction, and changes in contract provisions that narrowly define the work a particular employee group can do. Another potential change, he said, would be in contractually mandated staffing levels, an area that could prove crucial if the M.T.A. tries to eliminate the conductor's job on many subway trains, as it has indicated it might.
"I'm sure that they have a laundry list of things that they'd like us to consider," Mr. Seda said, "and they have told me some of those things," though he added that he had received some conflicting messages from M.T.A. officials and that no formal overtures had been made to the union. He said that the threat of layoffs had been made.
New York's Taylor Law, passed in the aftermath of a 12-day transit strike in 1966, prohibits strikes by public employees and carries harsh financial penalties for a violation. Striking workers are docked two days' pay for each day of a walkout, and the leaders of striking unions can face heavy fines. But that did not stop transit workers from staging an 11-day strike in 1980.
"This is going to be worse than 1980," Mr. Seda said. "It's going to be worse than '75, when there were all the layoffs."
Mr. Conway and the man who appointed him, Gov. George E. Pataki, have repeatedly shown an inclination to squeeze savings out of the transportation agency. In February, the Governor prevailed upon the M.T.A. board to avert a fare increase by cutting Transit Authority expenses by $113 million for this year and $201 million for next year, a move that brought on the first broad service cuts since the 1970's.
When cuts that have already been made take effect later this year and next year, the Transit Authority will have eliminated nearly 5,000 jobs since 1989, cutting its payroll to fewer than 40,000 people.
Mr. Conway said Thursday that despite the cuts voted earlier this year, the Transit Authority, with a $3 billion operating budget, must make up a $167 million shortfall before the year is over, and faces a deficit of $316 million next year, climbing to $627 million in 1999.
The 25-cent increase in the fare would generate an additional $275 million a year in revenue, but the bulk of the shortfall, Mr. Conway said, must be made up through cost-cutting. He refused to give specifics, other than to say his plan would rely on the cooperation of labor and management, and "it will entail certainly a reduction in staff." He did not say there would be layoffs, but he would not rule them out.
Mr. Seda blamed the situation on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Governor Pataki, each of whom cut subsidies for the M.T.A. by $128 million a year.
"Before they come to us for money, they have to talk to the Governor and the Mayor, who stole the money that's creating this gap," Mr. Seda said. "George and Rudy have stolen more money in the last six months than Jesse James did in his entire career."
At first he said of union concessions, "it's not going to happen." But he said that if it comes to a choice between that and huge job losses, "I will go to my membership and lay out the case, and see if we would be willing to do certain things to avoid layoffs." It would not be unheard of for a union, dominated by its older members, to agree to layoffs that would fall mostly on newcomers in order to protect hard-won wage and work-rule gains.
Paradoxically, Mr. Seda sounded at times like the Mayor, who has insisted that the M.T.A. is bloated and should cut waste before doing anything else. Mr. Seda, who insisted that all jobs related to actually keeping trains and buses running should be preserved, argued that the Transit Authority could eliminate 3,000 clerical jobs without hurting service, safety or maintenance.

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Sweatshops Are Thriving, Experts Say

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Almost one-fifth of the garment industry workers in Los Angeles, many of them foreigners who came to the United States to escape the crushing poverty of their homelands, are toiling in unregulated, sweatshop conditions, labor officials, economists and union organizers said today.
Exactly how many find themselves bound to employers who take advantage of their legal status, naivete and cultural alienation is not known. But experts said their numbers were flourishing despite a host of regulations on labor, health, safety and immigration designed to flush them out and shut their employers down. 
 "I have heard things like this for years," said Mark Rosenbaum, legal director of the Los Angeles office of the American Civil Liberties Union. "It's one of these dirty little secrets that everyone knows about."
On Wednesday, state agents raided a makeshift garment factory in El Monte, Calif., where they found nearly 70 workers from Thailand who lived and worked, sometimes for years, in conditions the agents described as close to servitude.
Federal immigration officials acknowledged today that they knew of conditions at the El Monte factory nearly three years ago but that they took no action until state officials got a similar tip six weeks ago.
"The state solicited our participation to join them when they issued the search warrant, and we agreed," said Virginia Kice, a spokeswoman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service. "But later our people felt that it was inappropriate to be present for a state warrant. We thought that maybe the case would be thrown out for a technicality."
Victoria Bradshaw, California's Labor Commissioner, today called the El Monte situation an aberration. She added, "I don't believe it's widespread."
Indeed, formal complaints about involuntary servitude are relatively rare. Since 1990, the Justice Department has prosecuted 29 people for violations of the antislavery laws, and 26 were convicted or pleaded guilty. Most of the cases involved migrant workers in Eastern states, not Asians in California.
Still, while brutal conditions like those found in the El Monte case are unusual, thousands of other workers often find themselves trapped in bleak, unregulated workplaces.
Of the estimated 120,000 garment industry workers in the Los Angeles area, 15,000 to 20,000 work in unregulated, sweatshop conditions, said Jack Kyser, chief economist of the Economic Development Corporation of Los Angeles.
"A lot of times you get people coming from offshore and setting up these shops, because it's a very easy industry to get into and you don't need a lot of capital," Mr. Kyser said. "But in many cases they don't understand all the rules and regulations they have to comply with and all the forms they have to fill out.
"They're probably doing business like they did it in the country of their origin, but in the United States, they're breaking the law."
In a random survey last year of 69 California garment manufacturers and contractors, the state Labor Department found rampant violations of safety and labor laws, including cases of employers locking fire exits and children as young as 13 working nine hours a day.
The survey also showed that 50 percent of employers violated rules requiring them to pay workers the minimum wage, 68 percent violated overtime requirements, and 92.8 percent violated various health and safety regulations. Workplace conditions are likely to be worst in makeshift factories that operate outside the law.
Joseph Rodriquez, executive director of the Garment Contractors Association, said: "Something like we saw in El Monte, with the slavery and barbed wire, is extremely rare. Unfortunately, it is not rare to find illegal contractors who are not registered with the state."
He added: "The company that isn't registered is probably violating minimum wage laws or overtime laws. That's what gives our industry a bad name."
At the El Monte factory, workers sewed strips of ready-to-wear garments, some of which ended up in major stores on the East Coast like Macy's, Hecht's and Filene's, Ms. Bradshaw said today. Spokesmen for several companies said today that they had no knowledge that laws were being broken.
Jim Abrams, a spokesman for May Department Stores, owner of both Filene's and Hecht's, said, "Our purchase orders clearly require vendors to comply with the Labor Standards Act and all applicable regulations."
He added, "We are in the process of attempting to ascertain if in fact this incident in El Monte involves merchandise being manufactured for delivery to any May division and, if so, the vendor involved."
Carol Sanger, a spokeswoman for Federated Department Stores, the owner of Macy's, said: "The first we heard about it was what we read in the paper this morning. And we have tried to get in touch with the appropriate authorities in California to find out what exactly it is that they found, because we have no knowledge of the operation, no record of ever doing business with any vendor or subcontractor with any operations in El Monte.
"The situation is appalling and would not be anything we condone."
Chanchanit Mortorell, executive director of the Thai Community Development Center in Los Angeles and one of the first people to see the El Monte factory after the raid, said there were numerous violations of health and safety laws at the site.
"When the authorities asked the workers to open the doors, they couldn't," she said. "They were locked from the outside. The police had to ax down each door. Everyone was shocked and terrified."
Another community leader, Nongyao Varanond, president of Thai Inc., a service program, said that of the shops she had visited, "only a few are like the one in El Monte." She added, "The others are usually in good condition, but the workers are paid less than the minimum wage.
"They don't have any place to go," Ms. Varanond said. "Where else can they find a job here? All of them are illegal."

HEADLINE: Esoteric Wedge of Academia Is Roiled by Hunt for Bomber

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
Last October an agent from the Federal Bureau of Investigation showed up in New Orleans at the annual meeting of The History of Science Society, the main professional gathering for academics studying the origins of science and how it has transformed the world.
The agenda featured esoteric items like a discussion of 19th-century social attitudes toward the germ theory and a detailed analysis of the inks that Galileo used in one of his manuscripts. 
 Carrying court papers, the agent subpoenaed the society's membership records and questioned scholars for clues to the identity of the serial killer, often called the Unabomber, who in 17 years has killed three people and injured 23 others with homemade bombs.
That subpoena, and the disclosure that the F.B.I. believes that the bomber is immersed in the most radical interpretations of the history of science, has roiled the usually placid waters of the discipline. And across the country, professors have begun reconsidering old suspicions, acquaintances and tracts to help solve the crimes.
"They've thrown a bomb into the community," said Stanley Goldberg, a science historian in Washington. "My impression is that we're all scurrying around in our minds, thinking of people who might be suspects."
The bureau had detected the bomber's interest in the history of science, as well as other disciplines including behavioral psychology, by poring over letters he had sent to newspapers and to intended victims as long ago as a decade. The 35,000-word manifesto that he sent to The New York Times and two other publications in late June not only corroborated that interest but also gave the bureau insight into the issues that concerned the bomber, the depth of his reading and the authors he respected.
More than a few historians of science, who blanched at the possible link between their usually staid area of study and the object of the most intense manhunt in F.B.I. history, have taken pains to distance the discipline from a maniacal murderer who seems to be familiar with their debates and lines of thinking.
But Landon Winner, a political scientist and technology expert at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y., said he was disappointed the F.B.I. had not consulted with him on the bomber. "I feel left out," Dr. Winner said. "It's like being left off the guest list for a really good party."
Scholars of the history of science investigate the origins of science from the Babylonians and Greeks onward. They study figures like Ptolemy, Copernicus, Newton, Galileo, Mendel and the Curies, and examine questions like how calculus was developed, and how telescopes, atom smashers and computers were invented and helped change the world.
In some history departments with no emphasis on the subject, professors sometimes believe that their pursuits are not considered as serious as political or philosophical history. "It was always regarded as a quixotic thing they let me play with," said Professor Harold Bauman, who has taught a variety of history courses for 30 years at the University of Utah in Salt Lake City.
Mr. Bauman has been interviewed three times by the F.B.I. since the bomber left a booby trap bomb on the Utah campus in October 1981; the device was defused before anyone was hurt. He said he was scheduled to be interviewed again by the F.B.I. yesterday and to be shown a copy of the manifesto to review.
Several other professors in the field have also been given copies of the tract, which condemns technological society and the scientific progress that scholars in this arcane field usually champion.
"They've got to be desperate," said David C. Lindberg, a physicist at the University of Wisconsin who specializes in medieval optics and religion and who is president of The History of Science Society. "These are extremely tenuous inferences they're making. But if it's the only thing they've got, then it seems to make sense."
Some academics, while endorsing the bureau's all-out search, take umbrage at the mention of their field and the bomber in the same breath.
"It's like saying an appreciation of Beethoven has something to do with the Nazis," said David A. Hollinger, a professor of history at the University of California at Berkeley.
Dr. Hollinger maintained that the ideas he read in newspaper excerpts of the bomber's manifesto were less out of the realm of the history of science than "generally from a more amorphous critical discourse that moves out of environmental groups and religious groups and some literary discourses."
"I would be looking more toward alternative education courses of the 70's," he said.
While conservative and scholarly for the most part, and sometimes downright stuffy, the field of history of science also has undercurrents and factions that have sometimes mounted intellectual attacks on the science establishment, blaming the military, industrial and academic worlds for social ills like unemployment and pollution.
That radical milieu seems to have been the breeding ground for the bomber, whose treatise says that science and the industrial revolution have undermined human values and calls for returning to a pre-industrial world better in tune with nature.
This week Director Louis J. Freeh of the F.B.I. announced that agents were talking to college professors around the country about the manifesto. The bureau, Mr. Freed said in a statement, "is taking this investigative step in an effort to determine whether that community might recognize the writer's work or be able to shed light on important or telltale aspects of the manuscript's general topic, the history of science."
In its hunt for the bomber's origins, the F.B.I. is focusing on Northwestern University and the Chicago campus of the University of Illinois, where the bureau believes that the killer might have lived in the late 1970's.
In the course of its inquiry, the agency has sown dissension among university officials quick to disclaim any kind of culpability.
"This is a working-class campus," Jan Rocek, dean of the graduate school of the University of Illinois at Chicago, said in an interview. "These characters tend to come out of more affluent families."
Charles Loebbaka, a spokesman for Northwestern, said, "University officials are cooperating with the F.B.I. and have been for sometime." But Mr. Loebbaka refused further comment, saying details would have to come from the F.B.I.
Over the decades, historians and writers like Lewis Mumford, Jacques Ellul, Theodore Roszak and Herbert Muller have worried that science systematically ignores human values. And even strongly pro-science historians admit that science tends to sow cultural discord because it is such a powerful agent of social change.
In the 1970's, the intellectual critique of the science establishment turned acid and sometimes violent as it joined with and was amplified by protests against the Vietnam War. Groups like Science for the People, a leftist organization, used confrontational tactics to disrupt meetings of scientists and to push for wider debate on the social devastation wrought by science and its ugly offspring, like napalm and nuclear weapons.
Science for the People was well-organized in the Chicago area, sponsoring meetings at the various universities and helping finance anti-war pamphlets. Its membership included all kinds of scientists, not just historians and philosophers.
After the August 1970 bombing of the Army Math Research Center at the University of Wisconsin in Madison, in which a researcher was killed, the Chicago collective of Science for the People helped finance a 119-page "indictment" of the math project, which was denounced as a "deadly power center" working against "the peoples of the world fighting for liberation."
The F.B.I., which often infiltrated such anti-war groups in the 1970's, has not indicated whether it is looking at the membership of the Chicago collective for clues. But some historians say that it should as a possible aid to tracking down the killer.
"This is a bright guy, but he doesn't know as much history of science as the F.B.I. thinks he does," said Dr. Goldberg, the science historian in Washington, who has read published excerpts of the bomber's manifesto. "He's on the fringes. It's more of a counterculture thing."
Keith R. Benson, the executive secretary of The History of Science Society, which is based in Seattle at the University of Washington, agreed. Mr. Benson said that, based on his talks with F.B.I. agents and his examination of the evidence, the killer was a knowledgeable outcast rather than a mainstream scholar.
"My suspicion is that this guy lurked around the halls of academia rather than being a graduate student," Mr. Benson said. "He's unbelievably sophisticated. He's covered his tracks."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Keith R. Benson, of The History of Science Society, said he believed that the serial bomber was a knowledgeable outcast rather than a mainstream scholar. (Loren Callahan/Seattle Post-Intelligencer) (pg. 7)
 
Map/Diagram: "WHERE IT HAPPENED: Tracking the Serial Bomber"
 In its effort to track down the terrorist whose bombs have killed three and injured 23 others in the past 17 years, the F.B.I. now believes that the bomber is a student of science history who may have taken classes or spent time at some university campuses from the late 1970's to the mid-1980's. Of the 16 bombing incidents, nine were at Universities or the homes of professors. (pg. 7)

HEADLINE: Dole Offers Welfare Bill, But Conservatives Reject It

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, set the stage today for a bitter debate over welfare policy as he introduced a compromise bill intended to overcome splits within the Republican Party. Conservatives immediately criticized it, saying it would not significantly reduce the number of babies born to unmarried women.
With the floor debate expected to begin on Saturday, Senator Dole and other Republicans were moving to the right in the hope of rounding up 51 votes for their bill. But in the process, they seemed to be diminishing their chances of winning support from moderate Republicans and conservative Democrats. So the outcome is in doubt. 
 Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, chairman of the Senate Republican Policy Committee, said: "Senator Dole's bill does what President Clinton said he wanted to do. It ends welfare as we know it."
Preliminary estimates by the Congressional Budget Office show that Mr. Dole's bill would save $70 billion, or 10 percent of the amount that would otherwise be spent in the next seven years on Aid to Families With Dependent Children, food stamps, Supplemental Security Income and child nutrition programs. The savings would be achieved by giving each state a fixed amount of money, or block grant, for cash assistance to poor people, and by changing the rules for determining eligibility and benefits in the other programs.
Aides to Mr. Dole said today that, after weeks of negotiations with conservatives, he was distressed to learn that the Christian Coalition had denounced the latest version of his bill. Brian C. Lopina, chief lobbyist for the coalition, told the Senator that "we will not support your bill in its current form" because it "will do little to change the alarming increase of illegitimacy."
Conservatives contend that the Government could discourage out-of-wedlock births by cutting off welfare payments to unwed teen-age mothers and by rewarding states that reduce such births. But some economists and sociologists suggest that the Government cannot alter behavior in that way.
Asked about the criticism, Mr. Dole, a Kansas Republican, said, "There is a split among conservatives on some of these issues." He said he was being true to conservative principles by arguing that the Federal Government should let governors decide how to deal with social problems like illegitimate births.
But Senator John Ashcroft, a conservative Republican from Missouri, said Mr. Dole's bill fell short on many counts. The bill, which would create a new Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services to supervise welfare programs, does not do enough to curtail Federal "meddling," Mr. Ashcroft said.
Democrats said they were pleased to see the splits in Republican ranks. But they have their own problems. In a meeting with Administration officials on Thursday, Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and Barbara A. Mikulski of Maryland complained that the White House was sending mixed signals.
A person who attended the meeting said the Democrats feared that Mr. Clinton would sign legislation like the Dole bill if it was "improved" in a few ways -- for example, with an amendment requiring states to continue spending their own money as a condition of getting Federal welfare grants.
The President's press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said there was "not an insurmountable distance" between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole.
"They could probably sit down and finish an acceptable bill and do it, you know, even before they go away for summer recess, if they wanted to," Mr. McCurry said. "The problem is that the extreme faction within the Republican majority in Congress keeps yanking the debate farther and farther to the right."
Mr. Dole's bill would end the longstanding Federal guarantee of cash assistance for poor families with children. States would have new freedom to decide who receives welfare benefits, and they would no longer have to put up any of their own money.
Mr. Dole's bill would require states to move half of their adult welfare recipients into jobs by the year 2000. Fewer than 10 percent of the five million adults on welfare are now employed.
Gordon L. Berlin, senior vice president of the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, a private group that has studied job programs across the country, said, "The work requirements in Senator Dole's bill could not be met by even the most successful job programs of the type established in Atlanta, Riverside County, Calif., and Grand Rapids, Mich."
Mr. Dole's bill would allow, but not require, states to deny aid to unmarried mothers under the age of 18, legal aliens and additional children born to families already receiving welfare. A companion bill passed by the House in March goes further, requiring states to cut off assistance in such cases.
The House bill would also authorize financial bonuses for states that reduce out-of-wedlock births. Mr. Dole's bill contains no such provision, but would require unwed teen-age mothers to live at home with their parents or guardians or in other places supervised by adults.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

House Votes Radical Shift In Phone and Cable Laws
The House approved a radical change in communications laws for the first time in six decades. Members voted 305 to 117 for vastly reduced regulations on everything from cable television to local and long-distance telephone services. The bill would give the Baby Bells something they have long sought: the right to enter the long-distance market.
 But in a setback for the television networks, House Democrats curbed some of the legislation's strongest elements of deregulation, winning key amendments to limit media ownership and to mandate that all new television sets include technology that would allow parents to block out programs with violence or sexual content. [Page 1.]
 
Having passed a spending bill and the telecommunications bill, the House adjourned for a monthlong recess in a wave of partisan sparring. [1.]
 
Edward J. Markey, an archetypal liberal Democrat, fought the conservative tide and won approval of two important changes in the House bill, relating to program coding and station ownership. [32.]
 
Tighter Rules for Lobbyists
President Clinton said he would soon tighten the rules for contacts between lobbyists and the Executive Branch and chided Speaker Newt Gingrich for the House's "delay, debate and division" on the measure. [9.]
 
Suit Dismissed on Nasdaq Trading
A suit against Nasdaq market makers was dismissed by a Federal judge, but both sides said they expected the plaintiffs to refile it soon. The State of Louisiana and some 30 private investors argued that big Wall Street firms had benefited from wide price spreads in the stocks that they bought and sold to private investors. The defendants included dozens of firms. [35.]
 
Rail Streamlining Is Predicted
Union Pacific and Southern Pacific Rail executives expressed confidence that their union would promote greater efficiency and service. Securities analysts largely agreed, suggesting shippers would benefit from lower rates to come. [33.]
 
Atlantic Bank Fined $1.1 Million
Atlantic Bank of New York was fined $1.1 million after it pleaded guilty to helping its clients avoid declaring large cross-border transactions. The bank is a unit of the National Bank of Greece and has strong ties to the Greek-American community. [34.]
 
Phone Strike Deadline Near
Four of eight regional telephone companies face strike threats by the Communications Workers of America if contracts are not reached by midnight. The 164,000 workers involved include operators, repair personnel, technicians and other employees. The companies are: Bell Atlantic, Ameritech, Bell South and Pacific Telesis. [7.]
 
Recycling Plant for New York
Pratt Industries of Australia agreed to build a $250 million waste paper recycling plant in Staten Island, which will be the first of its kind in New York. [22.]
 
Sweatshops Are Flourishing
At least one-fifth of the garment workers in Los Angeles are toiling in unregulated, sweatshop conditions, labor officials, economists and union organizers said. Experts said that employers take advantage of the workers' legal status, naivete and cultural alienation, despite a host of regulations intended to shut down the companies. [6.]

Stocks Drift Lower
Blue-chip stocks sagged in lethargic trading, although technology issues rebounded. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 17.96 points, closing at 4,683.46, which was off 32.05 points for the week. Walt Disney gave up some of its gains from earlier in the week, slipping 1 3/8, to 58. Oil stocks dropped on prospects for lower earnings. [35.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities rose modestly, after the employment report suggested there was still weakness in the economy, easing fears of rapid growth and rising inflation. [34.]
 
The dollar rose to a 21-week high of 91.43 yen, as traders suspected the Bank of Japan and the Federal Reserve would intervene in the market to drive up the dollar. [41.]

WAR FLARES ANEW IN CROATIA
The Croatian Government launched a long-threatened offensive to retake a swath of territory that has been under the control of rebel Serbs since 1991. 1
 

CROATIA URGED TO HALT ATTACK

HEADLINE: Unemployment Rises Slightly In New York and New Jersey

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
Unemployment rose in New York and New Jersey last month, but Labor Department officials said yesterday that the increases were small enough to allay any concerns about a regional economic downturn.
 "We're still in a holding pattern," John L. Wieting, the regional commissioner for the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said in an interview. "The situation has been pretty flat for nearly six months, and July brought no signs of improvement." He added, "But the fact that there has been no real deterioration is somewhat of a postive sign." 
 The unemployment rate in New York State rose to 6.2 percent in July from 5.9 percent in June. In New Jersey, the rate went up to 6.8 percent from 6.6 percent. Nationally, unemployment increased to 5.7 percent from 5.6 percent.
 New York City's unemployment rate provided a contrast, decreasing to 7.8 percent, from 8.1 percent in June. However, labor officials emphasized that the city's figures were not seasonally adjusted and that summer employment had pushed down the rate.
 Mr. Wieting said the city gained 90,000 jobs, an increase he termed encouraging. But as with the rest of the region, the city's economy remains essentially stagnant, he said.
 Connecticut is not one of the states for which employment data are released in the first batch of monthly statistics from Washington. In both June and May, the jobless rate in Connecticut was 5.1 percent.
 Mr. Wieting said the relatively small increases in the New Jersey and New York jobless rates were a sign that the region was not entering an economic downturn that some economists had feared. In fact, he said the number of people employed in July increased by 100,000 in New York State, a rise that he described as "a sizable increase in labor market activity." Still, even more people than that entered the labor market, resulting in the higher unemployment rate.
 In New York City, he said, an increase in employment in the private sector was being offset by the reduction of city government jobs by the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
 Mr. Wieting said the flat labor market had reduced upward pressure on wages, keeping the inflation rate low.

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Edged Higher Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
The economy shed factory jobs at an accelerated pace in July, as the unemployment rate edged up one-tenth of a point, to 5.7 percent, the Labor Department reported today.
 The Clinton Administration expressed disappointment in the figures, which came after a more upbeat series of recent reports had given signs that housing, consumer spending and even industry were rebounding from the economy's flat overall performance in the spring. 
 Despite evidence that consumers are in better spirits, analysts said companies remained uneasy because of still-high inventories and the lingering effects of a yearlong run-up in interest rates, which has only recently begun to reverse.
 "Businesses remain very cautious about hiring and producing," said Mickey D. Levy, chief financial economist at Nationsbank. He said that because of job uncertainty and other factors, he did not expect the upturn in consumption to continue, a view apparently shared by many of those who manage companies.
 The 85,000 factory jobs lost last month were in all areas of industry. Temporary shutdowns of auto plants for model change-overs were a relatively minor factor, analysts said. With July's drop in industrial employment -- the biggest in three and a half years and the fourth consecutive decline -- 188,000 factory workers have lost their jobs since March.
 Retail trade and other service jobs expanded enough to swell payrolls by 55,000 over all, but these gains were only mediocre and included a rise of 45,000 in relatively low-paying jobs in restaurants and bars.
 Today's report also showed a second consecutive hefty rise in hourly earnings. That caused nervousness among bond traders but not among economists, who generally saw it as something to be watched closely but not yet as a source of concern about rising inflation.
 Today's report seemed to have little effect on expectations of whether the Federal Reserve would cut short-term interest rates again. The weak job growth, which would tend to support such action, was accompanied by higher earnings, which give pause to those pushing for rate cuts. Most analysts continued to say that the Fed would take no action on rates at its next policy meeting, on Aug. 22.
 Data released today showed that the earnings of private production workers climbed 7 cents an hour in July and 5 cents in June after averaging increases of less than 3 cents for the 12 months through May. But because earnings figures are quite erratic, Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, said, "We will need to see additional months' data before concluding that the underlying growth rate of this earnings series has changed."
 She noted that a 16-cent rise in the four months that began in July 1994 proved temporary and suggested that the 15-cent rise in the latest four months might be similarly benign.
 Indeed, Joseph E. Stiglitz, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, called the advance in hourly earnings, along with a rise in aggregate production hours, which were up five-tenths of 1 percent in July, "a welcome boost to income."
 He predicted job growth would be 100,000 to 200,000 a month, probably at the lower end of that range, for the foreseeable future.
 The department's survey of payrolls also showed a 6-minute lengthening of the workweek despite a 12-minute decline in weekly factory hours. The percentage of manufacturing industries adding to payrolls skidded to 35.3 last month, the lowest that figure has been since April 1991, when the most recent recession had just ended.
Somewhat cushioning disappointment over the modest expansion of 55,000 in payrolls -- less than half what was forecast -- was a revision upward in June's gain to 250,000 from 215,000.
 The department's survey of households showed 474,000 more people with jobs, not enough to offset the 649,000 people who joined the labor force, and thus the unemployment rate moved up a statistically insignificant one-tenth of a point.
 Adult women dominated the job gains, which were partly offset by a drop among teen-agers, whose unemployment rate surged 1.8 points, to 18.2 percent.
 A total of 7.78 million workers, or 6.1 percent, held two or more jobs in July, up from 7.17 million, or 5.8 percent a year earlier, the report also showed.
 "Something is going on here," Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary, said in an interview, calling "the stress on family wages" a significant national problem.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Just What They Asked For: Higher Transit Fares

BYLINE: By Joyce Purnick 

 BODY:
THE most urgent question on this city's political table right now is whether transit fares will rise this fall, as the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority proposed this week. The smart betting is yes, for the most basic of reasons: New Yorkers voted for it, whether they realized it or not.
 They voted George E. Pataki into office last November, and Governor Pataki did what candidate Pataki promised he would do: He cut taxes. But tax cuts inevitably come at a cost. The changes in income taxes and business taxes enacted last spring weren't really cuts, they were tax shifts. If New Yorkers would tell themselves the truth, they would realize that the proposed transit increases are actually a tax increase, one that falls less on the Republican, suburban electorate that voted for Mr. Pataki and more on New York City residents who by and large did not. 
 If the increases proposed this week by the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority go through as proposed, bus and subway fares in New York City would rise 20 percent, to $1.50 from $1.25, while commuter railroad fares would go up 9 percent, and the round trip tolls on the M.T.A.'s bridges and tunnels would increase to $7 from $6, an increase of 16.7 percent. The authority chairman, E. Virgil Conway, also threatened to eliminate free- and reduced-fare rides for students.
 Mr. Conway's announcement was no doubt the opening shot in a negotiation, and it may be that the bus and subway fares will not rise the full 25 cents or, finally, that students will have to pay their way to school. But transportation increases of some magnitude are clearly on the way.
 Unless the economy rebounds, the state cut in income taxes and business taxes will mean lost revenues of over $600 million in the current fiscal year, and more in the future. Mr. Conway proposed the fare increases because the city transit system and suburban railroads are facing a budget gap of $388 million next year.
IT would be naive to assume that all of the lost tax revenue would have gone to the transit system if the tax cuts hadn't been enacted. But government policy reflects political choices. Surely with more money around, officials might not have proposed raising the fares as much, or charging students who ride to school.
 "For a guy who said 'lower taxes' all over the place, this is a tax on the working class," said the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer. "If you've got two kids in school, you're paying $1,000 a year. You tell these people 'I'm going raise taxes on your home $1,000,' there would be a French Revolution!"
 Why the concept of a tax shift is so difficult is one of the more baffling aspects of politics today. Or maybe people do understand and figure that as long as someone else shoulders the burden and they save a few bucks, it's O.K. In any case, somebody has to pay.
 The same is true of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's arguments about the student fares. The Mayor is furious that Mr. Conway says that even with fare increases, the M.T.A. won't be able to afford the free and reduced fares. The Mayor's anger is understandable: If the city really does make students pay for bus and subway rides to school for the first time since 1948, the Mayor will no doubt take the political hit.
 Mr. Giuliani says it costs nothing extra to transport students. "It costs the M.T.A. absolutely zero," he said. "No money to provide free transportation to public school students. The trains run anyway. The trains run at those hours anyway. The trains have precisely the same staffing levels." He feels the M.T.A. is using the issue to get more money from the city. "It's a subsidy," he said.
OF course it is. That is the point. There is no added expense to carry the students, but there is a cost to the Transit Authority if it loses the subsidy. The money was always no more, or less, than the city's contribution to the cost of running the system. Absent that subsidy, the budget gap will have to be made up somehow, because when Mr. Giuliani decided to withhold $128 million for student fares -- which gave Mr. Pataki the excuse to withhold part of the state's contribution -- the Mayor really just enlarged the Transit Authority's deficit.
 Mr. Giuliani says the system is poorly and expensively run and filled with cuttable fat, just like the Board of Education. But he does not control the semiautonomous M.T.A. any more than he controls the school board; in fact, less. The Transportation Authority is headed by an appointee of the Governor, Mr. Conway, and the 17-member board is made up mostly of Pataki choices. The Mayor has only 4 appointees.
 The authority could find other cuts to keep the student program. Or given the devastating appearance of being the first mayor to break with a 47-year tradition of paying students' way to school, the Mayor, the Governor and the Legislature will come up with a compromise. But the deficits are not going away. "The Mayor can't have it both ways," said Gene Russianoff, staff attorney for the Straphangers Campaign. "He can't cut the system by millions of dollars without putting huge pressure on the fare and service."
 Just as with the missing tax revenues, the money will have to come from somewhere, because government still delivers services to the people. The voters who so predictably elect candidates who promise tax cuts conveniently forget that.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up Again vs. Yen, Reaching a 21-Week High

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar climbed to a 21-week high against the Japanese yen yesterday on speculation that the Bank of Japan and the Federal Reserve were planning to enter the currency markets again to support the dollar.
 The yen has weakened against the dollar and European currencies since Wednesday, when the Japanese Government announced plans aimed at reining in the yen. 
 In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 91.43 yen, up from 90.52 late Thursday and the highest level since mid-March.
 The central banks of the United States and Japan staged a surprise intervention in the currency markets on Wednesday, aggressively buying dollars and selling yen. Earlier that day, Japan said it would make it easier for its insurance companies and other financial institutions to invest abroad, thus increasing the potential demand for dollars.
 Since Wednesday, traders have been cautious about taking the dollar too low, fearing that the central banks might move in again.
 "Everyone was watching to see if the central banks would return," said Peggy Reed, vice president at Credit Agricole in New York.
 While there was no confirmation of any intervention yesterday, Ms. Reed said that some traders were "suspicious" that the central banks were active because even when there was selling, "the dollar would not go lower."
 The dollar also jumped against the German mark on speculation that Germany's central bank might cut interest rates next week. Lower German rates would make mark-denominated interest rates less attractive to investors.
 In New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.3972 marks, up from 1.3909 marks.
 Analysts said the currency markets mostly shrugged off a Labor Department report that showed the increase in jobs in July was lower than had been expected.
