HEADLINE: Circling the Grocery Carts;
Stop & Shop Plans a Foothold in the New York Region

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

DATELINE: QUINCY, Mass.

 BODY:
The Yankees are coming.
 Stop & Shop, the supermarket leader by a mile in southern New England with well-managed stores that have been praised for their variety and spaciousness, has begun a southward push into what its executives, like Whitehall officials, call "the new territories": the suburbs of New York City. 
 For shoppers in the New York metropolitan area, this could be good news. Many local supermarkets fall far short of their counterparts in other regions. Many of the stores are old and small, with uninspired service, selection and ambiance, and limited parking. The Stop & Shop Companies, with sophisticated distribution, deep pockets, giant-store mentality and competitive chutzpah, is the antithesis of stodgy supermarket retailing.
 But for Stop & Shop, a company whose majority owner is Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the move is a daring one. High-quality supermarket chains from other regions have been wary of attacking this fortress of a market because of high costs for labor, real estate and transportation, said Mark Husson, a retail analyst at J. P. Morgan Securities.
 Stop & Shop, an 81-year-old chain based in this city south of Boston, has 130 stores, including 103 so-called superstores of 60,000 square feet each. With 3.5 million regular customers in southern New England and $3.8 billion in revenue, it has a market share of 23 percent, as large as that of its next four competitors combined.
 Though the company is tight-lipped on the subject, analysts say Stop & Shop plans to establish a beachhead of at least 30 superstores in the New York metropolitan area before the millennium, and will continue expanding after that. Joseph D. McGlinchey, chief financial officer of Stop & Shop, said the first superstore in the New York area, already under construction in South Setauket in Suffolk County on Long Island, will open next March. Stop & Shop has announced plans to open stores in New Jersey in East Rutherford, Morris Plains, Piscataway, Springfield and Wayne, and on Long Island in East Islip and Roslyn. Four or five of these should be up and running within a year. The company is also looking for sites in Westchester County, but will not say where.
 Why move south now? "In three or four years we'll reach our saturation point here," Mr. McGlinchey said. "We've got to go south to where the population is. There are more people on Long Island than there are in Connecticut, and in Connecticut we already have 52 stores."
 Indigenous chains are talking tough on invasion eve. "Every chain in this area is a street fighter when it comes to protecting their turf, and there's going to be a battle," said Stan Sorkin, a spokesman for Pathmark Stores, part of Supermarkets General Holdings. He stood in the wide aisles of a 59,000-square-foot, 8-month-old store in North Hackensack, N.J., that is a prototype for Pathmark's defense against Stop & Shop and others.
 It is the newest of the chain's "Pathmark 2000" stores, and greets entering customers with its Fresh Foods Plaza, a track-lit celebration of fresh fruits and vegetables, fresh-fish displays and deli counters. The chain has renovated or built 30 stores as Pathmark 2000 superstores; it also has 70 older stores in the New York metropolitan area. Pathmark hopes to upgrade 30 stores a year, but may not have the resources, because of its debt burden from a 1987 leveraged buyout.
 The market-share leaders in metropolitan New York are the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, including A & P, Food Emporium and Waldbaum's, with 18 percent; Pathmark, 16 percent, and Shop Rite, 15 percent, according to A. C. Nielsen data. A & P also professes aplomb about the Stop & Shop challenge. "We're bigger than they are, so we're not too frightened," said Michael J. Rourke, a spokesman for A & P, which has 1,100 stores in 23 states and Canada and is controlled by the Tengelmann Group of Germany. Three hundred of the stores are in the New York metropolitan area. "We know the territory pretty well, since we started in New York in 1859," he said.
 Last month, A & P opened a 60,000-square-foot superstore in Mahwah, N.J., and broke ground for another in Woodcliff Lake, N.J. It plans to have eight superstores in metropolitan New York in the next year.
 Shop Rite, another major competitor, includes groups of independent stores with no public financing and shallower pockets. Shop Rite did not return repeated phone calls.
 Money is less of a problem for Stop & Shop, which spent $150 million last year on capital expenditures alone and will do so again this year. "Many of Stop & Shop's competitors just don't have this kind of money to invest," said Clifton S. Robbins, a general partner of Kohlberg, Kravis, which owns 62.2 percent of the publicly traded Stop & Shop. He is one of five Kohlberg, Kravis directors on the nine-member board of Stop & Shop.
 Kohlberg, Kravis's initial investment of $100 million in the chain in 1988 is now worth more than $800 million, and the stock, which traded at $12.50 at the initial public offering in 1991, now trades at $27.125 on the New York Stock Exchange. "If Stop & Shop needed more money from us, we'd put it in, but they don't need it," Mr. Robbins said.
 Stop & Shop will finance the expansion with its own cash flow of $230 million, he said.
 The average Stop & Shop superstore has "60,000 square feet of awesome food retailing, with the highest sales per square foot in mainstream food retailing," said Mr. Husson, the J. P. Morgan analyst, who recently issued a report about Stop & Shop titled "Heavily Armed and Moving South."
 "When these supermarkets show up in northern New Jersey and Long Island," he added, "people will say, 'Wow.' "
 The chain, which has a profit margin of 8 percent, among the highest in the business, is "top drawer, with some very powerful friends," Mr. Husson said, referring to Kohlberg, Kravis and the two other supermarket chains in which the firm has a major interest -- Safeway and Vons. For example, Stop & Shop's premium private-label brand can be sold at a competitive price because it benefits from the economies of scale in purchasing with Safeway and Vons.
 Mr. Husson, who has rated the company as a long-term buy, called Stop & Shop "sharp at regional and ethnic marketing, and very good at merchandising to large Jewish populations." He added that its sophisticated distribution system allowed it to leave few gaps on the shelves, and that the stores were given the freedom to compete aggressively on pricing.
 In its most recent survey on customer satisfaction with supermarkets, in 1993, Consumer Reports magazine rated Stop & Shop in the first tier, based on the opinions of 10,000 readers. By contrast, three of Stop & Shop's future competitors finished last: Pathmark, the third worst; Grand Union, the second worst, and A & P, last out of 23 chains.
 Shop Rite fared better than its local competitors, but still finished below Stop & Shop.
 The 68,000-square-foot Stop & Shop superstore in Watertown, Mass., is typical of the chain's newer stores, with their large fish markets and produce and floral sections, pharmacies, bookstores and bakeries stocked with 600 items. The store has a full-service Baybank branch, and brings in many customers like Anthony Gentile, who arrived "to make a deposit at the bank, and so here I am in the fish aisle."
 "Let me tell you," he said. "I think the buys and the service here are very good."
 Ray Viola, the manager of the store, said it used a computer to help study customer traffic and plan staffing. The store tries to have enough workers to open a new register if more than one person is waiting, he said.
 Stop & Shop's store work force is 92 percent unionized in New England, according to the company, and Brian W. Hotarek, Stop & Shop's senior vice president for real estate, said it expected to be 100 percent unionized in the New York metropolitan area. About 300 jobs will be created with each new store, although other jobs may be lost if Stop & Shop gains customers from competitors.
 The Stop & Shop invasion is still a formidable gamble. The chain "must surmount the hurdles of new-market entry," said Gary M. Giblen, a retail expert who is a managing director at Smith Barney. "The graveyards are littered with the bodies of supermarket chains that have tried new-market entry as a major part of their strategy."
He cited disastrous moves by two chains that survived nonetheless: Food Lion, which tried to segue into Texas and Florida, and Smith's Food and Drug, which entered Arizona and Southern California.
 One barrier for Stop & Shop could be real estate. In the South and West, chains like Publix have capitalized on the availability of low-cost land to build larger stores. In the New York area, almost all the land is occupied. And expensive.
 Even finding a site is no guarantee of success. In Roslyn Village, L.I., where Stop & Shop has invested hundreds of thousands of dollars working on the site and the foundation for a superstore, some residents have tried to invalidate the supermarket's building permit, citing potential congestion and environmental damage.
 Two weeks ago, Stop & Shop fought back with a $26 million lawsuit in the Federal District Court for the Eastern District of New York, contending that village officials had violated the company's civil and property rights.
 The problems in Roslyn may be good news to Stop & Shop's competitors, but will only delay an inevitable reckoning with the chain. When the first Stop & Shop superstores are built, Mr. Giblen said, the most competitive of the local supermarket chains "will drop their prices and increase the amount of labor in their stores."
 "And then?" he said. "Shoppers will have a movable feast."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Obscure Global Bank Moves Into the Light

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
In a small Swiss city sits an international organization so obscure and secretive that for many years visitors got lost looking for a small plaque next to an otherwise undistinguished doorway.
 Control of the institution, the Bank for International Settlements, lies with some of the world's most powerful and least visible men: the heads of 32 central banks, officials able to shift billions of dollars and alter the course of economies at the stroke of a pen. For years, the United States participated in the closed conclaves of the Basel-based bank only as an observer, having turned down a chance to join the bank upon its founding in 1930. 
 Now, however, the bank is stepping out of the shadows a bit. Last September, the Federal Reserve, the United States' central bank, officially joined -- quietly and discreetly, of course -- and in June, Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, participated in the bank's annual meeting for the first time.
 Two other events this year have brought attention to the institution. Last winter, the bank agreed to put up $10 billion of the American-led $47 billion in credit for the bailout of Mexico. And in the last two months, the chairmen of the biggest central banks attended closed-door meetings held by the bank and subsequently cut some interest rates, giving the appearance of coordination.
 At the same time, the bank is beginning to draw the attention of the same unlikely array of American populists who have opposed the new World Trade Organization. From the consumer advocate Ralph Nader to Patrick J. Buchanan, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, these critics of foreign entanglements are beginning to add the Bank for International Settlements to their warnings.
 The Federal Reserve's decision to join the institution "is a major surrender of American sovereignty," Mr. Buchanan said. "This is going to be really the global bank that they're creating -- the global central bank."
 If elected, Mr. Buchanan said, he would demand an audit of the Federal Reserve and its various commitments, including its participation in the bank.
 Mr. Nader objects to the bank's unusual independence under international law, including an exemption from many Swiss laws. "It's outside the rule of law," he said. "It's above the law."
 A few liberal Democrats in Congress have also taken an interest in the bank, and one of them, Representative Paul E. Kanjorski of Pennsylvania, tried last year to persuade the Federal Reserve to delay joining the bank until studies could be done and hearings held.
 Fed officials defend the institution and its meetings as too valuable to ignore. "The information, understanding and analyses acquired at these meetings and through the statistical activities carried out under B.I.S. auspices contribute to more effective and more efficient policies," the Fed said in a blandly worded article in its monthly bulletin, the closest it had ever come to announcing that it had joined the bank.
 The Bank for International Settlements plays host to 10 closed-door meetings a year of top officials from the world's 11 most powerful central banks. It coordinates the development of minimum capital standards -- cushions against losses -- for banks around the world; those standards have an indirect effect on interest rates and the availability of loans. And its staff does extensive research on topics of interest to central bankers, including influential work over the last few years on the risks and advantages of derivatives.
 Central banks own 84 percent of the bank's stock, while private individuals own the rest, including the shares that the United States did not buy in 1930. The voting rights to the shares belong to the country to which they were originally assigned, so the Federal Reserve was able to join last year without buying back the shares.
 Mr. Greenspan, in addition to playing a leading role in the Mexico bailout, has become an increasingly regular guest at monthly meetings of central bank officials in Basel, feeding speculation about whether the bank has become a forum for coordinated changes in interest rates. The central banks of France, Canada and Japan all cut rates within a day after the Federal Reserve did so on July 6, while the central bank of Switzerland cut rates and Canada cut rates again right after the last meeting in Basel on July 10.
 But international monetary officials and financial analysts contend that the rate cuts are a mostly coincidental response to similar economic and financial market conditions in many different countries. "I think countries are pursuing their own objectives in these cases -- when the U.S. reduces rates it makes it easier for other countries," said Allen Sinai, the chief economist at Lehman Brothers.
 With Republicans in control of Congress, critics of the Bank for International Settlements may not get far soon. Representative Jim Leach of Iowa, the Republican chairman of the House Banking Committee, is one of the bank's defenders.
 "My view is that in a time of intertangled and intertwined international finances," he said, "it would be irresponsible for the United States not to work constructively with the B.I.S., and to insure that United States interests are represented."

HEADLINE: Mr. Dole and Deregulation

 BODY:
Corporate managers perpetually squawk about costly, job-killing regulations that Washington dreams up for no good reason. They exaggerate, but they have a point. Yet few in the Senate listened until the majority leader, Bob Dole, took up the issue. Now there are two regulatory reform proposals -- one good and one bad -- before the Senate. Neither has enough votes to pass. A "rump" group of Democrats is grasping for a faulty compromise.
One bill, proposed by John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, would require agencies to weigh the costs as well as the benefits of health, safety and environmental regulations in order to weed out those that would do more harm than good. The idea is to use cost-benefit analysis to inform public debate. 
 The bill offered by Mr. Dole goes further, prescribing the steps that agencies must take to conduct cost-benefit analysis. This statutory micromanagement threatens sensible rule-making. Cost-benefit analysis is too inexact, too full of qualitative ruminations about non-quantifiable benefits, to yield decisive answers. Mr. Dole's exactitude is a recipe for paralysis because it offers industry numerous ways to tie up Federal rules in court. What does it mean, for example, that agencies must use the best information or examine all reasonable inferences in cost-benefit analysis? Lawyers will get rich trying to answer.
Mr. Dole also gives industry the right to petition agencies to review old regulations within a fixed period of time, and to challenge in court an agency that denies such a petition. The bill would thereby create insurmountable problems for fiscally strapped agencies, whose budgets the majority leader is simultaneously preparing to cut. They would have to devote huge resources to reviewing old rules, or let those rules die by default.
Ironically, another section of the Dole bill makes his system of judicial checks and balances unnecessary. Both he and Mr. Glenn propose giving Congress plenty of time to review, and reverse, Federal rules before they go into effect.
Neither the Dole nor the Glenn bill has enough votes to pass. A group of Democrats, led by Kent Conrad of North Dakota, seeks compromise. The group would amend the Dole bill by loosening deadlines so that agencies would have enough time to review rules of petitioning industries. The group would guarantee that provisions of the Clean Air Act and other existing laws are not overturned by the new legislation. It would also jettison Mr. Dole's attempt to gut the so-called Delaney Clause, which is aimed at keeping even the smallest trace of carcinogenic additives out of processed food.
Despite these improvements, however, Mr. Conrad apparently wants to preserve the fatal flaw in the Dole approach: statutory prescriptions for cost-benefit analysis that invite legal paralysis. If he does so, his so-called compromise will make sure that Federal rules clog the courts rather than keep pesticides out of baby food, pollutants out of the air and dangerous equipment out of the workplace.

HEADLINE: Stiffing Straphangers

 BODY:
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's need to raise fares and cut costs is an unavoidable consequence of huge cutbacks in Federal, state and city subsidies. But its remedy for this problem is warped, and the abruptness of its unveiling by the M.T.A. chairman, E. Virgil Conway, was impolitic to say the least. The plan penalizes New York City riders and threatens an economy that is the core of the metropolitan area's prosperity.
Local subway and bus fares paid by many low-income people within the city would go up 20 percent, while commuter railroad fares would rise by only 9 percent. Worse, free passes for city school students would be eliminated. 
 Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, with typical finesse, calls the plan "a piece of junk." He exaggerates, but his point is valid. Mr. Conway, appointed by Gov. George Pataki, has laid out a plan that treats New York City more harshly than the suburbs and also seems to be tilted toward Republican constituencies. Even within the city, it grants special allowances for outlying areas that tend to be predominantly Republican.
The proposed increase in subway and bus fares -- 25 cents, rising to $1.50 from $1.25 -- would be the biggest ever, though past increases have been larger in percentage terms. The M.T.A. rationalizes that the city transit system faces much larger deficits than the suburban railroads, but that does not excuse suddenly taxing families with children in school -- an additional cost of $3 a day for each child.
The M.T.A. has lost more than $250 million in city and state subsidies in the past year, including the $128 million city subsidy for student passes, and will lose $80 million more if Congress kills the Federal operating subsidy, as seems likely.
Mr. Giuliani contends that it costs the M.T.A. nothing extra to carry students since trains and buses run regardless of whether students are aboard. That is true in some measure as far as the economics of transporting students go. But the explanation glosses over the fact that the Giuliani administration is withdrawing a major subsidy. In budgetary terms, the fact that the subsidy was labeled for student costs is less important than the fact that the system got this annual payment.
Ending the free rides for schoolchildren is the M.T.A.'s way of trying to make Mr. Giuliani ante up again. But this is a situation that calls for negotiation rather than confrontation. The negotiations would have to touch on these points: The children cannot lose their transportation, and the cost cannot be dumped on working families. It is also going to be difficult for the city, given its own deficit problems, to provide the money. That means it might have to come from other sources, such as imposing higher railroad fares and tolls on suburbanites and delaying the M.T.A.'s $125 million annual allocation for capital expenditures.

HEADLINE: Journal;
The Disney Trap

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
When a TV set still had so few channels you could count them on your fingers, Americans constantly complained, "There's nothing on!" Now we've entered that long-awaited multi-channel nirvana. But except for those who can't get enough of sub-equatorial soccer and Capitol Hill bombast, who believes that the vast wasteland has given way to the promised land? Most nights there's still nothing on.
The phenomenon of hunger amidst cultural plenty is hardly unique to TV. The movie palace that once housed a single film is now a multiplex, but if you're not part of the teen-age common denominator, isn't it harder than ever to find something to see, no matter how many screens? A new book? The superstore dwarfs the old independent bookseller, but for all the extra titles, the variety in the mix seems less. 
 What's happened? One answer can be found in the deals that have steadily consolidated American show business in recent years -- crowned this week by Disney's purchase of ABC. Whatever joy this merger of Goliaths brings to shareholders -- and some correspondents covering the story for ABC had unmistakable stock-option dollar signs in their eyes -- the bottom line for consumers is a further constriction of our popular culture.
The fewer corporate giants who control the content of what we see, hear and read, the fewer the choices -- no matter how large the increase in outlets for their cultural products. Instead of being able to choose between, say, "Pocahontas" and "Crumb," a consumer will be able to choose only among "Pocahontas: The Movie," "Pocahontas: The Musical," "Pocahontas: The Novelization," "Pocahontas: The World Wide Web Site," "Pocahontas: The TV Show" and "Pocahontas: The Theme-Park Ride" -- especially if that consumer doesn't live in the big cities where a specialty item like "Crumb" will have to be tracked down.
I exaggerate, of course, and the Disney-ABC merger is not all bad news, even though it sadly reduces ABC News's corporate status to that of Time at Time Warner. Just the announcement of the deal was more entertaining than most Hollywood productions because it came as a genuine surprise, with no advance hype. (The secret was kept, it's been reported, because investment bankers, the agent Michael Ovitz and cellular phones were kept out of the loop.) Another fun aspect of the Disney deal was its upstaging of Laurence Tisch's announcement of CBS's sale to Westinghouse the very next day. Mr. Tisch's inept timing of CBS's betrothal to a semi-decrepit rust-belt suitor was the perfect parting metaphor for his destruction of William Paley's Tiffany network.
A more serious virtue of the Disney deal and the homogenized mass culture it perpetuates is as a societal tie that binds. As America becomes increasingly fractionalized politically, linguistically and economically, mass culture may be the last common tongue we have. If the country will never rally around Bill Clinton or Newt Gingrich, then maybe an all-powerful Disney-ABC can provide the icons to unify us -- much as Lucy and Desi served that purpose back in the era when a far smaller electronic arena could be dominated by Paley's relatively modest CBS.
But corporate culture, however pleasing, is still corporate. Designed to sell to as many customers as possible, it is no more personal than most assembly-line creations. To the extent a "Lion King" or "I Love Lucy" reveals a human touch, they're the exceptions, while "Congo" and last month's canceled sitcom are more than ever the rule.
In a corporate culture, original and idiosyncratic artistic voices, which by definition reach smaller markets, have trouble making themselves heard. As our entertainment behemoths become larger and fewer -- a process to be accelerated even faster by Congress's telecommunications bill -- those essential alternative voices will have to fight to keep from being drowned out entirely.
But they won't necessarily disappear. When pop culture becomes too oppressively white-bread, history tells us, its prized international teen-age market protests by putting its dollars elsewhere; all it took was a stoned Jack Nicholson in the bargain-basement "Easy Rider" to bring the elephantine Hollywood studios of the 60's to their knees. If there's an invigorating flip side to this week's victory for corporate culture, it's that a new counterculture is sure to rise up in revolt.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Ida Lupino, Film Actress and Director, Is Dead at 77

BYLINE: By PETER B. FLINT 

 BODY:
Ida Lupino, an earthy, intelligent movie actress who created a luminous gallery of worldly wise villainesses, gangster's molls and hand-wringing neurotics, died on Thursday night at her home in Burbank, Calif. She was 77 years old.
Miss Lupino had cancer and had recently suffered a stroke, Mary Ann Anderson, her former secretary, said yesterday. 
 The actress was also celebrated for directing eight provocative and socially relevant feature films and scores of episodes of many long-running television series, including "The Untouchables," "Have Gun, Will Travel" and "Alfred Hitchcock Presents."
In the course of more than 50 films, Miss Lupino was a spiteful Cockney in "The Light That Failed" (1939), a crazed wife in "They Drive by Night" (1940), a loyal girlfriend in "High Sierra" (1941), an escaped convict in "The Sea Wolf" (1941) and a steely murderer in "Ladies in Retirement" (1941).
In later roles, she was a depraved warden in "Women's Prison" (1955), a sob-sister columnist in "While the City Sleeps" (1956) and the world-weary mother of a rodeo star in "Junior Bonner" (1972). Vincent Canby of The New York Times called "Junior Bonner" "a superior family comedy" made to order for both Steve McQueen and Robert Preston, but wrote "the loveliest performance is that of Miss Lupino."
In the early 1950's, she directed and helped write successful low-budget movies on such sensitive issues as illegitimacy ("Not Wanted"), rape ("Outrage") and pathological murder ("The Hitch-Hiker").
On television, she regularly starred in a dramatic anthology, Four Star Playhouse, from 1952 to 1956. In 1957 and 1958 she produced "Mr. Adams and Eve," a situation comedy about married film stars, in which her co-star was Howard Duff, her third husband. Many of the episodes dealt comically with their real-life experiences.
Ida Lupino was born in London on Feb. 4, 1918, during a German zeppelin bombing. Her paternal forebears were traveling players and puppeteers in Renaissance Italy. Later generations migrated to England in the 17th century. Her father, Stanley Lupino, was a noted comedian, and her mother, Connie Emerald, was an actress who was also descended from a theatrical family. A cousin, Lupino Lane, was an internationally popular song-and-dance man.
As a child, she improvised and acted scenes with her younger sister, Rita, in a small theater their father had built for them in their London garden. Her roles included Juliet, Camille and even Hamlet. At the age of 13, she entered the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art. At 15, she made her film debut in a Lolita-like role in "Her First Affaire." She made five more movies in Britain in 1933, then signed a contract with Paramount Pictures in Hollywood and played a dozen more sugary ingenues over the next five years.
The turning point came with "The Light That Failed," in which she forcefully played a vengeful prostitute who betrays an artist going blind (Ronald Colman). That performance and her next one, as a demented murderer in "They Drive by Night," won her a long-term contract at Warner Brothers.
Over the next decade, critics increasingly hailed Miss Lupino as one of the great film actresses. Her favorite role was in "Ladies in Retirement," as a stolid housekeeper who kills her overbearing employer so she can use the house as a sanctuary for her two insane sisters. The New York film critics honored her as the best actress of 1943 for her portrayal in "The Hard Way" of a ruthless woman who propels her younger sister to stardom and destroys everyone in her way.
Miss Lupino gracefully disguised the intense effort she put into shaping her roles, displaying an economy of motion and an ease in using precisely on-target gestures and intonation. She insisted she was not a born actress, saying: "I study and work hard. I take a script and mull over it and underline the bits I want to emphasize. When I go on the set, I know exactly what I want to do and how I want to do it."
In 1949, Miss Lupino and Collier Young, a movie executive and producer who was then her husband, founded Filmakers, an independent production company, for which she directed candid films with feminist themes. One of the most popular was "The Bigamist" (1953).
The energetic Miss Lupino called directing the most demanding work in films, requiring tactful but firm handling of many temperaments and giving clear instructions to a usually all-male, often skeptical crew. Though she spent many hours at what was then a man's calling, she was unstintingly feminine in bearing and manner, observing, "I'm not the kind of woman who can bark orders."
Miss Lupino was petite, standing only 5 feet 2 inches tall and weighing 112 pounds. She had auburn hair and violet eyes framed by half-inch-long lashes. Her leisure pursuits included skin diving, writing short stories and children's books, and composing music. One work, "Aladdin Suite," was performed by the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra.
She was married to (and divorced from) the actor Louis Hayward (1938 to 1945) as well as Mr. Young (1948 to 1951). She and Howard Duff were married in 1951 and divorced in 1983. He died in 1990.
Miss Lupino is survived by a daughter, Bridget Duff, and a sister, Rita Lupino.

HEADLINE: Paper Recycler Will Build Plant on S.I.

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
An Australian company has agreed to build a $250 million waste-paper recycling plant in Staten Island that will be the first of its kind in New York State, company officials and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday.
 To persuade the company, Pratt Industries, to build a plant in New York, the city agreed to give it $28 million in tax breaks and the state will provide an additional $14 million in abatements. 
 The 475,000-square-foot plant will be built in two phases over the next four to five years, beginning at the end of this year. When completed, it will provide 413 jobs.
 With the new plant, New York will have its first local processing facility for recycled waste paper. The city has agreed to sell up to 150,000 tons of waste paper, or half of its current supply, to Pratt annually.
 New York now sells the paper to local vendors who then ship the waste to recycling plants across the country. At full capacity, the Pratt plant will be able to convert 500,000 tons of waste paper a year into liner board and materials for corrugated board.
 Though the plant will employ fewer than 500 workers when complete, the Mayor said the $28 million in tax relief is "nothing in comparison to the enormous investment being made in the city, which the city recoups probably when construction begins and 1,000 people go to work."
 Mr. Giuliani estimated that local residents will earn an additional $131.5 million while the plant is being built.
 Other officials noted additional benefits.
 "The opening of Pratt Industries on Staten Island is a giant win for our economy, our residents and our environment," said Guy V. Molinari, the Staten Island Borough President, who noted that for every pound of paper sent to the recycling plant, one less pound will be dumped at the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island.
 Deputy Mayor John S. Dyson said Pratt's promise to buy the city's waste paper at no less than $10 per ton will also help the city achieve its recycling goals. He noted that about a year ago, the city actually had to pay as much as $35 to $40 a ton to get rid of the waste.
 "Now we know there will always be a revenue stream for our waste paper," he said. "This will provide the financial underpinning for the whole recycling program."
 John Doherty, the Sanitation Commissioner, said Pratt will be able to sort and recycle paper, including "mixed paper," or waste paper produced by offices, which the city plans to start recycling this fall.
"Now we can go out and purchase the equipment we need as we add material, and hire the sanitation workers we need," to collect this paper "knowing we have a contract that's going to pay," Mr. Doherty said.
 Previous plans for paper recycling mills, including one sponsored by a community-development group in the South Bronx, have faltered. Mr. Dyson said the city has been negotiating with three or four other waste-paper recycling firms. "I'm certain this announcement will spur those along," he said.
 The tax breaks offered to Pratt include a 100 percent building tax exemption for 15 years and a 10 percent exemption for 10 years after that. Pratt will also receive property tax abatements of $500 for every full-time employee and sales tax exemptions on building materials and machinery.
 The state's incentives include $1 million in road improvements and grants and loans from the Empire State Development Corporation.
 Pratt owns 10 paper recycling plants, including one in Indiana and another in Georgia. The company processes about 500,000 tons of waste paper a year in Australia, approximately half of that nation's waste-paper output.
 Richard Pratt, the company's owner and chairman, said the company had considered sites in New Jersey and Pennsylvania but ultimately decided on New York because of the ready supply of waste paper, and because of relatively low energy costs.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Unemployment Rate Edges Up

BYLINE: By SUSAN JO KELLER 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
The unemployment rate in New Jersey inched up to 6.8 percent in July from 6.6 percent in June, Federal officials said yesterday. That rate is more than a percentage point above the national unemployment rate, which rose to 5.7 percent from 5.6 percent in June. It is also the second highest unemployment rate among the nation's 11 major industrial states, after California, which posted a 7.9 percent rate. James Hughes, a professor at Rutgers University, said the state continued to feel the effects of restructuring and layoffs by major corporations. But he noted that the change in July was statistically insignificant and said he doubted that unemployment would rise much more in the coming months. [Related articles in Business Day, pages 31 and 44.]

SECTION: Section 1; Page 18; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 164 words

HEADLINE: Salvadoran Labor Law Protects Workers;
What Mexicans Earn

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Kenneth Schwartz's information in "Mexican Maquiladoras" (letter, July 27) is out of date. Based on his experience "just before and after the passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement," he tries to differentiate Mexican and Central American maquiladoras, or free-trade zone factories. Since he was there, the peso devaluation cut the value of Mexican worker paychecks by half. When I examined the pay stubs of workers this spring, I found all were receiving in the 53 to 59 cent an hour range. 
 Given the influence of United States prices in the border region, they have less buying power than their Central American counterparts.
Mr. Schwartz comments that Mexican plants do not employ child labor. He might have noted a plausible cause for this is the systematic firing of union organizers. This permits hiring adult labor for roughly the price of child labor.
 
PHILIP RUSSELL
Director, Mexico Resource Center
Austin, Texas, July 31, 1995

SECTION: Section 7; Page 32; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 942 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By Laurel Graeber 

 BODY:

ONCE UPON A TIME: A Floating Opera
By John Barth. Back Bay/Little, Brown, $12.95.
The hero of the author's 11th work of fiction has his creator's name and many of his identifying characteristics. But nothing else -- including the flow of time itself -- occurs in the expected manner. This autobiography-cum-novel "is brilliantly conceived, elegantly written, bursting with life," R. H. W. Dillard said here last year.
THE STRUGGLE FOR RUSSIA
By Boris Yeltsin. Translated by Catherine A.
 Fitzpatrick. Times Books/Random House, $14.
This memoir by a man who is his country's first freely elected leader has been reissued with an index (the hard-cover edition lacked one) and a new preface that refers to the events in Chechnya. But here, as in the rest of his book, Mr. Yeltsin makes a plea for popular support for a reformed but unified nation. Containing journal entries written mostly between August 1991 and October 1993, the book "is a reminder of how delicate a plant Russia's flowering of freedom is," Paul Johnson wrote in these pages in 1994, "and suggests that in present circumstances Mr. Yeltsin, with all his faults, may be the best -- indeed the only -- man to nurture it." Russia's totalitarian past is the subject of SPECIAL TASKS: The Memoirs of an Unwanted Witness -- A Soviet Spymaster, by Pavel Sudoplatov and Anatoli Sudoplatov with Jerrold L. Schecter and Leona P. Schecter (Back Bay/ Little, Brown, $14.95). As a member of Stalin's security forces, Pavel Sudoplatov participated in numerous murders and oversaw atomic espionage in Britain and the United States. Although last year our reviewer, Adam B. Ulam, cautioned against taking Mr. Sudoplatov's statements at face value, he found "Special Tasks" "a valuable document and very readable."
MR. VERTIGO
By Paul Auster. Penguin, $10.95.
This novel concerns the career of a St. Louis orphan named Walt, who is plucked from the streets in 1924 by a charismatic sage named Master Yehudi. Yehudi gets both Walt and the story off the ground by teaching the boy to fly. The tale "is witty, inventive in its language and invitingly playful with its metaphors," Jay Cantor wrote in the Book Review last year.
THE DUKE ELLINGTON READER
Edited by Mark Tucker. Oxford University, $15.95.
No one, it seems, had a halfhearted opinion either about jazz or about the man who created some of its most famous compositions. This collection includes praise, criticism and even some of Ellington's own words. It "is full of excellent writing," our reviewer, Peter Keepnews, said in 1993. Oxford is also the publisher of JAZZ: The American Theme Song, by James Lincoln Collier ($12.95), which seeks to subvert some time-honored dogmas concerning the music's roots. In doing so Mr. Collier "mounts an impressive examination of Creole culture," Russell Davies wrote in these pages in 1993.
THE PRINCE OF WEST END AVENUE
By Alan Isler. Penguin, $9.95.
Otto Korner, Holocaust survivor and published poet, is the resident of a Manhattan retirement home that is mounting a production of "Hamlet." As Otto explores the theatrical milieu of his present, he is drawn into the dark world of his Auschwitz past in a story that "is able to haunt us," Bette Pesetsky said here last year.
LOOKING AT THE SUN: The Rise of the New East Asian Economic and Political System
By James Fallows. Vintage, $14.
The author analyzes the strength of Japanese industrial policies, arguing that the Asian tendency to ignore standard laissez-faire doctrine should be a cautionary lesson to the West. Last year our reviewer, F. M. Scherer, said he "provides fascinating insights."
I AM SNOWING: The Confessions of a Woman of Prague
By Pavel Kohout. Translated by Neil Bermel. Harvest/ Harcourt Brace, $13.
Written by a Czech author once exiled as a dissident, this novel is narrated by Petra Marova, who is confused by the conflicting claims of her lovers and by the new choices of capitalism. It "is undeniably impressive," John Bayley said in the Book Review last year. The same publisher has also reissued a novella by another dissident author, the Chilean Luis Sepulveda. THE OLD MAN WHO READ LOVE STORIES, ($8), centers on an elderly settler in the Amazon who is asked to lead an expedition to track an ocelot that has been killing white prospectors. "Readers will be enchanted by this finely wrought tale," David Unger wrote here in 1994.
ABDUCTION: Human Encounters With Aliens
By John Mack. Ballantine, $6.99.
Including a new preface in which the author, a Harvard psychiatrist, addresses his critics, this book explains his research into the experiences of people who claim to have been contacted by extraterrestrials. Last year our reviewer, James S. Gordon, felt that Dr. Mack's investigations, while not entirely convincing, were still "fascinating, suggestive and even inspiring."
AVA
By Carole Maso. Dalkey Archive, $12.95.
Written in staccato sentences that reveal the second-by-second images traversing a woman's mind, this novel unfolds on a single day in the life of a college professor stricken with cancer -- her last. It "uses repetition and thematic layering to create a shimmering, impressionistic portrait that eschews linear narrative," Wendy Smith said in the Book Review in 1993.
UN-AMERICAN ACTIVITIES: A Memoir of the Fifties.
By Sally Belfrage. Harper Perennial, $13.
The author tried hard to be the pert blond cheerleader the era demanded, but even in high school she had too much baggage: her British parents were former Communists and ultimately deported. She "is a sharp, unsentimental observer," Elinor Langer wrote here in 1994. LAUREL GRAEBER
