SECTION: Section 6; Page 32; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 8975 words

HEADLINE: A WAR IN THE FAMILY

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN; Roger Cohen is completing an 18-month assignment as the Balkan bureau chief for The Times.

 BODY:
PARIS ZECEVIC EASES HIS METALLIC GREEN FORD PROBE OFF THE FREEWAY AND PULLS UP outside the R. & J. Barber Shop. A wasteland surrounds him, of audio stores and eateries, auto dealerships and repair shops, reaching into the featureless distance. Detroit. America. He yawns, stretches. His hair is tied back in a ponytail; stubble darkens his face; a loose belly suggests a young man going to seed. "I did not plan to grow a beard," he says, laughing. "But I was too lazy to shave, just too lazy. I got tired of it." His grim laughter lingers, full of disdain, the snicker of an uprooted man whose education has been singularly violent. Zecevic is a Bosnian Muslim refugee, one of the 2.7 million people displaced by the war. He pulls on a cigarette, zips his leather jacket and strides into the dingy store. "Can you shave me?" he asks.
"The only thing we shave here," declares the owner, "is necks." The tone is roughly that of a man saying, "The only thing we slit here is throats." The hairdresser shoots a glance at Zecevic in the mirror. Then he returns to the hair he is cutting. 
 Back in his car, just acquired with a bank loan of $12,000, Haris Zecevic muses on this encounter. It proves his pet theory that in America you can get everything except what you need. "Coming to the United States from Bosnia," he says, "one of the most difficult things is the transition from animal to human. I mean, I was in the war for a time and you have to change or you ain't going to survive. You have to learn to bite, to fight for whatever you can get. Here, you still feel like you felt before. That is, anyone messes with you and you take out a gun. You kill 'em, turn 'em into meat. You ever thought of taking a bite out of someone? But you know that you try any of that stuff here and you're in trouble."
Twenty-six years old, Haris Zecevic is a hollow man set down in the American wilderness. Just over three years ago, he was a kid from a middle-class Sarajevo family, hoping to become an engineer. In a city beneath the ski slopes and not far from the sea, he had few worries. Then Europe's post-Communist upheaval brought the continent's worst conflict since World War II to Bosnia and an unrelenting Serbian siege to Sarajevo.
His brother was killed by a Serbian shell in 1992. Lost and scared, Haris slipped out of Sarajevo and eventually reached Detroit as a refugee. One of the first things he learned there was that his mother, Bisera, had been shot dead by the Serbs. She died when United Nations troops beamed a spotlight on her as she tried to escape from Sarajevo by dashing across the airport one August night in 1993. Now he is obsessed with extracting his father from the Bosnian capital and by an amorphous desire for revenge.
Sometimes he hates all Serbs. More often, he focuses on his Bosnian Serb uncle, Slobodan Karisik, a telecommunications engineer who fled Sarajevo for Serbia soon after the war began on April 6, 1992. An irrational conviction that Karisik helped blow up Sarajevo's central post office and most of its phone lines on May 2, 1992, has taken hold of him. "You know, my uncle, he is the man I would kill if I had half a chance," he says.
At other times Haris Zecevic says he feels nothing. "That's a strange thing about my feelings," he remarks. "I don't have them too much anymore. Sarajevo left me with that. But, from time to time -- this is weird, this is sick -- one thing comes into my mind and it hurts me. I'm looking at pictures of my mom and my brother and I start wondering, what's happening to their bodies now, what do they look like in the ground? And that is something that is killing me."
THE SARAJEVO MORTUARY IS unrefrigerated this fourth summer of the siege because there is no electricity in the city, so the stench of bodies is often pungent. The smell seeps out of the tiled morgue into the small room of peeling paint and sagging plants where the records of the dead are kept. The names -- 3,060 in 1992, 3,091 in 1993 and 1,797 in 1994 -- are written in a spidery script across page after page of frayed ledgers: a dry chronicle of a European war and a city's dismemberment.
This woman, too, being wheeled in on a stretcher, will be such a name, recorded with the assiduity of the vestigial Communist bureaucracy that weighs on all the ill-born states of the former Yugoslavia. Smudged stamps and signatures will ratify her death. But they will say nothing of the way the left side of her head was torn open by hot metal, her gray hair matted with blood and her mouth contorted in a final grimace. Nothing, either, of the randomness of another Sarajevan death, delivered by a shell or some improvised 500-pound rocket as the 20th century slid down the slope toward its close.
I have come to the morgue to look for the name of Haris's brother, Muris Zecevic. I know him well by now from family photographs: the wide-eyed little boy with lank hair vacationing on the Dalmatian coast; the brooding adolescent with his guitar; the wiry, defiant young man who traded his musical instrument for a Kalashnikov and his jeans for military fatigues.
Three years have passed since his death. But the same shells that are audible on his father's video of the hasty funeral reverberate today through Sarajevo's tapering valley. And the loss of this 21-year-old Bosnian Muslim remains, in many ways, as unresolved as the Bosnian war itself.
I am searching still -- in the destruction of his family and in its dispersal from Sarajevo to places as far-flung as Detroit and Belgrade -- for some truth that might redeem, or at least explain, the premature death of Muris Zecevic in a makeshift trench near the bobsled track used at the 1984 Sarajevo Olympics and of his mother on the tarmac of Sarajevo's airport.
The last pictures show Muris in the summer of 1992 up on Trebevic mountain. Rising steeply above the south side of the city, it is a mountain before which Sarajevans feel naked and inclined to a collective scream, like that portrayed in Edvard Munch's famous painting. Once associated with winter skiing and summer picnics, it is now a font of anonymous death.
With a small group from what was a ragtag Bosnian Army, Muris had advanced up the slope to a position near an observatory built during the Austro-Hungarian Empire. The sun was shining and, in some of the photographs, he and his friends were laughing and making faces.
From a trench there, they were briefly able to interdict the strategic road linking the separatist Serbs' stronghold of Pale with the main Bosnian Serb garrison near Sarajevo at Lukavica. Until, on Aug. 3, 1992, several hundred shells fell on the emplacement, killing Muris Zecevic and five others.
It is on this same mountain that the Muslim-led Bosnian Army -- now trained, invigorated and far better equipped -- has been trading mortar fire with the Serbs since the offensive begun in June officially aimed at relieving the 40-month-old siege of Sarajevo. The fact that outgoing rounds now match those incoming is a measure of the shift in the conflict since Muris Zecevic died. Now, in a way that is new, this is a war between armies rather than a Serbian onslaught against civilians or amateur soldiers.
Nonetheless, the recent ousting of tens of thousands of Muslim civilians from Srebrenica -- during which Muslim men were taken to improvised detention centers and women and children were pushed over the front lines into Bosnian Government-controlled territory -- shows that the old pattern of Serbian "ethnic cleansing" has not changed. Moreover, Serbian artillery, inherited from the former Yugoslav Army, remains formidable. When Bosnian infantry tried to retake the crucial Pale-Lukavica road on June 16, they were again repulsed, with casualties, by accurate shelling. They retreated, just as the survivors of Muris Zecevic's unit did three years ago. And so the Balkan gyre turns.
Alija Hodzic has been running the morgue since June 1992. His deep blue eyes suggest a shrouded sea. In that time, he has recorded the deaths of his 22-year-old son, a niece and a nephew. His voice is gentle. "When the war is over . . . ," he says, only to catch himself: nobody can imagine when that might be. But if peace ever returns, he dreams of being a truck driver.
Asked to look up the deaths of August 1992, he searches for some time and then produces the relevant ledger. On Aug. 4, his hand has inscribed the name Muris Zecevic beside those of two of his friends, Tarik Kapetanovic and Zoran Susa, a Serb who was loyal to Bosnia's Muslim-led Government.
Names -- as alike on the page as the corpses in the soil -- they have ceased to signify anything. No hint remains that Muris Zecevic once exuded the vigor of a young man. Yet there is a verve about him in the most recent photographs that is unmistakable. "If you were angry with him, he would smile and everything would disappear," says Sanja Mrehic, his last girlfriend. "Nobody had his energy or vitality. For three months after he died I dreamed of him, and three times it was like reality. He was holding me, kissing me."
THE TIME OF MURIS'S DEATH WAS A PORTENTOUS one. Reports had just appeared of Serbian concentration camps through which many of the more than 750,000 Bosnian Muslim men, women and children killed or forced from their homes by the Serbs in the early months of the war had been processed.
Bill Clinton, then a Democratic candidate for President, had no doubts about how to respond. "The United States and the international community must take action," he declared the day after Muris Zecevic was killed. "If the horror of the Holocaust taught us anything, it is the high cost of remaining silent and paralyzed in the face of genocide."
Two days earlier, Aug. 2, 1992, a State Department spokesman, Richard Boucher, said "abuses and torture and killings" had taken place in Serbian "detention centers" throughout Bosnia.
But a day later, as Muris Zecevic died on Trebevic mountain, Boucher was contradicted by Thomas M. T. Niles, a former Assistant Secretary of State, who said such reports could not be confirmed. Thus was established a pattern of American confusion and vacillation in which the only consistent point has been a determination to avoid the direct involvement of American soldiers in the worst European security crisis in decades.
Meanwhile, the cost of paralysis continues to mount. The war has festered, growing ever more intractable and leaving open a fundamental question: What happened to this former Yugoslav republic of sudden mists and rushing rivers, this hybrid society on the age-old border of East and West, to unleash such destruction on the unsuspecting likes of the Zecevic family?
FOR ASIM ZECEVIC, A MILD-mannered dentist and the father of Haris and Muris, the first sign that war would engulf Bosnia came on Jan. 4, 1992, three months before the fighting began. A passionate hunter, he had gone into the hills east of the capital. Abruptly, a group of Serbs who were apparently undergoing paramilitary training fired several rounds over his head. "I could not believe it," he recalls. "I came back and I told my family, 'There's going to be war here.' "
By this time, Yugoslavia had already fallen apart. More than 10,000 people had been killed in the 1991 war in Croatia, where a Serb minority fought to resist joining a newly independent state it saw as hostile. The war, in which the Serbs were strongly backed by the Yugoslav Army, had clearly demonstrated the basic conundrum of dismantling Yugoslavia: the presence of a large number of Serbs living outside Serbia with no wish to submit to a Government dominated by Croatians, Muslims, Albanians or whomever.
Despite the proximity of the Croatian conflict, and the fact that the Serbian minority in Bosnia was larger than in Croatia, people in Sarajevo generally could not believe that war would strike them too. The singular Sarajevan mosaic of Catholic and Orthodox churches, mosques and synagogues, bespoke a Bosnian intermingling of cultures seemingly too dense to be wrenched asunder.
Fida Karisik, Asim Zecevic's sister, had intense personal reasons for believing war was impossible. Her husband, Slobodan -- the man Haris Zecevic now talks of killing -- is a Bosnian Serb.
But she, too, had stumbled on a grim warning. In 1990, with the emergence of Alija Izetbegovic and his nationalist Muslim Party of Democratic Action, Serbs had begun to feel uneasy. A Bosnian Serb friend of Fida Karisik's, Milanka Deilpara, warned her that Bosnia would be destroyed and Muslims massacred.
"I could not believe it," Fida Karisik says. "I asked her to explain. She said that although she was from Bosnia, she was first a Serb and the Serbs would have to take their share of the country. Same with the Croats. So there would be no room for Muslims. Yet Milanka, like me, was born in the Sarajevo area. And before I am a Muslim, I am a Bosnian."
BUT BOSNIA IS AN ELUSIVE, MANY-FACETED thing, built on the gradual coalescence of diffuse civilizations and bloods. Too elusive, perhaps, for a time when national tribes are on the march in the Balkans. The sight of its hazy mountains rising from the placid plain of the Sava River is always suggestive of mystery. Its valleys are steep, its people alternately supine and electric, its mud a morass in which successive empires and armies have sunk -- but not without trace.
The words closest to its soul include "sevdah," a nostalgic, brooding longing associated with lost love, and "ceif," a personal pleasure taken with no regard to what anybody else thinks. They capture the reflective pessimism and hedonistic iconoclasm of a people familiar with the follies and passing glories of a shifting world.
The country has existed for a long time -- the medieval kingdom reached its apogee in the 14th century -- but when Bosnia gained independence from Yugoslavia in 1992 it had not been a sovereign state for 530 years. To some, particularly nationalists in neighboring Serbia and Croatia, this was long enough to suggest that the place was a complete invention.
But Bosnia is a composition of its complex history rather than an imaginary land. For more than four centuries after its conquest in 1462, Bosnia formed the western edge of the Ottoman Empire. Thus was a large body of Muslim converts added to a mixed population of Catholic Croats, Eastern Orthodox Serbs and a small but influential Jewish community.
Contemporary Bosnia, a state about half the size of Pennsylvania, was defined by an intense mingling of peoples and religions: on the eve of the war, about 30 percent of marriages were mixed. In the last prewar census, in 1991, 41 percent of the population of 4.4 million was Muslim, 31 percent Serb and 18 percent Croat. The rest simply called themselves Yugoslavs.
While the Bosnian Serbs blame the war on Muslim nationalism, there was little doubt in the Zecevic family that the Serbian onslaught was cynically prepared and essentially ineluctable. Early in the year, Asim Zecevic saw big guns being removed from the main barracks to be placed on the surrounding hills. Artillery from the Croatian war, ended by a tenuous truce in January 1992, was also installed around the capital. When he asked officers of the Serbian-dominated Yugoslav Army why this was, he was told it was to protect the people.
"But protect them from who?" Asim Zecevic asks. "The guns were not pointing away from Sarajevo. They were pointing in."
In late February, tensions rose markedly when 64 percent of Bosnians voted for independence in a referendum boycotted by the Serbs. A few days later, a Serbian bridegroom was gunned down at a wedding party in the old, mainly Muslim Bascarsija section of town. Serbian paramilitary groups set up barricades near the Zecevic home in central Sarajevo. It appeared that war had begun. In fact, a relative calm held for another month.
But Muris Zecevic, unlike most of his compatriots, was getting ready for battle. Early in 1992, he joined the Patriotic League, a small group that provided military training and was the seed of the Bosnian Army. Most nights, his father says, he would disappear, refusing to say where he went. "Muris was kind of hyper-everything," his brother, Haris, says. "When he found some ideal, he went for it."
There is a video made by Bosnian television on April 5, 1992, the day before full-scale war broke out and the European union and the United States recognized Bosnia. It seems to capture the irrepressible and naive hopes of Muris Zecevic -- and of many of his people.
A group of Sarajevans are milling on the central Vrbanja Bridge when shots ring out, apparently fired by followers of the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic. Muris appears, wearing a beret and dark glasses and brandishing an automatic weapon. He alone is armed, and he fires shots into the air as the people shout "Cowards" and "Terrorists" to the Serbs shooting from a high-rise building. Then jet fighters from the Serbian-dominated Yugoslav Air Force pass overhead. Muris joins the people on the bridge in jeering and chanting, "Bosna! Bosna! Bosna! Bosna!"
When the Serbian shelling started the next day, Muris had no hesitation. He left home with the parting words, "Dad, the war's started for me and I'm not coming back."
IT IS ONE CURIOSITY OF THE WARS OF Yugoslavia's destruction that Belgrade, itself a much-conquered and much-bombarded city over the centuries, has been an island of somnolent moroseness. Along the leafy avenues, not a shot has been fired that bears a direct relation to the battles in which President Milosevic has played such a central role.
When the nationalist fervor whipped up by Milosevic exploded in 1991 and 1992, the streets were full of patriotic songs and the badges, uniforms, insignia and memorabilia of the Chetniks, the Serbian irregulars who fought the Turks in the 19th century and, later, the Nazis. Unemployed kids up from the boondocks bought what they could to disguise themselves as Serbian warriors before boarding buses for the killing fields of Croatia and Bosnia. Their mission was to terrorize civilians, cleanse territory of non-Serbs, grab what booty they could and -- the killing done -- stick up signs in cafes saying, "This Is Serbia." But the fervor passed quickly enough.
Unlike much of the rest of the former Yugoslavia, Belgrade still has buildings with roofs. There are no corpses floating on the Sava and Danube Rivers, whose confluence beneath the old Ottoman fortress of Kalemegdan retains a melancholic charm that makes all the bloodshed nearby seem infinitely remote. The crafting and sustenance of this illusion has been not the least of Milosevic's achievements.
In an outlying suburb, on the flat and fertile plain that unfolds north of the capital to form the Serbian breadbasket, Vesna Karisik could be found earlier this year living in a dowdy ground-floor apartment. She is the 17-year-old daughter of Fida and Slobodan Karisik. A first cousin of Haris Zecevic, she has not seen him since shortly after the Bosnian war began. Pale and slender, she has a face dominated by the vivid green eyes that distinguish many Bosnians.
Greeting me, she unconsciously goes through the rites of entering a Muslim home in Sarajevo: the removal of shoes, the donning of slippers and the offering of Turkish coffee. There is a natural grace about her.
"My mother," she says, "hoped that the war would stop and a certain life resume in Sarajevo and we would all return there. But we will never go back to Sarajevo. My friends are here in Belgrade now. I am trying to forget Sarajevo. It's too sad, everything is ruined and my memories are bad."
It was on April 12, 1992, six days after the shelling of Sarajevo began and Muris Zecevic left home to fight, that Vesna and her older sister, Jasna (then 14 and 16 years old), flew in a military aircraft to Belgrade.
They were to stay with a Serbian friend as a precautionary measure while the moment of madness passed. "We were convinced it would all be over in 10 days," their mother says. In fact, Fida Karisik would not see her daughters for more than two years.
Fida Karisik is a handsome woman with a strong, upright bearing who is now wound so tight inside that tears well uncontrollably at the mention of any of a range of subjects: the death of her nephew Muris Zecevic, the death of her sister-in-law Bisera Zecevic, the war, her children and husband in Belgrade, her future.
She works for the municipal administration and lives, most of the time, with her brother, Asim, and their 83-year-old mother, Hasnja, in a spacious but shabby apartment a few hundred yards from Sarajevo's Holiday Inn. "When Muris was killed, it was almost like losing my own child," she says. "My brother came and said, 'You know, Fida, there is no more Muris.' No politics is worth all these young lives."
She lights a cigarette, fighting tears, and continues: "I am completely divided inside myself. I feel very sorry about Muris and about Bisera, and I feel I must take care of Asim. But, on the other side, my children are there in Belgrade. I am being pulled in all directions. I cannot stand anymore to be separated from my children.
"I am not really angry with my husband personally because he did not take a gun. But the idea of Greater Serbia is in the head of all Serbs. Some are murderers, some are not, but all support the idea. Slobodan looks very nice and honest, but who knows?"
Slobodan Karisik declined to be interviewed. A brilliant and introverted man, in the view of family and friends, he was a university professor teaching electrical engineering. Fifty-four years old, he also worked 20 years for the Bosnian telephone service, designing its main switching exchange, and for the United Nations, installing telecommunications facilities in developing countries.
His daughter Vesna says the war took him completely by surprise. The day the shelling began, she was out with her mother. The family's car was stolen in the chaos. They went to the police station to report this. Young men were running in and out collecting weapons.
"We were ordered to go home, but there was shooting on all sides and we could not pass the Holiday Inn," Vesna recalls. "My mother threw me on the sidewalk and lay on top of me. Finally, we made it home. My father was watching television. He was white, white. I had never seen him like that. We told him about the car, but I don't think he even heard us. He said, 'From now on, nobody leaves this house except me.' "
LESS THAN A MONTH LATER, ON April 30, 1992, Slobodan Karisik left Sarajevo for good and joined his daughters in Belgrade. The circumstances of his departure have become a subject of a venomous exchange that illustrates how war destroyed the Zecevic-Karisik family and how truth changes on different sides of the lines.
For if a Muslim boy like Haris Zecevic, who loved his Serbian uncle, now wants to murder him, it is perhaps possible to grasp how relentlessly gory official propaganda could, in just a few years, turn Yugoslavs living in a single country into "Serbian Chetniks," "Muslim Fundamentalists" and "Croatian Ustashe" (Fascists), divided by impenetrable new borders and disposed to kill one another.
To Haris Zecevic in Detroit, his uncle's actions have assumed every shade of darkness: Slobodan Karisik absconded from the Bosnian capital, abandoned his Muslim wife, made off with their children and sabotaged Sarajevo's telephones. His uncle has become for him the single most potent symbol of the forces that took the life of his mother and brother.
But for Vesna Karisik in Belgrade, her father's flight from Sarajevo was a necessary step, provoked by threats from Bosnian Muslim officials. "As a Serb, my father risked being killed if he had stayed much longer in Sarajevo," she says.
Fida Karisik sees a more nuanced truth. By the end of April 1992, it was clear the war would not be over so quickly. She and her husband agreed that he should go to Serbia to look after the girls. But the idea, she insists, was that he would then find a job outside Serbia. "I told him I would go anywhere in the world with him," she says.
Slobodan left Sarajevo by bus on April 30. After the central Sarajevo post office was blown up a few days later, on May 2, 1992, with the loss of thousands of phone lines, the Bosnian police searched the Karisik apartment and interrogated Fida about her husband. Families related to Serbs were frequently interrogated at this time.
"Haris is not the only one who thinks Slobodan helped destroy the post office by placing a bomb," she says. "Others have said this to me. But I am absolutely sure he had nothing to do with it. He made that exchange. He would never destroy his own work."
Asked about her nephew's violent feelings toward his uncle, Fida Karisik replies: "Look, I understand Haris completely because he lost his brother and he lost his mother and Serbs have done all these terrible things to us Muslims. But things were not as he imagines."
Slobodan Karisik and his daughters struggled to make a new life in Serbia. Meanwhile, a slow fraying of the marriage -- never openly avowed -- clearly began. Fida Karisik felt her husband had betrayed her by staying in Serbia, where he took a job with the telephone company. She felt efforts to make contact -- through mail or ham radio -- always came from her side. After initially urging his wife to come with him, Slobodan Karisik appears not to have renewed the invitation.
It was only in June 1994, more than two years after the girls left Sarajevo, that their mother was able to see them again. A NATO ultimatum in February 1994 temporarily silenced Serbian artillery, permitting a limited number of crossings over the bridge linking the Serb-held Grbavica district and other parts of the city. Unaccompanied by their father, who said he did not want to go, Jasna and Vesna traveled down through Serbian-held Bosnia to Grbavica.
"I did not know how my mother would be," Vesna says. "But she was more beautiful than I remembered her. She was crying. We started crying too, for joy. We stayed in the apartment in Grbavica of my father's former secretary, and Mom held our hands the whole time in the apartment. She did not want to let go. Then, after a few days, she had to go back over the bridge. I watched my mother going over the bridge. She kept turning back and looking at us and crying. She would stop when she turned back. It was terrible, so difficult. Then a United Nations vehicle came and she disappeared." Sobbing fills the small Belgrade apartment.
The next meeting took place two months later in the Bosnian Serb stronghold of Pale. Again, Fida Karisik secured a temporary permit to cross the bridge and, this time, her husband came. In front of their children, the Muslim mother and Serb father tried to avoid talking about the politics of the war that had come between them. But it was not easy.
"At one point, Slobodan said he could make a list of the Serbs killed in Sarajevo at the beginning of the war," Fida Karisik says. "My reply was, 'You cannot make a list of the Muslims killed during this war -- there are too many of them.' And everyone in the room fell quiet after that."
The last meeting took place in October 1994. Again, Fida Karisik crossed the bridge. She secured fake documents identifying her as a Serb from friends in Grbavica and traveled with a cousin to Belgrade. The family was reunited for a few days.
But much was left unsaid. Fida Karisik expected her husband or daughters to urge her to stay, but she felt she never received this invitation. She was uncomfortable in Belgrade, but unable to explain why to her family. Her children were dismayed when she returned to Sarajevo; they had hoped the reunion would be permanent.
"I know my old grandmother and Asim are in Sarajevo, and my mother has her job there," Vesna says. "But it would be much better if she were here with us. How can she live alone in Sarajevo when her family is here?"
Vesna weighs this question and then goes on: "I try not to think about who is to blame for the war. From the moment the nationalist parties started spreading in Bosnia and the barricades went up, I knew it would not end in a nice way. It's so difficult in these mixed marriages now. I really don't know what to think. There have been many Muslims killed by Serbs and, on my father's side, some Serbs killed by Muslims. For myself, I cannot feel like a Muslim or a Serb. I certainly could never take sides against one of my parents. Never."
VESNA KARISIK APPEARS TO BE IN THE MIDDLE. But the middle ground barely exists in the Balkans, eroded by old and new violence, grievances, misunderstandings and sophisticated propaganda perfected over decades of autocratic rule. Vesna lives in a time when things are breaking apart. Truth is elusive. A bold experiment, a multiethnic state born before its time, Yugoslavia is dying very painfully.
The current violence is flashed instantaneously across the world's television screens. But each particular moment of destruction may be the fruit of a complex history that cannot be communicated. I thought of this as I drove back from Vesna's apartment and on past Kalemegdan, the old Ottoman fort long disputed by the Turkish and Austro-Hungarian Empires in this city halfway between Vienna and Istanbul.
Kalemegdan is one of the few traces that remain of the almost-350-year Turkish rule over Serbia, a dominion that turned Islam into the unwitting incubus of this proud people. The Serbs rose up against the Ottoman Empire in the early 19th century, leading the march to liberation of the south Slavs as Piedmont led Italy to unification. At the heart of the current Balkan conflict is the Serbian conviction that the breakup of Yugoslavia left Serbs with meager recompense for this and other sacrifices.
These sacrifices were immense during World War I. Perhaps a quarter of the Serbian population died. Under attack from Austria-Hungary and Bulgaria, the Serbian Army withdrew in the dead of winter across Albania to the Adriatic. During this epic retreat alone, 70,000 soldiers died. When the Serbs, supported by the French, came back to defeat Austria-Hungary and so help to destroy the Hapsburg Empire, they won a victory that brought Yugoslavia into being.
But Yugoslavia was ill born, skewed by this Serbian triumph. The south Slavs were united, but they were, in some ways, placed under the Serbian yoke. The Croats and Slovenes and Bosnians, who had fought on the side of Austria-Hungary, were joined in a country ruled by the Serbian monarchy in Belgrade. The Serbs, understandably enough, felt that Yugoslavia was their country because they had fought and suffered most for it.
Suffering and sacrifice: the theme is inexhaustible in Belgrade, where a veritable mythology of persecution and self-immolation exists. The tribulations were great. A half-century ago, the Serbs suffered a genocidal onslaught by the puppet-Nazi Croatian Ustashe during World War II, which was particularly devastating in northwestern Bosnia. As the largest population in Yugoslavia, they believed they were misused by Tito, who, they claimed, deliberately emasculated Serbia by creating a separate republic in Macedonia (conquered by Serbia in 1912) and giving self-rule to Kosovo (the cradle of Serbia but now 90 percent Albanian) and Vojvodina (which has a large Hungarian minority).
These were the real or imagined grievances that, from 1987 onward, Slobodan Milosevic was able to whip into the nationalist frenzy that destroyed Yugoslavia. A frenzy that, as the British author Mark Thompson has noted, saw Serbia suddenly "staggering back to its crib self-blinded, cursing the world."
The rampage across Bosnia was historical grievance reinterpreted as the license to murder and -- as Communism was officially disappearing -- the market economy reinterpreted as the license to steal at gunpoint. An onslaught in which all the honor and all the valor of Serbs over at least two centuries were trampled into the oozing Bosnian mud.
And what, I asked myself, did this gracious young woman, Vesna Karisik, and her entire uprooted Sarajevan family, have to do with all this? The retreat to Albania. Milosevic's cynicism. War as a kitsch video clip with militiamen donning the symbols of World War I Serbian royalist officers as they steal the jewelry of Bosnian Muslim women and cart off their kitchens as booty.
I had called on Mihailo Markovic, a dissident intellectual under Tito but now a prominent supporter of Milosevic. He lives in a comfortable Belgrade villa near the former mansion of Tito and the current home of Milosevic. It was all a mistake, he ventured. Yugoslavia was an impossible country. It was an attempt to forge a transnational entity when the peoples inside it -- Serbs, Croats, Slovenes and others -- had been delivered from empire but had not yet gone through the necessary historical phase of the nation-state.
So, I asked myself, the Muslim Zecevic and Muslim-Serbian Karisik families had been wrong to believe in Yugoslavia? Wrong to believe that the United States, which played a decisive role in creating Yugoslavia, would seriously strive to preserve it? Wrong to think that Serbian concentration camps would not be tolerated by a modern world where everything is immediately visible? Perhaps.
But this much seems clear: the modern world is a weightless place, easily distracted, restlessly diverted, more inclined to zap from channel to channel than to grasp that the dark tribal tide that swept this European family away came from the depths of time and has not been tamed. Not by the United States, the United Nations or anyone else. The apogee of its bloody cresting may therefore still lie ahead.
HARIS ZECEVIC IS remembering. In a dimly lighted Chinese joint in Detroit where kids do karaoke. A long way from home. Remembering what it was like to become a Bosnian warrior in Sarajevo and then to watch his younger brother, Muris, die.
His first weapon was his father's hunting rifle. It wasn't a question of loving Bosnia, he says. Or hating Bosnia. It was a question of survival. There were two choices: stand in front of the Serbs or let them in and get killed. He took the rifle.
He'd hardly ever fired a bullet before. But there was this strange feeling. Of the gun conferring authority. Of adrenaline and being invulnerable. "But if you bite too much," he says, "you're in trouble. And if you're pushing your luck, it's going to happen sooner or later."
So they were up there, on Trebevic mountain, pushing their luck. It was August, hot. Four months into the war and they were beginning to get organized. The hunting rifles had given way to automatic weapons, and they had one 12.7-millimeter machine gun. A group of Sarajevan kids -- what passed for the Bosnian Army.
Their commander, Bego Poturic, a mountain man, a hunter, was down in Sarajevo. They'd been up there too long, the Serbs knew their position; they were expecting the order to withdraw. But Poturic returned with an order to hold the trench overlooking the Pale-Lukavica road. Nobody knows who gave these instructions.
Haris was responsible for the schedule: he could decide who would go to the exposed trench, who would remain at their base in the old Austro-Hungarian observatory. "I kept Muris out," he says. "But he came to me, insisting on going to the trench with his friend Tarik Kapetanovic. You couldn't stop Muris. I had to redo the whole schedule to fit them in."
Then, in the late afternoon, it started. From his position at the observatory, Haris watched the Serbian mortar shells going in, near the trench, around the trench. Where exactly? There was so much dust rising, he could not see. He thought of the trench. It was strong. Big logs laid one on top of the other. Some rocks, some blankets, piles of earth. They should be all right. No way of getting there to see, the fire was too intense.
It is well past nightfall before the shelling eases and Haris can make his way over there. He can't see much. He takes the hand of the first man. It's cold. Somehow, he feels, in the dark, there's no life left in the trench.
Then he makes out Tarik's head -- with a gaping hole in the middle of it. He tries to pull him out, but a log has fallen over him. Haris calls for help. Some other men take over. He never does see his brother. But later they tell him that there wasn't much left of him to see.
"I thought, why Muris, not me?" Haris says. "I'm older, supposed to take care of him. That night, up there, when the shelling started again, I was really scared."
Guilt, rage, fear: they have wrapped themselves in a tight knot inside Haris Zecevic. To survive in America, he has sealed Bosnia inside him. Nobody would understand anyway. So he has tried to take on this big, new country with a certain bravado. But sometimes the pain creeps back.
How is he to tell his mother and father? Haris comes down the mountain the next morning, looking for somebody with a sedative when he meets a friend, who tells him that word of Muris's death is already out. His mother, when she sees the faces of the men who come to inform her, simply asks, "Which one of them is dead?"
She was brave, she did not cry much or scream. His father fell very silent. "He just keeps quiet," Haris says. "Keeps it inside. That is what I'm afraid of. So many people went nuts and my father's the only one I have left. I have to get him out of there."
Since Muris's death, Haris says, he has never had a dream that he remembered.
WHEN HIS MOTHER, BISERA, was killed, just over a year after Muris, Haris couldn't cry. He had cried for his brother. He wanted to for his mother. But all he could do was gasp for air. Nothing would come out of his eyes. "It's not that something in me is destroyed," he says. "I guess it's that most of me is destroyed." Haris believes that if he had stayed in Sarajevo, his mother might still be alive. The belief is probably irrational, but it is persistent.
At the time his mother was killed, Haris had been in America for just two weeks. Broken by Muris's death, troubled by thievery and greed among soldiers and officers in the Bosnian Army and obviously scared, he says he won the Government's permission to leave and escaped from Sarajevo in February 1993. He ran across the United Nations-controlled airport at night. Eventually, his application to the United States Refugee Resettlement Office in Croatia was approved. On July 27, 1993, Haris flew from Zagreb to Detroit, where he was met by a Bosnian immigrant and old friend of the family, Nino Cernovrsanin.
Although his mother died on Aug. 11, Haris did not find out until early September. There were no phone lines to Sarajevo. When Cernovrsanin told him he had bad news, Haris echoed his mother's words: "Which of my parents is dead?"
When he found it was his mother, he says something in his head crashed for a while. All he could think of was returning to Sarajevo, somehow, to exact some kind of revenge. "I was out of my mind," he says. "If I had gone back then I would have killed the first Serb I found and you would not be talking to me here today."
His mother was killed at the age of 52 by Serbian machine-gun fire. She was trying to follow her son's route across the airport at night -- the only way out of the encircled city. Suffocating under the siege, terribly wounded by Muris's death, this highly strung woman had decided to risk her life to reach Butmir, an area west of the city where the Zecevic family had a country house.
It was to this house in Butmir that the family used to go every year to celebrate Bairam, the Bosnian Muslim feast that marks the end of the Ramadan period of fasting. Only part of the Zecevic family fasted, but they always organized a big party for Bairam. Asim would buy a lamb and his sons would help him skewer it on a spit. Then they would dig a pit and light a fire over which they slowly cooked the animal. These parties -- to which about 15 people would come -- are now among the rare moments that Haris still remembers when the family was together and happy. The vacations on the Dalmatian coast that his father recalls with great fondness appear to have been blotted from his mind.
Bisera Zecevic was about 55 yards short of the Butmir side of the airfield when a United Nations personnel carrier beamed a spotlight on her. "She was not guilty of anything," Haris says. "She just wanted to get some food and some air. She had some memories, she wanted to get over to Butmir. She'd been in a cage for over a year. What would you do?
"And then some United Nations soldier who probably doesn't even know what he's doing points a beam at her and makes her a target."
The United Nations tookcontrol of Sarajevo airport in the summer of 1992, under an agreement with the Serbs. It has seen stopping Sarajevans from escaping across the airfield as part of the exercise of that control. But the fact that Bisera Zecevic was shot dead with the help of the United Nations while trying to escape from the surrounded capital of a state recognized by the United Nations underlines all the ambiguities and problems of the peacekeeping mission. A mission that has fed people, when possible, so, in the words of cynical Sarajevans, fattening people for the slaughter. A mission that has been a divided international community's way of trying to contain the Bosnian war while shying away from the bold steps needed to resolve it.
It seems Haris Zecevic is probably wrong when he says he could have saved his mother. After Muris's death, Asim and Bisera could not sleep at night. They would sit by the window, smoking, waiting. There was little to eat, nowhere to go. Like her dead son, Bisera was willful. She was boiling inside. But she never showed anyone how she was suffering.
Only when friends would come around unannounced during the day would they catch a glimpse of her pain. They would find her in tears. She was still working for an import-export company. But her sense of claustrophobia was overwhelming. She wanted to see the house that would remind her of Muris. When she announced that she was going to try to escape across the airfield to Butmir, her sister-in-law, Fida Karisik, urged Asim to forbid her to go.
"Don't you make conflict in my home," Bisera said. "I have decided to go and that is the end of it."
Before she left on the night of Aug. 11, she asked Fida to promise to take care of Asim. It appears that she knew exactly what was awaiting her.
DETROIT IS WEIRD. You drive 70 miles in a day, on highways that cross each other at right angles, and that's normal. Nothing takes the place of the Sarajevo coffee shop where pleasure is found in idle conversation with friends encountered by chance on streets that snake around the hills. Where wisdom is slowly gleaned as coffee grains dissolve in the mouth, from watching the way the shadows fall and the way the same place moves through the seasons. But after life in a dirt trench, weirdness is a relative thing.
So Haris Zecevic is getting the hang of it, this Detroit, this United States of America. He started out in Clinton Township, a grim place. Since then he's been on the move: Dearborn, Hamtramck, Madison Heights. But he's mostly managed to stay out of downtown Detroit, a place he describes with the Bosnian phrase "pojesti ce te mrak" -- "the darkness will eat you."
He's had four cars. Smashed the first one after two weeks -- an '85 Thunderbird bought for $3,000. Next came a $200 Buick. But that broke down after two weeks. So he walked to work for a while or found lifts with friends, before buying a Mazda and finally his $12,000 Ford Probe.
"It's weird," says Haris. "Here, you can't work, you can't do anything if you don't have a car. No public transport, nothing, zero! In Sarajevo they can't understand it."
He worked for a while in Cernovrsanin's metal-processing shop but tired of that. He then found work in the company of Cernovrsanin's son-in-law, a genial Anglo-Indian named Previn Mistry, who moved from London a couple of years ago. Haris works with lasers precise enough to cut a hole in a human hair without burning the hair. He programs robots that use computer-directed lasers to weld car parts, earning $27,000 a year -- better pay than most of the 1,000 or so other Bosnian Muslim refugees in the Detroit area.
"After Haris's mother died, you could see the strain he was under," Mistry says. "So I tried to structure a situation where he had to move forward. Haris is very computer literate. He's fast. But he's not studying enough. You see, I want to turn him into a professional."
On a mild March day, it's hot in Haris's one-bedroom apartment. The place costs $485 a month and the central heating can't be regulated. He's shaved himself now and made a bad job of it -- there are cuts all over his neck.
His wife, Vildana, is pregnant. She was Haris's longtime girlfriend in Sarajevo. He managed to get her out through a humanitarian agency in April 1994. She arrived in the United States on June 21, 1994, almost a year after Haris, and they were married the following November.
Now Haris complains that Vildana does not understand him, his need to make a career, his need to spend $12,000 on a Ford Probe that goes fast enough to provide him with a shot of adrenaline, his financial problems, his worries over the baby and over his father in Sarajevo, his sense of suffocation.
Vildana is concerned about money and is philosophical about Haris's fast-changing moods. She is still lost, here in the middle of America. "I still think I'm in Sarajevo and the rest is a dream," she says. She gets up and turns off the television.
The television has been bought on credit. So has the stereo system and the furniture. Vildana also has a car that Haris has leased. He has been learning fast about the American dream. He has Visa, American Express and various store credit cards. He's 26, heavily in debt, trying to make a life, with Bosnia buried inside him.
There's a Bosnian party in Hamtramck, a Polish-dominated township in northeastern Detroit, and Haris decides to go. The place smells of Bosnia: the cigarette smoke, the beer, the plum brandy, the lamb. There is a pall of weariness and pain, too, detectable amid the loud good cheer and the laughter. A Bosnian fleur-de-lis -- like the one in Haris's Sarajevo apartment -- is draped over the television.
Haris greets Nedzad Stukan, who lost one of his legs at Mostar. And Ramiz Gigic, who got shrapnel in his eyes in Sarajevo and now has 20 percent vision left in one eye. They're lucky: they're alive and they're out of there.
Cernovrsanin comes up to me. "Things can't get better," he says accusingly, "until we are all back in our homes." This remark sets the tone. I see, quickly enough, that at this gathering I am the representative of America's betrayal of Bosnia.
Somebody asks why America won't give the Bosnians weapons, but Haris steps in. "Let's cut the [expletive]," he says. "We ain't ever going to change anything with all this talk. This war's gone too far now. Unless the United States is ready to give us Muslims two million green cards, the end will only come when one of the armies is beaten."
LATER, WE GO AND SEE Ekrem Sorguc, a friend of Haris's and another Bosnian Muslim refugee living in Hamtramck. He was rounded up by the Serbs in Hadzici, west of Sarajevo, on May 14, 1992. They took him from his home and marched him off to a camp in the former Hadzici sports center, just as three-quarters of a million Muslims were marched off, early in the war, from the 70 percent of Bosnia now held by the Serbs.
In the camp, Sorguc saw men beaten and bleeding who were forced to suck their own blood from the floor without leaving a drop. He saw a Serbian guard trying to prize the wedding ring from a man's finger before losing patience and simply cutting off the finger. He saw other prisoners forced at gunpoint to perform fellatio. He saw people taken away to be executed. All this to the refrain of, "This is Serbia" or "You're not Muslims, you're Serbs who converted."
From Hadzici, Sorguc was taken to other prisons. Eventually he was freed in a prisoner exchange and got out of Bosnia with his family. Now, they live in a ground-floor apartment rented to them by a Serb, Dragan Vranes, who lost all his family in World War II -- massacred by the Ustashe -- and immigrated to America in 1972. He has six houses in Hamtramck and has done a great deal to help Muslims arriving in Detroit. His acts amount to a sort of living proof of the folly of Bosnia's destruction. "I don't care who is who," he says. "What have I got against them or anybody?"
This American Serb has a decorating company and knows everyone in Hamtramck. He finds televisions for the Muslim refugees, eases them out of scrapes with the police, shows them around the cheaper supermarkets and lends them money.
"Haris lost everything," Vranes says. "But he thinks too much about over there. There's nothing to do about it. The first thing is to try to forget that thing over there. He can't concentrate and he don't need that stress."
ASIM ZECEVIC HAS a room with a view. From his dentist's studio in the center of Sarajevo he can see Trebevic mountain and, he insists, the actual spot where his son Muris was killed. When the war is over -- and the end, he says, will be military and not political -- he will go and visit the spot.
Like many Sarajevans, he tries to keep up appearances. He always wears a tie and a small gold tiepin in the form of the Bosnian fleur-de-lis. He is punctual about his work and he never raises his voice. But his skin sags. He is sometimes unshaven, and his eyes are often blank. When he is asked how he is, he always says, "Very well." Then he smiles wearily to himself. Occasionally, he confesses that he cannot sleep at night and that he suffers from pains in his shoulder.
His family has been in Sarajevo for at least five generations. Now he hardly recognizes the city. There has been the destruction, of course. But also a vast influx of refugees who do not know the city's manners. Cemeteries and vegetable gardens have spread all over the place, wooden graves and sprouting onions where city parks used to be.
Muris has been dead for three years. Bisera for two years. He has not seen Haris for two and a half years. Fifty-six years old, he is alone with his sister, Fida, and his old mother, Hasnja. Sometimes he drinks a brandy or two at breakfast. Sometimes, gazing at family photographs, he seems very far away. "A man can suffer a lot," he says. "The outer limit of what a man can stand is not yet known."
On the 3d of every month, he goes to Muris's grave; on the 11th, to Bisera's. The graves are close to each other, in one of the cemeteries that rise above Bascarsija, the old Turkish quarter where the shells are crashing again these summer months. On his son's grave is written, "Muris Zecevic (Sehit) 1971-1992." A "sehit" is a hero and martyr.
This is a land where fathers bury their sons. They tend the plots around the wooden graves. Here, where the men are buried, none of the dead are more than 30 years old. Asim Zecevic stands there, in prayer, his arms outstretched, his palms turned upward, in a gesture that is at once humble and infinitely imploring.
Higher up, there is the grave of his wife. From here, there is a magnificent view down into the encircled city, down through the old white stone graves with their turbanlike bulbous tops, past the newer wooden graves, on to the town itself with its mingled minarets and church steeples and, beyond them, the high-rises of Dobrinja, built for the 1984 Olympics.
It is still a magnificent town, Sarajevo, cradled by the mountains. Despite the 40 months spent under assault, some vestige of the city's fabric remains, a fabric of civility and courage and tolerance. Perhaps, in the end, this is what all these Bosnian boys died for.
Asim begins the long trudge home. "This is my style," he says, "calm on the outside, inside a storm." Then he looks up to the mountains, where the Serbian gunners lurk. "Those people up there, I trusted them," he says, gesturing to the hills. "Now they want the Muslims to disappear. But we will not go away. We cannot take peace at any price. We paid a very high price, so we cannot sell this country so cheaply."
Back at home, he settles wearily into his armchair. It is late June and the boom of shelling resounds through Sarajevo's valley. Fida is there. She has not heard from her daughters in Belgrade for months and she is worried. Asim is concerned about getting the necessary papers to visit Detroit. Their mother, Hasnja, spry and wise, brings coffee. Haris, she says, should come back home when the war is over because it is sad to be in a foreign country, better to be at home.
Then they all start to tell the story of the birth of Haris and Vildana's son. The telephone rang in complete darkness. There is no electricity in Sarajevo. Fida stumbled toward the phone. Then Asim heard Fida screaming for joy. He said, "You don't need a phone, they can hear you in America." He groped toward the phone and Haris said, "Dad, you've got a grandson."
Asim, who is laughing as he recounts this, says he then tried to sit down, but the chair fell over and he landed on the floor on top of his 83-year-old mother who was also trying to reach the phone in the darkness. She injured her leg, Asim his back, and they all talked until the sun came up. "I heard my great-grandson's voice on the phone," Hasnja says. "I was crying."
The boy was born in Detroit on June 2, 1995. He is an American citizen. His name is Muris Zecevic.

HEADLINE: Recycling Banks: Some Debits, Some Dividends

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
REMEMBER banks -- those imposing marble Greek Revival-style temples found in every downtown, usually not far from a similarly solid and conservative structure called City Hall? How about bank branches or savings and loan offices -- those modest, modernist buildings that often dispensed money like Big Macs at drive-up windows?
Slowly, almost imperceptibly, banks seem to be vanishing from the American architectural landscape, both in cities and in the suburbs. No, they aren't disappearing as fast as old-fashioned movie theaters, department stores or other soon-to-be relics of 20th century commercial real estate. They are, though, frequently being shut down, sold, subleased, re-leased or remodeled for new uses, ranging from the merely unusual (restaurants and rug stores) to the highky unlikely (houses of worship and wine cellars.) 
 The evolution has occurred the most, perhaps, in the Northeast, where the financial-services sector of the economy has shrunk substantially over the last decade, in part, ironically, because of the turbulence in the region's real estate market in the late 80's and early 90's.
In some cases, though, especially in cities, when a bank closes, the physical carcass, sadly, is of landmark quality or close, and any new usage may seem somewhat incongruous, lacking the dignity usually associated with these magisterial buildings.
The former American Savings Bank, for instance, at 103 East 15th Street in Manhattan, is a neglected neo-Classical tomb with the entabulature of Union Square Bank above its doors. The new owners have announced plans to turn it into a restaurant and music club called the House of Blues, which, to some developers still reeling from the credit crunch a few years back, may not be an inappropriate name for a bank.
The former East River Savings Bank at 22 Cortland Street in Lower Manhattan was built in 1934 by the architects Walker & Gillette in the Art Deco style and is often referred to as one of the best buildings of the period in New York. The building is today a Century 21 department store.
Then there is the former New York Bank for Savings at 81 Eighth Avenue, at 14th Street, later a Gold Dome Bank, a 99-year-old, 40,000-square-foot building that has a copper domed roof, walls sheathed in travertine and antique chandeliers. The building is now Central Carpet, which is, according to the store's owners, who spent hundreds of thousands of dollars restoring the property, "the Grand Palais of Rugs."
"It's better than being demolished," said Clark Strickland, president of the Preservation League of New York State, which is based Albany, in reference to 81 Eighth Avenue.
The number of banks has declined substantially over the last 10 years in the New York metropolitan region, in part because of mergers and acquisitions, in part because of the failure of many savings and loans and in part because of automation, particularly the ubiquitous automated teller machine, which has eliminated entire branches, as well as thousands of teller jobs.
Thrift institutions, as savings and loans are often known, have been hit much harder than banks. There were 38 thrifts and 195 branches at the end of 1984 in Connecticut, according to the Federal Office of Thrift Supervision. A decade later there were 13 thrifts and 101 branches. In New Jersey the number of thrifts fell to 69 from 139 over the same period and the number of branches fell to 556 from 861. In New York, the number of thrifts fell to 66 from 93 and the number of branches to 517 from 732.
Even large banks, however, have cut back the number of branches they operate. When Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover Trust merged in 1991, they had about 440 branches in New York. Today, the combined company has about 275 branches. More consolidations -- rumors of a merger between Chemical and Chase Manhattan have been widely reported in recent days -- could close scores more branches.
Nevertheless, branches are not likely to disappear, replaced by ATM terminals and on-line banking systems. In fact, nationally, the number of bank branches, excluding thrift institutions, has increased over the last 10 years because of continuing expansion in the south, Midwest and the Rocky Mountain region.
"There continues to be a great need for the branches," said Ken Herz, a spokesman for Chemical Bank. "We will always maintain a very large branch network. Branches continue to be important not just to individual customers but also to small businesses."
Citibank has even opened six branches in Connecticut in the last three years. "We are going to look for more locations," said Susan Weeks, a spokeswoman for Citibank. "So no -- branch banking is not dead."
And some bank branches that close reopen as other banks. Chemical Bank recently gave away a building it closed in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn to a small credit union there, the Central Brooklyn Federal Credit Union.
Most banks lease their suburban locations and own their older buildings. When a decision is made to close down a branch, a lease can have as little as a few months to run or as long as 20 years. Rents run the gamut from $15 a square foot to $200 a square foot. "Like anything else, location is everything," said Richard E. Lucia, senior director for corporate retail properties at Chemical Bank.
Suburban bank branches have been re-leased for myriad uses, ranging from dry cleaners to t-shirt shops to churches. A former Connecticut National Bank branch in Monroe, Conn., became the Sunday School and youth center for the Stepney Baptist Church in 1991.
"We don't use the drive-up windows for church purposes -- there is no one there to collect money," said Pastor Bill Minser. "We pass the offering plate for that."
"We also like that fact that this building is air-conditioned," he added. "That wouldn't necessarily be the case if it were 150 years old."
Climate control is a real consideration when leasing a former bank. Alfred A. Mirin, an associate at CB Commercial Real Estate Group in Stamford, Conn., said that the larger older banks were difficult to heat and cool because of the high ceilings, and the floors were often slabs of marble that were difficult to remove to put in new plumbing. "It is not necessarily an easy sell," he said.
Suburban banks in high-traffic locations and those with drive-in facilities are the easiest to lease. "In today's world, anything with a drive-through is a hot commodity," said Jonathan K. Putnam, director of the Hartford office of Cushman & Wakefield, the commercial real estate broker.
"I have seen a drive-through D'Angelos and a drive-through Boston Chicken, places that in the past I have never seen a drive-through," he added, referring to two fast-food chains that usually do not have drive-through windows but have leased former bank buildings with such facilities.
He said that new drive-throughs are often hard to establish these days because of local land restrictions. And the best locations have already been taken. "They are hot pieces of real estate," Mr. Putnam said. "Generally, what you are finding, though, is that banks are trying to dump the bad locations not the good ones."
He noted that Dunkin' Donuts and McDonald's have been seeking out former banks in which to locate franchises. He said a Dunkin' Donuts recently moved into a former Bank of Hartford in Cromwell, Conn., and a McDonald's recently received permission to buy an old Gateway Bank in Fairfield, Conn.
"Banks are good sites for retrofitting," said Dominick Musilli, a McDonald's real estate representative based in Windsor, Conn.
He said the vault in the Fairfield bank branch would become restrooms and the teller counters would become fast-food counters. The Fairfield Planning and Zoning Commission, however, has turned down requests from the restaurant to use the drive-in windows. "We are appealing that decision," Mr. Musilli said.
Older bank buildings can be more difficult sells. There are curently two former banks on the market in downtown Stamford, Mr. Mirin said, and one has been vacant for three-and-half years. "They are trophy properties," he said. "They would be great for a museum, but how many museums are there?"
"Restaurants love them too, but the restaurant business is having a hard time," he added.
One bank that became a restaurant was the former People's Bank headquarters in Bridgeport, Conn., a traditional bank structure with columns, marble floors and vaulted ceilings. Last year it became Roberto's, a pizza parlor.
"It's just awesome," said Robert Mirafiore, the owner, "especially the 40-foot ceilings.".
The restaurant uses the former vault as a bar and service area. "People go up to the vault to get their drinks," Mr. Mirafiore said.
One of the most difficult tasks in retrofitting a bank, particularly an older one, is dealing with the vault. With their thick concrete walls and steel doors, they can weigh several tons. "It can be an obstacle," Mr. Lucia said. "But if it's in the basement, as it often is, then it is less of an obstacle, as the door can usually be taken off and the vault used for storage."
Vaults in newer banks are quite different from the old-fashioned round or oval steel-and-brass variety with one or more combination locks and a door handle like a ship's wheel. More modern vaults are modular, meaning they can be dismantled fairly easily. They also tend to have walls reinforced with inch-thick steel rather than the 18 inches of concrete in older banks. "It has the same strength rating," Mr. Lucia said.
Some new tenants have found innovative uses for the old decorative vault doors, if not the vaults themselves. At Fidelity Investments in Boston, which is based in an old Shawmut Bank headquarters, two vault doors have been laid on a wooden base for use as a conference table.
Sometimes, the entire vault is left in place and used as a marketing tool. In East Hampton, L.I., the Coach Leatherware Factory Outlet, which is housed in a former bank building, uses its vault for a small art gallery featuring local artists.
"It was too expensive to have the door removed and the space was odd, so they got creative and put in an art gallery about three years ago," said Amy Pierson, salesperson at the store.
At Rothman's, a men's clothing store at 17th Street and Park Avenue in Manhattan, the priciest suits are kept in a 20-foot-by-30-foot vault. (The dressing room is the old safety-deposit-box room, but without the boxes.)
"A lot of customers come in and say, 'I only shop in the vault,' " said Ken Giddon, president of Rothman's.
Mr. Giddon said that to remove just the vault door would have cost at least $10,000; the building was a Chase Manhattan Bank until 1985. "A lot of these vaults were dropped in when the buildings were built, and getting them out is very problematic no matter what your budget," he said. "It is, essentially, a huge cement and steel box that is part of the structure and support of the building."
Keeping the vault -- usually about 12 feet by 18 feet in size -- and using it for storage or display has its costs, too, though. "We had to get sprinklers, and we spent about $2,000 to make it a legal room," Mr. Giddon said.
Lane Brettschneider of Lane's Floor Coverings & Interiors in Manhattan received an estimate of $250,000 three years ago to remove the vault at the space they now lease at 2 Park Avenue, which used to be a Chemical Bank branch.
They have also tried -- and failed -- to sell the vault to anyone interested for $5,000, plus removal. "It's a joke," Mr. Brettschneider said.
In the meantime, Mr. Brettschneider, an oenophile, has turned the space into a combination carpet sample library and wine cellar containing about 40 single bottles and 50 unopened cases. The two rooms are separated by a Plexiglas wall, so carpet-book browsers in the library can also gaze at the wine, which is kept chilled at 58 degrees, at the other end of the vault.
"We hold wine tastings with our seminars on floor coverings," Mr. Brettschneider said. "It is a way for us to get architects in here and hear us talk about floor coverings. When they hear we are serving a 1978 Petrus, it brings them right in."

HEADLINE: Streetscapes: The Brooklyn Academy of Music;
Restoring the Crown to a 1908 Queen of a Building

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
OVER four decades, many people have winced and averted their eyes as they passed the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where the removal of the 1908 building's delicate terra-cotta cornice in 1953 created a painful sight.
In a city of preservation successes, it was an awful wound. 
 But as it turns out, this scar itself is impermanent: The Academy of Music is going to replace the cornice.
The Academy was established in 1859 in Brooklyn Heights by a group of citizens to provide a home for opera, concerts, public meetings and other events.
In 1903 a committee raised $1 million to construct a new building farther out at Lafayette Avenue between Ashland Place and St. Felix Street, near elevated lines and the Flatbush terminal of the Long Island Rail Road.
A new Academy was a source of great concern to Brooklyn, especially because the City of Brooklyn became part of New York City in 1898, which "threatened the very existence of its distinctive civic life" as the magazine Architecture wrote in 1908.
Herts & Tallant produced an early scheme, a grand, stone monument comparable to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. They worked out an ingenious and compact plan, a side-by-side opera house (with 2,217 seats) and concert hall (with 1,406 seats), sharing a huge rectangular foyer fronting on Lafayette Avenue and, above, a similarly sized room that served as a banquet hall and ballroom.
Fortunately, Herts & Tallant's original exterior was scaled down for reasons of cost. Their first design mimicked many of the city's civic monuments of the time, but there is nothing in New York like the revised scheme, which deftly mixes grand scale and intelligent economy.
The final work is of soft, cream-colored brick, lightly varied as if salvaged from some ancient ruin, and mixed with some of the best terra-cotta work in the city. The main doorways are surrounded by alternating panels of musical instruments and rondels of small carved figures. These figures -- a chorister, piper, triangle player, and others -- grimace, they sing, they reach, they blow, all with lifelike and expressive individuality. They look like they were modeled from life on some unruly kindergarten choir.
The names of composers are bracketed by soft criss-cross patterns at the ends of the building, and sophisticated terra-cotta work punctuates the rest of the building, including lions' heads with red tongues at the cornice.
It is the rich contrast between the soft, rippling brick walls and the luscious detail of the terra cotta -- produced by Atlantic Terra Cotta -- that gives this building a stature comparable to more ambitious limestone monuments.
Besides the exterior, there was another change in design. In July 1908 the trustees told Henry B. Herts that some of the undraped figures in the ballroom might make Brooklyn's leading citizens blush, and had him add some coverings. The architect minimized the incident to The New York Tribune: "A fig leaf here, a laurel wreath there and the air of respectability thereby attained was astonishing. The committee was perfectly right in asking to have the figures draped."
But Architecture felt sure that the volatile, high-living Herts was not properly quoted.
"Do you know Harry Herts?" the magazine wrote. "Well if you do you can possibly imagine what he said."
The new Academy opened for inspection on Sept. 16, 1908, when 10,000 people crowded through its halls, many no doubt looking for fig leaves and laurel wreaths.
PETER CASLER, director of capital projects for the Academy, said the cornice was a constant problem, with repeated repair campaigns even in the 20's. In 1953 the architects Brown, Lawford & Forbes, with Tuck & Eipel, engineers, made alterations to the building, including cleaning the facade but also removing the cornice, replacing it with a plain wall.
The loss of the cornice has seemed immutable, even as the Brooklyn Academy of Music experienced a remarkable revival beginning in the 60's. "The Queen of England without a hat" is how Elliot Willensky and Norval White described the loss in the 1988 edition of the A.I.A. Guide to New York City. But now the Academy has the engineers Robert Silman Associates and the Stein Partnership, architects, designing a replacement cornice in fiberglass, designed to exactly match the missing work.
Last month the Academy received general approval for the $800,000 restoration from the Landmarks Preservation Commission. This is part of a projected multiyear, multimillion-dollar renovation of the building, which will include many internal improvements as well.
"Historic integrity and state-of-the-art interiors -- we think that's what will make the greatest facility," says Karen Hopkins, executive vice president of the Academy.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
In Elizabeth, Dusting Off an Art Deco Treasure

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: ELIZABETH

 BODY:
Standing above the discount stores and fast-food restaurants of Broad Street, Hersh Tower is a throwback to another era. Its facade is an elegant mix of pale brick, black marble and nickel. Its lobby is an Art Deco showpiece, with terrazzo floors, marble walls and elaborate grill work.
 The 14-story bulding languished through a number of owners and an economic malaise that has plaqued Elizabeth for decades. But the lastest owners, two brothers who own a real estate company in New York City, have renovated Hersh Tower, hoping to attract new businesses to the city.
 "The historical value of this building interested us, and the proximity to New York interested us," said Edward Wydra, one of the new owners. "We think it could be a very viable building."
 Hersh Tower was the tallest bulding in Elizabeth when Louis Hersh, an Elizabeth businessman, built it in 1931. (These days, only the Union County Court building is taller.) At the corner of Broad and East Grand Streets, it was brimming with law offices, insurance agencies and other businesses for decades.
 But tenants fled as the building fell into disrepair, and by the 1980's it was almost empty. A bank foreclosed on the bulding in 1990, and three years later, the Wydras took over the $3.4 million mortgage. Since then they have spent more than $1 million on renovations. Among other things, they have replaced the elevators, polished the marble for the first time in 64 years, and replaced silver leaf in the lobby.
 Because Hersh Tower is within Elizabeth's Urban Enterprise Zone, new tenants can benefit from tax incentives and other forms of state aid. It is only 45 percent occupied, but the Wydras said they are confident that the building, with its views of the Manhattan skyline and proximity to the Elizabeth train station, will attract more businesses.
 "This town is going to come back booming," Edward Wydra said. "There's a new energy coming that's going to turn this place around."
 Meanwhile, the Wydras have a backup plan: last week, they registered the building with the Union County Film Commission so that it might be used for a movie set someday.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
10 Days to Takeoff for a New Airline and a Dormant Airport

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: EWING TOWNSHIP

 BODY:
The sign outside the Trenton-Mercer Airport building says "Airport Terminal." It might as well say "Grand Opening."
On Aug. 16, Eastwind Airlines is to become the first commercial jet carrier to call Trenton home and New Jersey's first new airline since Kiwi International Air Lines started in Newark in September 1992. 
 It is a risky endeavor: of the 47 airlines that have started in the United States since 1990, only 27 are now operating. But if Eastwind survives, it will help revitalize a moribund, almost anonymous airport that hasn't had a commercial jet flight since 1992 and is better known for the General Quarters restaurant inside the terminal than anything to do with aviation.
And a successful airline would give Mercer County, which is reeling from a succession of factory closings, something tangible to claim as its own, much the way people have embraced the Trenton Thunder minor-league baseball team.
"This gives us one more identity, just like the baseball stadium has," said Robert D. Prunetti, the County Executive. "It is sort of a boost, if not materially right now, then certainly psychologically."
County and state officials are doing their best to trumpet Eastwind's debut. On Aug. 15, Governor Whitman is to preside at a ribbon-cutting ceremony, complete with tours of Eastwind's two Boeing 737-200 jets and souvenir pins of the Eastwind mascot, a bumblebee wearing sunglasses.
The next day, Eastwind plans to begin its (what else?) "Bee Line" service: two flights a day to Boston (at 7:55 A.M. and 2 P.M.) and one to Greensboro, N.C. (5:15 P.M.). The fares -- $53 each way to Boston, $63 each way to Greensboro -- are more than 30 percent below those of other carriers in Newark and Philadelphia. Eastwind hopes to provide service to Florida by Christmas, said Richard R. Haller, its vice president of marketing.
History is not on Eastwind's, or Trenton's, side. United Airlines had daily jet service from Trenton to Chicago via Allentown, Pa., from 1983 to 1986 but stopped because too many passengers preferred Newark and Philadelphia. USAir flew to Pittsburgh in 1991 and 1992 but stopped because the average flight was less than 30 percent full.
In a business whose highest industrywide profit margin in any year is 2.5 percent, most start-up airlines fail. The reasons are manifold: bad management, unpredictable economy, rising costs. Yet more and more people want to be involved, in part because there is a certain glamour associated with the business, said Mark L. Gerchick, acting assistant secretary of the Federal Department of Transportation. In 1990, two companies applied to start new airlines; last year, 24 applied.
But some analysts say now might be a decent time to try. The economy is strong, fuel costs are down, and the collapse of major carriers like Pan Am and Eastern has left some room for smaller players.
"It's always hard starting up an airline," said Ray Neidl, an airline analyst at Furman Selz in New York, "but I think probably the strategy Eastwind is trying is a good one: keep costs low, find a market niche, stay away from the big guys."
Eastwind has been two years in the planning, the brainchild of its president, James E. McNally Jr., who previously worked as a consultant to troubled airlines for the accounting firm Price Waterhouse. It is a subsidiary of UM Holdings Ltd., a privately held company in Haddonfield with interests in fitness equipment, medical services and real estate.
Eastwind officials won't say how much money it needed to start. But it usually takes $10 million to $20 million to start an airline, said Barbara Beyer, president of Avmark Inc., an airline consulting concern in Rosslyn, Va.
To succeed, Eastwind intends to mimic Southwest and Valujet, which emphasize rock-bottom fares and no-frills service -- but not People Express, which expanded too fast and finally collapsed.
"People get jet fuel in their veins and they want to grow quicker, but in my viewpoint, bigger is not necessarily better," Mr. McNally said. "You have to keep your eye on the bottom line and the balance sheet."
And the potential, as well. Two million people live within 30 minutes of the airport, which is just off Interstate 95. And although Mercer County has lost thousands of jobs in recent months, the New Brunswick-to-Trenton corridor still has blue-chip employers like Princeton University, Johnson & Johnson, Merrill Lynch and Dow Jones.
To encourage Eastwind to tap that potential, the county received $300,000 from the state to renovate the airport. It repainted the passenger areas, bought metal detectors and a baggage carousel, and even changed the name of the airport from Mercer County Airport to Trenton-Mercer Airport. But the parking is still free.
To break even, Eastwind needs to fill 45 percent of its seats; for now, the airline hopes to reach one-third of capacity. And while it has been a little tough informing people that there is, indeed, a Trenton airport, the company says it is confident.
"We have to get people used to getting out of this airport because right now, this airport is like an imaginary place," said Thomas H. Paine Jr., an Eastwind spokesman. "It's a short-term problem, but a long-term advantage because we'll be here first."
