HEADLINE: CHATTER;
Paying Child Support

 BODY:
The New Jersey Supreme Court has rejected a divorced father's argument that his child-support payments be reduced so he could spend the money as he saw fit when he cared for his children. Is this fair, or not?
 
Saving for the Future 
 The words "as he sees fit" bother me with children involved. If he is spending all the money, will there be something left to save for future plans, such as college or career training? I agree with the Supreme Court ruling that his payments should not be reduced. In an age where inflation overtakes fixed payments, it is unlikely that any of the money will be squandered, if that is his fear.
CLAIRE GIBBONS
Greene, N.Y.
 
Having to Pay Twice
 I work with a gentleman who is paying child support for three children to his ex-wife. The oldest girl, who is 14, ran away from her mother to live with him. He started to protest the fact that he was still required to pay child support to her for a child now living with him. His ex-wife threatened to take him back to court for alimony if he continued his protests. I have no problems with the mandate that a father pay support for his children (in fact, I think any respectable person would do it without a court order), but situations such as this have got to be stopped. Where will it end?
ERIC HOWARD
Somerset
 
A Frightening Prospect
 Hurray for the New Jersey Supreme Court. Having noncustodial parents be allowed to reduce their monthly payments so that they can spend the money as they see fit scares the living daylights out of me. This recent ruling supports women's rights as parents, not to mention our right to reasonably exist.
SHARON FREEMAN
Vineland
 
Protect the Children
 The man who brings a child into this world and refuses to support him or her or thinks he can cut back on it should have wages garnished by courts until the child is 21 years of age. And if he refuses to work, his unemployment and welfare payments should be sent to the children.
DAN DERNBACH
Leicester, N.Y.
 
Paying Extra on Visits
 The noncustodial parent, usually the father, pays his share to the mother. The hidden assumption is that the father spends no other money on his children. But for a father who wants to be involved with his kids and who fights to secure a reasonable visitation arrangement, anything extra he spends for food, clothing, entertainment or gifts is over and beyond what he already gives his spouse for child support.
Adding to the insult, support payments are not deductible for the paying spouse, and they're tax-free to the receiving spouse.
DAVID PAUL
Yardley, Pa.

HEADLINE: Wheels, Deals, Half-Pipe Dreams

BYLINE: By JESSE McKINLEY 

 BODY:
Kanaf Hagi lay in his cramped room in a Oneida County juvenile detention center on a warm July morning and imagined himself flying. A hyper kid with trigger reflexes, Kanaf could feel his feet twist in phantom intimations of what they could do on wheels, and his mind spun with images of himself mid-sky, body stretched beyond the ground and way beyond the fences of juvenile hall.
Kanaf had just served a year-long sentence for beating a man with a pair of num-chuks while stoned. Today he was leaving. There was only one thing on his mind: getting back to the skate ramps of Mullaly Park. 
 That same morning, Julio Rivera, a slight, soft-faced 14-year-old with a shaggy head of hair, pulled himself out of bed early at his home in the South Bronx. Yanking on his skates, he glided down the long wooden hallway of his home and headed for the door. His mother, Raquel, amazed at her son's early rise, screamed her daily blessing, "Que Dios te bendiga!," at the closing door.
Outside his home, at East 162d and Walton Avenue in the Bronx, Julio slipped his headphones into his ears and started toward Mullaly, avoiding rough spots in the street and instinctively turning up the volume. Ever since he'd taken up in-line and stopped hanging on the street -- dropping bottles from the roof, xxxxx -- his former mates called him "Shrimpy" or "white boy."
But today it was too early for taunts. Julio had gotten up to wait for Kanaf to return, the friend who first taught him how to skate the ramps and rails of Mullaly Park's skate rink, before he was sent away. Kanaf had been the best skater that the local crowd at Mullaly had ever seen. Now that he was coming back, Julio had a few things to show him.
Kanaf and Julio are skate dreamers, two urban hopefuls in a new sport called aggressive skating. Aggressive is one of a number of so-called alternative sports, like snowboarding, downhill biking and bungee jumping currently in vogue with the young and televised. Alternative sports make good TV, and TV makes good for the athletes, with made-for-the-small-screen spectacles like ESPN's Extreme Games and MTV sports shows creating mini-celebrities of those willing to risk life and limb to create eye-catching visual fare.
Aggressive skating consists of in-line skaters, moving at maximum sped, performing tricks, flips, and grabs while either in a half-pipe or on a street course dotted with ramps, rails and boxes. But competitions are only part of the game. Aggressive skaters and their fast, flashy talents are rapidly being recruited by advertisers who want to cash in on the young, subculture feel of the sport to peddle everything from candy bars to sunglasses.
The air of hip glamour hanging around the sport are also encouraged by skate companies themselves, who keep stables of an elite skaters on monthly retainers and fly them around the country for promotional events and competitions. Their motivation is simple: In-line is the nation's fastest growing sport, with sales of over million dollars in 1994, according to statistics from the National Sporting Goods Association. And aggressive skating, with whole new lines of special skates (selling for about $200 a pair), pads and wheels, is in-line's fastest growing segment.
Companies scout places like Mullaly Park's skate rink, the city's only rink equipped with a half-pipe and a street course, for young skaters to add to their teams.
Success can come as fast as the sport. Take the case of Rollison Rivera, a one- time pitching prospect for the Yankees from Washington Heights, who took up skating at Mullaly a year ago. Last October, he was featured in a video which was shown on MTV That led to a sponsorship and monthly retainer from Rocce's skates. Today, he has endorsement contracts with four other companies, is starring in new documentary, "Hoax 2" about the sport, and is negotiating for a wheel endorsement contract that would pay him a nickle for every wheel sold. Count of the number of skates you see on a Manhattan street and you understand the potential for quick cash.
But Rollison's story is rare. A much more common deal involves free merchandise: boxes of wheels, t-shirts, ball bearings, clothing, even skates. What companies expect in return is for skaters to talk up the products.
But for the sport's participants, mostly under 20, mostly male, the appeal is not only economic. It's emotional. Aggressive skaters say they are part of a close-knit community that shelters them from the dangers of the streets and gives them individual and group identity.
The sport has its own heros, most known by nicknames, first names or just initials (like Arlo Isenberg, or Arlo, the king of the street, and C.E., Chris Edwards, a California skater with his own line of skates.)
It has its own lingo and traditions. The term "roller blading" is a considered a curse. It is offensive amongst aggressives to wear Spandex, the common garb of recreational skaters. They talk about run-ins with "gromlits" (i.e. skateboarders) and the old days on "quads" (standard roller skates).
The skating rite of passage is "sessioning" -- a practice where a pack of skaters travel from location to location using various bits of the urban landscape to hone their skills. Favorite spots are the steps at Union Square with their waxed curbs, or the "Screamer", a 25-step long rail in downtown Manhattan, which the skaters "grind" down i.e. use the middle wheels of the skate to locomote and the side of the skate to brake their descent. Mastering an especially difficult handrail can become a covert citywide challenge -- the rails at St. Luke's Hospital on 58th Street and 8th Avenue are the current dare.
Whether or not the sport will have mass appeal or staying power is debatable. What is certain is that the odds of making a career out of being a professional in-line skater are extremely long. (There are about 150 skaters nationwide making a decent living as "professional" in-line skaters, experts say -- professional basketball, by contrast, hires about 360, at much higher rates.)
Still, the possibility of that is enough to make young people like Kanaf and Julio dream of long green lawns with skate ramps, of making a life by doing something they love, or even just the simple attention brought by winning a neighborhood competition.
Maybe that attention would bring a break: a recommendation by a scout for an sponsorship or an endorsement offer. And that maybe, could lead to something bigger. At the very least, for Kanaf and Julio, winning means respect from peers and pride in one's self.
It is those things that make them skate, those things that make them move.
 
THE FIRST SKATE
Monday afternoon. Kanaf flew down River Avenue towards Mullaly. His tight schedule (off the bus at 1 P.M., to the skate shop for wheels, then home, to Mullaly by 3) had been blown by Manhattan traffic and his grandfather's reluctance to run red lights. But now he was out of the car and on skates again.
Mullaly skate rink is a smooth concrete oval in the corner of Mullaly Park, a run-down patch of green flowing north from Yankee Stadium. The rink, at East 164th Street and River Avenue, is the almost exclusive domain of children and teenagers. Facial hair is rare. And the trash that litters the broken concrete around the rink consists of soda bottles, ice cream containers, and candy wrappers. The park is overseen by two tattooed twentysomthing BMX bikers who sport Parks Department t-shirts and read "Pictorial" to bide the time. Two rusted snow plows resting inexplicably in one corner of the park signal the abandonment of adult bureaucracy.
When Kanaf turned the corner into the park, he saw things had changed. The skate rink had been nearly barren when he left, with the exception of a beat-up half pipe and few rotting plywood ramps which periodically got burned by vandals. Now, the park was crammed new ramps and practice rails.
Some things were the same: the empty chemical drums that served as giant steps up to the top of eight foot tall half-pipe, the Puerto Rican flag painted on a ramp, and the deafening screech of the passing 4 train overhead.
The big difference was in the crowd, its size and its makeup.
"50 skaters I don't know," Kanaf thought to himself. And young. Kids he last had seen as clumsy 5 year-olds were on skates. And on ramps.
Ray Mendez was one of the first to see Kanaf back. Ray is a 20-year old professional skater (an elder, by aggressive standards) who grew up in the same building as Julio. An assured young man with a casual, easy to talk to style, he is the de facto big brother to most young skater at Mullaly. He saw changes in Kanaf too.
Kanaf had left a street talker, a cocky skate prodigy whose talent was "phenomenal," according to Ray, but whose attitude was of "a little snot." Ray remembered when Kanaf would get baked and try to skate, one time running into a biker and breaking his nose. But now Kanaf's whole manner had changed: something about him was calmer, more focused.
"He had a smile on his face," said Ray.
After a few high five's and screaming "Heys" and "Where you beens" from friends, Kanaf glided onto the rink, forgetting his pads and immediately hopping onto the half-pipe.
He fell. Laughter came from everywhere. Kanaf laughed too but felt the flare of embarrassment inside him. I really fell off, he thought. He got up and retreated to the edge of the rink.
It was then someone handed Kanaf a flyer. There was a competition at the rink that coming Saturday, July 15. Two photos on the flyer jumped out at Kanaf. Both were of Julio, arching his legs behind him, perfectly, to touch his back in mid-air.
Julio couldn't take the heat. He'd waited at the rink till the sun had burned him and then gone home.
Sitting in the relative cool of his room, he considered his pencil sketches of airborne skaters pinned to his walls: contorted bodies suspended in different skate grabs and flips, some that he had mastered, others that he had simply imagined.
Julio stored his skates in their spot on his empty bookshelf ("his library" he calls it) and went to play with his nephew, one of eight people he shared with house with. He'd play for a while, do some drawing. Then maybe, when the sun had settled down, head out to find Kanaf again.
Kanaf stayed till 6, and then went home, leaving others who stayed behind after the rink had closed. They just hopped the fence and kept skating.
At home, Kanaf caught his mother, Sue, trying to move some stuff into his room. He stopped her and insisted she sit.
Sue Nagi's heart had almost stopped years before. It was after her quintuple bypass that Kanaf, left without as much supervision, had begun to hang out with a bad group. ("The kids with the cheap skates," Mrs. Nagi called them.)
"They were pulling me away with a rope and finally I hung myself," said Kanaf.
Kanaf didn't want her, or him, to get sick again.
 
A DAY OF FRUSTRATION
Tuesday stormed. Puddles everywhere on the rink.
Kanaf brooded, angry at the weather. His moods always were dark when he couldn't skate. He felt impatient. He'd watched videos in the detention center of skaters he knew making their names. He'd seen their pictures on magazine covers and followed their results in competitions. He didn't have time for rain.
You can watch skaters at Mullaly scramble when the rain hits, and then watch them buzz back to the rink when the sky clears, whizzing down the streets around the rink like bees returning to a hive. Even in the winter, skaters plow paths to get from ramp to ramp. But the on again, off again rains bred by the humidity and heat made the whole afternoon a wash.
Kanaf's mother had told him that when he got out, with credo should be "Live to skate, skate to live" and Kanaf agreed. But he'd have to wait till the rink was dry.
Julio sat around and gourged himself on some cuchifritos from a shop on East 161st Street and thought evil thoughts about Disney. Julio's only seeming break into the in-line world was a photo shoot he'd had in January for a Disney kid's book. They'd taken him to a fancy Manhattan photo studio and dressed him in Spandex. Instead of a skate ramp, they'd put him on a trampoline and asked him to "do skate tricks." He'd done his best and they'd promised mail a check.
"Neither rain nor sleet nor dark of night..."
Nothing had ever come.
By Wednesday afternoon, clearer and hot again, Kanaf was back up to speed, headphones dangling from his ears, performing tricks that made the younger skaters stop and gape, sometimes breaking up his time with a cigarette break. His quick smiles marked each flight on the half-pipe. He grabbed more air on every pass, egged on by the crowd. "More air!" "Come on, you Energizer bunny!" Kanaf responded by swinging high off on end, twisting his body one and half times around while swinging his right hand across his body to grab the outside of his left skate, a manuever called a mute-method.
During a break, Kanaf caught a figure shooting down East 164th, straight through the intersection, not even breaking to swing the sharp right turn into the park. It was Julio.
Kanaf didn't quite recognize the speeding figure until he got close. And he got close fast.
He stopped. They hugged. Julio hung near Kanaf's arm for a bit, uncertain, while Kanaf talked around the group, teasing some of the other skaters to get higher, to trust the momentum of ramp's curve. Then Julio moved away, up on the platform above the half-pipe. Ray had been assuring a younger that if he dropped into the half- pipe shoulders first, he would be okay. Julio was in before the younger kid could work up the nerve. Julio instantly, cold, pulled him a move he'd made up himself, a backwards 360 with a . He called it the P.R. (for Puerto Rico) flip.
Damn, Kanaf thought.
Julio had once broke a pair of skates trying a move like this, leaving him skateless for a full year before he could afford a new pair. It was period, he admits, half-smiling, half-hiding his head in his chest, that he would pass by the park and watch from beyond the gates. "I kept crying" he said. But there was nothing wrong with Julio's skates now.
Kanaf pulled the flyer from a pocket and showed it to a friend.It hit him. "That's Julio," he said quietly. "I left, and he soared."
He knew then that the competition, a place where he had told himself he was just going to find out "where I am now" was going to come down to between him and Julio.
 
ACTION
Thursday the first offer came.
Ray's fledgling instruction and promotion company, City Sk8, had been asked by a Japanese production to assemble some skaters to stage a session hitting all the major spots around the city. Ray asked Julio and Kanaf to come along.
They shot on Friday, going from Mullaly, down to Columbus Circle, threw Central Park for a while, down to the Chelsea Piers and then finally to Union Square.
Julio marveled at the star treatment, free food and cameras everywhere, taking down what he did and said. He felt like a movie star, and thought, 'This is the best day of my life, this is what I want.'
Kanaf asked Julio to do some tricks: a mute, a Gumby, a method. Julio did every move and ask Kanaf to match him. Kanaf coaxed spitting laughs out of Julio, and started calling him Rosa, a nod to a fellow juvie mate, a gymnast named Delarosa.
Julio didn't know what it meant, so he laughed. They goofed for the camera. They hit their marks. They scouted each other. They shot for 16 hours for no pay, but the attention of an video entourage and a rapt audience wherever they went.
Finally, dog tired and thinking about the next day's competition, Kanaf and Julio headed home.
 
THE COMPETITION BEGINS
Saturday was the hottest day of the year. By noon, the sheet metal on the half-pipe was sizzling hands of falling skaters.
A DJ worked out of a van was parked in the corner of the park and bass heavy rap and hip hop boomed through the park. A PA had been set up and the competition's organizers, Ray and his partner David Smith, took turns trying to announcing competitors names and adding commentary to routines: "Oh, that's a 360 transfer, baby. Nice!" The half-pipe's platforms were draped with banners announcing Hyper Wheels and Power Bars, and topped with a McDonald's flag. The park guys had run a hose over the roof, creating a single stream shower for people to cool off in. Blankets sat in the shade for parents. Skaters showed early and came from everywhere, slowing the competition down by adding multiple rounds.
By the midday start of vert competition, the temperature was 101. Kanaf, Julio and 11 other skaters had signed up for the vert, the faster, harder to master end of aggressive. (51 signed up for the street course.) The competition would be one round of prelims then the top 8 would compete in the finals.
A corwd of baout 200 people had showed up to watch, driven to the shade of the park by the heat indoors. Hanging around the edge of the rink was a German photographer, a Brooklyn skate enterpreneur looking to form a team, and a handful of pros, not allowed to compete, but watching for new talent.
The first round showed off Kanaf and Julio. Kanaf, heavier and steadier, older and stronger, could trust momentum would build behind him. Julio had to work a little harder for the speed.
And Kanaf had style. In a black soccer-style shirt and frayed dungarees, Kanaf milked the stalls between tricks, gripping the edge of the platform with his skates like flamenco dancer: arms slightly bent, head cocked, eyes in the middle distance. And then down into the pipe, seemingly fed by the music, effortlessly gaining speed, arms to his side, and then with a perfectly timed push, up, two, three, four feet into the air, turning his body from the sky to the ground to the sky again, landing and shooting backwards towards the other curve of the pipe. No sign in his body of any fear of falling on anything but the glide of four wheels still in motion.
But Julio had moves. Smaller, almost birdlike, he found the twists and grabs less clumbersome. Perching for a moment on the edges of the platforms, he would swoop down, pushing his skates with more desperate action, looking for the speed to launch him up. But then suddenly, airborne, twisting, his fast hands locking into sudden perfect positions, he would be frozen for a moment. Then as soon as eyes could snap his image, the next moment he was falling back into the pipe, landing and pushing again to gain the speed for the next flight
The judges, a trio of sponsored skaters, gave the prelims lead to Kanaf. Julio was 2d.
In between, Kanaf smoked and fast-chatted a battery of girls and buddies. Julio stayed atop of the half-pipe, fiddled with the hem of his "Your Wheels Suck" t-shirt and thought about the next round. His watched parts on the street competition and played eye-tag with a girl standing beyond the park's fence.
When the finals came, hours late, the sun had begun to set behind the projects to the west of the park. The water had got out of hand and many of the spectators were drenched.
In the finals, Kanaf stuck with a high air strategy, blasting up and twisting, ripping 540's, following one leap with another, confident that he was skating "harder than I ever skated before." Coming down out of the pipe, he was covered in sweat, like he'd stepped through the makeshift fountain. He thought about it: This is all the sweat that I clogged in my pores for a year coming out.
But Julio dogged Kanaf, spinning mercilessly, again and again, using a simple ideas to keep focus: Where's the ramp? Put fear to the side. Don't fall and look stupid. The remaining crowd fed him, Kanaf screaming along with the rest.
When the judges tallied their cards, there was a tie.
A playoff was hastily arranged to decide the competition between Julio and Kanaf. The lights on the basketball court had already clicked on, and the DJ had packed up, taking the PA and the commentary with him. The crowd had dwindled.
Julio approached Kanaf.
"You want first?" said Julio.
He said he was exhausted, and could hardly see the ramp. The prizes between first and second weren't that different, and he'd be happy with second...
Kanaf responded before the words got out of Julio's mouth.
"If you're not to going to skate, I'm not going to skate, it'll be a tie," said Kanaf. "But I want to skate, so you get your little butt out there."
Kanaf stood on the edge and dropped in. The routine was good, no falls, no misses, but lacking the speed and intensity of before. Kanaf missed the grind and beat of the music, the energy of the big crowd.
He finished. Julio began.
At first, it seemed like his regular routine, said Ray. But then he pulled it. Flying up the curve of the pipe, he made a push about six inches from the top and entered the air that Kanaf had seemed to own all afternoon. He flipped skates over head, his eyes flashed with sky's dusk, so high that he "smelled pollution," he said. He completed a full flip and then, twisting like a cat falling from a roof, turned his body 180 at the last instant to land moving forward towards the other curve of the pipe.
Silence for a second. Then shreiks of "Oh man, oh man!" He had pulled a pro move, a gravity bender known as a Mc-Flip.
The decision was unanamious.
Ray pronounced Julio "King of Mullaly."
"Was that so hard?" asked Kanaf.
Julio seemed stunned. "I didn't feel a thing," he said. He said later that when he smiled, it was in the shape of a U -- a half-pipe of a smile.
 
EPILOGUE
A week later, Kanaf got a call from casting agent from American Express. Two days later he was filming in Central Park, playing a skate messenger in a Jerry Seinfeld ad. He had to wear Spandex, but got paid $810 for two days work.
Both Julio and Kanaf were signed to Free Ride, a new skate company in Brooklyn. Unfortunately, it's called Free Ride because its skaters skate free.
Ray also booked Julio and Kanaf onto his City Sk8 team, and their first show is planned for next month. "I'm making sure they get sponsored. They'll have careers," said Ray.
In the meantime, every afternoon the sky is clear at Mullaly Park, they'll skate to live, and live to skate.
 
 
 
From Gring to Gromlit: A Glossary
 Someday you might overhear something like this: "He pulled a mute method and then he tweaked it into a gumby."
Here's a guide to the basic lingo of aggressive skating.
 
Anti-rocker: The wheel alignment that makes grinding easier. (Two middle wheels are slightly smaller than the two outside wheels, improving the skate's grip.)
 
Gromlit: A slang word used to describe skateboarders.
 
Grind: The action of sliding along a rail, skates roughly perpendicular to it. The two outside wheels are used to cradle the rail and gravity does the rest of the work.
 
Gumby, mute, method, rocket: The basic skate grips, all involving grabbing a skate or skates while mid-air.
 
Hip hop: The action of hopping with the hands along the coping, or top metal bar, of a half-pipe while in a handstand.
 
Invert or sad plant: A handstand on the top of a half-pipe.
 
Quads: Standard roller skates.
 
Sessioning: When a pack of skaters travel from location to location using handrails, steps and curbs to perfect moves. Favorite spots are an area under the Brooklyn Bridge on the Manhattan side called the Brooklyn Banks and the "Screamer," a 25-step-long rail in downtown Manhattan.
 
THE BUSINESS OF A RISING SPORT
 
 Who the Corporate Players

 * Skate and accessory manufacturers seeking to cash in on the nation's fastest growing sporting goods market.
 * Advertisers seeking urban, youthful feel to sell products from credit cards to candy bars.
 * Television networks and video companies looking for new, cheap sports programming that appeals to a public jaded by the turmoil in more traditional sports.

 What the Skaters Do

 * Promote skate equipment by talking it up in skate parks and hangouts, using a company's skate equipment, sporting its logos on shirts, helmets and hats provided by the company.
 * Perform at trade shows and store openings to provide entertainment and build crowds.
 * Scout for other talented skaters to become members of company teams.
 * Give advice on research and development of new products; test new products.

 What the Skaters Get

 * Top skaters kept on retainer by large companies like Roller Blades can earn up to $6,000 a month. Skaters travel around the country and, and in some instances, overseas to promote and compete.
 * Many deals involve free merchandise, payment of entrance fees to tournaments and small royalties for any photo or broadcast appearance.
 * Other deals pay in the neighborhood of $300 for appearances at trade shows, store openings and in commercials.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1963 words

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
One Way to College: Buy Now, Learn Later

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

 BODY:
AS one of five children of a working-class Ohio family, David Sweet financed college the hard way, with loans that he is still toiling to pay off at the age of 34. So when his son, Paul, was born five years ago, Mr. Sweet was determined not to weigh him down with the same millstone.
Mr. Sweet and his wife, Cindy, became two of the hundreds of thousands of participants in a novel college-financing venture that is catching fire around the country. They enrolled in a state-operated plan that allows them to prepay up to four years of tuition at an Ohio state college at a locked-in price -- roughly $15,000 at today's rates. No matter what the caprices of tuition, inflation or politics during the next dozen years, Paul will be able to start state college as a freshman with much of his tuition paid off. 
 "It will be like going to the store and paying 29 cents a gallon for milk," predicts Mr. Sweet, a tall, lanky communications director for a health-care affiliate of the Chamber of Commerce in Columbus.
In the years since 1986, as tuition has risen ever more sharply, seven other states -- Alabama, Alaska, Florida, Massachusetts, Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wyoming -- have set up comparable plans, and a half-dozen more have passed legislation to do so. Still more -- including New York, New Jersey, California and Illinois -- have made inquiries. By one expert's estimate, more than 400,000 American families are already enrolled in such plans, almost half of them in the robust $1.5 billion Florida program.
The financial premise behind these programs is that by pooling tens of thousands of individuals' savings in what are considered to be safe investments, the states can earn enough to cover the cost of future tuition increases, which have been handily outpacing inflation.
To be sure, the plans have their detractors. Critics worry that a sustained period of low investment returns could undermine some of the weaker plans. The states, not the students, are on the hook if that happens, but that just means taxpayers in general will have to make up any shortfalls, critics say. While those who sign up are fully protected, they might earn more by investing elsewhere, perhaps in a mutual fund. What's more, the plans make little sense for poor families, which can qualify for state aid. Worse yet, critics contend, prepaid tuition plans could even discourage states from providing direct tuition assistance to truly needy students.
Nonetheless, state officials like prepaid tuition plans because they provide a politically popular service during an era when they have been forced to raise tuition sharply at state colleges, up to a peak nationally of 12 percent in 1991-92.
"They're almost patriotic," said Michael A. Olivas, a University of Houston law professor who has studied the plans. "Who can be against any plan that encourages parents to save money to send their children to school and rewards them for it? It's almost a no-brainer."
With increases in tuition exceeding gains in consumer prices by three or more percentage points in each of the last five years, participants like these plans because most lock in "tomorrow's tuition at today's rates," as the Massachusetts sales brochure points out. The Florida plan promises that "you never have to worry about whether the amount you saved will be enough."
"What I like about it is, once I put the money in, it can't be taken out," said Mr. Sweet, who together with his wife, a medical records specialist at a hospital, earns under $60,000. "If I decide I want a new car or the water heater blows up, I can't raid that fund."
Gale Richards, a home economics teacher in New Port Richey, Fla., has already paid off four years of college and two of dormitory expenses for her 9-year-old daughter, Bonnie, by putting down $135 a month for five years.
"There's a peace of mind about having that for her," said Ms. Richards, who earns $26,000 a year. "She's extremely bright, and there might be other options available for her, but at least we have this basic program."
The plans come in all shapes and sizes. Some states sell contracts guaranteeing they will pay whatever the tuition will be down the road; others sell bonds whose value can be applied toward the tuition bill. In Ohio, participants buy up to 400 "tuition units" of the $15,000 price tag of four years at a state college, paying $37.50 a unit.
The Sweets, who in addition to their son, Paul, have an 18-month-old daughter, Sarah, are squirreling away birthday gifts and the money they earn from trading in recyclables so they can put away $40 a month toward roughly half the cost of their children's anticipated college education. They want the children to pick up the rest of the tuition through summer jobs and savings.
Most states allow participants to make payments either in lump sums or in monthly Christmas Club-type installments as low as $25. The payments can be made at banks, through payroll deductions or with coupon books.
"This gives people a discipline of savings that they're used to, that they've done all their lives with other things," said William W. Montjoy, executive director of Florida's program.
The Florida program, whose popularity stems from a low-priced college system that means a Floridian can buy four years of senior college for a newborn at a rock-bottom $5,639, offers separate prepayment plans for dormitory costs and permits the savings to be transferred to out-of-state institutions. If a child cannot qualify for admission to a state college, the parents receive a refund of the money paid into the program, though not the accumulated interest.
Walter C. Young, a retired junior high school principal who represented Fort Lauderdale in the Florida Legislature for 20 years, decided to give each of his three grandchildren a gift of a fully paid college education. Over a seven-year period, he paid $3,500 to educate Ian Dasho, 17, $4,000 for Robert Bucellato, 8, and $5,000 for Elisabeth Tucker, 5. Whether the three decide to go to Florida State or Harvard or Slippery Rock State, they can apply the prevailing tuition at Florida's state colleges during their senior year of high school toward a college of their choice.
"I question whether I would have done it for the grandchildren if I didn't have an easy way to do it," said Mr. Young, 73.
Massachusetts, with more private college seats than public, does Florida one better by selling "U-Plan" bonds whose face value at maturity can be applied toward all or part of the tuition at 67 participating colleges in the state, including such elite private institutions as Wellesley, Smith and Mount Holyoke. By buying bonds, which pay an interest rate of 2.5 percentage points above the consumer price index, participants actually purchase a percentage of tuition at a Massachusetts college of their choice, with the percentage varying by college.
SOME plans, though, have had their problems. Michigan, the first state to enact a prepaid tuition plan, has halted new enrollments since 1991, because its plan's earnings fell 2.5 percentage points behind the pace of tuition increases.
Wary of the Michigan experience, Florida and Ohio set their purchase prices slightly above prevailing tuition costs. Nevertheless, last year, Ohio's officials chewed their nails as their investments returned only 1 percent. But this year, with investments earning 14.5 percent, they're delighting in their shrewdness.
In Ohio, proceeds from the prepaid program are invested by the state's pension system and thus risk is sharply reduced, with no more than 50 percent of a portfolio in equities. Since 1994, the investments have been backed by Ohio's full faith and credit.
Because of a favorable court ruling, even Michigan may soon get back into the prepaid tuition business. Last November, a Federal appeals court said Michigan should not have paid taxes on the investment income it earned and required the Internal Revenue Service to refund the state an amount lawyers calculate at $75 million. That decision is expected to open the floodgates for states that have been cautious about starting plans.
(Once they start college, students enrolled in prepaid plans do have to pay Federal income taxes on the appreciation in the value of their contracts.)
Prepaid tuition plans are not for everybody. They mostly attract middle-income people who get nervous choosing among stocks, bonds and mutual funds. Ohio's surveys show that most buyers, like the Sweets, earn $35,000 to $70,000. Canny investors, or those who can afford to pay canny investors, may do better by buying mutual funds. But state officials and satisfied participants point out that a mutual fund does not come with a guaranteed tuition.
Barbara M. Jennings, executive director of the Ohio Tuition Trust Authority, discourages low-income families from joining, saying they would be siphoning money they need for immediate essentials when the likelihood is their children will qualify for state grants.
"To me this is a middle-class empowerment thing that needs to be there because middle-income people are not qualifying for anything but student loans, and don't have the purchasing power to pay for college," said Mrs. Jennings.
Critics also see a number of philosophical and financial drawbacks to the plans. They worry that a convergence of low investment returns and rising college costs could spell disaster for the states.
"I think the states have fared O.K. because we've been in a bull market," said Peter A. Roberts, who runs a popular private prepaid tuition plan called the College Savings Plan in Princeton, N.J. "Inflation has been going down and the investment rate of return has been going up. The true test will come when those situations reverse themselves."
But that possibility does not worry participants like Mr. Young of Florida because the full faith and credit of the state is behind the plan.
"It may hurt the state," he said of a stock market decline. "But it will not hurt the people involved in the plan."
SOME experts believe that if the prepayment plans succeed in saturating the state colleges, state legislators may be less generous with the money they provide for student aid and loans. Indeed, both Mr. Roberts and Mr. Olivas think the plans are regressive transfers of wealth because every time a plan runs into trouble, a state may feel obligated to close the gap.
"People who don't go to college," Mr. Olivas said, "are paying for the elite who do go to college."
Mr. Roberts said, "It's definitely reverse Robin Hood." Mr. Roberts acknowledges that his own plan has been hurt by state plans with distinct tax advantages that he can't offer. Last year, Mr. Roberts filed a Federal suit against the Florida plan for infringing on College Savings Plan's patented investment technique.
Mr. Olivas also believes that college admissions officers will favor applicants backed by prepayment plans.
"I think the pressure is going to be irresistible to give preference to those kids who've got aid in hand as opposed to the ones who are need-eligible," he said.
Still, Mr. Olivas thinks the plans make sense because they serve as a ballast to keep tuition costs down. "Legislatures have to moderate tuition rates fully aware that the existence of this plan depends on modest raises, not wild swings," he said.
It is precisely their confidence in the state that has drawn people like the Sweets to put their measured earnings in this novel venture.
"Some of my friends say that I should go with a mutual fund because you can do better than something that just keeps up with inflation," Mr. Sweet said. "But I don't know of any mutual fund that is backed up by the full faith and credit of the state of Ohio."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 10; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1498 words

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
The American Dream Glitters Still -- in Foreign Countries

BYLINE: By ROBERT BRYCE 

 BODY:
IN 1991, John Connelly lost his job. With more than a decade of experience as a materials supplier, Mr. Connelly, now 45, hoped to find a new one quickly. After eight months, though, he began to worry. Finally, frustrated, he interviewed with Samarec, a Saudi Arabian oil company.
Within weeks, he was living in Jidda, making $55,000 a year and loving it. 
 Mr. Connelly is not alone. This may be the era of downsizing in the United States, but overseas, in both developed and developing nations, companies and governments are actively seeking skilled American workers, from engineers to entrepreneurs. "There are good opportunities now, but I only see them getting better," says Robert Sanborn, the director of the career center at Rice University in Houston and author of two books on working overseas.
Mr. Sanborn and other international employment advisers say the spread of capitalism and the globalization of the economy has created this worldwide demand.
The overall numbers of such jobs are elusive, but one common measure -- the tax forms filed by all Americans working abroad, regardless of employer -- are moving up. According to statistics from the Internal Revenue Service, about 159,000 Americans filed such tax forms in 1983. In 1987, about 171,000 forms were filed, and in 1991 there were approximately 220,000. Moreover, these statistics probably understate the truth because many citizens abroad do not file tax forms.
The I.R.S. has no statistics that are more recent -- it surveys these numbers just once every five years -- but Mr. Sanborn and others say the figures are only getting bigger.
"If you have the technical skills, language and cultural ability, and the proper temperament, there are opportunities," says Paul Flask, of Korn/Ferry International, an executive search firm. The firm recently found several American executives to help manage one of Russia's biggest industrial companies, Zil.
Mr. Flask, however, warns against thinking that getting a job abroad is easy. "You don't buy a book for $25 and apply," he said.
Still, the demand is widespread. In Eastern Europe, for instance, Poland, Slovakia, the Czech Republic and other nations embarking on market economies are eagerly seeking workers with business expertise. In the Czech Republic alone, some 10,000 Americans are now working, according to the American Embassy in Prague.
Erik Best, the president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Prague, is one of many Americans who have begun businesses in the city. Mr. Best publishes The Fleet Sheet, a daily newspaper published in English. "For those who speak Czech there are lots of opportunities," he said. "If they don't, the opportunities diminish -- but they are still there."
Like many Americans working abroad, Mr. Best, 32, had traveled extensively in the region before moving to Prague. He also speaks Russian, has an M.B.A. from the University of North Carolina, and has studied the economies of Eastern Europe.
Newly capitalist countries are not the only seekers of American labor. The Australian Government, anxious to bolster its economy, is energetically encouraging American entrepreneurs to relocate. The effort -- the attractions include dual citizenship and assistance in both relocation and business start-ups -- will snare an expected 3,600 American immigrants this year, compared with less than 1,400 in 1994.
One small-business owner, Elias Aghnatios, will move to Australia on Dec. 1. Mr. Aghnatios has run a computer sales and service company in Santa Monica, Calif., since 1987, but no more.
"I've had enough" of Los Angeles, he says. "I can't afford to buy a house here." He plans to open a computer company in Sydney or Brisbane, where, he says, the business climate is good.
IMMIGRANTS to Australia need a good deal of pocket change, however; the bigger a person's business and resources, the greater the chances of admission. On average, American entrepreneurs moving to Australia take along $500,000.
In the Middle East, however, skills alone are sufficient to land jobs. In the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia and elsewhere, the public and private sectors employ thousands of Western workers, including engineers, draftsmen, technicians and safety inspectors. The Government of Qatar, now in the midst of a $3.5 billion construction program to develop a natural gas field in the Persian Gulf, will have several hundred job openings for American workers in the next two years, says Steve Michaels of the Leslie Corporation, an international recruiting company.
While salaries in that region may be somewhat below comparable American pay levels, other factors often more than make up for the difference. In the United Arab Emirates, for example, cash allowances for housing, travel and other costs often add up to 38 to 44 percent of salary. And many Persian Gulf countries impose no income tax. Coupled with the I.R.S. exclusion of up to $70,000 in overseas income from taxes, that means American workers in that region often pay no tax to anyone.
Add in the generous housing and other subsidies, and "the only thing they have to buy is food and entertainment," says Mr. Michaels. (Of course, such advantages disappear in countries, like many in Western Europe, where tax rates and living expenses are higher than in the United States.)
Latin America, also thirsty for skilled workers, is where Brad Gray chose to go. He worked for AT&T until July 1, when he took a job with Itatel, a Brazilian company.
"I wasn't looking for a job, not at all," says Mr. Gray, who has worked for nearly a decade on cellular telephone and paging services. Instead, he was lured by the challenge of setting up a wireless communications network in a country with 155 million people. So he is selling his home in Austin, Tex., and, on Aug. 12, moving with his wife and 11-month-old son to Sao Paulo.
Of course, life-style preferences often play a big role in the decision to work overseas. For Mr. Aghnatios, for example, there is the smog and overcrowding of California, and his biggest concern -- a good quality of life for his 9-month-old son. "That's what it comes down to," he said. "Australia has a slower pace of life, the air is cleaner."
For others, the lure is adventure. After a three-year stint in Saudi Arabia, Mr. Connelly moved back to Denver in January. He could have found a job in the United States, he says, but took a job in Bombay, India, instead, because the domestic offers were either boring or didn't pay enough.
"You get hooked," he said. "Going overseas kind of spoils you for regular work."
That goes for children, too. After cruising the Nile and doing other exotic things during Mr. Connelly's stint in Saudi Arabia, his three school-age children have the perspective of world travelers. "The Holidome in Omaha," Mr. Connelly says with a chuckle, "just doesn't do it for them anymore."
 
 
 
Job Hunting Overseas
 WILL CANTRELL says there are two types of people who want to work overseas: the dreamers and serious job seekers.
The dreamers "expect to be overpaid and live in some exotic foreign capital," says Mr. Cantrell, who publishes The International Employment Hotline, a newsletter. "They are not willing to do what it takes to be qualified in the international job market."
For the serious seekers, Mr. Cantrell recommends the same strategies used in getting domestic jobs. Work the phones and network aggressively, for example. If you belong to a professional association, interview members who have worked abroad.
Seek out reputable headhunters and other talent-search firms -- especially those active in international placements or with offices worldwide.
For example, the Leslie Corporation of Houston is retained by Middle Eastern governments and companies to fill positions in a wide variety of fields.
Consult international employment listings. Large-circulation newspapers and periodicals carry them, but also check out specialty sources.
Mr. Cantrell's newsletter, which costs $39 a year, lists hundreds of overseas jobs (703 620-1972). Transitions Abroad, published every two months, is geared to entry-level work; it costs $19.95 a year (800 293-0373).
Also subscribe to foreign newspapers and periodicals for their job listings, or consult these publications at larger public libraries.
If it is practical and if you know where you want to live, visit there and look on-site -- this is always easier than a long-distance search.
Browse the many books on foreign employment. A popular one is "The Almanac for International Jobs and Careers," by Ronald L. Krannich and Caryl Rae Krannich (Impact, $19.95).
Although the hunt for foreign work is much like any job search, remember that it can take much longer than its stateside counterpart. "Job hunt while you are actively employed," Mr. Cantrell advises. Looking for a job abroad is "not for desperate people who have to put food on the table."
 ROBERT BRYCE

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS: FUNDS WATCH;
Sitting Tight Abroad Despite Weak Returns

BYLINE: By Carol Gould 

 BODY:
MUTUAL fund investors who own foreign funds remain committed to their holdings despite weak performances over the last 12 months, according to a recent survey by the Gallup organization for Scudder, Stevens & Clark Inc.
For the 12 months ended July 19, foreign stock funds gained a paltry 2 percent, while Pacific stock funds lost just under 1 percent and Europe stock funds gained 14 percent, reported Morningstar Inc., the fund researchers. Although the figure for Europe is far from bad, it pales next to the 24 percent gain for United States diversified stock funds in the period. 
 Investors, though, are undeterred. A quarter of all fund shareholders own global or international mutual funds, according to Gallup, which conducted telephone interviews with 1,000 households with stock or bond funds outside of employer-sponsored saving plans. Most of these people plan to stay in for the long haul, no matter the short-term results, the survey found.
More than half of the fund investors without international funds said it was unlikely that they would buy any. The most common responses -- 18 percent each -- were too risky, unfamiliar and no money available for investing.
Fund owners said they believed the greatest opportunities in the next three years were in Europe and the Pacific Basin, though Russia garnered a significant number of mentions as well. The greatest risks involved in foreign investing, the fund owners said, are economic and political instability. A year earlier, they were far more concerned about political turbulence than about economic conditions. In what may be a reminder of how quickly people forget, currency fluctuations fell to third on the list of risks. For the last year, of course, the dollar has largely been declining against foreign currencies, making foreign investments worth more for Americans.
 
Disappearing Acts
More and more funds are simply vanishing. Already this year, as many funds have been merged out of existence or liquidated as in all of 1994, according to Morningstar.
About 60 percent of this year's 189 disappearing funds can be attributed to mergers, largely because of consolidation by parent companies. The merger of Smith Barney and Shearson alone has accounted for the demise of 50 funds. More recently, Liberty Financial's acquisition of Colonial and First Union's purchase of the ABT and Evergreen groups have created a frenzy of fund consolidation, analysts say.
A lesser factor is a decision by some fund companies to simplify pricing. When investors began balking at paying hefty up-front sales charges several years ago, sponsors found ways to make fees less obvious, and along the way they created complex fee structures. One class of shares might have a redemption fee that declines over several years, while another might have an up-front sales charge. Van Kampen Merritt and the One Group have cut back from four classes of shares to three. Given the complexity of choosing among multiple classes, investors can only hope it's the beginning of a trend.
 
Investing Tools
 Morningstar's new software, Principia for Mutual Funds, is compatible with Windows and includes data on more than 6,500 funds. But it lacks the fund manager profiles, analysts' commentary and portfolio holdings that can be found on Morningstar's Ondisc product. Principia contains 98 categories of information on each fund as well as tools to find and rank funds and to draw charts. Similar data are available for closed-end funds and annuities. A one-year subscription to Principia is $95; a one-month trial subscription costs $45. Call (800) 876-5005.
The Vanguard Retirement Planner, software available in Windows and DOS versions, costs $15 plus $3 for shipping. The Vanguard Retirement Investing Guide, an 11-chapter book, costs $10 plus $3 for shipping. Both can be ordered for a total of $26.50. To order, call (800) 937-8368.
Kemper Financial Services has prepared a booklet to help investors choose a money fund. It is available by calling (800) 694-1080, extension 501.
 
Prospectus in English
There is good news for investors who are fed up with slogging through mutual fund prospectuses filled with legalese and jargon. Eight mutual fund companies began testing a new, slimmed-down version, called a "profile" prospectus, last week. For now, the short versions will be mailed along with the longer ones.
 The abbreviated prospectus provides 11 pieces of basic information, including the fund's goals, risks, investment strategies, appropriateness, fees and expenses. A bar chart shows the fund's total return for 10 years, making comparisons with other funds easier and showing years of declines.
The test has the blessing of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which will work with the fund companies to evaluate the project's success. Although eight companies were involved in the initial project, any company can now adopt the format for any or all funds, as long as the longer prospectus is given to investors as well.

Manager Changes
Neil Devlin has handed over the reins of Templeton Income to Tom Latta, who will also keep running Franklin Templeton German Bond.
 
New Funds
Ariel Premier Bond, a joint venture of Ariel Capital Management and the Lincoln Capital Management Company, aims for maximum total return by investing in high-quality fixed-income securities.
The Flex-Partners group of Dublin, Ohio, is offering mutual funds with sales charges as a counterpart to the Flex funds group. The new investments are the TAA fund, a "fund of funds" that will invest in other stock funds, and the BTB fund, which invests in equities of foreign and domestic utilities that do not use nuclear power.
 
In Brief
Vanguard's version of Schwab's fund service is now available on a limited basis. Vanguard Fund Access provides a consolidated statement and a central account for investors in funds from nine other groups, including Benham, Dreyfus, Mutual Series, Neuberger & Berman and Strong. So far, only a small group of Vanguard Brokerage customers have been offered the service, but it will be expanded over the next year. Fund transactions cost $35.
Bank Polska Kasa Opieki S.A. and Alliance Capital Management have signed a letter of understanding to form the Trust Fund Company, a jointly owned venture that would market funds to Polish investors. Alliance's move follows that of the Pioneer group, which set up a Poland fund in July 1992
Berwyn Income has exceeded $100 million and expects to close to new investors shortly. Its companion fund, Berwyn, has $76 million and also plans to close at $100 million.
Colonial Newport Tiger has stopped accepting new retail accounts through the no-load program of Charles Schwab & Company, but existing shareholders can add to their positions. Financial advisers, though, can still buy the fund for clients without a sales charge.
Stein Roe Young Investor, a growth fund intended to teach children about money and investing, has reduced its minimum investment to $100 from $500 for people who invest at least $50 a month in an automatic investing plan, through Jan. 31, 1996.
Value Line Fund has changed its investment style to try to reduce volatility by adding stocks ranked 3 by Value Line to its mix, previously limited to stocks ranked 1 and 2. Value Line ranks stocks on a 1 to 5 scale, 1 being the most likely to outperform the general stock market.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;
Domino Real-Estate Deal Cleared

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
A final obstacle has been removed to a complex deal to relocate both the City University Graduate Center and the State University College of Optometry in a $173 million project involving the old B. Altman department store and two other sites.
In a three-year process, the college will move from 315 Park Avenue South at 24th Street to CUNY's building at 33 West 42d. CUNY will move to the Altman building, on Fifth Avenue at 34th. To allow the deal, Gov. George E. Pataki signed a special law cutting off state funds for the optometry college's $7 million annual rent, breaking its lease without penalty or compensation to the landlord. Mr. Pataki's press office did not respond to a reporter's inquiries. 
 The law is under attack from State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, some real estate industry leaders and the owners of 315 Park. The owners, TM Park Associates, say the move could bankrupt them, since their $50 million mortgage is based on the lease's lasting till 2004. They plan to sue. Mr. McCall's office called the law unprecedented and said it could have serious consequences, hampering future lease negotiations.
"The concept that the state can simply abrogate a contract seems to me unfair, unethical and immoral -- you and I could not get away with that," said Michael Cohen, president of Williams Real Estate, which has several leases with state agencies. He called the law a terrible precedent.
Controversies aside, officials at the optometry college and CUNY Center say they are delighted at the prospect of new homes. CUNY, which opened in 1961, long ago outgrew its 172,924-square-foot 42d Street building and spilled over into 100,831 square feet rented in adjacent buildings.
"We're really cramped," said Pam Bayless, a spokeswoman. "The hope is to get out as soon as possible."
Despite agitation within the Real Estate Board of New York to oppose the lease-breaking law, the industry organization has not done so. Some critics say that reflects the influence of Peter L. Malkin, a governor of the board and a real estate power who is a general partner in the redevelopment of the Altman site. He did not respond to a request for an interview.
The CUNY move is the third time Mr. Malkin's partnership has benefited from special legislation and public money to help rescue the troubled Altman project and fill it with new occupants and owners.
After the store closed in 1989, the partnership tried to convert the building into the New York Resource Center, a mart for the office furnishing industry. But that flopped as the city sank into recession. Then the partnership tried dividing the building into condominiums for nonprofit institutions who, by owning, would avoid property taxes.
Senator Roy Goodman, who is also the Manhattan Republican Party chairman, sponsored the lease-breaking law and also introduced an earlier bill that helped land the Altman building's first occupant. That legislation enabled the State Dormitory Authority to finance $30 million for Oxford University Press to buy 110,000 square feet in the top five floors of the building's eastern end, facing Madison Avenue. Oxford moved in this year. Mr. Goodman was out of town last week and unavailable for comment.
The Dormitory Authority is also helping finance a $125 million project creating the Science, Industry and Business Library in 213,000 square feet on the lower eight floors of the Madison wing, scheduled to open later this year. CUNY's move, also authorized by state legislation and financed by public funds, will fill 375,000 square feet of Altman's remaining space, making CUNY the building's major occupant.
 BRUCE LAMBERT

HEADLINE: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI 

 BODY:

HARLEM
A 19-Day Week Of Celebration
It started 21 years ago as a one-day celebration of Harlem. This year, Harlem Week is running for 19 days with concerts, films, basketball competitions, a carnival and a conference on economic development.
The activities, most of which are free, will be held throughout the sprawling, diverse community.
"This is our festival to showcase Harlem in a positive light," said Marko Nobles, a spokesman for the event. "The mood of Harlem changes during this time."
Through Aug. 27, the Museum of African-American History and Arts will show films daily as part of the 1995 Harlem Week Black Film Festival in the art gallery of the Adam Clayton Powell Jr. State Building, 163 West 125th Street, at Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard.
The Harlem Carnival will take place Thursday at noon at 123d Street and Morningside Avenue.
Harlem Week; for more information and a schedule of events: (212) 427-3315.
VAN CORTLANDT PARK
A Musical Mosaic: Rag, Pops and Bach
The Bronx Arts Ensemble's Summermusic concert series continues Sundays through Aug. 27.
The ensemble is made up of a core group of about 15 freelance musicians playing the flute, oboe, clarinet, bassoon, horn, violin, viola, cello and bass.
On Sundays the group plays outdoors at 2 P.M. at the Rockwood Drive Circle in Van Cortlandt Park (near Mosholu Parkway and Broadway) and then again indoors at 4 P.M. at McGinley Center at Fordham University, Bronx Rose Hill Campus at Southern Boulevard.
Concerts, different each weekend, include the Brass Pops today, Ragtime Favorites on Aug. 13, Latin American Celebration on Aug. 20 and Bach Festival on Aug. 27.
Bronx Arts Ensemble; for information and directions call (718) 601-7399.
 
FLUSHING
Call: Save Qu Yuan! Response: What, Again?
The dragons are coming back to the lake in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park today with the fifth annual Hong Kong Dragon Boat Festival.
The boats, which are 39 feet long, have dragon heads at the prow and tails at the stern. Each is powered by a team of 20.
The race is based on an ancient Asian legend, said Melinda Parsons of the Hong Kong Government office in New York. Around 400 B.C., Qu Yuan, a court minister who was loved by the people but not by the king, was banished. For a time, he wandered about the countryside, writing poetry, but he eventually decided to drown himself in a river. Local fishermen raced to save him, but in vain. Their rescue dash is re-enacted in the dragon boat race.
Six boats will race today, and the championship will be decided next Sunday.
Hong Kong Boat Festival, Meadow Lake in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park; today, 1 P.M. to 4 P.M., and next Sunday, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.; free; (212) 629-0370.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Washington: Not Just Another Big City?

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
DESPITE the gloss and pomp of its Federal superstructure, the nation's capital offers as much urban pathology as Detroit and New York City. Underneath a patina furnished by museums and monuments, the city has lurched from mayoral scandals to fiscal crises, with high rates of crime, homelessness and teen-age pregnancy. The capital, in the view of some Republicans, represents the failed liberal agenda writ large.
 So it was all the more remarkable last week that Newt Gingrich, the Speaker of the House, attended a town meeting at a local high school to emphasize his commitment to rejuvenate the capital and make it a model of urban policy. He says he is receptive to ideas that cost money, whether they involve hiring more police officers or giving special tax breaks to city residents. 
 At the same time that the Speaker affirmed his desire to remodel the District, House Republicans were cutting housing assistance and education and job programs that funnel billions of dollars a year into distressed inner-city neighborhoods like those in Washington.
 How to reconcile these disparate efforts is a mystery. Mr. Gingrich, who recognizes that Congress has a special responsibility for the District, says his vision is to make Washington "the best capital city in the world" by 2000. His ideas applied elsewhere in the country would cost tens of billions of dollars, and he would be seeking more money, not less, for the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
 Mr. Gingrich appointed a task force of House Republicans to brainstorm for new ideas on education, housing, crime, welfare and taxes in the capital. One panel member, Representative Rick A. Lazio of Long Island, said: "It is inescapable that this city is going to require an infusion of Federal dollars to meet the challenge of making it the best capital city in the world. It's not going to happen simply through regulatory changes and cheerleading."
 Even as Republicans were lavishing attention on Washington, the House passed an appropriations bill last week that cuts the budget of the Housing Department by 26 percent, to $19.4 billion next year from $26.1 billion. The bill would cut assistance for homeless people by 39 percent, to $676 million from $1.1 billion, and money for the renovation of public housing would be reduced 32 percent, to $2.5 billion from $3.7 billion.

 
 
Few Specifics as Yet
 The House also passed a spending bill for the Labor Department that would eliminate the summer jobs program for disadvantaged youth. President Clinton had requested $958 million. Democrats said the program teaches work habits to teen-agers and helps keep peace in the cities, but the House Appropriations Committee said it found no evidence that it produced any lasting improvement in employment or earnings.
 At Wednesday's town meeting, Mr. Gingrich listened more than he talked. He promised "significant tax relief" for city residents and said he would seek "increases in resources" for the city, but he offered few specifics.
 "I have to applaud the systematic way the Speaker has generated ideas for Washington," Henry G. Cisneros, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said recently. "I wish he would widen his vision and encourage the same kind of innovation across the country."
 The capital's tax base has been eroding and its population is declining. After two decades of home rule, Congress has revoked some of the powers it granted the city, whose residents say they suffer taxation without full representation. In April, Congress created a financial control board capable of overruling actions of the Mayor and City Council that would exacerbate the city's current fiscal emergency.
 "The great virtue of the fiscal crisis," Mr. Gingrich said, "is that it forces people to confront the scale of the problem and creates an opportunity for us to rethink the future of Washington."
 While the Speaker was ferreting out ways to revitalize the capital, Republican troops under his command passed the housing bill. Mayor Dennis W. Archer of Detroit, a Democrat, said the measure would be "devastating to every major city in the United States."

 
 
Words and Deeds
Mr. Cisneros said that the Republicans were cutting welfare, food stamps, child care and child nutrition programs, as well as housing assistance. Taken together, he said, these bills will "draw jobs, private investment and income out of inner-city neighborhoods," at the very time Mr. Gingrich says he is trying to stimulate private investment and employment in Washington.
 The Speaker recently invited the nation's mayors to join him in writing a "contract with the cities," after the Contract With America, the manifesto that set the agenda for House Republicans in their first 100 days this year. Cities, he said, might keep 20 percent of any savings that result from more efficient operation of local programs, or from the elimination of "stupid" Federal mandates and requirements.
 Washingtonians who are skeptical of the Speaker suggest that he is exploiting the city and its Mayor, Marion S. Barry Jr., to show that Republicans have an urban agenda and harbor no racial bias. But Eleanor Holmes Norton, Washington's nonvoting delegate in the House of Representatives, who introduced Mr. Gingrich to the audience Wednesday, appears to have become a true believer.
 "This is an overwhelmingly liberal, Democratic town," Mrs. Norton said. "Gingrich is our opposite politically." But, she said, "the ultraconservative Speaker" has repeatedly shown that he is willing to help "the ultraliberal District," as he did last week when the House passed a bill to inject extra highway money into the nearly bankrupt city.
 George E. Peterson, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute, a nonpartisan research center here, said "there's a potential inconsistency" between the Republicans' solicitude for the capital and their crusade to cut spending on urban programs elsewhere. The Speaker says many of those programs have failed, but he clearly views Washington as a special case, requiring new approaches and resources.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Business Often Goes to the Swift, Not the Best

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
IT was Emerson, by most accounts, who said: Build a better mousetrap, and the world will beat a path to your door. And for a nation of optimists, inventors and entrepreneurs, the maxim embraces an American ideal -- smarts and hard work will be rewarded.
 Woolly-headed nonsense, according to some leading economists. "It's naive to believe that efficient engineering solutions win in the marketplace," declares Paul A. David, a professor at Stanford University and a senior research fellow at Oxford University's All Souls College. "That view is not supported by the study of history." 
 The notion that markets make winners of second-best technology appears perverse. But one of the most telling examples, it seems, is now making its way to the marketplace with a vengeance: Windows 95, a new software program from the Microsoft Corporation, is scheduled to go on sale Aug. 24. Yet as a media phenomenon, it has already become the business world's equivalent of the O.J. Simpson trial, written, discussed and scrutinized endlessly.
 The fuss is because Windows 95 is the lastest version of an industry standard -- Microsoft's operating system software, which runs more than 80 percent of the world's personal computers. Though the product is not yet on the shelves, reviewers have given Windows 95 high marks for being a big improvement for most computer users, making PC's less frustrating to use and able to do more. Windows 95 is so good, they agree, that it is almost like Apple's decade-old Macintosh system.
 So why is Microsoft's Windows the industry standard while Apple's Macintosh is a distant also-ran? The search for answers to such questions has spawned a cottage industry of economists who try to explain not only the seeming paradox of personal-computer software but also why keyboards use the qwerty format (the first six letters), why the VHS format prevailed in videocassette tapes, why light-water reactors were used in nuclear power plants and why alternating current is used to transmit electric power.
 Sometimes, these economists say, the best product lost in the marketplace, and at other times the success of the winner did not hinge on superior design or performance. Instead, they talk of "network effects," "increasing returns markets," "path dependencies" and "leverage." In layman's terms, history and luck have a lot to do with the outcome.
 This school of thought seems an affront to market economics. The "invisible hand" of the marketplace, if not moral, is at least supposed to be ruthlessly efficient. Still, there is a logic to why some products become industry standards even when they are not necessarily superior to alternatives. Initially, the product may have benefited from more aggressive marketing or missteps by rivals. Later, the advantages of being ahead snowball, insuring that consumers flock to the leader.
Microsoft's Windows, which was introduced in 1985, has certainly been a beneficiary of that logic. Microsoft sold its software far more successfully than Apple to companies, the big growth market for personal computers until recently. As its dominance grew, Microsoft's operating system became the standard that more and more software applications, from word processing to E-mail, were written to run on, which in turn attracted more users. A major advantage to using Windows was that "everybody else was" -- inferior or not, it became the common language of computing.

 
 
The Qwerty Factor
 The same principle of "self-reinforcing advantage" that helps explain choices in technology, says Paul Krugman, a Stanford economist, can also be used to explain why industries are clustered in certain places. Or why cities, like New York and Chicago, continue to thrive long after their original economic rationale has disappeared.
 Silicon Valley, Mr. Krugman notes, is best suited for growing apricots. "There is nothing in the soil or air that makes it ideal to make microchips here," he said. But once the industry got started in the early 1970's, a skilled labor pool, networks of specialized suppliers and a community of people sharing ideas all combined to insure that the heart of the semiconductor industry and then software makers would reside in Silicon Valley. Mr. Krugman tells of similar blend of clustering that resulted in 80 percent of America's carpet-making industry being located around Dalton, Ga.
 The way chance and history can determine winners is what Mr. Krugman calls "the world of qwerty."
 The man responsible for securing qwerty a respectable place in economic history was Mr. David, the Stanford and Oxford scholar, who wrote a minor classic entitled "Clio and the Economics of Qwerty," published in the American Economics Review in 1985.
 In it, Mr. David presents some of the well-known history of the typewriter. The qwerty typewriter was designed by a Milwaukee printer, Christopher Latham Sholes, and introduced in the 1870's. The keyboard layout was designed partly to insure that typebars would not jam if the operator typed too quickly. And the second row contained all the letters needed to peck out the brand name: TYPE WRITER.
 Rival designs surfaced during the typewriter boom of the 1880's, like the so-called Ideal keyboard, which placed in the home row the sequence DHIATENSOR, which is said to be the 10 letters needed to spell 70 percent of the words in the English language. Later, in 1932 August Dvorak and W.L. Dealey patented another keyboard arrangement, the Dvorak Simplified Keyboard, which has devotees to this day and holds many records for speed typing.
 The key to qwerty's success, Mr. David says, was the use of its keyboard format by schools teaching touch typing in the late 1880's. Qwerty's use in training made it the standard, which sharply increased the costs and inconvenience of switching to another, more efficient system.
 Yet the qwerty doctrine has now brought a revisionist attack from Stan Liebowitz, an economist at the University of Texas management school, and Stephen E. Margolis, an economist at North Carolina State University. They raise doubts about the claims that alternative keyboards, especially the Dvorak, were superior. In fact, one study in the 1940's by the Navy was conducted under the auspices of a time-motion expert, Lt. Commander August Dvorak. "Paul David tells a great story," said Mr. Liebowitz. "It just turns out to be wrong."
 Mr. David replies that his critics may be right on some details, but he insists that his qwerty conclusion remains unchallenged. "The game was already over by 1910," he said. "Qwerty was the de facto standard."
 The story of the Beta and the VHS has another theme: Beta came first, and to this day some say it was superior. But the VHS offered two hours of recording time instead of the Beta's one. Sony changed its Beta, but not fast enough.
 And the mousetrap? Well, it turns out that people are constantly coming up with new mousetrap patents. Some have made inroads, but none has apparently supplanted the basic standard yet.
 In 1988, Claude Coots, a textile worker in Mentone, Ala., patented the Electric Mouse Exterminator, which is a small rectangular box with an entrance at one end, bait at the other and an electrical killing mechanism. Mr. Coots, now 65 and retired, tells a sad story of unreliable partners, business mistakes and an investment lost.
 "It was a better mousetrap," he said, "but everybody gave up on it."
