HEADLINE: DANCE;
When Disbanding Is the Only Logical Step

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING 

 BODY:
Ralph Lemon's career as a modern dance choreographer took off in 1990, a decade after he created his first pieces. He was internationally acknowledged as a leading member of his generation in American dance. He had established a small but highly respected company of dancers attuned to the demands of his bold, complex style of choreography. And he was passionate about his work. "I love the edge of it, the challenge," he told an interviewer the following year. "I love the fight. Not the struggle, but the challenge of solving problems I pick out of the air."
Yet Mr. Lemon had started to feel a sense of foreboding about the field in general. "Everything started to get like a roller coaster," he said in a recent interview. "We'd have a good year touring, then the next year work would be cut in half. And I was one of the fortunate ones." 
 By 1993, he began to think seriously about working in new ways to "stretch the form" of dance, as he puts it. Then, last October, he told his six dancers he was going to disband the company.
It was a hard decision. He had made a point of involving them in creative decisions; together they had formed a close-knit family of performers, and it would not be easy to find jobs like this. But in their hearts, Mr. Lemon said, the dancers knew that it was time. "I told them that I was frustrated, that I felt this was becoming a little abusive," he said. "They kind of agreed."
The 10-year-old Ralph Lemon Company will go out in style, with seasons at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass., where the troupe performs Aug. 18 through 20, and at the Joyce Theater in Manhattan in October. Mr. Lemon will move on to projects -- about half of which are already financed -- that include collaborations on a photographic book, directing a video documentary on Haitians living in Miami, staging movement for a play to be produced by the Penumbra Theater of St. Paul, and creating a film-dance duet with Bebe Miller, another choreographer who has chosen not to have a company. The Lemon dancers will try to find other work as performers or in other areas of dance.
But the pool of modern dance companies is slowly shrinking, as choreographers are restructuring, rethinking or closing down the single-choreographer troupes that have been a tradition in American modern dance. The Lar Lubovitch Dance Company will concentrate for the next year and a half on creating dances rather than performing. Susan Marshall talks of reconsidering the traditional company structure and reorganizing her choreographic work. Laura Dean, daunted in part by the lack of affordable studio space in New York City, is re-establishing her group of musicians and dancers in Salisbury, N.C. And Bella Lewitzky recently closed her 30-year-old troupe out of a desire to "leave behind the perpetual struggles of getting boards, finding money, just surviving," she told Dance Magazine.
Most of the choreographers are in their 30's and 40's and have maintained small or medium-sized troupes for 10 to 15 years. Some have decided that they can no longer continue creating dances while faced with the burden of trying to keep even a small organization afloat in a difficult economy and an atmosphere of seeming antipathy toward the arts in America. The specter of the demise of the National Endowment for the Arts hangs over dance these days, symbolizing for many a despair about the future.
"There doesn't seem to be any mercy," said Maxine Glorsky, a stage manager who has worked with the Lubovitch company. "I think the reason people are closing companies is because they know they can go nowhere, they can ask for nothing. There is no support, no underpinning any more. People used to go banging on doors. Now they're not bothering. No one is listening behind those doors."
But there are other, more complex reasons. Most of the choreographers came of artistic age during the dance boom of the late 1970's and 80's, when everyone had ideas, and audiences were eager and growing. The audiences are still there, Paul Taylor suggests, speaking from the perspective of one who has lived through a good many of the rises and falls of modern dance in a career spanning four decades.
What has changed, then? It may be that the ideas no longer seem so new and thrilling, and that the struggle is now less for achievement than for simple survival.
Mr. Lemon, who is 42, arrived in New York from Minneapolis in 1979. "There was a lot of exciting energy for dance," he said. "This wonderful feeling of anything being possible, in the sense of where you could go with the form, beyond what was traditional. And I was getting a lot of encouragement."
He presented his first evening of choreography in 1981. The next step seemed clear. "Everyone I danced with had a company," Mr. Lemon said. "It seemed to me I was following a tradition. That was the way it worked in modern dance."
To develop one's own work and style, it was necessary to have a core group of dancers who would serve as instruments for the expression of that style. To keep such a group at the ready meant providing employment. And it was then -- and is now -- easier to raise money for an institution than for an individual artist. In 1985, Mr. Lemon incorporated a hitherto informal group of dancer friends as a nonprofit organization. By 1995, its annual operating budget was $170,000.
In talking about the last 10 years, Mr. Lemon frequently described himself as lucky. Friends helped him manage his company. For the last three years he and his dancers have rehearsed free of charge at the Dia Center for the Arts on Mercer Street, a lifeline organization for small and medium-sized companies and individual artists. But it was becoming increasingly clear to Mr. Lemon that he would not be able to offer the full-time employment and health benefits that he felt his dancers deserved, at least in the foreseeable future. His dancers would never have the stable employment of the performers he had worked with in state-supported European troupes. And his worries were making it harder to concentrate on making dances.
"The art form is about struggling," Mr. Lemon said, repeating a familiar dictum about American modern dance. "But I'm not settling for that. It's affecting my work. I need to find a kind of space and work that is right for me. It means letting go of that traditional dance company model. Too much of my time was spent trying to hold on."
Yet this has been "the hardest year," Mr. Lemon said. "I opened up this can of worms. A grieving has been taking place. There has been a sense of abandonment. There was anger."
 FOR THE FIRST FEW MONTHS, RECALLED Nicholas Leichter, a company member, several of the dancers simply could not accept the news. Eventually, there was a sense of relief and even happiness for Mr. Lemon. Wally Cardona, who joined the group in 1987, agrees. "I thought he was doing a very right thing for himself and for the company," Mr. Cardona said. "A lot of time was being spent on just holding things together, which for a group of creative artists is a little limiting."
As reality sank in, the dancers began to make plans to move on. Mr. Leichter and Mr. Cardona will be presenting their own choreography in concerts at St. Mark's Church in November and December, respectively. Mr. Leichter even dreams of eventually forming his own company, particularly as he watches the dancers he wants to work with committing to other choreographers so as not to waste their young years off the stage.
Mr. Cardona will continue to teach dance. Barbara Gruber plans to get her master's degree in dance and become a teacher. "I really want a life," she said. Some will leave dance. Few in the company had been able to support themselves entirely by dancing. Most had already been dancing part-time with other groups. But now the search begins again for a place to put down artistic roots.
Ms. Gruber and Mr. Cardona worry about the dancers of the future. Ms. Gruber talks of a gifted and intelligent 24-year-old dancer she knows who she fears will never have a solid career as a performer. Mr. Cardona watches the young dancers in his classes, so well-trained and technically adept, and wonders if they will ever dance anywhere but in the studio. And how will they learn to be individuals without the opportunity to test themselves on stages, in a company situation? "It takes a long time," Mr. Cardona said, looking back on "all those years with Ralph, on different stages, learning who I was." His students, he added, can do anything asked of them. "But they are losing themselves."
It is from those dancers that the choreographers of the future will come. The modern masters learned about their craft in part from performing with companies. Mr. Taylor began to create dances while performing with Martha Graham, working with friends at first as a way to learn about being a dancer.
"I can't tell you how valuable an experience it is to be in a company," Mr. Taylor said. "Martha herself gave me the feeling that I could do something in this direction. Being around people you learn that it's possible, that it can happen. You learn how rehearsals are conducted. You learn about stages. You learn about what you want to steal and definitely what not to."
Faced with shrinking careers, some dancers may begin to choreograph prematurely in their attempt to get onto the stage. "I think a lot of dancers jump into choreography too soon, before they are ready," Joan Duddy, director of dance programming at Dia, said. "What's that line from 'A Chorus Line'? 'There I was on unemployment, dancing for my own enjoyment.' "
Ms. Duddy is discovering that even solo performers are having to revert to the shared programs that were a necessity of dance in the 1960's, despite the fact that Dia offers one of the most affordable deals in New York dance.
Some choreographers are turning away from dance altogether. "A lot of younger choreographers are becoming involved in film, video, opera and theater," said Sali Ann Kriegsman, director of Jacob's Pillow and the former director of dance at the N.E.A., "though film and video are also extremely difficult to raise money for. One could get very depressed. But I think it's exciting that these artists are trying to come up with ways of working that are more responsive to their needs." What must be done now, Ms. Kriegsman added, is to develop ways for choreographers to move in and out of dance.
Mr. Lemon agrees that the shift is not necessarily a bad thing. "The Judson said no to technique," he said, referring to the iconoclastic Judson Dance Theater movement of the 1960's that ushered in postmodernism in dance. "I'm saying no to the traditional company model. I'm playing with the edge of not dancing any more." At the same time, Mr. Lemon has been setting up dance workshops around the country. "Arenas where I can continue to explore," he explained, "to stay connected to the dancing part.
"A part of me feels that dance is dying in this country. I would really like to see how and if the form becomes something else, transforms. The traditional company model is all we know. Is there something else?"

HEADLINE: Wheels, Deals, Half-Pipe Dreams

BYLINE: By JESSE McKINLEY

 BODY:
Kanaf Hagi lay in his cramped room in a Oneida County juvenile detention center on a warm July morning and imagined himself flying. A hyper kid with trigger reflexes, Kanaf could feel his feet twist in phantom intimations of what they could do on wheels, and his mind spun with images of himself mid-sky, body stretched beyond the ground and way beyond the fences of juvenile hall.
Kanaf had just served a year-long sentence for beating a man with a pair of num-chuks while stoned. Today he was leaving. There was only one thing on his mind: getting back to the skate ramps of Mullaly Park. 
 That same morning, Julio Rivera, a slight, soft-faced 14-year-old with a shaggy head of hair, pulled himself out of bed early at his home in the South Bronx. Yanking on his skates, he glided down the long wooden hallway of his home and headed for the door. His mother, Raquel, amazed at her son's early rise, screamed her daily blessing, "Que Dios te bendiga!," at the closing door.
Outside his home, at East 162d and Walton Avenue in the Bronx, Julio slipped his headphones into his ears and started toward Mullaly, avoiding rough spots in the street and instinctively turning up the volume. Ever since he'd taken up in-line and stopped hanging on the street -- dropping bottles from the roof, xxxxx -- his former mates called him "Shrimpy" or "white boy."
But today it was too early for taunts. Julio had gotten up to wait for Kanaf to return, the friend who first taught him how to skate the ramps and rails of Mullaly Park's skate rink, before he was sent away. Kanaf had been the best skater that the local crowd at Mullaly had ever seen. Now that he was coming back, Julio had a few things to show him.
Kanaf and Julio are skate dreamers, two urban hopefuls in a new sport called aggressive skating. Aggressive is one of a number of so-called alternative sports, like snowboarding, downhill biking and bungee jumping currently in vogue with the young and televised. Alternative sports make good TV, and TV makes good for the athletes, with made-for-the-small-screen spectacles like ESPN's Extreme Games and MTV sports shows creating mini-celebrities of those willing to risk life and limb to create eye-catching visual fare.
Aggressive skating consists of in-line skaters, moving at maximum sped, performing tricks, flips, and grabs while either in a half-pipe or on a street course dotted with ramps, rails and boxes. But competitions are only part of the game. Aggressive skaters and their fast, flashy talents are rapidly being recruited by advertisers who want to cash in on the young, subculture feel of the sport to peddle everything from candy bars to sunglasses.
The air of hip glamour hanging around the sport are also encouraged by skate companies themselves, who keep stables of an elite skaters on monthly retainers and fly them around the country for promotional events and competitions. Their motivation is simple: In-line is the nation's fastest growing sport, with sales of over million dollars in 1994, according to statistics from the National Sporting Goods Association. And aggressive skating, with whole new lines of special skates (selling for about $200 a pair), pads and wheels, is in-line's fastest growing segment.
Companies scout places like Mullaly Park's skate rink, the city's only rink equipped with a half-pipe and a street course, for young skaters to add to their teams.
Success can come as fast as the sport. Take the case of Rollison Rivera, a one- time pitching prospect for the Yankees from Washington Heights, who took up skating at Mullaly a year ago. Last October, he was featured in a video which was shown on MTV That led to a sponsorship and monthly retainer from Rocce's skates. Today, he has endorsement contracts with four other companies, is starring in new documentary, "Hoax 2" about the sport, and is negotiating for a wheel endorsement contract that would pay him a nickle for every wheel sold. Count of the number of skates you see on a Manhattan street and you understand the potential for quick cash.
But Rollison's story is rare. A much more common deal involves free merchandise: boxes of wheels, t-shirts, ball bearings, clothing, even skates. What companies expect in return is for skaters to talk up the products.
But for the sport's participants, mostly under 20, mostly male, the appeal is not only economic. It's emotional. Aggressive skaters say they are part of a close-knit community that shelters them from the dangers of the streets and gives them individual and group identity.
The sport has its own heros, most known by nicknames, first names or just initials (like Arlo Isenberg, or Arlo, the king of the street, and C.E., Chris Edwards, a California skater with his own line of skates.)
It has its own lingo and traditions. The term "roller blading" is a considered a curse. It is offensive amongst aggressives to wear Spandex, the common garb of recreational skaters. They talk about run-ins with "gromlits" (i.e. skateboarders) and the old days on "quads" (standard roller skates).
The skating rite of passage is "sessioning" -- a practice where a pack of skaters travel from location to location using various bits of the urban landscape to hone their skills. Favorite spots are the steps at Union Square with their waxed curbs, or the "Screamer", a 25-step long rail in downtown Manhattan, which the skaters "grind" down i.e. use the middle wheels of the skate to locomote and the side of the skate to brake their descent. Mastering an especially difficult handrail can become a covert citywide challenge -- the rails at St. Luke's Hospital on 58th Street and 8th Avenue are the current dare.
Whether or not the sport will have mass appeal or staying power is debatable. What is certain is that the odds of making a career out of being a professional in-line skater are extremely long. (There are about 150 skaters nationwide making a decent living as "professional" in-line skaters, experts say -- professional basketball, by contrast, hires about 360, at much higher rates.)
Still, the possibility of that is enough to make young people like Kanaf and Julio dream of long green lawns with skate ramps, of making a life by doing something they love, or even just the simple attention brought by winning a neighborhood competition.
Maybe that attention would bring a break: a recommendation by a scout for an sponsorship or an endorsement offer. And that maybe, could lead to something bigger. At the very least, for Kanaf and Julio, winning means respect from peers and pride in one's self.
It is those things that make them skate, those things that make them move.
 
THE FIRST SKATE
Monday afternoon. Kanaf flew down River Avenue towards Mullaly. His tight schedule (off the bus at 1 P.M., to the skate shop for wheels, then home, to Mullaly by 3) had been blown by Manhattan traffic and his grandfather's reluctance to run red lights. But now he was out of the car and on skates again.
Mullaly skate rink is a smooth concrete oval in the corner of Mullaly Park, a run-down patch of green flowing north from Yankee Stadium. The rink, at East 164th Street and River Avenue, is the almost exclusive domain of children and teenagers. Facial hair is rare. And the trash that litters the broken concrete around the rink consists of soda bottles, ice cream containers, and candy wrappers. The park is overseen by two tattooed twentysomthing BMX bikers who sport Parks Department t-shirts and read "Pictorial" to bide the time. Two rusted snow plows resting inexplicably in one corner of the park signal the abandonment of adult bureaucracy.
When Kanaf turned the corner into the park, he saw things had changed. The skate rink had been nearly barren when he left, with the exception of a beat-up half pipe and few rotting plywood ramps which periodically got burned by vandals. Now, the park was crammed new ramps and practice rails.
Some things were the same: the empty chemical drums that served as giant steps up to the top of eight foot tall half-pipe, the Puerto Rican flag painted on a ramp, and the deafening screech of the passing 4 train overhead.
The big difference was in the crowd, its size and its makeup.
"50 skaters I don't know," Kanaf thought to himself. And young. Kids he last had seen as clumsy 5 year-olds were on skates. And on ramps.
Ray Mendez was one of the first to see Kanaf back. Ray is a 20-year old professional skater (an elder, by aggressive standards) who grew up in the same building as Julio. An assured young man with a casual, easy to talk to style, he is the de facto big brother to most young skater at Mullaly. He saw changes in Kanaf too.
Kanaf had left a street talker, a cocky skate prodigy whose talent was "phenomenal," according to Ray, but whose attitude was of "a little snot." Ray remembered when Kanaf would get baked and try to skate, one time running into a biker and breaking his nose. But now Kanaf's whole manner had changed: something about him was calmer, more focused.
"He had a smile on his face," said Ray.
After a few high five's and screaming "Heys" and "Where you beens" from friends, Kanaf glided onto the rink, forgetting his pads and immediately hopping onto the half-pipe.
He fell. Laughter came from everywhere. Kanaf laughed too but felt the flare of embarrassment inside him. I really fell off, he thought. He got up and retreated to the edge of the rink.
It was then someone handed Kanaf a flyer. There was a competition at the rink that coming Saturday, July 15. Two photos on the flyer jumped out at Kanaf. Both were of Julio, arching his legs behind him, perfectly, to touch his back in mid-air.
Julio couldn't take the heat. He'd waited at the rink till the sun had burned him and then gone home.
Sitting in the relative cool of his room, he considered his pencil sketches of airborne skaters pinned to his walls: contorted bodies suspended in different skate grabs and flips, some that he had mastered, others that he had simply imagined.
Julio stored his skates in their spot on his empty bookshelf ("his library" he calls it) and went to play with his nephew, one of eight people he shared with house with. He'd play for a while, do some drawing. Then maybe, when the sun had settled down, head out to find Kanaf again.
Kanaf stayed till 6, and then went home, leaving others who stayed behind after the rink had closed. They just hopped the fence and kept skating.
At home, Kanaf caught his mother, Sue, trying to move some stuff into his room. He stopped her and insisted she sit.
Sue Nagi's heart had almost stopped years before. It was after her quintuple bypass that Kanaf, left without as much supervision, had begun to hang out with a bad group. ("The kids with the cheap skates," Mrs. Nagi called them.)
"They were pulling me away with a rope and finally I hung myself," said Kanaf.
Kanaf didn't want her, or him, to get sick again.
 
A DAY OF FRUSTRATION
Tuesday stormed. Puddles everywhere on the rink.
Kanaf brooded, angry at the weather. His moods always were dark when he couldn't skate. He felt impatient. He'd watched videos in the detention center of skaters he knew making their names. He'd seen their pictures on magazine covers and followed their results in competitions. He didn't have time for rain.
You can watch skaters at Mullaly scramble when the rain hits, and then watch them buzz back to the rink when the sky clears, whizzing down the streets around the rink like bees returning to a hive. Even in the winter, skaters plow paths to get from ramp to ramp. But the on again, off again rains bred by the humidity and heat made the whole afternoon a wash.
Kanaf's mother had told him that when he got out, with credo should be "Live to skate, skate to live" and Kanaf agreed. But he'd have to wait till the rink was dry.
Julio sat around and gourged himself on some cuchifritos from a shop on East 161st Street and thought evil thoughts about Disney. Julio's only seeming break into the in-line world was a photo shoot he'd had in January for a Disney kid's book. They'd taken him to a fancy Manhattan photo studio and dressed him in Spandex. Instead of a skate ramp, they'd put him on a trampoline and asked him to "do skate tricks." He'd done his best and they'd promised mail a check.
"Neither rain nor sleet nor dark of night..."
Nothing had ever come.
By Wednesday afternoon, clearer and hot again, Kanaf was back up to speed, headphones dangling from his ears, performing tricks that made the younger skaters stop and gape, sometimes breaking up his time with a cigarette break. His quick smiles marked each flight on the half-pipe. He grabbed more air on every pass, egged on by the crowd. "More air!" "Come on, you Energizer bunny!" Kanaf responded by swinging high off on end, twisting his body one and half times around while swinging his right hand across his body to grab the outside of his left skate, a manuever called a mute-method.
During a break, Kanaf caught a figure shooting down East 164th, straight through the intersection, not even breaking to swing the sharp right turn into the park. It was Julio.
Kanaf didn't quite recognize the speeding figure until he got close. And he got close fast.
He stopped. They hugged. Julio hung near Kanaf's arm for a bit, uncertain, while Kanaf talked around the group, teasing some of the other skaters to get higher, to trust the momentum of ramp's curve. Then Julio moved away, up on the platform above the half-pipe. Ray had been assuring a younger that if he dropped into the half- pipe shoulders first, he would be okay. Julio was in before the younger kid could work up the nerve. Julio instantly, cold, pulled him a move he'd made up himself, a backwards 360 with a . He called it the P.R. (for Puerto Rico) flip.
Damn, Kanaf thought.
Julio had once broke a pair of skates trying a move like this, leaving him skateless for a full year before he could afford a new pair. It was period, he admits, half-smiling, half-hiding his head in his chest, that he would pass by the park and watch from beyond the gates. "I kept crying" he said. But there was nothing wrong with Julio's skates now.
Kanaf pulled the flyer from a pocket and showed it to a friend.It hit him. "That's Julio," he said quietly. "I left, and he soared."
He knew then that the competition, a place where he had told himself he was just going to find out "where I am now" was going to come down to between him and Julio.
 
ACTION
Thursday the first offer came.
Ray's fledgling instruction and promotion company, City Sk8, had been asked by a Japanese production to assemble some skaters to stage a session hitting all the major spots around the city. Ray asked Julio and Kanaf to come along.
They shot on Friday, going from Mullaly, down to Columbus Circle, threw Central Park for a while, down to the Chelsea Piers and then finally to Union Square.
Julio marveled at the star treatment, free food and cameras everywhere, taking down what he did and said. He felt like a movie star, and thought, 'This is the best day of my life, this is what I want.'
Kanaf asked Julio to do some tricks: a mute, a Gumby, a method. Julio did every move and ask Kanaf to match him. Kanaf coaxed spitting laughs out of Julio, and started calling him Rosa, a nod to a fellow juvie mate, a gymnast named Delarosa.
Julio didn't know what it meant, so he laughed. They goofed for the camera. They hit their marks. They scouted each other. They shot for 16 hours for no pay, but the attention of an video entourage and a rapt audience wherever they went.
Finally, dog tired and thinking about the next day's competition, Kanaf and Julio headed home.
 
THE COMPETITION BEGINS
Saturday was the hottest day of the year. By noon, the sheet metal on the half-pipe was sizzling hands of falling skaters.
A DJ worked out of a van was parked in the corner of the park and bass heavy rap and hip hop boomed through the park. A PA had been set up and the competition's organizers, Ray and his partner David Smith, took turns trying to announcing competitors names and adding commentary to routines: "Oh, that's a 360 transfer, baby. Nice!" The half-pipe's platforms were draped with banners announcing Hyper Wheels and Power Bars, and topped with a McDonald's flag. The park guys had run a hose over the roof, creating a single stream shower for people to cool off in. Blankets sat in the shade for parents. Skaters showed early and came from everywhere, slowing the competition down by adding multiple rounds.
By the midday start of vert competition, the temperature was 101. Kanaf, Julio and 11 other skaters had signed up for the vert, the faster, harder to master end of aggressive. (51 signed up for the street course.) The competition would be one round of prelims then the top 8 would compete in the finals.
A corwd of baout 200 people had showed up to watch, driven to the shade of the park by the heat indoors. Hanging around the edge of the rink was a German photographer, a Brooklyn skate enterpreneur looking to form a team, and a handful of pros, not allowed to compete, but watching for new talent.
The first round showed off Kanaf and Julio. Kanaf, heavier and steadier, older and stronger, could trust momentum would build behind him. Julio had to work a little harder for the speed.
And Kanaf had style. In a black soccer-style shirt and frayed dungarees, Kanaf milked the stalls between tricks, gripping the edge of the platform with his skates like flamenco dancer: arms slightly bent, head cocked, eyes in the middle distance. And then down into the pipe, seemingly fed by the music, effortlessly gaining speed, arms to his side, and then with a perfectly timed push, up, two, three, four feet into the air, turning his body from the sky to the ground to the sky again, landing and shooting backwards towards the other curve of the pipe. No sign in his body of any fear of falling on anything but the glide of four wheels still in motion.
But Julio had moves. Smaller, almost birdlike, he found the twists and grabs less clumbersome. Perching for a moment on the edges of the platforms, he would swoop down, pushing his skates with more desperate action, looking for the speed to launch him up. But then suddenly, airborne, twisting, his fast hands locking into sudden perfect positions, he would be frozen for a moment. Then as soon as eyes could snap his image, the next moment he was falling back into the pipe, landing and pushing again to gain the speed for the next flight
The judges, a trio of sponsored skaters, gave the prelims lead to Kanaf. Julio was 2d.
In between, Kanaf smoked and fast-chatted a battery of girls and buddies. Julio stayed atop of the half-pipe, fiddled with the hem of his "Your Wheels Suck" t-shirt and thought about the next round. His watched parts on the street competition and played eye-tag with a girl standing beyond the park's fence.
When the finals came, hours late, the sun had begun to set behind the projects to the west of the park. The water had got out of hand and many of the spectators were drenched.
In the finals, Kanaf stuck with a high air strategy, blasting up and twisting, ripping 540's, following one leap with another, confident that he was skating "harder than I ever skated before." Coming down out of the pipe, he was covered in sweat, like he'd stepped through the makeshift fountain. He thought about it: This is all the sweat that I clogged in my pores for a year coming out.
But Julio dogged Kanaf, spinning mercilessly, again and again, using a simple ideas to keep focus: Where's the ramp? Put fear to the side. Don't fall and look stupid. The remaining crowd fed him, Kanaf screaming along with the rest.
When the judges tallied their cards, there was a tie.
A playoff was hastily arranged to decide the competition between Julio and Kanaf. The lights on the basketball court had already clicked on, and the DJ had packed up, taking the PA and the commentary with him. The crowd had dwindled.
Julio approached Kanaf.
"You want first?" said Julio.
He said he was exhausted, and could hardly see the ramp. The prizes between first and second weren't that different, and he'd be happy with second...
Kanaf responded before the words got out of Julio's mouth.
"If you're not to going to skate, I'm not going to skate, it'll be a tie," said Kanaf. "But I want to skate, so you get your little butt out there."
Kanaf stood on the edge and dropped in. The routine was good, no falls, no misses, but lacking the speed and intensity of before. Kanaf missed the grind and beat of the music, the energy of the big crowd.
He finished. Julio began.
At first, it seemed like his regular routine, said Ray. But then he pulled it. Flying up the curve of the pipe, he made a push about six inches from the top and entered the air that Kanaf had seemed to own all afternoon. He flipped skates over head, his eyes flashed with sky's dusk, so high that he "smelled pollution," he said. He completed a full flip and then, twisting like a cat falling from a roof, turned his body 180 at the last instant to land moving forward towards the other curve of the pipe.
Silence for a second. Then shreiks of "Oh man, oh man!" He had pulled a pro move, a gravity bender known as a Mc-Flip.
The decision was unanamious.
Ray pronounced Julio "King of Mullaly."
"Was that so hard?" asked Kanaf.
Julio seemed stunned. "I didn't feel a thing," he said. He said later that when he smiled, it was in the shape of a U -- a half-pipe of a smile.
 
EPILOGUE
A week later, Kanaf got a call from casting agent from American Express. Two days later he was filming in Central Park, playing a skate messenger in a Jerry Seinfeld ad. He had to wear Spandex, but got paid $810 for two days work.
Both Julio and Kanaf were signed to Free Ride, a new skate company in Brooklyn. Unfortunately, it's called Free Ride because its skaters skate free.
Ray also booked Julio and Kanaf onto his City Sk8 team, and their first show is planned for next month. "I'm making sure they get sponsored. They'll have careers," said Ray.
In the meantime, every afternoon the sky is clear at Mullaly Park, they'll skate to live, and live to skate.
 
 
 
From Gring to Gromlit: A Glossary
 Someday you might overhear something like this: "He pulled a mute method and then he tweaked it into a gumby."
Here's a guide to the basic lingo of aggressive skating.
 
Anti-rocker: The wheel alignment that makes grinding easier. (Two middle wheels are slightly smaller than the two outside wheels, improving the skate's grip.)
 
Gromlit: A slang word used to describe skateboarders.
 
Grind: The action of sliding along a rail, skates roughly perpendicular to it. The two outside wheels are used to cradle the rail and gravity does the rest of the work.
 
Gumby, mute, method, rocket: The basic skate grips, all involving grabbing a skate or skates while mid-air.
 
Hip hop: The action of hopping with the hands along the coping, or top metal bar, of a half-pipe while in a handstand.
 
Invert or sad plant: A handstand on the top of a half-pipe.
 
Quads: Standard roller skates.
 
Sessioning: When a pack of skaters travel from location to location using handrails, steps and curbs to perfect moves. Favorite spots are an area under the Brooklyn Bridge on the Manhattan side called the Brooklyn Banks and the "Screamer," a 25-step-long rail in downtown Manhattan.
 
THE BUSINESS OF A RISING SPORT
 
 Who the Corporate Players

 * Skate and accessory manufacturers seeking to cash in on the nation's fastest growing sporting goods market.
 * Advertisers seeking urban, youthful feel to sell products from credit cards to candy bars.
 * Television networks and video companies looking for new, cheap sports programming that appeals to a public jaded by the turmoil in more traditional sports.

 What the Skaters Do

 * Promote skate equipment by talking it up in skate parks and hangouts, using a company's skate equipment, sporting its logos on shirts, helmets and hats provided by the company.
 * Perform at trade shows and store openings to provide entertainment and build crowds.
 * Scout for other talented skaters to become members of company teams.
 * Give advice on research and development of new products; test new products.

 What the Skaters Get

 * Top skaters kept on retainer by large companies like Roller Blades can earn up to $6,000 a month. Skaters travel around the country and, and in some instances, overseas to promote and compete.
 * Many deals involve free merchandise, payment of entrance fees to tournaments and small royalties for any photo or broadcast appearance.
 * Other deals pay in the neighborhood of $300 for appearances at trade shows, store openings and in commercials.

HEADLINE: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI

 BODY:

HARLEM
A 19-Day Week Of Celebration
It started 21 years ago as a one-day celebration of Harlem. This year, Harlem Week is running for 19 days with concerts, films, basketball competitions, a carnival and a conference on economic development.
The activities, most of which are free, will be held throughout the sprawling, diverse community.
"This is our festival to showcase Harlem in a positive light," said Marko Nobles, a spokesman for the event. "The mood of Harlem changes during this time."
Through Aug. 27, the Museum of African-American History and Arts will show films daily as part of the 1995 Harlem Week Black Film Festival in the art gallery of the Adam Clayton Powell Jr. State Building, 163 West 125th Street, at Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard.
The Harlem Carnival will take place Thursday at noon at 123d Street and Morningside Avenue.
Harlem Week; for more information and a schedule of events: (212) 427-3315.
VAN CORTLANDT PARK
A Musical Mosaic: Rag, Pops and Bach
The Bronx Arts Ensemble's Summermusic concert series continues Sundays through Aug. 27.
The ensemble is made up of a core group of about 15 freelance musicians playing the flute, oboe, clarinet, bassoon, horn, violin, viola, cello and bass.
On Sundays the group plays outdoors at 2 P.M. at the Rockwood Drive Circle in Van Cortlandt Park (near Mosholu Parkway and Broadway) and then again indoors at 4 P.M. at McGinley Center at Fordham University, Bronx Rose Hill Campus at Southern Boulevard.
Concerts, different each weekend, include the Brass Pops today, Ragtime Favorites on Aug. 13, Latin American Celebration on Aug. 20 and Bach Festival on Aug. 27.
Bronx Arts Ensemble; for information and directions call (718) 601-7399.
 
FLUSHING
Call: Save Qu Yuan! Response: What, Again?
The dragons are coming back to the lake in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park today with the fifth annual Hong Kong Dragon Boat Festival.
The boats, which are 39 feet long, have dragon heads at the prow and tails at the stern. Each is powered by a team of 20.
The race is based on an ancient Asian legend, said Melinda Parsons of the Hong Kong Government office in New York. Around 400 B.C., Qu Yuan, a court minister who was loved by the people but not by the king, was banished. For a time, he wandered about the countryside, writing poetry, but he eventually decided to drown himself in a river. Local fishermen raced to save him, but in vain. Their rescue dash is re-enacted in the dragon boat race.
Six boats will race today, and the championship will be decided next Sunday.
Hong Kong Boat Festival, Meadow Lake in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park; today, 1 P.M. to 4 P.M., and next Sunday, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.; free; (212) 629-0370.
 
ALSO AROUND TOWN
 
CHILL OUT Central Park Wildlife Center, Fifth Avenue at 64th Street; weekend-long event focusing on polar bears and penguins; games and crafts; $2.50 for adults, 50 cents for children 3 to 12, $1.25 for the elderly; (212) 861-6030.
 
HEALTH FAIR Diagnostic screenings, demonstrations by the Fire and Police Departments, massages and information on subjects like baby care, victim counseling and services for the elderly; Wednesday; Townsend Avenue between Mount Eden and East 174th Street; food, entertainment; (718) 716-8000.
 
HIROSHIMA A silent peace walk in remembrance of the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki 50 years ago will start at the New York Buddhist Church on Riverside Drive between 105th and 106th Streets and continue north to Riverside Church at 122d Street; today, 1 P.M. to 4 P.M.; (212) 678-0305.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;
Domino Real-Estate Deal Cleared

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
A final obstacle has been removed to a complex deal to relocate both the City University Graduate Center and the State University College of Optometry in a $173 million project involving the old B. Altman department store and two other sites.
In a three-year process, the college will move from 315 Park Avenue South at 24th Street to CUNY's building at 33 West 42d. CUNY will move to the Altman building, on Fifth Avenue at 34th. To allow the deal, Gov. George E. Pataki signed a special law cutting off state funds for the optometry college's $7 million annual rent, breaking its lease without penalty or compensation to the landlord. Mr. Pataki's press office did not respond to a reporter's inquiries. 
 The law is under attack from State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, some real estate industry leaders and the owners of 315 Park. The owners, TM Park Associates, say the move could bankrupt them, since their $50 million mortgage is based on the lease's lasting till 2004. They plan to sue. Mr. McCall's office called the law unprecedented and said it could have serious consequences, hampering future lease negotiations.
"The concept that the state can simply abrogate a contract seems to me unfair, unethical and immoral -- you and I could not get away with that," said Michael Cohen, president of Williams Real Estate, which has several leases with state agencies. He called the law a terrible precedent.
Controversies aside, officials at the optometry college and CUNY Center say they are delighted at the prospect of new homes. CUNY, which opened in 1961, long ago outgrew its 172,924-square-foot 42d Street building and spilled over into 100,831 square feet rented in adjacent buildings.
"We're really cramped," said Pam Bayless, a spokeswoman. "The hope is to get out as soon as possible."
Despite agitation within the Real Estate Board of New York to oppose the lease-breaking law, the industry organization has not done so. Some critics say that reflects the influence of Peter L. Malkin, a governor of the board and a real estate power who is a general partner in the redevelopment of the Altman site. He did not respond to a request for an interview.
The CUNY move is the third time Mr. Malkin's partnership has benefited from special legislation and public money to help rescue the troubled Altman project and fill it with new occupants and owners.
After the store closed in 1989, the partnership tried to convert the building into the New York Resource Center, a mart for the office furnishing industry. But that flopped as the city sank into recession. Then the partnership tried dividing the building into condominiums for nonprofit institutions who, by owning, would avoid property taxes.
Senator Roy Goodman, who is also the Manhattan Republican Party chairman, sponsored the lease-breaking law and also introduced an earlier bill that helped land the Altman building's first occupant. That legislation enabled the State Dormitory Authority to finance $30 million for Oxford University Press to buy 110,000 square feet in the top five floors of the building's eastern end, facing Madison Avenue. Oxford moved in this year. Mr. Goodman was out of town last week and unavailable for comment.
The Dormitory Authority is also helping finance a $125 million project creating the Science, Industry and Business Library in 213,000 square feet on the lower eight floors of the Madison wing, scheduled to open later this year. CUNY's move, also authorized by state legislation and financed by public funds, will fill 375,000 square feet of Altman's remaining space, making CUNY the building's major occupant.
 BRUCE LAMBERT

HEADLINE: THEATER;
At 21, This Show Must Be Doing Something Right

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
DURING ITS MARATHON 21-year run, the musical revue "Beach Blanket Babylon," a frenetic spoof of American politics, culture and ethnic life, has become a San Francisco institution. More than three million Bay Area residents and tourists have squeezed in to see it at the 400-seat Club Fugazi in the city's North Beach neighborhood. Hotel concierges recommend it for what The Los Angeles Times has called its "pure fun, the epitome of the San Francisco experience."
Many fans see it more than once. The department store tycoon Cyril Magnin came back 464 times. But in June, the man who could probably top that figure, Steve Silver, the show's creator, producer and driving spirit, died of AIDS at the age of 51. "The little show that could," as the local newspaper columnist Herb Caen called it, now faces the future on its own. 
 Inspired by the 1960's movie series with Annette Funicello and Frankie Avalon ("Beach Party," "Beach Blanket Bingo"), the revue consists of a live, rocking band and an ensemble of singers and dancers who deliver sight gags and puns as they quick-change into outlandish costumes, towering wigs and oversized hats -- ingredients that Mr. Silver wanted when he began to create the show on the city's streets in 1974.
He produced the first indoor version of "Beach Blanket Babylon" in the back room of a local restaurant. For atmosphere, he covered the floor with sand, put the waiters in swimsuits and stamped the audience's hands with Coppertone. It was a popular hit from the start and moved to its current location in 1975.
In an interview last February, after his public announcement that he had AIDS, Mr. Silver insisted, "This show is not closing; everything will stay the same." Five years earlier, he had begun grooming Kenny Mazlow, 42, a featured performer and the show's assistant director and choreographer, to take over the creative reins.
Jo Schuman Silver, Mr. Silver's widow, is the new producer. With 85 full- and part-time employees, 10 of them in the cast, the revue grosses nearly $5 million a year for Steve Silver Productions, a privately held company that Ms. Schuman Silver now runs. According to David Lincoln King, the general manager, annual operating expenses for eight shows a week are virtually the same as the gross revenues. Ticket prices range from $18 to $45 and drinks and other concessions generate another $200,000 annually, he said.
Marsha Garland, executive director of the North Beach Chamber of Commerce, a neighborhood group, said the show generates $2 million to $4 million a year for the local economy. "It's a phenomenon" for the area's restaurants, bars and hotels, Ms. Garland said. "If it left, there would be a big black hole in North Beach."
Ms. Schuman Silver is optimistic about the future of her husband's favorite show. She said she was exploring possibly opening it in other markets, perhaps Boston, Chicago or Dallas, with New York as the ultimate goal. "It will go on," she said simply.
"Beach Blanket Babylon" has lasted, Mr. Caen said, because Mr. Silver "never made it bigger than it had to be. He didn't move into a larger theater, get more glamorous name performers. It has a real San Francisco feel to it, neighborly, misleadingly simple. He kept control in a very intelligent way."
Val Diamond, the star for the last 17 years, said the show "doesn't pretend to be anything it's not. In fact, the show is much better if you don't think." During the finale, Ms. Diamond wears one of Mr. Silver's hat fantasies, executed by Alan Greenspan: a 200-pound, 12-foot headdress showing the San Francisco skyline on which buildings rise and lights flash. A 33-foot version, built for the 20th-anniversary show, is displayed in the San Francisco City Center. The city threw a party last year to honor Mr. Silver for his civic contributions and the show.
 SIX MONTHS LATER, MR. Silver announced he was seriously ill. He had been secretly fending off AIDS for five years, and now he was losing his eyesight. He was hospitalized just before Christmas and then rallied, returning home for six more months, before his death on June 12.
In signature style, he designed his own funeral, choosing his eulogists and choreographing numbers by the "Beach Blanket" cast. "It was definitely a Steve Silver production," Ms. Schuman Silver said.

HEADLINE: Census Study Sees Ethnic Shifts

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
THE county's population will grow only slightly during the next 25 years, but there will be dramatic changes in the racial and ethnic makeup of Westchester, a new report on census trends shows. By the year 2020, blacks, Asians and Hispanic residents living in Westchester will equal the number of whites living here, according to the study released late last month by the County Planning Department.
The latest census predictions have broad implications for many sectors of society -- including education, transportation, recreation, housing and public medicine -- and will no doubt bring about significant changes in the delivery of services, said the county's Planning Commissioner, P. Lynn Oliva. 
 Commissioner Oliva referred to the government report as "a blueprint for spending, a tool to help us plan ahead."
The census study says that by 2020, Hispanic residents will make up 24 percent of the county's population, up from 9.9 percent in 1990.
Asians and people from the Pacific islands will constitute 10 percent of the population, up from 3.7 percent five years ago. And the numbers of blacks will grow to nearly 17 percent from 13 percent at the beginning of this decade.
By contrast, the white population will decrease to slightly less than 50 percent, from 73 percent in 1990.
Ms. Oliva said Westchester will still be in large part "a wealthy area of one-family homes, with golf courses and parks," but will also exhibit a growing diversity over the next quarter century -- a pattern that has already begun to manifest itself.
While some analysts, like Dr. Anthony A. Cupaiuolo, director of the Michaelian Institute of Public Policy and Management at Pace University, described the trends as "dynamic and eclectic," others expressed concern about widening demographic divisions in the years ahead.
A draft report released last week by the New York Metropolitan Transportation Council, a regional planning organization representing Nassau, Suffolk, Putnam, Rockland and Westchester Counties and New York City, addressed what it called "challenges of uncertain impact and complexity."
"Increasing racial, ethnic, linguistic and cultural diversity, and a widening income and economic disparity confront the region as the effects of heavy foreign immigration, continued job and housing discrimination, unequal access to capital and education resources, and impending cutbacks in social safety-net expenditures combine to broaden the gap between the 'haves' and the 'have nots' in our society," that report says.
The changing racial makeup of Westchester is part of a larger regional trend that the Transportation Council has been documenting for some time. That organization's report says there are 12.4 million whites -- 62 percent of the population -- in the New York City area, down from 15.7 million, or 79 percent, in 1970.
Hispanic people account for 3.3 million people, or 16 percent of the regional population, compared with 1.6 million, or 8 percent, in 1970.
Blacks also account for 3.3 million people and 16 percent of the population, although their numbers have not grown as quickly. The Transportation Council counted 2.3 million blacks, or 12 percent of the population, living in the region in 1970.
Asians are the smallest but most rapidly expanding group, with 1.2 million people, or 6 percent of the population, up from 200,000, or 1 percent, in 1970.
The report notes that five in every eight residents of New York City are Hispanic, black or Asian. In New Jersey, those numbers are one in three. In the mid-Hudson region, about one in every four residents is a member of a minority group. And in Connecticut and Long Island, it is one in every five -- fewer than the average for the country.
Since 1970, nearly three million immigrants have moved to the region, and half of those have been admitted under the family reunification provisions of immigration law, which contributes to "tight concentrations of newcomers in ethnic enclaves," the report says.
The Westchester Planning Department report on census trends corroborates those findings, noting that most of the county's population growth will be in the southern part, in cities like Mount Vernon and Yonkers, where many members of minority groups settle.
The population of Yonkers, for example, is expected to increase to 191,250 in the next 25 years, from 188,082 in 1995. By then, the report says, slightly more than one-fifth of the county will live in that city.
But over all, projections show no major geographic shifts in the population. By 2020, 46.6 percent of the county's population, slightly less than in 1990, will live in the south. Thirty percent of the county's population, slightly more than in 1990, will live in the northern part of Westchester. And about 23 percent, slightly less that five years ago, will live in the central area.
But what will change is the type of housing that is built in the county. The report says that as the racial makeup of the county changes, there will be a demand for more multi-family housing, including rental units -- what Commissioner Oliva called "a starter form of housing."
Housing construction will be "fueled by in-migration" from the Bronx and other areas within the New York City and will occur near waterfront areas and along the central corridors in the county like Routes 1 and 9 and the Saw Mill River Parkway, the report says.
Housing development is expected to be limited in the north, where the Croton watershed covers 60 percent of the area, because of New York City's strict watershed regulations.
In other census projections, the report says that the county's population, now 888,000, will grow an average of less than 1 percent a year, and by the year 2020 will reach 905,000. It also says that the population is not likely to exceed 910,000 in the future, based upon limits determined by employment opportunities and the availability of housing.
In 25 years, Westchester's share of the Hudson Valley region's total employment is projected to decline to 39 percent from 47 percent. Over all, though, the total number of wage and salary jobs in the county is projected to grow by 16.4 percent, or 74,000.
The net increase in housing is not expected to exceed an average of 1,000 units a year from now to 2020, the report says.
"The historic highs of the 1960's and early 1970's in terms of housing construction will almost certainly not be sustained again," the report says. "The building shortfall, especially in multi-family construction, is a major constraint on population growth."
In other population projections, the report says, the current baby boom, which is defined as more than 10,000 births in a year, is expected to continue to the end of the decade. And another "baby-boomlet period" is expected between 2010 and 2015.
Meanwhile, the under-20 population in Westchester is expected to decline to about 19 percent of the overall population by 2020 from 24 percent in 1990. The numbers of those 20 to 64 will increase to 64 percent, from 61 percent five years ago. And the 65 and older group will increase to 17 percent from 14 percent in 1990.
William N. Cassella, chairman of the Westchester County Planning Board, who called the report's findings "expected, not surprising at all," pointed out that the demand for more affordable housing will be coming from two sectors: immigrants who cannot yet afford single-family homes and the growing group of those 65 and older.
Mae Carpenter, director of the County Office for the Aging, said recent surveys of the elderly showed affordable housing to be a primary concern for that group, many of whom now spend about half of their incomes on housing, because the county has a limited stock of affordable units.
She said the census projections for 2020 pointed up an urgent need to address the housing and transportation concerns of the elderly so that they do not become isolated from other sectors of the population.
Educators, too, said the report would serve as a planning tool. At Westchester Community College in Valhalla, Betsy Weiner, director of College Communications, said college enrollments reflected population shifts in the population at large.
She said demand was already very high for non-credit English as a second language courses and for a credit course on diction for non-native speakers of English.
She noted also that Hispanic students represented 10 percent of enrollments, blacks 17 percent and Asians 5 percent. Hispanic and Asian students are the fastest-growing groups at the college, while enrollments of blacks have "begun to flatten out," she said.
The Department of Social Services would not comment on the report, and a spokesman there said Commissioner Mary E. Glass did not necessarily foresee any major changes in the delivery of services.
But at the Health Department, Commissioner Mark Rapoport said the population shifts further complicated the outlook for public medicine, which was also having to adapt to many other changes at the same time. He said he foresaw a possible conflict between the increased demand for public services and a government policy that is "looking toward private-sector partnering" and less of a direct-treatment role.
"It's hard to predict how this will all play out," Dr. Rapoport said, "so we prefer to plan only two years in advance and make incremental changes. It's the only way to go when the general patterns are not all that clear."

HEADLINE: Sales on a Seesaw: Retail Picture Mixed

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
A REPORT on retail trade in Westchester, based on the the 1992 Economic Census, shows gains in some areas and losses in others.
Gross retail sales in the county grew at a modest 10 percent from 1987 to 1992, lagging behind the state's retail growth of 15.2 percent. 
 Sales activity in the north of the county appeared strong for the period and was increasingly concentrated in towns like Yorktown and the Mount Kisco-Bedford area. By contrast, retail performance in the county's southern cities dropped off, although it remained vigorous along the Route 100 and Route 1 corridor in places like Mamaroneck and Port Chester. The Route 9 corridor near the Hudson River, however, showed a mixed sales picture for towns like Ardsley, Irvington, North Tarrytown and Croton-on-Hudson.
Over all, retail sales in the county in 1992 were about $7.4 billion, compared with $6.8 billion in 1987. That represents a 10 percent gain in actual dollars, but a decrease of 13 percent when the figures are adjusted for inflation. From 1967 to 1987, retail sales made gains of up to 52.5 percent in each five-year period.
The total payroll for retail trade in the county rose to $932 million in 1992 from $815 million in 1987, or 14.3 percent But the number of employees in retail trade dropped to 59,559 from 64,947 -- a loss of 8.3 percent.
Westchester ranked fourth in retail sales for New York counties in 1992 after Manhattan ($17.4 billion), Nassau ($13.7 billion) and Suffolk ($10.7 billion).
Yonkers ranked third among the state's cities for retail sales that year ($1.3 billion), after New York City ($36.5 billion) and Buffalo ($1.4 billion). White Plains ($885.7 million) ranked sixth. New Rochelle ($415.7 million) fell to 15th place from 8th in 1987.
The top 10 retail centers in the county in 1992 in terms of sales dollars were Yonkers, White Plains, Yorktown, New Rochelle, Greenburgh, Scarsdale, Mount Kisco, Mount Vernon, Eastchester and Bedford. The lowest were Irvington, Rye Brook, Cortlandt and Hastings-on-Hudson. The report said that there were 1,654 eating and drinking places in Westchester in 1992, or 26.9 percent of all retail establishments. But they generated only 8.6 percent of the county's retail sales.
By contrast, there were 878 food stores, and they generated $1.5 billion in sales, or 20.2 percent of all retail sales.
There were only 216 automobile dealerships, but they accounted for $1.4 billion in sales -- or 19 percent of the county's retail trade for 1992. In 1987, however, auto sales accounted for 22.1 percent of all sales in the county, and the report noted that the 1992 recession "undoubtedly had a dampening effect on new car sales."
Annual sales per employee, when adjusted for inflation, declined 5.5 percent, to $98,373 in 1992 from $104,147 in 1987.
The report was the fourth on retail trade in the county prepared by the County Planning Department. The Economic Census, also known as the Census of Business, has been conducted by the United States Bureau of the Census every five years since 1967. It provides information on retail trade, wholesale trade, service industries, manufacturing and agriculture for counties and municipalities nationwide.
The census included all establishments with paid employees that sell merchandise for personal or household consumption and render services related to the sale of goods. It did not include governmental organizations or establishments like warehouses.
For the first time, the 1992 Census of Retail Trade provided data on individual towns. In previous years, that information had not been broken out and was included in a category called "Balance of County."
Albert A. Annunziata, the Planning Department's director of research, said that since 1992 the retail sales picture had improved and that retail sales tax receipts were up.
"The county on balance is maintaining a good position in the metropolitan region for retail trade," he said, attributing part of the gains in the last three years to Westchester's emergence from the most recent economic recession.

HEADLINE: Shooting for the Basket, and in the Process, for a Better Life

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
THE stampeding sounds of sneakers echoed through the second-floor gymnasium at the Y.M.C.A. on Riverdale Avenue here, as Randy's Bus and Van team squared off against the team from Saturn of White Plains in a ferocious basketball game. Despite the sweltering night, unrelieved by the circulation of a few sluggish fans, the players raced up and down the court, leaping to dunk baskets and make jump shots, hitting nothing but net, until Randy's won, 58-56.
But the players in this late-evening game, on July 27, were doing more than just shooting hoops. As participants in the new Midnight Basketball program in Yonkers, these young men were among 120 local participants in a social experiment that seeks to combine sports and self-improvement. 
 The Yonkers program is part of New York Midnight Basketball, which has leagues currently in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn as well as a women's league. A sister program exists in Albany. The program targets an inner-city population ages 17 to 26. New York Midnight Basketball, founded by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in 1994, serves about 500 people a year. It is a program of HELP (Housing Enterprise for the Less Privileged) an organization that provides housing for the homeless and other social services. Beyond basketball, the program, which is financed by donations, tries to motivate participants toward schooling and the job market.
Councilwoman Symra D. Brandon of Yonkers, who represents the First District, approached Midnight Basketball last year about expanding into Yonkers. The program began a season here in June; it will continue through September.
"The hook wasn't just basketball, but real workshops, so that these young men could do something other than basketball," Ms. Brandon said. "The program is a viable option to keeping them off the streets. Yonkers doesn't have a lot of programs for youngsters at night."
The games provide an activity not only for the players but for the spectators, who are invited to watch without charge. The Yonkers games typically draw 200 to 300 fans.
On the national level, Midnight Basketball has been in existence for the last decade. There are programs in cities like Atlanta, Chicago, San Antonio and San Francisco. The Oakland, Calif.-based National Association of Midnight Basketball Leagues represents a network of about 50 different leagues nationwide.
The local organizers said the program seeks to help young adults who are unemployed or underemployed and who lack educational credentials or skills. To be eligible to take part, all potential players must attend eight evenings of "boot camp," a rigorous program of motivational workshops and intense physical activity. Those who stay with the program are selected for basketball teams sponsored by local businesses in a public draft in which attitude and attendance count for more than athletic ability. There are 10 players assigned to a team, with five alternates.
The games, which begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M., are held two nights a week. In order to play, participants have to attend pre-game workshops on topics like resume writing and interviewing techniques; AIDS awareness and health-related issues like alcohol and drug abuse; preparation for the high school equivalency diploma and applying for college financial aid, and conflict-resolution skills. Some coming workshops will even include job-recruiting sessions from local employers. From the 1994 New York Midnight Basketball program in New York City, about 40 percent of the participants moved on to college or full-time jobs. Each participant is scheduled for one game and one workshop each week.
"We didn't want another basketball league," said Mike Klein, executive director of New York Midnight Basketball. "We want to be seen as a jobs and education program. It's not just about basketball. Basketball is the magnet, the hook, to get these guys to come in. The guys will listen to a workshop, not to a teacher in a classroom. To play in Midnight Basketball, you have to follow the rules. This is a program based on personal responsibility. When these guys are 30, basketball won't pay the bills."
The rules are strict and enforced. For each player on a team, there are anywhere from three to five alternate players eager to take his place.
"If they don't come to the workshops, they can't play," said Ray Jones, coordinator for the workshops. "If they come late and don't have a good excuse, like a note from their employer or a documented emergency, they can't play."
Jim Bostic, a Yonkers native and former player for the Detroit Pistons, is manager of Midnight Basketball in Yonkers. "The basketball aspect is the smallest part of it," he said. "We threw it in to draw the young men in, and also to break up the monotony of the classes and workshops.
"I made boot camp as tough as possible to simulate life and see how they handle it. I wanted to see if they quit, or if they could find a way around difficult situations. The program helps them be more marketable and employable. Here's a chance for them to pick themselves up and restart their life."
The program relies on community members as team coaches and mentors for the players. "The basketball coach is there for other things besides basketball," Mr. Klein said. "It comes down to networking, and what we're trying to do is generate new networks."
Midnight Basketball receives no government funds. A variety of sponsors underwrite the league, paying $2,000 a season to support a team or $250 for sponsoring an individual player. Yonkers has eight teams, sponsored by Saturn of White Plains, Randy's Bus and Van, the Cross County Shopping Center, Greenway Plaza Shoprite, the Yonkers Minority Business Association, Roizman Development Inc. and the law firm Novick, Edelstein, Lubell, Reisman, Wasserman & Leventhal. One more team sponsor is still being sought. Other contributors include Con Edison, Nike, Snapple, H.I.P and two radio stations, WQHT, which broadcasts as Hot 97 (97 FM), and WRKS-FM (98.7), which broadcasts as KISS.
The corporate sponsors "need this population for their employees," Mr. Klein said. "These guys need a job, and they need to make the connection to work. We're trying to transfer that work ethic."
Ms. Brandon added: "What sold sponsors is this link. Shoprite, for example, wants to get two or three young men from this program to work in their store and go through college."
A recent workshop for the players, led by a counselor from the neighboring Y.W.C.A., Dwayne Middleton, focused on the decision-making process and how the participants could set and meet goals for themselves. One participant, Nate Wylie, 19, a graduate of Lincoln High School in Yonkers, where he was an all-county quarterback, termed the program beneficial. "I like people who participate," said Mr. Wylie, who is working with disabled children before going to college in the fall, "and I like to play sports."
Kibwe Dorsey, 20, who attended Roosevelt High School and is hoping to earn his equivalency diploma, conceded that "boot camp was hard, but it was disciplined." He continued: I really like to play basketball, and this keeps me off the streets and keeps me out of trouble. I want to go to college and play sports."
The effort is working, said Mr. Jones, the workshop coordinator. "What I like about the program is that it's taking young men with nothing to do, and giving them something to do," he said. "This may be the last opportunity for some of them."
More information about Midnight Basketball is available by calling Councilwoman Brandon's office at 377-6311 or contacting the program directly at 476-1806.

HEADLINE: Long Island Q&A: George Bundschuh;
From H.M.O.'s to AIDS Research, It's More Than Insurance

BYLINE: By SUSAN E. KONIG 

 BODY:
THIS year the New York Life Insurance Company celebrates its 150th anniversary. For nearly 40 years George Bundschuh has worked for the company, becoming president in 1990. He will retire in October.
With $69 billion in assets, New York Life ranks fifth among American insurance companies. It has 200 offices in North America, with three on Long Island, and others in Europe, Asia and South America. Life insurance accounts for by far the largest share of business, but the company also owns the Sanus Corporation, a health maintenance organization with 900,000 customers, and sells asset-management services, pension products, mutual funds and annuities. 
 Mr. Bundschuh became president after having been vice chairman. He earned a B.B.A. in accounting from Pace University and a master's from the Columbia University Graduate School of Business. For 28 years he has lived in Port Washington, where he and his wife, Joanne, raised two children.
Q. How many people have life insurance and how have sales been?
A. About 154 million Americans have some type of life insurance. Sales were flat last year, although they didn't fall. I think they pretty much reflected the economy.
Q. Who should buy life insurance? Should young single people buy it to obtain lower rates?
A. I don't think anyone should buy it unless they have a need. Once you buy a policy you can always borrow some of the money and put more in later. As for young single people, if you are truly farsighted -- that is, if you know you are going to be married and have children, you have extra cash and you know that at this point in time you'll get good rates because you're in good health -- then maybe you should buy. But the decision should really be based on need.
Q. What kind of insurance should Long Islanders buy?
A. In terms of financial planning and protecting the family, life insurance is an excellent base. It's quite important for families with children, so that should something happen to the wage earners there is a stream of income to provide for housing, education, etc. After that you may want to think about other capital-accumulation opportunities. If your firm has a 401K plan, for example, take advantage of it, because the tax preferences make it ideal. I.R.A.'s and annuities are also an excellent way to build up a sizable asset base.
Q. What would you say to people who feel life insurance has become too expensive?
A. The first thing you want to do is distinguish between permanent and term insurance. Term insurance is much cheaper, because all you're really doing is considering the mortality risk. It's strictly a death benefit. There's no buildup of cash. When you have a permanent policy -- a whole-life policy, a universal-life policy -- there is a death benefit plus a built-in savings component. Yes, you're putting more into the policy, but you're building an asset base which you can use for living expenses. People seem to think borrowing on their policy is just for emergencies. That's not true. It can be a "planned for" thing. You may want to build a cash base for someone's education, a new home, etc., and there are built-in tax preferences. Because this business is so competitive I think you can find the coverage you need at a good price.
Q. With increasing single-parent families, are more women buying life insurance?
A.Absolutely. Men are still the primary buyers. But, in 1994, 40 percent of our sales were to women. Women represent 35 percent of our life-insurance business. More women are selling life insurance, too. Nearly 20 percent of our agents are female.
Q. What is a "second to die" policy?
A. It's an estate-planning tool, really. It is a policy which pays off when both parties, a husband and wife, pass away. The advantage is that the premium is typically much lower than they would be on each party individually. So it serves a real need. And it's a pretty popular product these days.
Q. What job opportunities exist in the industry?
A. There are some excellent opportunities for college graduates in a number of areas like computer systems, actuarial sciences and investments, to name just a few. I started in investments. And there is always a need for good agents. But most people starting as agents have had prior experience elsewhere in the business world. You don't often see people right out of school, because one needs a network of business people to sell to. It's also a very tough business, though it can be quite lucrative. And you can make your own hours. It's not a 9-to-5 job. Agents have the most success when they sell to their peers. So they generally "grow up" with their clients. As the client gets older, earns more money and needs more insurance, that's when the agent really does well.
Q. What do you think of the Island's real-estate market?
A. I think it's perking up, but frankly it has a ways to go. And hopefully the improvement won't be offset by a surge in interest rates. That's the danger to Long Island right now. The market has clearly bottomed, and I think it will continue to grow, with that one proviso, that we don't have another surge in interest rates.
Q. How is the health-insurance industry doing?
A. It's growing rapidly. Last year was very significant for the industry, because Clinton's health-care plan was still a possibility, and that would have affected us adversely. But Congress decided against a "grand health care scheme." And because of that, we see progress being made with regard to some much-needed changes in the system. We're all sensitive to the need for "portability" of health insurance. The Health Insurance Association of America has made some proposals along those lines. We're also quite cognizant of the issue of uninsured people and hope this, too, can be resolved. I think over the next year or so the emphasis will shift from the Federal to the state level, as Congress starts focusing on other things. They spent so much time and energy on health care last year I think they're finally ready to see improvements made "incrementally." And I doubt we'll see anything major like the Clinton proposal introduced again.
Q. How has AIDS affected the health-insurance industry?
A. The industry was affected by the spread of AIDS right from the start. And I'm proud to say that funding research is the priority of the New York Life Foundation, an AIDS-related research and educational organization. I think the industry has handled AIDS pretty well. As far as group health insurance goes, there is generally no screening for pre-existing conditions like AIDS. But we've adjusted for that. I can't say AIDS has had a significant adverse impact on group insurance. And we feel we've been able to provide people who have this disease with the proper treatment.
Q. What changes do you foresee in health care?
A. We're already seeing some dramatic changes, and they're all moving toward managed care. There will be a great deal of innovation. Our company just signed a letter of intent with Duke University Health Systems to form a managed-care company in South Carolina. This is the first time in this country that an H.M.O. has teamed up with a major research hospital. We want to create new standards in medical care by pooling our expertise. Duke will learn more about how a managed-care environment works, and we'll learn more about quality medical care and how to apply it.
Q. Why does your company, which does business nationally and internationally, retain the New York Life name?
A. Obviously the company was started in New York. But when we began going overseas in the mid-80's, I was amazed to find that the name was so well accepted. I think it was because New York is looked upon as a worldwide financial center. Personally, I thought the name would suggest something very provincial. But it's actually had the opposite effect. So we're using it in many foreign markets.
Q. What advice would you give to someone shopping for insurance?
A. Check the rating agency manuals. There are a number of independent sources like Standard & Poor's, Moody's and A. M. Best whose job it is to evaluate companies and assess their credit standing. It's very important to look at that. It's also important to choose an agent who is knowledgeable, reputable and experienced, and one whom you'll feel comfortable with on a long-term basis. You can do this through referrals. You can also call up any company office and ask to speak to an agent. You'll get a feel for his or her personality, and you can compare recommendations before you choose someone. If you're considering very large purchases, you may want the advice of a variety of professionals such as accountants or lawyers to make sure the products you're buying will meet your financial objective.
