SECTION: Section 7; Page 3; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1504 words

HEADLINE: Junk Bondage

BYLINE: By Joseph Nocera; Joseph Nocera is a contributing editor at Fortune and the author of "A Piece of the Action: How the Middle Class Joined the Money Class."

 BODY:

PAYBACK
The Conspiracy to Destroy Michael Milken
and His Financial Revolution.
By Daniel Fischel.
332 pp. New York:
Harper Business. $25. 
IT'S 1995. What do you think now about the crimes of Michael Milken? Do you think the former junk bond king was at the center of "the greatest criminal conspiracy the financial world has ever known" -- as James B. Stewart famously described him in the best-selling book "Den of Thieves"? Or do you take the revisionist view that he and his firm, the now-defunct Drexel Burnham Lambert, were unfairly railroaded by the Government, as Daniel Fischel, a University of Chicago economist, argues in "Payback"?
Do you think Mr. Milken's most visible creation, the junk bond market, destroyed companies or built them? Is Ivan Boesky, the crooked arbitrager whose allegations were most responsible for putting Mr. Milken behind bars, a repentant criminal or a craven liar? And how about Rudolph Giuliani, the United States Attorney (now, of course, New York's Mayor) who went after Mr. Milken and many other Wall Street figures? Was he just doing his job, or was he conducting, in Mr. Fischel's phrase, a "reign of terror"?
What's amazing is not just that these questions have been around for so long -- nearly a decade, believe it or not -- but that they still resonate. Mr. Milken remains a subject of such fascination that The Wall Street Journal devoted a recent front-page story to his postprison life. More to the point, the questions surrounding Mr. Milken's downfall aren't even close to being settled. If anything, now that the smoke has cleared -- he was released from prison two years ago -- they have become more contentious than they were in the 1980's.
One important reason for this is that there is so much ambiguity surrounding the Milken affair; even the fact that he pleaded guilty to six felonies can be interpreted in a number of different ways. But another reason, nearly as important, is that virtually every writer to have taken up the subject has, rather than face those ambiguities directly, used them to stake out extraordinarily inflexible positions. Thus, several years ago, the writer-actor-lawyer Benjamin J. Stein could publish a virulently anti-Milken book while the journalist Jesse Kornbluth could write a book that practically canonized Mr. Milken -- even though both men were relying on the same facts.
"Payback" fits squarely in this lead-with-your-chin tradition. Its subtitle alone tells you that this will not be a subtle exploration of ambiguity. Indeed, Mr. Fischel is about as subtle as a sledgehammer. What is surprising is that the author, who acted as a consultant to a number of key Wall Street figures in the 1980's, including Mr. Milken, doesn't use his position as "an insider to many of the events that are the subject matter of this book" to enliven his account -- that is, to humanize the individuals he writes about. Then again, it is perhaps not that much of a surprise, since Mr. Fischel's contempt for journalists like Mr. Stewart, who do rely on humanizing devices like anecdotes, practically drips off the page.
Mr. Fischel has taken a different approach. He has attempted to build a case -- not just on behalf of Mr. Milken, but also on behalf of many of the other figures brought low by the Wall Street scandals -- in much the same way a lawyer lays out a final argument. One's verdict, however, is likely to be mixed: though there are plenty of places where his logic is powerful, there are other places where his sympathies simply get the best of him. As a result, he ends up more or less preaching to the converted.
The most telling part of Mr. Fischel's account is his detailing of the excesses of the Government, both in hunting down Wall Street figures whose crimes were far from evident and, in a larger sense, in helping create such 1980's disasters as the savings-and-loan crisis. With barely controlled rage, Mr. Fischel recounts the stories of minor Wall Street characters like Timothy Tabor and Richard Wigton, who, on Mr. Giuliani's orders, was hauled away in handcuffs. He tells of the United States Attorney's willingness to use the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, known as RICO -- a statute aimed at mobsters -- to cripple firms like Drexel and Princeton/Newport Partners, which were not cooperating to Mr. Giuliani's satisfaction. "The Government's police-state tactics," Mr. Fischel labels such methods. Inasmuch as the principals of Princeton/Newport had their convictions overturned on appeal on the ground that they had been convicted of things that simply weren't crimes, and Mr. Tabor and Mr. Wigton were never even brought to trial, it would be hard to disagree.
Mr. Fischel is similarly correct in saying that the S. & L. crisis -- for which Mr. Milken was largely faulted, because so many big S. & L.'s held Milken-issued junk bonds -- was an instance where government was the real culprit. It was Congress, after all, that changed the rules of the game, making it possible for S. & L.'s to buy junk bonds. And when Congress -- in a knee-jerk reaction to Mr. Milken's troubles -- then passed a law forcing S. & .L's to sell off their portfolios en masse, it pretty much guaranteed that the junk bond market would crash, and the S. & .L's with it. That the junk bond market is now thriving is further proof of how woefully misguided Congress's action was.
Yet in his eagerness to exonerate Mr. Milken et al., Mr. Fischel goes wildly overboard. In this he really does resemble a lawyer -- but, alas, a lawyer who has got so involved with his client that he has lost his ability to evaluate the evidence coolly. Thus, for every Princeton/ Newport, there are cases where Mr. Fischel attempts to defend the indefensible. He rails on about the conviction of his former consulting client Charles Keating, for instance -- a man who gulled elderly savers into putting their money into risky bonds whose worth collapsed when his S. & L. did. He says that Victor Posner, who notoriously bought companies only to loot them, "created wealth for investors and society as a whole." He even claims that those who decried the 1980's as the "decade of greed" were motivated by the desire "to delegitimize and discredit the efforts and success of others." In other words, they were envious.
And then there is the thorny issue of Michael Milken. Were some of the felonies to which he pleaded guilty technical violations of securities law, as Mr. Fischel charges? Yes. Is it likely that Mr. Milken fell on his sword in part to save his brother, Lowell, who was also being threatened with indictment? Probably. Is it true that when prosecutors were allowed, in an extraordinary hearing, to make their best case against Mr. Milken, they fell flat on their faces? Without question. But can one therefore draw the conclusion, as Mr. Fischel does, that there is "no evidence" that Mr. Milken committed any crimes at all? Not remotely.
For instance, try as he might, Mr. Fischel never adequately explains away the relationship between Mr. Milken and Mr. Boesky. He describes their business dealings as "routine reciprocal accommodations to preserve good client relationships," but they were far more than that. Mr. Milken both underwrote and invested in the fund Mr. Boesky used to bet on hostile takeovers -- many of which were made possible thanks to Mr. Milken's junk bonds. The temptation on Mr. Milken's part to help Mr. Boesky was powerful, as was the incentive for Mr. Boesky to do Mr. Milken's bidding. And when the Government uncovered a $5.3 million invoice from Mr. Milken to Mr. Boesky for "consulting services" -- an invoice that both men would later admit was a settling between the two of them for illegal securities transactions -- the prosecutors had their smoking gun. Mr. Fischel is reduced to complaining that the four Milken felonies that stemmed from that invoice weren't all that felonious, since "the Government never could identify any . . . injury to anyone." By that standard, Heidi Fleiss was railroaded, too.
What the Milken debate lacks -- and "Payback" is a good example of this -- is common sense. Common sense suggests that Mr. Milken was not the greatest white-collar criminal who ever lived -- not even close. But common sense should also lead us away from the position, taken by people like Mr. Fischel, that a completely innocent man was destroyed by the forces of darkness. If you ask former Drexel hands -- and not those who turned state's evidence, either -- they'll tell you that Mr. Milken did cross the line. "I really like Mike," one such person told me a few years ago, "but he deserved to do some time."
Strip away the overheated rhetoric and you're left with a man who admitted to committing some white-collar crimes and wound up spending two years in jail. All in all, that seems just about right. Perhaps someday we'll be able to admit that. When we do, we'll finally be ready to come to terms with what Michael Milken wrought.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 13; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 2300 words

HEADLINE: The Ground Beneath Our Feet

BYLINE: By Maxine Kumin; Maxine Kumin's most recent book is "Women, Animals, and Vegetables: Essays and Stories."

 BODY:

IN GOOD HANDS
The Keeping of a Family Farm.
By Charles Fish.
229 pp. New York:
Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $21.
 
HERE AND NOWHERE ELSE
Late Seasons of a Farm and Its Family.
By Jane Brox.
143 pp. Boston:
Beacon Press. $18.
 
EPITAPH FOR A PEACH
Four Seasons on My Family Farm.
By David Mas Masumoto.
233 pp. San Francisco:
HarperSanFrancisco. $20.
 
MAPPING THE FARM
The Chronicle of a Family.
By John Hildebrand.
Illustrated. 252 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $23. 
 LOSING the family farm has almost become a literary genre of its own, one rich with sentiment and, unavoidably, some sentimentality. At times, there seem to be nearly as many people writing about farming as there are actual farmers. And with the rate that agribusiness is gobbling up small holdings, the equation might actually be approaching parity.
Rarely have shoppers who buy their bacon and chops out of the supermarket case heard the pig's final throaty gurgle at slaughter, or seen the past-peak milk cow stunned to her knees before being sacrificed for hamburger. Too many people cling to a storybook picture of piglets and calves cavorting in green pastures -- and mourn the encroachment of subdivisions even as they move into them. Those who get no closer to the furrow than their weekly sojourn at the roadside farm stand are susceptible to romantic notions about the purity of the work ethic, the spiritual rewards of tilling the soil, tapping the sugar maples and being at one with nature. Of course, there are ample rewards to be gained from a life on the land, but they are often realized in complicated ways. It is just this intricate intersection of satisfaction and sacrifice that is explored in four elegiac new books about small farming ventures ranging from New England to California.
Charles Fish confronts his own family's situation squarely and thoughtfully in his first book, "In Good Hands: The Keeping of a Family Farm." Although Mr. Fish takes us back to the 1830's as he traces the history of his ancestors' small Vermont dairy farm, he is concerned with far more than an evocation of a way of life or a vision of the vanishing past. From the very outset, it is clear that he also intends to examine contemporary issues of morality, connections between Yankee rectitude -- "honesty, duty, charity, compassion, sexual restraint, clean speech, frugality, faith, love of country, and hard work" -- and the demands of the outside world.
Jane Brox is the granddaughter of Lebanese immigrants who came to New England in 1900 to work in the mills and bought a piece of land instead, some 30 miles up the Merrimack River from Newburyport, Mass. She grew up helping to pick, sort, sell and partake of the fruits of the family truck farm. After college, she left home and went to live on an island, where she worked as a baker. Gradually, the farm drew her back. "Here and Nowhere Else" is a poignant account of that return and recommitment, darkened by the realization that her contract with the land might soon be broken.
David Mas Masumoto, a third-generation Japanese-American, raises peaches and grapes in the San Joaquin Valley of California on land coaxed into productivity by his father and mother, possibly the same soil on which his grandparents labored as new immigrants. A committed organic farmer, Mr. Masumoto also works hard as a freelance writer to illuminate the life of the small farm, and thus save a niche for it. "Epitaph for a Peach: Four Seasons on My Family Farm" amply demonstrates what a prodigious struggle that can be.
John Hildebrand married into a tightly knit family that farms the same 240 acres near Rochester, Minn., that were acquired by its Irish ancestors in the 1880's. The land he describes in "Mapping the Farm: The Chronicle of a Family" produces corn, soybeans and alfalfa. Much of the corn and alfalfa go to support two dozen Hereford cows with their calves, as well as an annual cash crop of pigs. The cows are pasture-bred rather than artificially inseminated. Their manure is returned to the soil. Corn is only grown twice on a field before that field is turned to soybeans, a legume that puts nitrogen back into the soil, and then alfalfa. As on the other farms, there's a rhythm and balance to each seasonal task and pleasure, and Mr. Hildebrand is brilliant at detailing them.
All of the farms described in these four books are in jeopardy today, although some are more precarious than others. Agribusiness and public apathy are the most obvious villains. Economic forces squeeze the small farmer dry; it requires enormous fortitude and flexibility to stay afloat in the present-day market, where, as Mr. Hildebrand puts it, "giant corporations at the top exercise a virtual monopoly on food from farm to table." On the other hand, individual consumers don't often provide much solace: palates dulled by fast foods no longer seem able to appreciate subtle tastes. If they could only sample Mr. Masumoto's tree-ripened peaches, with "flesh . . . so juicy that it oozes down your chin," perhaps they might be swayed.
After all, customers still flock to Jane Brox's family farm stand for tomatoes and corn in season. The same handful of loyal workers pick blueberries in July, apples in August and September and squash and pumpkins in October, but there are few to take their places when they're gone -- and no one to supplant the aging patriarch. "He is 83," Ms. Brox reports. "By now both knees are bad, and he is stone blind in one eye." He worries about where people will get their corn.
The one son who might have succeeded Ms. Brox's father is troubled and unwell, with a longstanding drug problem. "He goes unwashed and unshaven, and his clothes are ragged," she notes with alarm. "He is sullen and alone," his eyes "shining and feral." Neither of the two other siblings wants to take over the farm, a predicament Ms. Brox describes crisply yet with great feeling. As the suburbs encroach, land values soar. Soon the fields will be swallowed by housing developments. People will have to get their corn, starchy and days old, at the supermarket.
These kinds of market forces may also compel Mr. Masumoto to give up his luscious Sun Crest peaches. An organic baby-food producer rescued one crop, but this remarkable peach has a short shelf life and does not withstand shipping and storage well. The sole organic farmer of the group, Mr. Masumoto is an idealist who seems to have found his vocation, at least in part, for esthetic reasons. Initially, he planted cover crops in his orchards simply to provide lush clover for his wife and new baby to stroll through in the spring. Next he added wildflower seeds to the mix, again for the sheer pleasure they provided. Gradually he came to realize that these early blooms were a welcome mat for beneficial insects.
 MR. MASUMOTO'S style is naive, lyrical and, alas, a little repetitive. Still, "Epitaph for a Peach" is an important book. It is not resignation but stoicism that tinges this text, eliciting sympathy and admiration. Mr. Masumoto makes a convincing case for composting and cover crops, as opposed to industrial fertilizers and heavy reliance on herbicides. He has observed the sterility of soils treated year after year with these compounds. Some wells in his valley have shown traces of dibromochloropropane, a chemical once used to control microscopic pests. "No one knew it would contaminate drinking water," Mr. Masumoto explains. And now people in the neighboring cities are angry about their damaged water supply. "How could you farmers poison the water?" they ask. In this matter, small farmers may often suffer for the activities of their much larger rivals.
Family farmers like Mr. Masumoto are also at the mercy of both the weather and the labor market. In late August, it is time to harvest the grapes, which must have 20 days of full sun in order to dry into dark, sweet raisins. Time passes, but workers are scarce. They go first to the big producers; Mr. Masumoto waits and frets. The drama builds as a storm front approaches. The harvest is almost over, and 35,000 trays of would-be raisins are on the ground. A good part of the crop is lost as a second front overtakes the first. Nevertheless, Mr. Masumoto will persevere. "When I first started," he tells us, "I realized I would never make a fortune in farming, but I hoped I could be rich in other ways -- and maybe, just maybe, my work would create some other kind of wealth in the process."
John Hildebrand's "Mapping the Farm" provides thorough documentation of the intangible, emotional wealth Mr. Masumoto is talking about. Longer and more ambitious than the three other books, it manages to be both a personal testament and an absorbing chronicle of agrarian history. Mr. Hildebrand's accounts of the Depression years and the strike of the Farm Holiday Association (which pledged to withhold produce from market until a fair price was obtained) are gracefully interwoven with the experiences of his own in-laws, the O'Neills. He describes, for example, the emergence of the firebrand Father Coughlin, whose radio broadcasts lambasted the agricultural policies of the New Deal, and William Lemke, Coughlin's hand-picked candidate for the Presidency, even as he shows how the O'Neills were caught up in the politics of the time. In a similar fashion, he provides a fascinating disquisition on the delivery in 1911 of the 20-horsepower steam traction engine that would liberate the workhorses on the O'Neill farm -- and modernize threshing across the country.
 THROUGHOUT this absorbing book, historical facts enrich descriptions of present practices. Mr. Hildebrand is even able to summon up an idyllic and now all but obsolete scene without making it seem a cliche: milking time in the old barn, with cats lined up waiting for the final pint and children at liberty, between their assigned tasks, to climb to the haymow and swing on the ropes. Yet at the same time, Mr. Hildebrand is unsentimental about castrating terrified calves and packing hogs off to slaughter, and he seems to accept on faith the ungovernability of the few horses that figure in his account. ("Someone tethered the big sorrel to the back of a manure spreader, where, maddened by flies, it drove one of the spokes into its head.")
Attending a livestock auction at the county fair, Mr. Hildebrand is dismissive of the animal-rights movement because the members he has met seem "less interested in the connections between humans and animals than in the expiation of a free-floating guilt." But he acknowledges that such connections are sometimes troublesome: when unacceptable levels of nitrates are found in the farm's drinking water in the spring, the cause is laid to "traces of fertilizer and manure that had percolated through the fields and into the groundwater."
This sort of unflinching observation is the strength of Charles Fish's account of his family's history as farmers in Vermont. For every abstract noun in his often richly speculative text, there is a buttress of specific detail, from killing woodchucks to recording milk production statistics, from the sweaty work of putting up hay in summer to the icy job of spreading wet manure, by hand, on the fields in winter. Pigs are slaughtered, calves castrated, chickens decapitated, for there is nothing on the farm that does not have its price.
A Rhodes scholar, the holder of a Ph.D. from Princeton, a world traveler, Mr. Fish returned in mid-life to the hilltop village of Dummerston Center, Vt., and from this quiet pulpit began his searching philosophical inquiry into the boyhood summers he spent on the nearby family farm. His splendid book is informative, reflective, investigative and wise. And it is further enhanced by a final section, called "Witnesses," that reproduces various family documents, including an essay composed by his great-great-grandfather, who bought the land in 1836, as well as scrapbook jottings by his quietly authoritative grandmother and portions of a diary Mr. Fish kept during the summer he turned 8 years old.
The farm he remembers from his childhood now operates as a vegetable market garden, and Mr. Masumoto's peach and grape operation is still pursuing its goal of offering pesticide-free ripe fruit in defiance of large-scale commercial pick-em-green enterprises. But a less secure future awaits the O'Neill farm in Minnesota and Ms. Brox's family spread in New England. "None of the children had been groomed to take over the farm," Mr. Hildebrand says of his wife and her siblings. "By accident or omission, they had been reprieved from a life they hadn't asked to be reprieved from." A compromise is reached in which the aging parents give the farm to their children while still maintaining a life-estate interest. The hard decisions are thereby postponed. This year, one son will put in the crops, a son-in-law will repair the fences and so on. For the time being, "each grain of soil belongs to all eight children and cannot be divided."
Reading these books is a way to see what ought not, in a much larger sense, be divided. But it may already have happened, for we have lost much in terms of our allegiance to the land. Perhaps it is the function of the genre of writing practiced by these four authors to provide urban dwellers, hungry for their lost roots in the hayfields and cow barns of their great-grandparents, with at least a tenuous connection to the earth and living creatures. Indifference and ignorance are as much the villains as technology, greed and pollution. Possibly these books will heighten public awareness of the fragility of the environment and alert readers to the stewardship required if our land and our water are to be rescued from ongoing contamination.

HEADLINE: Why Applaud an Increase in Unemployment?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"More From Labor in New York," your July 30 editorial encouraging the Mayor to seek "more concessions" from city workers, is based on distortions and myths.
The most disturbing is the idea that eliminating tens of thousands of jobs is a positive step, as if the people who lose these jobs (or new workers who won't be able to get those jobs) simply disappear or magically find employment elsewhere. 
 A person who loses a job is unemployed. An eliminated job perpetuates unemployment. Joblessness is at the root of this city's problems. It's a burden on services, a drain on revenues and a source of deterioration of our quality of life. To applaud its increase is absurd.
This says nothing of the services lost when these jobs are eliminated, but you seem to believe that city workers aren't really providing services. Instead, you advance the contention that the city must "force" an increase in productivity.
I can attest, and document, that the city's work force is stretched thin. Many of our members are handling responsibilities designed for two people, and a visit to any city office will demonstrate how service delivery has become a frantic challenge for those who remain.
The editorial suggests measures "workers everywhere have had to accept," including insurance co-payments and elimination of overtime. But many city workers already make co-payments as part of their benefits packages. And where (except in the most barbaric situations) have workers been forced to work overtime without adequate compensation?
You want city workers to work several hours more a week without getting paid. Working overtime takes us back to the turn of the century; working without pay takes us back to slavery.
 
ARTHUR CHELIOTES
President, Local 1180
Communications Workers of America
New York, Aug. 2, 1995

HEADLINE: Cuban Leadership Shows Little Hope Of Closer U.S. Ties

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Aug. 6

 BODY:
After months of diplomacy that raised Cuban hopes for a thaw in relations with the United States, the Government of President Fidel Castro appears to have abandoned hopes for a significant improvement before the American presidential election next year.
In recent speeches and interviews, Mr. Castro and his senior aides have criticized the Clinton Administration as sharply as ever, attacking its support for the American economic embargo against Cuba and describing its proposal to increase contact between the countries as sabotage in disguise. 
 "The enemy does not cease in its efforts to destroy us," Mr. Castro said in one address. Even more moderate American opponents of the Cuban Government, he insisted, "want to penetrate us, weaken us, create all kinds of counterrevolutionary organizations to destabilize the country, whatever the consequences."
Such remarks have prompted concern from the United States and from European and Latin American governments that strongly oppose the American embargo and hope to encourage democratic political reform in Cuba while promoting foreign investment and trade.
Diplomats say the official statements have not coincided so far with any visibly tougher treatment by the Communist Government of those whom it has seen as potential agents of the new subversion: students, scholars, members of the country's tiny but growing civic groups.
But after making small political moves that encouraged American officials, Cuban officials have increasingly dismissed the idea of gradual progress toward closer ties with the United States. Once again, they have suggested that so long as the embargo remains, political change in Cuba is out of the question and efforts to solve other problems between Havana and Washington are probably a waste of time.
"Let us not be fooled," Foreign Minister Roberto Robaina said in an interview last week with a Cuban newspaper. "All of the other measures about which there is so much speculation are also instruments for the submission of our country."
"They are not debating whether or not to cut off our heads," he said of American policy makers, "but how they will do it, with a knife or with a razor."
Mr. Robaina and other Cuban leaders have generally been much more upbeat about the potential for improved ties with the United States since the two countries signed an agreement last September to end an exodus of more than 30,000 refugees from the island.
A second accord, announced on May 2, was a particular triumph for the Castro Government. For the first time since Cuban revolutionaries came to power in 1959, American officials agreed to deport Cuban refugees who try to enter the United States illegally. Some 20,000 Cubans who had been held at the Guantanamo Bay Naval Station since trying to flee the island in rafts last summer are also to be allowed to emigrate to the United States under the deal.
In announcing the pact, Cuba's chief negotiator, Ricardo Alarcon, said it was "only fair" to recognize "positive factors" in the Clinton Administration. After unflagging support for Cuban exiles going back to the end of the Eisenhower Administration, he said, President Clinton "turns things around 180 degrees."
Mr. Alarcon and other Cuban officials reiterated at the time that they would never agree to the United States' longstanding demand that Cuba open up its one-party political system in exchange for an end to the embargo.
But they praised what they described as political courage on the part of the Clinton Administration and said the accord should be understood as proof of Cuba's willingness to negotiate in good faith. They also took several modest steps toward rapprochement with their political critics.
In early June, the Cuban authorities released six political prisoners, two of them relatively well-known dissidents. Mr. Castro then made what American officials saw as one of his more significant political gestures in recent years, meeting with Eloy Gutierrez Menoyo, an exile political leader who spent 22 years in Cuban jails. Mr. Castro also held a rare encounter last month with Cuban Catholic bishops at the home of the Vatican envoy in Havana.
The Communist Party's top official for hemispheric relations, Jose Antonio Arbesu, described the harder tone of recent Cuban Government remarks as "a matter of putting one's feet on the ground."
"The blockade is the essence of this problem, and there is no sign that it is going to change," Mr. Arbesu, who heads the party's Americas section, said in an interview. "It would be very difficult for the Clinton Administration to take important steps to improve things between now and the next election."
Cuban officials have been bitterly critical of efforts by conservative Republicans in Congress to tighten the embargo, and what the Cubans describe as the Clinton Administration's acquiescence in that campaign.
Legislation proposed earlier this year by Sen. Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, and Rep. Dan Burton, Republican of Indiana, would punish foreign companies that do business with Cuba and press for full compensation for American citizens with claims to private property seized since the revolution. State Department officials say the law could increase the value of American claims against the Castro Government from about $6 billion to as much as $100 billion.
The Clinton Administration has objected to parts of the bill, saying they would violate international law. But its alternative proposal for pressing the cause of democratic reform in Cuba -- a combination of continued economic sanctions and greater political and social contacts -- has begun to anger Cuban officials almost as much.
"They want to exercise their influence by way of wide exchanges with different sectors that they consider permeable, giving away juicy scholarships, impressing us with their millionaire institutes, their technologies, and their centers of social research," Mr. Castro said in his state-of-the-nation speech on July 26.
Referring to what American officials call the second track of their policy, he added, "Those are the ones who want to destroy us from within."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY: DIGITAL COMMERCE;
2 plans for watermarks, which can bind proof of authorship to electronic works.

BYLINE: By Denise Caruso 

 BODY:
WATERMARKS in paper stock, visible when held up to the light, have been used for centuries to thwart counterfeiters and help prove the authenticity of documents and currency. In recent years, some cable channels and networks, like Comedy Central and CNN, have been stamping their programs with a video version of the watermark.
These video watermarks, which appear in a corner of the television screen, identify the channel for browsing viewers and, cable executives hope, scare off a few video pirates. 
 So it is no surprise, as information becomes currency in the global economy, that so-called digital watermark technologies are beginning to appear. As with their paper and broadcast counterparts, the concept behind digital watermarks is to provide a secure means to certify the origin, ownership and authenticity of digital works. And by doing so, they can provide the first line of defense against piracy of digital media like music, photographs, film, words and video games.
Because making and distributing copies are tasks that computers and networks perform with ease, some people argue that it is impossible to protect digital media from counterfeiters. They say that today's intellectual property laws simply cannot be applied to digital works. On the other hand, most large media companies contend that despite the increased risk of theft, they can protect their assets with existing law and a little creative problem solving.
But even if today's copyright laws are rejected as irrelevant in a digital world, or if authors and publishers choose not to collect a dime for what they put on a disk or distribute over a network, there will still be a need to verify the authorship of digital works -- if only to give credit where it is due and to protect the creator from plagiarism.
Thus, digital watermarks are not intended to increase commerce on computer networks, or even to prevent copying. Instead, their inventors say that they simply bind proof of authorship and other identifying data so tightly to the work that attempts to erase or remove them will cause permanent damage and render any copy useless.
Two start-up software concerns -- the DICE Company in Palo Alto, Calif., and the Digimarc Corporation in Portland, Ore. -- have taken slightly different approaches to creating digital watermarking systems. Each has patents pending on its processes for inserting and locking the watermarks in a file. Each approach uses a variation of data-security technology that scatters identifying information in such a way that it cannot be reassembled without an electronic key to the code.
Digimarc, which was founded by Geoffrey Rhoads, an astrophysicist who wanted to copyright his digital photos of Jupiter, is looking for partners to build products around its many patents. DICE -- an acronym for Digital Information Commodities Exchange -- is about to release an early version of its watermarking system, called Argent, for use in the music industry.
Cane Records, an independent music label run by University of Miami students, is using Argent technology to embed watermarks in the master recordings of its latest compact disk, a compilation of South Florida bands that is scheduled for release at the end of August.
The idea, according to DICE's vice president of technology, Marc Cooperman, was to demonstrate that the technology is compatible with existing audio equipment and that it is possible to embed a digital watermark without affecting sound quality. Dan Warren, the audio engineer who mastered the Cane recording, indeed states emphatically there was "no degradation whatsoever" in sound quality after embedding the mark.
This particular watermark, scattered as data in a random pattern invisible to the CD playback unit, included the date the disk was manufactured, its universal product code, the artist, title, producer and engineer for each track, the copyright year and copyright authority (Cane Records, in this case) and how many CD's were pressed.
By itself, this information may have little use. But as a test, the Cane disk reveals how watermarks may make it possible for publishers to sell media on computer networks without ceding the battle to pirates.
In an on-line purchase, Mr. Cooperman said, a watermark could easily include the purchaser's name, authenticated at the time of purchase along with an identifying customer account number. Consumers as well as counterfeiters are likely to be more careful about copying what they buy if they know illegal copies can be traced to them.
So far, it is not possible with either the DICE or the Digimarc systems for a consumer to read the watermark on a piece of digital media.
Only the publisher or owner of the copyright holds the electronic key that makes the watermark readable. That may be useful to the copyright holder, but it does not help the person who wants to know if it is permissible to copy a particular work -- or from whom to receive or purchase such permission.
Digimarc's founder, Mr. Rhoads, said he was working on a method that would allow the embedded watermark, which people cannot read or alter, to co-exist with a public watermark that people can read.
Whether or not Digimarc or DICE develop their experimental technologies in large-scale systems for digital commerce, big media companies are already exploring the potential benefits of the digital watermark concept.
Ed Horowitz, chairman of the interactive media unit of Viacom Inc., said he was intrigued by the potential.
Whether starving artist or media conglomerate, he said, "Our challenge as publishers is to decide whether the things we value, our pearls, are things we want to get paid for, or whether they are pearls we want everyone to have."
And the first obvious step is to establish who, in fact, owns those pearls. Though the technology for digital watermarks is still in early development, it may prove to be the cornerstone upon which an information economy is built.

HEADLINE: Plan Links Child Support To Licenses

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 6

 BODY:
New York State will begin suspending the driver's licenses of parents who fall more than four months behind in their child-support payments, Gov. George E. Pataki said today.
The new policy, similar to ones tried in a small but growing number of states, is designed to put some sting into an arsenal of child-support collection programs that have proved to be largely ineffective. State officials also hope that it will reduce welfare costs by pulling some families out of poverty. 
 Courts have ordered child-support payments in 380,000 cases in New York State. In 350,000 of those cases, or 92 percent, parents are behind in payments. Together, they owe more than $1 billion, an amount that is expected to grow by $321 million in the next year, state officials estimate. In 170,000 cases, or almost half, no payments have ever been made.
"This is a staggering figure, and it cannot be permitted to continue," Mr. Pataki said in a statement today. "My message to deadbeat parents is simple: If you fail to make your child-support payments, you risk losing your driver's license."
New York is sharing in a national frustration over collecting child-support payments. Nationwide estimates say those payments are made less than 20 percent of the time.
Suspending driver's and professional licenses has emerged as the new weapon of choice in that fight. Maine, Massachusetts and California have initiated programs similar to New York's, and all have reported some level of success, New York officials say.
President Clinton has also advocated the idea as part of his national welfare agenda.
Dan Hogan, a spokesman for the state Department of Social Services, said that the mere threat of license suspension had helped increase collection rates in other states. He said Maine had collected $26 million from 13,023 chronic nonpayers since it began threatening license suspensions in August 1993. In that period, only 100 licenses were actually suspended.
"From the Maine experience, you can see most people realize it's a serious threat," Mr. Hogan said. "We're saying, 'Here's your chance to get in and clean things up because we're coming after you if you don't.' "
Under the new policy, which was approved by the Legislature in June as part of the state budget, the state will begin mailing notices Monday to 190,000 parents to warn them about the new policy. About 380,000 notices will be mailed in September, with half of those going to the same people who will receive letters this month.
In October, the Department of Motor Vehicles will begin requiring that applications for new licenses or renewals include Social Security numbers, which will help in tracking people who owe child support.
The Department of Social Services will then begin randomly comparing D.M.V. records against lists of parents who owe child support and suspending licenses when matches are made.
By next summer, the state expects to have in place a computer system that will allow D.M.V. clerks to find out immediately when someone applies for a new license or a renewal if the person is more than four months behind in child support. If the answer is yes, that application will be denied on the spot. If the person has a license, it will be suspended.
Under the policy, a parent's license would remain suspended until that person either paid the arrears or agreed to a payment schedule. Mr. Hogan said the new policy was expected to increase child-support payments by $30 million in the coming year.
Mr. Hogan said California, which has issued warnings to 22,889 drivers, had seen its child-support collections increase by $10 million. Massachusetts sent 60,000 warning notices last year and has collected $600,000 as a result, he said.
The new policy will also allow the state to suspend the professional licenses of people who are behind in their child-support payments. However, Mr. Hogan said, the state is still developing a program to track down those people.
Until now, the state's strongest tool for enforcing child-support payments has been to deduct money from a delinquent parent's paychecks. But that policy has been somewhat ineffective, Mr. Hogan said, because people change jobs frequently and employers have often been slow to forward information to the state.
The state also has the power to intercept tax refunds and unemployment insurance benefits and to seize bank accounts to enforce child-support payments. But Mr. Hogan said that suspending driver's licenses was expected to be more efficient and effective because it is simpler and involves fewer legal machinations.
Child support has become an integral part of the welfare debate here and in other state capitals because so many single parents wind up on the public dole. In New York State, half the families receiving court-ordered child-support payments are also receiving public assistance. Ninety percent of the time, those families are headed by women.
Some welfare experts have questioned whether cracking down on "deadbeat dads" will significantly help poor families because the absent fathers are often poor themselves and capable of only minimal payments to their children.
But Russell Sykes, deputy director of the State Communities Aid Association, which lobbies on behalf of poor people in Albany, said national studies had shown that many fathers who fall behind in their child-support payments are not poor but are simply unwilling to pay.
"Unlike the popular perception, many who aren't paying can pay," Mr. Sykes said. "That's why we are very supportive of Pataki's efforts to force payments."
Mr. Sykes said the Pataki administration should take even stronger measures to enforce child-support payments, including speeding up the process of establishing paternity. He also recommended that the state transfer the responsibility for tracking delinquent payers from the Department of Social Services to the Department of Taxation and Finance, where enforcement would probably be more rigorous, he said.

HEADLINE: In TV Deregulation, Qualms About Losing Local Control

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
G. V. Montgomery is worried that the Walt Disney Company could bring sex and violence to the South. Mr. Montgomery is a Democratic Representative from Mississippi, and during a House debate on the communications bill last week, he cited Disney as a reason not to lift Government restrictions on the ownership of media properties.
In Mr. Montgomery's home district, the local ABC affiliates routinely pre-empt programming, like the racy "N.Y.P.D. Blue," that might offend their viewers. Now that Disney is acquiring ABC, Mr. Montgomery fears that the company could snap up ABC stations like WLOV in Columbus, Miss., which is owned by an independent businessman. 
 If Disney owned the Mississippi affiliates, he said, it would be far less likely to block out ABC's programs in deference to local standards, because the network is seeking the largest national audience for its programming and advertising.
The perceived threat to localism is a key argument of those who oppose the growing concentration of media ownership. And it proved potent enough that 60 Republicans joined 168 Democrats on Friday in voting to retain stricter limits on that ownership, tempering a bill that clears away regulations in every other corner of the communications industry.
Curbing the power of giant media conglomerates has long been a popular issue among politicians. But last week's billion-dollar deals, in which Disney agreed to acquire Capital Cities/ABC Inc. and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation agreed to buy CBS Inc., galvanized lawmakers who previously regarded the debate over communications legislation as mostly an arcane battle between local and long-distance phone companies.
"This has catapulted media concentration to the front page," said Representative Edward J. Markey, a Massachusetts Democrat who sponsored the amendment on media-property ownership. "The average consumer is far more concerned about this than whether they are going to have three new long-distance companies."
Many critics contend that it is not in big metropolitan markets where media consolidation and the deregulation of the telephone and cable monopolies pose the biggest threat. According to this argument, robust competition in such markets would give big media companies the incentive to keep consumers by giving them what they want. It is in smaller towns and rural areas, over which big companies might not care to fight, that a narrowing of voices could hit consumers the hardest.
Despite his victory on the amendment, Mr. Markey still voted against the bill because he said it would allow other types of media concentration that he considered dangerous. Specifically, he said, the bill would still let one company own multiple media properties -- like newspapers and television stations -- in a single market. Mr. Markey said this would quash alternative voices.
Indeed, Mr. Markey's amendment was narrowly focused on television ownership: No company can own stations that reach more than 35 percent of the television households in the nation. The original bill would have raised that limit to 50 percent, from the current 25 percent. The amendment also prohibits one company from owning a TV station and a cable system in the same market -- an existing restriction that the original House bill would have removed.
The Senate's communications bill, passed in June, would also lift the cap on station ownership from 25 percent to 35 percent, but unlike the House bill would retain a series of restrictions on cross-ownership of media properties. The House and the Senate must reconcile the two bills in a conference committee this fall.
The House bill would allow a variety of new combinations: Newspaper publishers could own a TV station or a cable system in the same city. Broadcasters could own an unlimited number of radio stations nationally, and multiple stations in one city. A company could even own two TV stations in one city, provided that one of the stations uses a lower-power UHF signal.
It was only coincidental that the Disney and Westinghouse deals occurred in the same week as the House vote on the bill, but they might have been difficult to conclude without the changes provided for in the legislation. By buying CBS, for example, Westinghouse will own 39 radio stations across the country, including the two all-news stations in New York City, WCBS and WINS. In addition, Westinghouse will own 14 television stations, covering roughly 33 percent of the nation's households.
If the original version of the House bill had passed, Westinghouse could have bought even more stations -- which some analysts said was one of its primary goals in buying CBS.
By buying Capital Cities/ABC, Disney would own two television stations in Los Angeles, KABC and KCAL. Both are higher-powered VHF stations, so Disney's chairman, Michael D. Eisner, has said he may sell KCAL. But under the bill, Mr. Eisner could seek a waiver from the Federal Communications Commission to hold onto both of them.
Moreover, the Senate and House bills are both silent on the issue of vertical integration, which occurs when programming companies own one or more distribution channels. Disney-ABC, Time Warner Inc. and Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation are the most notable examples of such integration. Time Warner owns both the Warner Brothers studio and many cable television systems, while the News Corporation owns both the 20th Century-Fox studio and the Fox television network.
Thomas J. Tauke, the chief lobbyist for the Nynex Corporation, the regional Bell company, said lawmakers focused briefly on the dangers of vertical integration after the Bell Atlantic Corporation, another regional Bell, announced a plan to merge with the cable giant Tele-Communications Inc. in 1993. But after that deal foundered, such concerns died on Capitol Hill, said Mr. Tauke, a former Republican Congressman.
He also said the emergence of new distribution channels, like the Internet, had allayed fears that a few giant companies would gain a stranglehold over the dissemination of information.
But consumer advocates and other critics of the legislation said the danger of such a stranglehold had not diminished. The Internet is still a niche medium, where the audience for an information service at any one time can be measured by the tens of thousands at most -- as opposed to a mass medium like the ABC network, which attracts viewers by the tens of millions.
Disney, moreover, will also have access to telephone wires through its programming venture with three regional Bells: the Ameritech Corporation, SBC Communications Inc., and the BellSouth Corporation.
"Yes, you'll have access to the Internet," said Jeff Chester, executive director of the Center for Media Education, a research group in Washington. "But if your modem is connected to the BellSouth network, the first thing you're going to see when you click on is Mickey Mouse."
Media executives contend that they have little choice but to consolidate. Entertainment has become a global business dominated by companies with the resources to produce and distribute a vast amount of programming, or "content."
Martin D. Franks, the senior vice president and chief lobbyist of CBS, said his network needed to grow to compete with its rivals. Fox, for example, stripped eight affiliates from CBS last year, in part because Mr. Murdoch could invest $500 million in the stations' parent, New World Communications.
Yesterday on the ABC news program "This Week With David Brinkley," Barry Diller, the former chairman of QVC Inc. who at one time last year was poised to become the new head of CBS, said vertical integration "will continue while there's money to fuel it."
"Once the money stops, once we get a big advertising recession," he added, "you'll see things get thrown over the side for survival."
 As for the issue of station ownership, executives of Capital Cities/ ABC noted that most television stations were already owned by station groups. In Mr. Montgomery's Congressional district in Mississippi, for example, the affiliate in Meridian is owned by Richard Benedek, a New York businessman who owns three other ABC affiliates around the country.
Patricia Matson, a spokeswoman for ABC, said outside owners could serve local needs better by having the resources to invest in large local news operations. And often, when local stations pre-empt network offerings like "N.Y.P.D. Blue," the replacement fare is cartoons or network reruns -- not programs tailored to local tastes.
Even critics of media concentration acknowledge that it is hard to gather solid data about its effect on what Americans watch, read or listen to. But, the critics say, there is plenty of anecdotal evidence that television and radio programming has become more uniform and less adventurous as those businesses have consolidated into giant conglomerates.
"As you get bigger and bigger, you have to have more predictable programming," said Ben H. Bagdikian, the former dean of the Graduate School of Journalism at the University of California at Berkeley. "There is simply too much risk in innovation."
Mr. Bagdikian also said large media companies did not pay as much attention to local issues because such programming was not as profitable as mass-market fare. He noted that large radio station groups had replaced local disk jockeys across the country with nationally syndicated celebrities like Rush Limbaugh and Howard Stern.
The House voted solidly last week that the nation needs a deregulated communications industry to compete globally in the 21st century. But the prospect of distant overlords ignoring the tastes of local communities touches an old-fashioned political chord familiar to many lawmakers.
It goes to show that as in politics, all media is local.

HEADLINE: Burden of Transit-Fare Rise Will Not Be Borne Equally

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
As one who lives in the no man's land of two-fare zones, Arnold C. Lewis of Springfield Gardens, Queens, will be one of those hit hardest if the price of a token climbs to $1.50. But he considers himself lucky.
"It will be hard for me, but I'll live," said Mr. Lewis, 49, who counsels inmates at a work-release center in Harlem. "However, someone who works for minimum wage, what is that person supposed to do? Some of them live in two-fare zones, too, and it's already $5 a day just to get to and from work." 
 Commuters like Mr. Lewis have to scour their pockets and purses twice on the trip to work, first for a bus and then for a subway. And last Thursday, they and millions of others across the metropolitan area learned that they might have to dig a little deeper.
To cope with rising costs and falling government subsidies, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, E. Virgil Conway, proposed increases in bridge and tunnel tolls and subway, bus and commuter railroad fares. He also said that the M.T.A. would stop issuing free or half-fare transit passes for 500,000 students.
Under Mr. Conway's plan, riders would bear a larger share of the costs for all of the region's public transportation, but the added expense would not fall equally on different groups of commuters, and some people would actually pay substantially less.
But in recent interviews, one thing united several users of public transportation: an angry sense that they were being asked to shoulder an unfair burden, and a weary belief that this was about what could be expected from government.
The largest proportional increase, 20 percent, would be borne by straphangers like Julio Vega, a maintenance worker from Brooklyn, who would have to pay $1.50 instead of $1.25 for a subway token.
The transit fare increase would fall hardest on the estimated 350,000 two-fare zone commuters, many of whom live in eastern Queens and southeastern Brooklyn. But Mr. Conway pledged to eliminate the zones in 1997, letting residents of those areas transfer between subways and buses free.
Under Mr. Conway's plan, riders on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad and the Long Island Rail Road would pay 9 percent more, a smaller proportional increase than subway and bus riders. But many suburban residents, like Stephen Marro, a self-employed film maker from Long Beach, L.I., take both the train and the subway to work, so they would be hit twice each way by the increases.
The tolls on major bridges and tunnels between boroughs would rise 17 percent, from $6 for a round trip to $7. But the discount toll paid by Staten Island residents like Peter Trombetta, a general contractor, who take the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge to Brooklyn, would fall to $3.20 from $4.
For Mr. Vega, the F train, which he catches at Avenue I, is a lifeline, the only link between his home in Borough Park and his $25,000-a-year job in housing maintenance at New York University. The price of subway trip is already hard on his family, he said, but "we have no other choice, we really don't."
He and his wife, a nurse, struggle to support themselves, their two unemployed children and three grandchildren. "We don't do a lot," he said. "Everything is just based on paying the rent and the bills."
One of his most difficult tasks, he said, is to find $5 each day to give his son and daughter so that they can take the subway to look for work. "It's a little bit unfair to those who really can't afford it," he said.
His own commuting now costs $12.50 a week and promises to rise to $15. He estimated that all told, he, his wife and his children spend $75 a week on subway tokens, a figure that would climb to $90 with the fare increase.
For two-fare commuters like Mr. Lewis and his friend, Valeria Roberts, 43, the fare increase would mean another $1 a day, $5 a week and $250 a year just to get to and from work. Both take the Q111 bus on Guy R. Brewer Boulevard to the E train at Jamaica Center for the long ride to Manhattan. Ms. Roberts gets out at 34th Street, while Mr. Lewis transfers at Times Square to the 2 or 3 train.
Mr. Lewis, who is single and whose children are grown, acknowledges that, with a $40,000-a-year income from his job at the Lincoln Correctional Facility in Harlem, he will be able to absorb the added cost.
For Ms. Roberts, a single mother who lives in Jamaica, Queens, and whose son attends the University of Maryland, the stretch will be harder. She earns $29,000 a year working at the Matching Gift Center, a firm that administers charitable giving programs for large companies. She still remembers her shock at discovering two-fare zones when she moved to New York four years ago, after living in Chicago and Washington, where riders can transfer from trains to buses for a quarter.
Many New Yorkers have no choice but to use the subway, but not so Mr. Marro, the film maker, who is self-employed and describes his financial situation as "comfortable." Most days, he takes the 8:37 out of Long Beach and tries to get some work done aboard the train with his Apple Power Book balanced on his knees.
But with a fare increase, "I'd rather stay home," said Mr. Marro, 36, who is married but has no children.
The weekly ticket from Long Beach to Pennsylvania Station that he often buys now sells for $44, and would cost $4 more with the fare increase. If he traveled to Manhattan four times in a week, the amount he would spend on subway tokens to and from his Gramercy Park office would rise to $12 from $10.
Mr. Trombetta, 28, the Staten Island contractor, drives every workday over the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge to jobs in Brooklyn, so he stands to benefit from the lower toll for island residents -- but only if he drives his car. The discount will be available only to residents who have electronically read stickers in their car windows, and the stickers are not available for trucks.
"For my car, absolutely I would get the pass to get the savings, but a lot of days I drive the truck to work," he said. "I guess I would try to drive it as little as possible."
Mr. Trombetta, who would not give his income but described himself as middle class, said he was skeptical that the savings would last long or that the new system would work smoothly.
"Probably a year, a year and a half from now, they'll claim that they're losing millions of dollars a year on it and they have to raise it again. It doesn't end."

HEADLINE: Quarterly Treasury Refunding This Week

 BODY:
In addition to today's regular weekly auction of 3- and 6-month bills, the Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes its quarterly refunding. The Treasury will auction 3-year notes tomorrow, 10-year notes on Wednesday and 30-year bonds on Thursday.
By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding 3-month bill was 5.39 percent and the 6-month bill was at 5.39 percent. In when-issued trading late Friday afternoon, a 3-year note was being offered at rate to yield 6.05 percent; a 10-year note at a rate to yield 6.48 percent, and a 30-year bond at a rate to yield 6.86 percent. 
 Government issues being priced this week include today's Sallie Mae issue of $600 million of six-month floating-rate notes and tomorrow's Fannie Mae issue of $500 million of five-year debentures.

HEADLINE: Animal Advocates Protest Plans for a Primate Lab

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

DATELINE: TUXEDO, N.Y., Aug. 3

 BODY:
For the 225 chimpanzees at the New York University Medical Center's primate laboratory here, the routine varies from fun and games to medical tests that could mean the difference between life and death for members of another primate species, human beings.
On this morning, while five diaper-clad baby chimps tumbled or napped amid a collection of stuffed toys and a pair of 3-year-olds watched "The Wizard of Oz" on television, in other buildings dozens of adult chimpanzees infected with the AIDS virus or hepatitis were taking part in vaccine studies. 
 For 28 years, the chimpanzee and monkey colonies at the Laboratory for Experimental Medicine and Surgery in Primates, or Lemsip, have played an internationally recognized role in research, in areas ranging from AIDS to alcoholism to organ transplantation.
And, while many laboratories housing primates have been harshly criticized by animal-rights advocates, Lemsip has been credited for its open-door policy and relatively humane conditions.
Now, though, animal-welfare advocates and conservationists, led by Dr. Jane Goodall, a pioneer in the study of chimpanzee behavior, have joined with the laboratory's staff in protesting plans to transfer ownership of the laboratory to the New Mexico-based Coulston Foundation, which has a history of violations of Federal animal-welfare regulations.
As recently as last month, the Department of Agriculture accused the foundation of keeping several dozen chimpanzees in undersize cages and causing the avoidable deaths of at least five chimpanzees. Three of them died in October 1993 when a space heater malfunctioned and pushed temperatures in a holding room to 140 degrees.
In addition, the foundation's leader, Dr. Frederick Coulston, has long been a target of animal-welfare advocates because he favors the use of chimpanzees, the closest living relative of humans and an endangered species in their home range in Africa, in toxicity tests of drugs and industrial chemicals.
Should the Coulston Foundation acquire Lemsip's 225 chimpanzees, it would control more than half the 1,500 chimpanzees currently being used for medical research in the United States, said Suzanne Roy, program director for In Defense of Animals, a California-based advocacy group. "If the Coulston Foundation can't even insure that its own facilities are in compliance with the law," she said, "how can they take over another facility?"
Unfazed by his critics, Dr. Coulston, an 81-year-old zoologist who has used monkeys and apes in laboratory tests since 1936, defended his record and plans. He denied reports that most of the 540 chimps in his care were locked in small individual cages. "We keep most of them in family groups," he said. "Just like in the jungle, only better, because they've got food to eat without having to forage."
He said the heater malfunction had occurred two months after his organization took over a laboratory from New Mexico State University. "Now we're fixing the place up," Dr. Coulston said. "By Sept. 15 there will not be a single violation of any kind."
The Coulston Foundation in Alamogordo, N.M., owns about 400 chimpanzees and has sought to acquire 140 that it leases from the United States Air Force. In May, Dr. Goodall led a separate effort, so far successful, to prevent the military from giving Dr. Coulston the Air Force chimpanzees, which are descendants of animals used in the early days of the American space program.
Dr. Coulston said the Air Force was eager to give away the animals, which have no military use anymore and are extremely costly to maintain. "I've been working with the Air Force since 1963," he said. "This is not over yet."
In an Aug. 1 letter to the New York University Board of Trustees, Dr. Goodall said, "I request that you require the Coulston Foundation to completely solve, to the satisfaction of Federal authorities, all violations at its New Mexico facilities before giving T.C.F. any role in the ownership or management of the Lemsip labs."
Donald Buford, the chief executive officer of the Connecticut-based Jane Goodall Institute, a nonprofit group financing the rescue and relocation of chimpanzees in Africa, said: "All we're saying is put the brakes on. We're talking about the fate of over half of all the research chimps in the United States. There may be a better, longer-term solution than might be on the table at this time."
Lemsip's director, Dr. Jan Moor-Jankowski, said he was concerned not only with the fate of the chimpanzees but also with the future of a $705,000 endowment that is supposed to be used to care for animals once they have outlived their usefulness as research subjects. Dr. Moor-Jankowski expressed concern that the Coulston Foundation might find a different use for the money.
During a tour of Lemsip, Dr. Moor-Jankowski, 71, said he felt that New York University's decision to get rid of the laboratory was retribution of a sort. As members of a university committee reviewing animal experiments, he and Dr. C. James Mahoney, Lemsip's deputy director, had criticized other primate experiments run at a separate N.Y.U. lab.
Both men resigned from the committee when the experiments, which involved administering crack cocaine to monkeys, were allowed to continue. "For 28 years," Dr. Moor-Jankowski said, "Lemsip fit perfectly with N.Y.U.'s research program. Now suddenly it doesn't. This is what I get for speaking out."
University officials vehemently denied that the decision to seek a new owner for Lemsip had anything to do with that incident. Dr. David Scotch, an associate dean of the university's medical school, called the decision economic. "It doesn't take much to realize," he said, "that given what the health-care situation is like in New York, the Medical Center has to concentrate on what it does best."
Dr. Mahoney said he was puzzled by N.Y.U.'s determination that the laboratory no longer matched the medical school's research agenda. As he sat in a rocking chair in the nursery, cradling Cory, a 4-month-old chimpanzee, he said, "What could be more current and applicable to human needs than research on AIDS and hepatitis?"
Officials at New York University said the laboratory would require millions of dollars in renovations to meet increasingly stringent Federal standards. Despite the praise it has received for its relatively humane approach to its primate colonies, Lemsip is old and has been cited for overcrowding of animals.
But Dr. Moor-Jankowski contended that he had raised extra money to build a retirement home of sorts for older chimpanzees, which would rectify the space problem. He added that the university's depiction of Lemsip as a money loser was false.
"The laboratory has always been self-supporting," said Dr. Moor-Jankowski, explaining that its $4 million annual budget is covered by drug companies or other research institutions that have contracts for particular projects.
The Aaron Diamond AIDS Research Center, a laboratory in Manhattan affiliated with New York University, had also proposed taking over Lemsip, said Dr. David D. Ho, the center's director."But N.Y.U. has already gone very far with Coulston," he added. "It's virtually a done deal."
Hoping to prevent the transfer of the laboratory to the Coulston Foundation, Dr. Moor-Jankowski, Dr. Mahoney and Dr. Preston Marx, who directs the AIDS projects financed through the Aaron Diamond Center, have proposed a "friendly takeover" in which they would raise enough capital from corporations and donors to buy the laboratory.
For now, however, the Coulston Foundation appears to be the leading contender. Dr. Scotch of the medical school said no final decision had yet been made, but he added: "I believe the Coulston Foundation will rectify the violations that they have been cited on. I think that the Coulston Foundation is a perfectly suitable candidate."

HEADLINE: MEDIA: MAGAZINES;
An ambitious survey by Conde Nast Traveler zeros in on the wallets of readers.

BYLINE: By Deirdre Carmody 

 BODY:
Richard D. Beckman, publisher of Conde Nast Traveler, is releasing today one of the largest studies ever done by a single magazine on the buying habits and tastes of its readership.
The magazine industry has long been dependent on what is known as syndicated research, which provides vast amounts of information based on interviews with thousands of readers of magazines and helps advertisers make decisions about where to place ads. 
 What has been nagging at Mr. Beckman is that only a very small number of Conde Nast Traveler readers are included in syndicated research. Of the 20,083 respondents whose questionnaires were tabulated recently by Mediamark Research Inc., for instance, only 315 said they were readers of Conde Nast Traveler.
Because the magazine has a circulation of 900,000, Mr. Beckman thought information about 315 people was inadequate to try to project the tastes and buying habits of all the magazine's readers. So he decided to conduct his own survey.
Conde Nast Traveler, which is owned by Advance Publications, sent a 12-page questionnaire to 400,000 subscribers in its April issue. Within four weeks, readers returned 75,000 questionnaires, of which 50,564 were eventually used in the survey.
The results will provide advertisers with unusually detailed information about the magazine's readers. More than 14,000 respondents, for instance, explained what they had purchased and why from a long list of men's and women's apparel designers, where they shopped and how they rated stores, how many airplane trips they took for business and how many for pleasure, and so on.
For advertisers, of course, this kind of information is pure gold. Several, however, said it could not take the place of syndicated research.
"In principle, we will certainly look at it, and we applaud anybody's initiative to try and shed greater research light on solving our clients' problems," said Mark Stewart, senior vice president-media director at McCann-Erickson, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. "But remember, no publisher has ever related primary data without showing their publication in a favorable light."
Alan Jurmain, executive director of media services at Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York, a unit of The Lowe Group, said that there was a general lack of information about affluent consumers and that he thought many media directors at advertising agencies would find the Conde Nast Traveler study useful.
"We don't believe in a single magic box, but usually we have to make lots of inferences from limited resources," he said. "The more fresh data we have from sizable samples just makes us smarter and our insights sharper."
Mr. Beckman said he spent 25 percent more on his survey than it cost him to participate in syndicated research conducted by the Simmons Market Research Bureau. Although Mr. Beckman declined to give specific figures, sources at the magazine said it spends about $90,000 for each syndicated research study.
Mr. Beckman has dropped Simmons but still participates in syndicated research conducted by Monroe Mendelsohn Research and Mediamark. And Mediamark's custom division tabulated the new Conde Nast Traveler study.
"I think syndicated research was never meant to be particularly effective in evaluating upscale magazines," Mr. Beckman said. "The onset of this research was in the 'Father Knows Best' days, to show that mass magazines could compete with television."
Wealthy, well-educated readers like those who subscribe to Conde Nast Traveler make up only a small percentage of the total number who show up in the overall syndicated research. Of 22,051 respondents to the latest Simmons study, only 622 said they read the magazine. And out of 11,704 tabulated by Monroe Mendelsohn Research, only 890 said they read Conde Nast Traveler.
Mr. Beckman said he was also troubled by the fact that syndicated research includes information about total audience -- in other words, including anyone who reads someone else's copy of a magazine or who picks it up in the doctor's office -- and does not give more weight to the people who actually buy a magazine.
The Simmons study estimates the total readership of Conde Nast Traveler to be 2.5 million people.
"If syndicated research focused more on the primary subscriber, I think you would have a tremendous improvement in value," Mr. Beckman said.
Conde Nast Traveler, which was started in 1987, has become one of the most successful travel publications, having weathered the recession and come out intact.
And its "truth in travel" editorial stance has frightened away only a few advertisers. Last year, the magazine reported that Delta Air Lines Inc. led the list of airlines that were fined by the Federal Aviation Administration for maintenance violations. Delta immediately yanked the remaining $95,000 of its ad budget for 1994. The airline did not say the move was in retribution for the article but called it a needed trimming of its ad budget.
Rebecca McPheters, president and chief executive of Simmons, praised the Conde Nast Traveler study and said the magazine had gotten a wealth of information from a large base of its readers.
"I applaud what they have done, but it's not a substitute for syndicated research," she said. "The principal value of a syndicated study is that it allows for fair comparisons within the media."
And, she added, "I haven't given up on getting Conde Nast Traveler back in the fall."

LENGTH: 645 words

HEADLINE: China: Kind Words, Little Effect

 BODY:
For weeks, the Clinton Administration choreographed a fence-mending meeting between Secretary of State Warren Christopher and China's Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen. When the two met last Tuesday in Brunei the rhetoric was diplomatically polite and the spin resolutely upbeat. Unhappily, any optimism they may have generated about the relationship was doused when Beijing expelled two American military officers for alleged spying.
The Pentagon says the two men were engaged in legal surveillance. Mr. Christopher complains that their ill-timed snooping needlessly compromised his mission. Nice try. The string of incidents that have repeatedly tripped up relations between the United States and China this year cannot all be dismissed as bureaucratic accidents. 
 Washington set off a predictable furor in Beijing when it correctly granted a visa to Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui. China responded with intentionally provocative missile tests near Taiwan. It deliberately roiled Washington by detaining an American citizen, Harry Wu, charging him with the capital crime of espionage and restricting his access to consular officials.
Two Administrations have struggled for six years to try to restore the smooth course of United States-China relations that prevailed before the Tiananmen Square massacre of 1989. But despite the countries' mutual interest in diplomatic cooperation and economic exchange, the fundamentals of the relationship have changed in ways that make a return to easy harmony unlikely.
The most explosive issues are human rights and Taiwan. To restore harmony, both countries will have to find a satisfactory way to reconcile America's belief in democracy and human rights with the authoritarian cruelty of Chinese Communism, which 16 years of economic reform have not significantly softened. They will also have to find a way to exclude the threat of military force from China's relations with Taiwan.
Washington cannot impose its own idea of capitalist democracy on China. But neither can it turn its back on Chinese citizens who peacefully struggle for internationally recognized human rights. Tensions over the succession to Deng Xiaoping make this a period of particularly harsh and arbitrary repression.
As for Taiwan, Washington has long accepted Beijing's view that it is part of China, a view that Taipei officially shares. But reality is more complicated. Taiwan is becoming an affluent democracy while China, even with its huge economic gains, remains a largely impoverished dictatorship. As Taiwan grows more democratic, its political leaders have had to bow to public desires for a more distinctive international presence.
That puts America in an awkward predicament. It cannot and should not disavow democratic Taiwan, which currently buys twice as much from the United States as China does. But neither should Washington provoke China by embroiling itself in the Taiwan independence issue.
Washington is struggling to walk a narrow path on the democracy and Taiwan issues, at once principled and pragmatic. Beijing has concluded that what Washington is really trying to do is undermine the Communist regime. Nothing could be further from the truth, but Beijing, feeling threatened, has resorted to belligerent diplomacy, heightened repression and military muscle-flexing.
In this atmosphere, Mr. Christopher's soothing words cannot have much lasting effect. Clashes over human rights, and now Taiwan, occur with increasing frequency and rancor. All the more reason, then, for the Clinton Administration to resist China's demands for concessions it cannot make without antagonizing public opinion and touching off a Congressional revolt. That means insisting on Washington's right to grant visas to Taiwan's leaders and refusing to invite China's President to Washington while Harry Wu remains in jail.
