HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
The Race for an Even Bigger Bomb

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

DARK SUN
 The Making of the Hydrogen Bomb
 By Richard Rhodes
 Illustrated. 731 pages. Simon & Schuster. $32.50.
In the closing pages of his prize-winning history "The Making of the Atomic Bomb" (1986), Richard Rhodes wrote that immediately after the successful testing of the A-bomb, Edward Teller and Enrico Fermi "renewed theoretical work on the problem of thermonuclear ignition," the explosive force of which was expected to be 10 megatons, or 1,000 times the yield of the Hiroshima bomb. 
 A reader might anticipate, then, that in his sequel, "Dark Sun: The Making of the Hydrogen Bomb," Mr. Rhodes would begin his narrative in 1945 or thereabouts, and trace the events that culminated at 7:15 A.M. on Nov. 1, 1952, with the successful testing at Enewetak atoll of the thermonuclear device known as Mike.
But no. In his new book, Mr. Rhodes goes back to January 1939, nine months before the outbreak of World War II, when "a letter from Paris alerted physicists in the Soviet Union to the startling news that German radiochemists had discovered a fundamental new nuclear reaction." He then traces the events leading to the Soviet testing of a nuclear-fission bomb at Semipalatinsk on Aug. 29, 1949. ("Did it look like the American one?" shouted Lavrenti Beria, the director of the project, to one of his subordinates who had witnessed a United States test at Bikini atoll in the Marshall Islands.)
Not until page 455 does Mr. Rhodes take up the dramatic technical details involved in the design of Mike, which he finally describes in these words: "Steel, lead, waxy polyethylene, purple-black uranium, gold leaf, copper, stainless steel, plutonium, a breath of tritium, silvery deuterium effervescent as sea-wake: Mike was a temple, tragically Solomonic, evoking the powers that fire the sun."
Why does Mr. Rhodes take this seemingly roundabout approach, which is not even hinted at in his title? Because in his view the story of the hydrogen bomb is only secondarily a technological one. What mainly drove American physicists to design the more powerful bomb was the news that the Soviet Union possessed an atom bomb. And the reason the Russians had achieved the bomb was mainly spying, Mr. Rhodes insists. So his story of the H-bomb is not so much technology as the interaction of politics, diplomacy, war, espionage, theoretical and practical physics and paranoia.
Mutual distrust seems to have been the key to the story, or so it appears from the author's two-sided view of the arms race between the two cold-war antagonists. By matching up newly published Russian espionage information with the records of the F.B.I. and the confessions of Klaus Fuchs, Harry Gold, David and Ruth Greenglass and Alan Nunn May, Mr. Rhodes makes a persuasive case that Julius Rosenberg was guilty of espionage (Ethel's culpability remains elusive), and that the Soviet nuclear program benefited hugely from the country's extensive network of spies.
Espionage supplied the Russians with critical details of concepts, materials and design. Of Mr. Greenglass's crude sketches, Mr. Rhodes writes, "It was a long way from imploding cylinders to three-dimensional lensed implosion systems, but in fact the two-dimensional experiments proved crucial to the design of the small device at the center of the implosion system -- the initiator -- that produced a burst of neutrons at the right time to start the chain reaction."
After all, as Mr. Rhodes makes clear, the Russian physicists were far from unsophisticated. In fact, what he says held them back was Beria's insistence that they shun pure physics and model their project after what espionage supplied. As a result, writes Mr. Rhodes, the first Soviet atom bomb was a copy of the bomb dropped on Nagasaki, and the first Soviet nuclear reactor was almost exactly the same as a classified American reactor. Still, despite Beria's strictures, Andrei Sakharov managed to come up with the right design for a hydrogen bomb even before American physicists did.
What held the Americans back from developing a hydrogen bomb, in Mr. Rhodes's view, was a relaxation of vigilance brought on by the end of World War II and an attempt by the nuclear establishment to place all discoveries under international control. Then, when Teller undertook to develop what he named the Super, he impeded the program by setting his sights on megaton yields, which "blinded him to the promise of incremental achievement that Andrei Sakharov immediately recognized."
But paranoia eventually defined the conduct of both sides, in Mr. Rhodes's view. Stalin, fearing American intentions, lowered his iron curtain on Eastern Europe and demanded that his scientists give him the bomb. President Truman, in response, unleashed Gen. Curtis LeMay and his Strategic Air Command, and decided on purely political grounds to press ahead with the development of the hydrogen bomb.
J. Robert Oppenheimer, the father of the atom bomb, raised moral objections to building the bigger bomb. For his trouble, Mr. Rhodes says, he was expelled from the nuclear establishment by having his security clearance removed. To this event Mr. Rhodes devotes an entire chapter, his own arresting version of Rolf Hochhuth's famous documentary drama "In the Matter of J. Robert Oppenheimer."
But if Mr. Rhodes is critical of the way both the United States and the Soviet Union abandoned morality in the rush to embrace their doomsday weapons and of their near use of them in the Cuban missile crisis, he is restrained in his final judgment of the nuclear arms race. Was it really necessary to put the United States $4 trillion in debt and to trigger the collapse of the Soviet Union's economy? he asks.
"From a longer perspective, the arms race was a process of communication and of learning," he concludes, "paced as all progress is paced by the limitations of human intellect. The discovery in 1938 of how to release nuclear energy introduced a singularity into the human world -- a deep new reality, a region where the old rules of war no longer applied. The region of nuclear singularity enlarged across the decades, sweeping war away at its shock front until today it excludes all but civil wars and limited conventional wars."
In short, so far, so good, with huge question marks looming on the horizon. But if the history of nuclear energy is still very far from complete, Mr. Rhodes has made a powerful drama of the messy events that have occurred up to now.

HEADLINE: MUSIC REVIEW;
Brightness And Light, Earnestly

BYLINE: By BERNARD HOLLAND 

 BODY:
German music's incorporation of French and Italian cultures is borrowed sunlight. The juxtaposition of Bach and Telemann with Albinoni and Vivaldi said as much at Thursday's Mostly Mozart concert. The players were the members of Tafelmusik, the period-instrument orchestra from Canada; the place was Avery Fisher Hall.
Here was Bach, the admiring student and transcriber of Vivaldi's scores, transforming Italian models into something dark and serious. The Violin Concerto (BWV 1041) is in A minor, a key the composer reserves for heavy pondering under overcast skies. Telemann's suite, "Musique de Table, III" offers a clever gloss on French dance styles of the late Baroque. The virtuoso writing has its own wit, albeit a wit more subdued and self-conscious than the originals on which it is based. This is a paradox of the German mind, which yearns for the Gallic and the Latinate while clinging to its own consuming earnestness. 
 If Goethe's famous Italian journey was, as he described it, a passage from northern gloom into incredible brightness, then Albinoni's Concerto for Two Oboes just before intermission helps explain what Goethe meant. Lighter than air and gracefully formed, this is delightful entertainment, possessing not a hint of instruction or moral purpose. Vivaldi's D-Major Concerto for Four Violins is more dramatic but viscerally so, filled with high-pitched brilliance and vivid gesture.
The evening's best moment was a concocted Suite by Handel, in which an overture from "Radamisto" and dances from "Il Pastor Fide" serve as resources. Tafelmusik has chosen well, for nowhere else in this concert did profound inventiveness mix so easily with bright light and uninhibited vigor.
Tafelmusik, 16 years old and 18 musicians strong, is an orchestra of admirable reliability though not of blazing individual virtuosity. John Abberger and Washington McClain were the excellent oboists. David Greenberg, Kevin Mallon, Christopher Verrette and Thomas Georgi played competently in the Vivaldi. Jeanne Lamon, Tafelmusik's leader and first violinist, played the Bach with determined seriousness but had her struggles in the finale.
Fisher Hall in an odd way solves the problem of where to play period-instrument concerts for modern audiences. Its size offers many seats to sell, thus promising a little more economic viability; the bright acoustics reflect the intimate older sounds with some presence and clarity.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Washington McClain, left, and John Abberger, of Tafelmusik, at the Mostly Mozart concert on Thursday. (Steve J. Sherman)

HEADLINE: U.S. Message to Vietnamese: Freedom Pays

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 6

 BODY:
The sons and daughters of those who prevailed in the Vietnam War met Secretary of State Warren Christopher today, and he told them in surprisingly stark terms that independent courts, a free press and an end to authoritarianism were their best hope for achieving prosperity.
In a 45-minute speech today at the Vietnamese Government's top foreign-policy school, the Institute for International Relations, Mr. Christopher described at length the democratic changes that have swept through parts of Southeast Asia over the last two decades and made it clear that Vietnam was far behind. 
 Before a clearly attentive audience of several hundred -- mostly students who listened to his English delivery directly even though they had access to a simultaneous translation over earphones -- Mr. Christopher explicitly linked progress in human rights to Vietnam's hopes of joining the booming market economies of Asia.
"Sustained economic development is more likely where courts provide due process, where newspapers are free to expose corruption, and where business people can make decisions with free access to accurate information," he said, describing conditions that are in drastically short supply in this authoritarian -- but increasingly nonideological -- Communist nation.
"Indeed, the reality of Japan, Hong Kong, South Korea and Thailand tells us that the rule of law and accountable government are the bedrock of stability and prosperity," he said. "The reality of Burma and North Korea tells us that repression entrenches bureaucracy."
In a more ordinary setting, such comments would hardly have seemed surprising. But Mr. Christopher gave the address shortly after meeting the general secretary of the Communist Party here, Do Muoi, and it was clearly intended as a signal that Washington will raise human rights issues as Vietnam seeks a far broader economic relationship with the United States.
Mr. Christopher might well have included Vietnam on his short list of repressive nations. Political dissent is still a serious crime here, and even the publication of essays urging political or constitutional reform has resulted in detention and imprisonment; religious activity is also controlled in this country of more than 72 million people.
He did not mention the cases of any political prisoners today, and he carefully avoided direct criticism of the leaders with whom he signed an agreement normalizing diplomatic relations on Saturday.
Nonetheless, Mr. Christopher was speaking in the heart of Hanoi, where today he formally raised an American flag over a new United States Embassy. And in the course of his talk, Mr. Christopher, 69, essentially urged the students to bring about fundamental change in a system that owns every outlet for information, controls the country's property and generates more than its share of corruption.
It is not the kind of classroom instruction that students are accustomed to receiving in this country, where most of the population is under the age of 25.
"When you hear American talk about freedom and human rights, this is what we mean," he said. "Each of you ought to have the right to help shape your country's destiny, as well as your own."
Throughout his weeklong trip through Asia, Mr. Christopher and his aides have argued that economic and cultural engagement with Vietnam is the quickest way to bring about changes in its human rights record. The same argument has been made in the case of China, although so far the evidence of success is slim. Clearly, the Vietnamese Government is betting the opposite: that it can follow a Chinese model, liberalizing its economic system without giving up too much social or political control.
The students appeared to have been chosen largely from the institute, although the United States Embassy here encouraged local employees to bring their friends. The audience looked unsurprised by the Secretary's message, and there were no provocative questions, except for one asking what Mr. Christopher planned to do about Bosnia.
The students seemed less interested in his comments about human freedom than in his discussion of economic issues.
"If Vietnam wants to grow, it has to change its thinking about the economy," one student, Tran Van Thuy, said afterward. "The more foreign investment comes to Vietnam, the more jobs that are created."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Secretary of State Warren Christopher greeted Vietnamese near the United States Embassy in Hanoi after its opening ceremony yesterday. (Associated Press)

SECTION: Section A; Page 13; Column 2; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 1782 words

HEADLINE: Affirmative Action, on the Merit System

BYLINE: By Orlando Patterson; Orlando Patterson, professor of sociology at Harvard, is author of "Freedom."

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
For years Americans have complained about government programs for the disadvantaged that do not work. Now, however, we are on the verge of dismantling affirmative action, the one policy that, for all its imperfections, has made a major difference in the lives of women and minority groups and has helped us achieve the constitutional commitment to the ideal of equality and fairness.
In utilitarian terms, it is hard to find a program that has brought so much gain to so many at so little cost. It has been the single most important factor in the rise of a significant, if still economically fragile, black middle class. 
 So it is hard to understand why it has become the most contentious issue in the nation. One would have thought that a policy that so many politicians denounced would have adversely touched the lives of at least a substantial proportion of those opposing it.
The facts show just the opposite. A National Opinion Research Center survey in 1990, still applicable today, found that while more than 70 percent of white Americans asserted that whites were being hurt by affirmative action for blacks, only 7 percent claimed to have experienced any form of reverse discrimination. Only 16 percent knew of someone close who had. Fewer than one in four could even claim that it was something they had witnessed or heard about at their workplace.
So what was the source feeding all the outrage? The vast majority of those interviewed claimed to have heard about the problem either through the press or from other second-hand sources, like their political leaders.
Of course, such data would not matter were affirmative action something inherently evil. But this could hardly be the case, because for more than 15 years leaders of both parties, including Senator Bob Dole and Gov. Pete Wilson of California, both Republican Presidential candidates, supported this initiative. Indeed, they lauded it, as both morally defensible and the only effective means of remedying the intolerable exclusion of disadvantaged minorities and women from opportunities to train and apply for the better-paying working- and middle-class jobs.

What happened? How did so manifestly worthy and effective a program lose the support, including that of some people who stood the most to gain from it?
Blaming the media or the cynicism of our leaders will not do, the transparent opportunism of Mr. Dole and Mr. Wilson notwithstanding. Several factors account for the collapse of support for affirmative action.
The first is that the largely erroneous arguments of neo-conservative and other right-wing critics somehow carried the day. Merit, we were repeatedly warned, was being undermined, resulting in both individual inequities and, worse, severe threats to our economy and the demands of a high-tech society.
Nonsense, both. Only a minuscule number of whites, we now know, are affected by affirmative action, and of this small fraction, a still smaller percentage are able to claim genuine grievances.
The claim that our economic efficiency is being threatened is simply laughable. Oddly enough, the problem right now is not a shortage of highly trained manpower but an oversupply, demonstrated by a saturated market for scientists and engineers. An alarming number of them are becoming lawyers (the overdependence on which being perhaps our biggest waste of manpower resources).
White men still control more than 99.9 percent of all the important top positions in private and public institutions, as well as the vast majority of middle-level and high-paying jobs. They will continue to do so until well into the next millennium.
There is also the argument that affirmative action has done nothing for the underclass and poor but favors people already in the middle class. Although rhetorically it is extremely effective, it is deliberately misleading. This point figured prominently the recent broadsides against the University of California's affirmative action policies from Governor Wilson and an influential university regent, Ward Connerly.
But affirmative action was never intended to help the poorest and least able. It is, by nature, a top-down strategy, meant to level the field for those who are capable of taking advantage of opportunities denied them because of their sex or race.
For the underclass and the working poor, an entirely different set of bottom-up strategies are called for, although no one seems to know what these might be.
The University of California's experience with affirmative action demonstrates beyond doubt the shallowness of the politicians' criticisms. Over the past 12 years, it has achieved its goal of incorporating students from disadvantaged minorities.
But far from experiencing a decline in standards, the university has not only fulfilled its mandate of selecting students from the top one-eighth of the state's graduating class, but has increased its eligibility requirements five times during this period. It is now a far more selective institution than before the introduction of affirmative action, with improved graduation rates for both black and non-black students.
Nothing could be more hypocritical and contradictory than the spectacle of a Republican governor demanding that his state's university system rely solely on the crude instrument of test scores to select 70 percent of its incoming students.
Republicans never tire of saying that what made America great are the virtues of honesty, courage, initiative and imagination, integrity, loyalty and fair play, all best demonstrated by a person's track record and especially his or her perseverance in the face of adversity. Why then are conservatives vilifying universities for taking these values seriously in selecting the next generation of leaders?
Race, we are told, should have nothing to do with the assessment of these virtues. Race, however, refers to several aspects of a person. It refers to physical appearance, and this, every African-American would agree with Senator Dole and Governor Wilson, should be a matter of no importance.
But for African-Americans, race also means surviving an environment in which racism is still pervasive. It has to be taken into account in assessing the content of any black person's character, and to assert that this amounts to a divisive glorification of race is as disingenuous and as absurd as claiming that we are divisively glorifying poverty and broken families when we take account of these factors in assessing a white student's character.
There is a third important meaning of race, and it is here that we enter tricky ground.
Blackness also connotes something positive: the subcultural heritage of African-Americans that in spite of centuries of discrimination has vastly enriched American civilization out of all proportion to the numbers, and treatment, of the group creating it. The University of California, like other great institutions of learning, rightly has seen the exposure of all its students to this important minority culture as part of its educational mission.
This is a noble goal, but it is fraught with dangers. What brought me around to support affirmative action after some strong initial reservations was not only its effectiveness as a strategy for reducing inequality, but also its possibilities for cross-pollinating our multi-ethnic communities. In the process, it could promote that precious, overarching national culture -- the envy of the world -- which I call ecumenical America.
But the promotion of diversity has done nothing of the sort, as Governor Wilson and Mr. Connerly were able to argue with devastating impact. To the contrary, both on and off our campuses affirmative action seems to have been distorted by its beneficiaries into the goal of balkanizing America both intellectually and culturally. One has only to walk for a few minutes on any large campus to witness the pervasiveness of ethnic separatism, marked by periodic outbursts of other chauvinisms and hostilities.
No group of people now seem more committed to segregation than black students and young professionals. Their motto seems to be: separate, yes, but make sure there is equality, by affirmative action or any other means. To a lesser extent, the tendency of the new black middle class to segregate itself residentially and to scoff at the norms and values of the ecumenical mainstream is the off-campus version of this lamentable betrayal and abandonment of the once cherished goal of integration.
Ethnic separatism has also had deleterious academic consequences. In an experiment conducted at the University of Michigan by two psychologists, Claude Steele and Richard Nisbett, a group of disadvantaged minority students who were encouraged to be part of the campus mainstream, and made to understand that the highest standards were expected of them, consistently performed above the average for white students and the student body as a whole. Members of a control group who took the familiar route of ethnic solidarity and consciousness-raising performed well below the average.
At its best, affirmative action compensates for one of the greatest disabilities of minority members: their lack of access to vital networks and other social capital which white men simply take for granted, whether it is the construction worker who mobilizes his neighborhood ties to get on a high-paying work crew, or the upper-middle class manager who draws on his grammar school and Ivy League contacts to land the vice presidency of some budding company.
Once in, however, too many minority workers and women felt entitled to automatic promotion and were too quick to use the accusation of racism or sexism when it was denied. Too many supervisors practice a patronizing racism or sexism. The cynical promotion of unqualified people, even if it happens only occasionally, damages the legitimacy of affirmative action since it takes only one such mistake to sour an entire organization.
Also damaging were clearly illegal practices like using blacks and women as entrepreneurial fronts to gain access to preferential contracts.
These are all correctable errors. Universities and businesses should return to the principle of integration, to the notion that diversity is not something to be celebrated and promoted in its own right, but an opportunity for mutual understanding and the furtherance of an ecumenical national culture.
The President should remain firm in his principled resolve to defend a corrected version of affirmative action. And if we give it a time limit of 10 years, it might still be possible to save this troubled but effective and badly needed policy.

NBC to Pay $1.27 Billion To Broadcast Olympics
NBC short-circuited the traditional bidding process for the Olympics by agreeing to pay $1.27 billion for the television rights to the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney, Australia, and the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City.
NBC executed a triple gambit: It shut out the Fox Network, owned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, from acquiring the Summer Olympics in Mr. Murdoch's native land; prevented Walt Disney from making a quick splash in sports TV, and ended CBS's run with the Winter Olympics. [Page A1.]
 
Bankers Say Public Offering Is Possible for Donaldson
Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities is considering an initial public offering, investment bankers said. It could raise as much as $400 million. [D2.]
 
Archer Dismisses Informer for U.S.
Archer-Daniels-Midland dismissed Mark E. Whitacre, the senior executive who was an undercover informer in a Government investigation of possible price collusion, accusing him of stealing $2.5 million. [D6.]
 
Consumer Credit Up in June
The Fed said consumer credit grew by $9.6 billion in June, the 25th straight month it has risen, but the rate of increase slowed. [D15.]
 
Insurers Seek Credit Line
Bankers in New York are near completion of two credit agreements totaling $2.5 billion that would help insurers pay claims after a big storm. The credit would not be enough to cover possible losses from the worst storms. [D7.]
 
I.B.M.-Toshiba Venture Expected
I.B.M. and Toshiba are expected to announce plans today to invest more than $1 billion in a semiconductor plant in Virginia, people familiar with the announcement said. [D6.]
 
First Bank to Buy Firstier
First Bank System, based in Minneapolis, said it had agreed to buy Firstier Financial, based in Omaha, for about $700 million in stock, or about $38 a share -- less than yesterday's opening price. Firstier closed at $37 a share, down $2. First Bank is offering 0.8829 of a share for each Firstier share. [D8.]
 
Broadway Stores' Shares Fall
Shares in the Broadway Stores lost nearly half their value, falling $1.375, to $1.625, amid speculation that the Los Angeles-based department store company might have to sell assets or seek bankruptcy protection. [D18.]
 
Truce in Battle for Mesa
David Batchelder declared an truce in his battle to take control of Mesa Inc., proposing a new set of directors but backing away from his plan to unseat the current ones. [D5.]
 
Oil Demand Estimates Rise
The International Energy Agency raised its projections for global oil demand by 100,000 barrels for both this year and next. [D5.]
 
Cellular Spinoff Unlikely
Analysts and investment bankers are delighted at the possibility that Nynex and Bell Atlantic may spin off their merged cellular-phone operations. But the companies are more likely to sell a piece of the venture. Market Place. [D8.]
 
Bantam Names New Division
Bantam Doubleday Dell said its newest publishing division would be called Broadway Books and that it had acquired the rights to more than a dozen books, including two by Bernice King, the youngest daughter of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. [D7.]
 
Discord at Fund for Russia
The merger of two investment funds that pump American money into Russian ventures has spurred intense public discontent from the fund chief passed over for chairman. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Growth Rate Slows for Consumer Credit

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Consumer credit grew for the 25th straight month in June, the Federal Reserve reported today, but the rate of increase was the slowest in four months.
Borrowing grew by $9.6 billion in June, compared with $13 billion the previous month and $11.5 billion in April. The latest increase was the smallest since a $4.7 billion rise in February. 
 "It looks like growth in consumer debt is starting to tail off a little bit," said Roseanne Cahn, chief economist at the CS First Boston Corporation in New York. "Consumer debt is not at worrisome levels. The statistics show credit-card spending as increasing in market share, but it's partly because it's being used as a substitute for cash."
Analysts said June's slower rate of increase in borrowing might also reflect the fact that there had been unusually large borrowing in April and May to help pay tax bills.
Consumer spending, meanwhile, has risen at a slower pace this year, though lately it has shown some signs of picking up moderately.
The Government previously reported that spending rose at a 2.5 percent annual rate in the second quarter, compared with a 1.6 percent rate in the first three months of the year.
The growth in consumer spending had slowed as the Federal Reserve raised interest rates seven times over a one-year period ending in February. The Fed reversed course in July and lowered short-term rates to stimulate the faltering economy.
The Fed said today that consumer credit rose in June at an annual rate of 12 percent, compared with 16.6 percent in May and 14.8 percent in April. Credit-card purchases and car buying accounted for nearly all the increase in debt.
Auto loans rose $3 billion in June, compared with $3.9 billion the previous month. That amounts to an annual growth rate of 10.9 percent in June and 14.4 percent in May.
Credit-card debt grew at an annual rate of 19.7 percent, or $6 billion, down from a 24.9 percent rate, or $7.5 billion, in May.
The category that includes loans for mobile homes, education, boats, trailers and vacations rose in June by only $604 million, or at an annual rate of 2.8 percent. That compares with a $1.7 billion increase in May, or a 7.9 percent rate.
Over all, outstanding consumer credit, which includes all household debt not secured by real estate, rose to $967.9 billion from $958.3 billion.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: THE IMPLICATIONS;
Balkan Opening: To Peace or More War?

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Now that Croatia's lightning offensive has redrawn the map of the Balkans, the question is whether this is an unexpected opportunity for peace or the prelude to another round of war.
The cautious optimists, including some European and American officials, hope that Croatia's emergence as a muscular regional power, combined with NATO's recent ultimatum against the rebel Serbs in neighboring Bosnia, offers the best chance in recent years for a negotiated settlement. 
 But other officials warned that Croatia's triumph might just as easily have the opposite effect in the volatile Balkans. The Serbs' disarray could harden the attitudes of the Bosnian Government, emboldening its leaders to turn down a peace agreement they might have accepted just a few weeks ago.
The rout of the Serbian rebels in Croatia adds tens of thousands of soldiers to a Bosnian Serb army whose main weakness was its lack of manpower. And an overconfident Croatia might be tempted to attack Serbian-held territory in the eastern part of its country, a move that would almost certainly bring the Yugoslav Army into the fray.
In an interview tonight with National Public Radio, President Clinton reflected the ambivalence of his advisers and American intelligence analysts. He said the addition of more troops to the Bosnian Serb forces could have a "destabilizing effect," but he added, "No one knows for sure."
"I'm hopeful," Mr. Clinton continued, "that this will turn out to be something that will give us an avenue to a quicker diplomatic resolution, and not a road to a longer war."
The new balance of power means new calculations for all sides. In Sarajevo, the Bosnian Government has to weigh whether to agree to something like the pending Western map for Bosnia, which gives the Serbs control over 51 percent of the country. That is significantly less than the 70 percent they now control, but more than some hard-liners in the Government will accept.
"The greatest single concern of American policy makers," a senior Administration official said, "is that the Bosnian Government will overshoot the mark, and try for more than they can bite off, provoking a Serb counterattack."
Perhaps the most significant calculations are those being made in Belgrade by Slobodan Milosevic, the President of Serbia and a canny opportunist.
For the last four years, Mr. Milosevic has resolutely pursued the dream of uniting all Serbs in one state, a Greater Serbia that would emerge from the breakup of Yugoslavia. He backed Serbian rebels when they carved out the Serbian Republic of Krajina from Croatia in 1991. Six months later, he provided the supplies, ammunition and essential support that allowed the Bosnian Serbs to seize 70 percent of the newly independent nation of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
But Western nations made Serbia pay a price for those victories: crippling economic sanctions. About a year ago, Mr. Milosevic began asking for the sanctions to be lifted, and offered himself as peace broker in Bosnia. He promised Western nations to deliver the Bosnian Serbs' support for a peace plan worked out by the five-nation "contact group."
That has not happened yet. Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb political leader, defied Mr. Milosevic, saying he would not relinquish at the bargaining table what his troops had won on the battlefield.
Croatia's lightning victory may break that impasse. Mr. Karadzic tried over the weekend to demote Gen. Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb military commander. Field officers have rallied to support General Mladic, and American officials said Mr. Karadzic might be ousted.
Paradoxically, a military coup might bring peace closer. American officials believe that Mr. Milosevic has more influence over General Mladic. Until the struggle is resolved, there will be no serious diplomacy. "We don't know to whom we should be talking," an American official said.
Even if there is a settlement of the Bosnia conflict, American and European officials see a long-term danger that a resurgent Croatia and the Serbs will eventually carve up Bosnia between them.
President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia and Mr. Milosevic held a series of secret meetings in late 1990 and early 1991 in which the two discussed dividing Bosnia between them, with only a tiny enclave in the middle left to the Muslims.
Those talks broke down, and rebel Serbs backed by the Yugoslav Army seized one-third of Croatia.
There are signs that Mr. Tudjman has not given up on his idea. The Times of London today published a map of Bosnia 10 years from now that Mr. Tudjman hand-sketched for the leader of Britain's Liberal Democratic Party, Paddy Ashdown, at a banquet in London three months ago.
With a big S, the Croatian leader split Bosnia top to bottom, with Croatia getting everything to the western side of the S, including Sarajevo, and Serbia everything to the east.
There is an important constraint on Mr. Tudjman, whose journey from Communist general to nationalist leader bears some resemblance to Mr. Milosevic's: He wants his country to be seen as a responsible member of the world community. In Mr. Tudjman's vision for Croatia, his nation eventually joins the European Union, and enjoys all the privileges that other Central Europeans nations have at international institutions like the World Bank.
American and German officials have made it clear he can have all that and more -- as long as he does not attempt a land grab in Bosnia or allow his military forces to perpetrate the atrocities that have characterized the fighting in the Balkans for the last four years.
Several American and European officials acknowledged the peril to the Bosnian Government of an ascendant Croatia.
"The stronger the Croats, the more dangerous it is for the Bosnians," an American official said.
The official added that Bonn and Washington could restrain Mr. Tudjman's impulses to slice more territory out of Bosnia, saying, "Tudjman's desire to be a responsible member of the world community is our only card, and so far it's been working."

HEADLINE: France Takes Lead in Worldwide Arms Sales

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
France surpassed the United States as the leading arms dealer to third-world countries last year, probably signaling the end of American dominance in the $25 billion-a-year weapons market to developing nations, a Government study reported today.
Sales from the United States to what the study defined as developing countries fell to their lowest levels in eight years, to $6.1 billion last year from $15.4 billion in 1993, while sales from France jumped to $11.4 billion from $3.8 billion, the Congressional Research Service said. 
 France had a banner year selling jets, ships and submarines to Pakistan and Middle Eastern countries, while the United States had only one large deal, the sale of up to 25 F-15's to Israel.
The American share of sales to third-world countries fell to 24 percent last year from 61 percent in 1993, while France's share increased to 45 percent from 15 percent. More than 70 percent of the arms sold worldwide go to the third world, mainly to the Middle East and Asia.
Arms control advocates expressed surprise at the figures but cautioned that they might show only a brief hiatus in larger American weapons sales. "The French are catching the U.S. in a year where some of its major purchasers are just catching their breath," said Caleb Rossiter, director of The Project on Demilitarization and Democracy, an arms control group in Washington.
United States military contractors also cited the boom-bust trend of big deals in the international arms bazaar, but also seized on the figures as evidence the Clinton Administration should increase assistance to American companies competing with government-subsidized European competitors.
"We're not asking for a lot," said Joel L. Johnson, international vice president for the Aerospace Industries Association, who noted that American industry has been seeking an export credit mechanism.
Overall, arms sales to third-world countries dropped slightly to $25.4 billion last year from $25.5 billion in 1993, continuing a steady decline since the end of the cold war in 1990.
Richard F. Grimmett, a senior analyst who prepares the report each year, said that since 1990 and the stunning success of American high technology in the Persian Gulf war, the United States had established itself as the world's preeminent arms merchant. France, Britain and Russia formed a second tier of arms dealers to the third world.
But Mr. Grimmett said that pecking order was up for grabs.
"As competition over a shrinking international arms market intensifies, it is likely that suppliers in these two tiers will regularly shift in their rankings relative to one another," the report concluded.
The Clinton Administration announced a new policy in February that approved the continued sale of arms to its important allies and friendly nations. This policy, which made explicit an approach that had governed arms transfers since the Reagan Administration, followed an 18-month debate within the Government about whether the United States, as the world's largest weapons exporter, should promote a global policy of export restraint.
Mr. Clinton sided with advocates of using arms sales to promote foreign policy goals. But Mr. Clinton also put more weight on domestic economic gains.
"The Clinton policy publicly elevates the significance of domestic economic considerations in the arms transfer decision-making process to a higher degree than has been the case in previous administrations," the congressional report concluded.
But last year, France reached the biggest weapons deals with third-world buyers: Pakistan bought Agosta 90-class submarines, Qatar bought Mirage 2000-5 fighter jets and Saudi Arabia purchased La Fayette-class frigates.
"The lesson is that U.S. market dominance and unwillingness to lead the way in multilateral restrictions on arms sales has cleared the way for France, Britain and other countries to get what they can," said Lora Lumpe, a senior official at the Federation of American Scientists, which advocates restraints on conventional arms deals.
The Middle East remains the largest arms market in the third world. Saudi Arabia, despite its financial problems, led all developing countries in arms purchases in 1994, concluding new deals worth $9.5 billion. China was a distant second with $2.5 billion. Israel ranked third with $2.4 billion.
Arms control advocates said the sales tend to promote nondemocratic governments. "The more these countries spend on military equipment, the less they are investing in their own economies," said Thomas A. Cardamone Jr., who monitors conventional arms sales for the Council for a Livable World Education Fund. "It's not a way to create democratic governments or stronger economies in those countries."
Indeed, the Project on Demilitarization and Democracy in a study also issued today concluded that 85 percent of American arms sales to developing countries in the last four years went to nondemocratic governments, as defined by the State Department.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
For $1.27 Billion, NBC Accomplishes An Olympic Sweep

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
NBC fired a remarkable pre-emptive strike at rival networks yesterday by agreeing to pay $1.27 billion for the television rights to the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney, Australia, and the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City.
With support from General Electric, which owns it, NBC executed a nifty triple play: it shut out Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, which owns the Fox Network, from acquiring the Summer Olympics in the magnate's homeland; prevented the Walt Disney Company, which agreed to acquire Capital Cities/ABC last week, from making a quick splash in sports television, and ended CBS's run as the home of the Winter Olympics at three. 
"It's symbolic in a competitive sense, but it's probably a bigger blow to News Corporation, with its global reach, than to Disney," said Harold Vogel, a media analyst for Cowen & Company. "It's a well-timed and appropriate move."
Olympic rights fees have traditionally been subject to competitive bidding among all the networks. But by striking a deal with such speed, NBC short-circuited the bidding process and, in turn, startled its opponents.
NBC is paying $715 million for the Sydney Games, 56 percent more than the $456 million it paid for next year's Summer Olympics in Atlanta. It is paying $555 million for the Salt Lake City Games, exceeding by 47 percent CBS's winning bid for the 1998 Winter Olympics in Nagano, Japan.
"As part of the arrangement, we'll also be selling NBC to the I.O.C.," joked Robert Wright, president and chief executive of NBC, referring to the International Olympic Committee, which sells worldwide Olympic television rights.
The total sum is extraordinary, even given the rights-fee inflation in sports television, because it pays for just the rights to two weeks of programming per Olympics. By contrast, Fox's $1.58 billion contract for National Football Conference rights covers four seasons. CBS's $1.725 billion, seven-year extension of its rights to the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's basketball tournament is for a monthlong extravaganza.
But an Olympics can dominate prime-time ratings for two weeks, as the Winter Olympics from Lillehammer, Norway, did for CBS last year.
With the Sydney Olympics taking place later than usual, in September, NBC can use the Games to counter its rivals' new-season programming.
Even at such extraordinary financial levels, Dick Ebersol, the president of NBC Sports, said the network would at least break even because of the strength of the sports-advertising market and the ability to sell two Olympics at once.
NBC's $715 million offer for Sydney includes $705 million in cash and $10 million in what is known as an "in-kind" contribution. That may include NBC giving the Sydney Olympic Organizing Committee $10 million for tourism-related television advertising.
According to executives familiar with the situation, the I.O.C., which negotiates all worldwide television rights for local organizing committees, felt confident about accepting NBC's bid after Fox indicated that it would pay $701 million in cash.
Vince Wladika, a Fox spokesman, said: "We don't comment on speculation."
"What Fox would or wouldn't do is moot at this point," said Dick Pound, the chairman of the I.O.C.'s television committee.
NBC's desire to buy two Olympics at once persuaded the I.O.C. to forgo next month's planned four-network bidding process for the Sydney rights. Olympic rights fees have sometimes been the subject of intense competition among the networks, and that has helped drive up the price. This time, NBC's price was already high enough.
"This was too good a deal for us not to say yes to," Mr. Pound said. NBC's offer placed two conditions on the I.O.C.: ABC, CBS and Fox could not be told, and it had to be accepted by Sunday night.
"If it was not accepted, we'd withdraw it and we wouldn't bid on Sydney at the same level," Mr. Ebersol said.
Privately, the emotions of NBC's rivals yesterday ranged from acceptance to disappointment. Publicly, they were nearly mute.
David Kenin, the president of CBS Sports, said: "Congratulations to NBC. This is their deal. We won't have any further comment." ABC's comment echoed CBS's.
Mr. Wladika of Fox added: "The Olympics is a great event. We wish NBC well."
All three rival networks had reason to want one or both Olympics.
Mr. Murdoch was believed to be keen about broadcasting the Summer Olympics of his native land to his adopted home. CBS wanted to broadcast its fourth straight Winter Olympics. ABC wanted to re-enter the Olympic game, from which it has been absent since the 1988 Calgary Winter Olympics.
There is no assurance of profits for a network telecasting the Olympics. NBC and Cablevision Systems split a $100 million loss on the 1992 Summer Games because of their ill-fated pay-per-view Olympics Triplecast. The 1988 Seoul Olympics reported losses at the network level, although the loss was recouped with profits made by the stations NBC owns.
"You assume the robust ad network," Mr. Ebersol said. "But one Olympics is five years away, the other seven years. The markets go up and down. There are cycles."
Until last week, NBC had not anticipated making a dual Olympic bid. NBC even discussed making a joint bid for the Sydney rights with ABC before Disney acquired the network. "It was one of several options," said Mark Mandel, an ABC spokesman.
NBC executives were, in fact, skittish about going overboard on a bid for Sydney, despite greater-than-expected success in marketing next year's Summer Olympics in Atlanta, where advertising sales have exceeded $615 million.
"We had a hard time getting our hands around Sydney as a stand-alone," Mr. Wright said.
But as late as last Wednesday, Mr. Wright and Mr. Ebersol were continuing to discuss a Sydney bid alone.
"The numbers were supportable for a bid, but not quite," Mr. Ebersol said. "Then Mr. Wright said, 'Why don't we go for two?' " The idea gained quick approval from Jack Welch, G.E.'s chairman. Mr. Ebersol flew on the General Electric jet to Goteborg, Sweden, to get a go-ahead from Juan Antonio Samaranch, the I.O.C., chairman, and then back across the Atlantic to Montreal, to make the deal with Mr. Pound.
Rights fees are divided by the I.O.C., the national Olympic committee of the host country and the local organizing committee, with the local committee getting about a 60 percent share.
Executives of the Sydney and Salt Lake City Olympic committees were delighted with NBC's offers. Sydney was projecting 43 percent less than the $715 million; Salt Lake City expected only $400 million, 38 percent less than the $555 million NBC bid.

HEADLINE: Stocks Move Higher in Price, With Dow Climbing 9.86

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market moved higher yesterday as traders bought shares of companies expected to show higher-than-average earnings increases in the months ahead.
Cyclical issues that are sensitive to moves in the economy led the Dow Jones industrial average higher by 9.86 points, to 4,693.32. General Electric rose 1 1/8, to 58 3/4; Goodyear, 1 1/8, to 43 1/4; Alcoa, 1, to 57 5/8, and International Paper, 1 1/8, to 86 3/8. 
 "The market did not have too much to feed on, although there was more of a positive slant than a negative one," said Peter G. Grennan, senior vice president of Smith Barney. "Even since the Federal Reserve cut interest rates on July 6, the Dow has just stagnated."
Analysts noted that many investors were wary about the Treasury Department's quarterly auction of $42.5 billion in bonds and other securities, which begins today. They said the stock market was waiting to see whether Japanese institutions took advantage of Tokyo's loosened rules on overseas investing and participated heavily in the Treasury auction.
Broader market indicators advanced along with the Dow. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 1.09 points, to 560.03; the Nasdaq composite index rose 4.13 points, to 995.22, and the American Stock Exchange's market value index picked up 0.66 point, to 524.86.
Advances on the New York Stock Exchange topped declines by 1,208 to 971. Trading on the first Monday in August was relatively light, with 277.1 million shares changing hands, compared with 314.7 million shares on Friday.
Some of the well-known technology stocks followed through on their recent advances. Texas Instruments rose 1 7/8, to 146 1/2; Intel, 1 1/2, to 63 1/2; National Semiconductor, 7/8, to 26; Bay Networks, 1 1/2, to 42 7/8, and Cisco Systems, 1 3/8, to 55 5/8.
Multiline insurance companies also gained as institutional investors rotated their interest to this sector. Aetna jumped 1 1/2, to 64 3/8, and Travelers increased 7/8, to 48.
An analyst's downgrading apparently caused a 4 3/4 decline in Lattice Semiconductor to 32 7/8. Digital Equipment, which last week posted disappointing fourth-quarter results and whose personal computer chief resigned soon thereafter, sank 2 3/8, to 41 7/8.
Firstier Financial slumped 2, to 37, after First Bank System said that it will buy Firstier for $37.96, less than its closing price of $39 on Friday. First Bank, meanwhile, gained 3/8, to 43 3/8.
Among other issues, Mid-South Insurance agreed to be acquired by Trigon Blue Cross-Blue Shield and jumped 4 1/8, to 14 1/4. Nike rose 2 1/2, to 96 1/8, following two positive reports from security analysts raising the likelihood that the company will split its stock. Addington Resources, which announced that it will sell its nonenvironmental businesses, climbed 4, to 14 1/4.
And Piedmont Management, which reported sharply higher second-quarter profits, rose 2, to 12.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Up; Japan Buying Is Watched

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved a little higher yesterday, on optimism that a stronger dollar will increase foreign demand this week at the Treasury's auctions.
But many in the market are skeptical that Japanese buying in the quarterly auctions, at which $42.5 billion of United States securities are being sold, will be stronger than ususal, despite last week's announcement by the Japanese Finance Ministry that it was loosening rules to encourage Japanese institutions to invest more overseas. But few expect the demand by Japanese investors will be anywhere near the level they exhibited in the 1980's. 
 "The market is becoming more skeptical that the Japanese are going to rush in and buy," James Blumenthal, an economist with MCM Moneywatch in New York, said. "The market, I think, is overly optimistic. I expect when it comes it will begin with a gradual increase in participation, especially with the dollar being weak."
A stronger dollar would make dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities more attractive, and less likely that they would abandon the financial markets here to limit foreign exchange losses.
Traders said activity was muted yesterday, with no new inflation news expected before Thursday and Friday, when the Producer Price Index and Consumer Price Index numbers are released; few market participants moved to establish substantial new positions before the start of the refunding and ahead of more data. some see a potential for a rally at the end of the week if the inflation data are favorable.
The 30-year bond rose 8/32 , to a price of 1098/32 to yield 6.89 percent, down from 6.91 percent on Friday.
The Treasury's quarterly auction begins today with the sale of $18 billion of new three-year notes. At yesterday's weekly bill sale the Treasury sold $25.2 billion of new three- and six-month securities at average rates of 5.41 percent and 5.40 percent, respectively.
Ahead of today's three-year note auction, dealers were offering the new issue at a price to yield 6.02 percent, while the five-years were offered at a price to yield 6.45 percent, with the 30-year bond at a price to 6.84 percent. All showed improvement of a few basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, in yield from last week.
Typically the major bond dealers drive prices lower to raise investor interest in the auctions. But the firms will not have to push yields much higher to get that demand, said Hugh A. Johnson, chief investment strategist at the First Albany Corporation. "But we could get a real kick from an increase in foreign demand," he said, forecasting that the long bond would stabilize between 6.80 percent and 7 percent.
Michael Englund, chief economist at MMS International in San Francisco, said huge participation by the Japanese private sectors is probably "more story than reality."
He added, "Japanese central bank intervention has been huge this year, and they no doubt would appreciate the Japanese private sector to pick up some of the burden."
Asked if he had any clues about Japanese participation at this week's auction, Peter Hirsch, managing director and head of the government trading desk for Salomon Brothers said, "If one could get the answers, they could get rich."
In the municipal bond market yields were up modestly, as the market prepared to sell about $4.8 billion of new issues this week, a gain of $1.7 billion over last week's total.
Some investors have been reluctant to buy tax-exempt securities recently, for fear tax laws would be changed, and bond funds have seen an outflow of cash.

HEADLINE: Don Patinkin, Israeli Economist and University President, 73

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Don Patinkin, an eminent American-born Israeli economist who served as president of Hebrew University, died yesterday in Jerusalem. He was 73.
The cause of death was lymphoma, some friends in the United States said. 
 Mr. Patinkin is best known for his book, "Money, Interest and Prices," published in 1956. "Patinkin wrote the definitive work on money -- the book Keynes never wrote," said Paul A. Samuelson, the Nobel-prize winning economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
But his most enduring achievement may well be the establishment of serious tradition of economics scholarship and respect for free markets in socialist-minded Israel, his adopted home.
Mr. Patinkin was born in Chicago, the son of an emigrant from Russia. He graduated from the University of Chicago in 1943, the same year he completed a decade of study of the Talmud at the Chicago Yeshiva.
But Mr. Patinkin chose economics rather than religion as a profession, finishing a Ph. D. at the University of Chicago in 1947 and staying on as a faculty member. A deep commitment to Zionism led him to immigrate to Israel in 1949.
When he assumed the post of lecturer at Hebrew University, there was no modern economics department at the university and little attention to the discipline anywhere in the new nation. "He was the Abraham of Israeli economics," Mr. Samuelson said, the teacher of virtually all the economists who have in turn made Israel a center of the profession.
Mr. Patinkin's most important research was an extension of his doctoral thesis. At the time, there was still a great division between an older school built on the premise that the quantity of money in circulation simply affected the average level of prices, and post-Depression scholars struggling to find the links between money, production and employment.
Mr. Patinkin parsed the issues in ways that even admirers describe as Talmudic. Thus while he accepted the new analytic framework created by John Maynard Keynes, he rejected the key Keynesian idea that unemployment would not eventually fall along with wages and prices in a depression.
Later in his career, he became a scholar of the history of economic thought. His most distinguished contribution was a painstaking review of the intellectual revolution after World War I that shattered classical economics. Paradoxically in light of his critique of Keynes's research, he debunked the notion that Keynes's contemporaries rather than Keynes himself deserved much of the credit for the sea change in economic theory.
Mr. Patinkin's highest academic position, the presidency of Hebrew University from 1983 to 1986, brought him no joy. He resigned abruptly, taking responsibility for the deterioration in the university's finances that had been hidden by Israel's bout of high inflation.
Mr. Patinkin is survived by his wife Devora, a research biologist at Hebrew University, and his son, Aran, and his daughters, Na'ama, Ilana and T'mira, all of whom live in Israel.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Don Patinkin. (Camera Press, 1985)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Mark Declines and Dollar Rises On Hopes for German Rate Cut

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar surged to a three-week high against the German mark yesterday as hopes again grew that the Bundesbank would reduce interest rates in Germany this week.
With a series of United States Treasury auctions also scheduled this week, the dollar was little changed against the Japanese yen. The Treasury's quarterly auctions will provide a chance to judge whether Japanese corporate investors will buy more United States bonds, bolstering the demand for dollars. The Treasury plans to sell $42.5 billion in securities, starting today. 
 In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.4070 marks from 1.3972 marks on Friday. It slipped to 91.30 yen from 91.43 yen.
Many currency traders expect the German central bank to trim the key money market rate, the 14-day securities repurchase rate, tomorrow. That could foreshadow a cut in the discount rate as early as Thursday, when the bank's policy-making council returns from its summer recess.
Lower German rates often help the dollar by making German deposits less attractive.
Expectations of another German rate cut grew on Friday when the vice president of the Bundesbank, Johann Wilhelm Gaddum, expressed surprise that money market rates had not already fallen. Many analysts took his remarks as a sign the bank wanted to steer the repurchase rate lower.
"I think a small repo rate cut, of three to five basis points, should be expected, with no change in the discount rate," said Marc Chandler, senior analyst at the Deutsche Bank Securities Corporation in New York. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The Bundesbank last trimmed the repurchase rate -- to 4.50 percent from 4.51 percent -- on June 7. It last reduced the discount rate, which acts as the floor for German money market rates, to a six-year low of 4 percent on March 30.
Speculation that German rates might fall also drove the mark down against other European currencies. It declined to five-month lows against the Italian lira and the Swedish krona, to a seven-month low against the Spanish peseta, and a seven-week low against the British pound.
Not everyone expects a repurchase rate cut. "The Bundesbank takes pleasure in a firmish currency," said Sean Bovenizer, senior vice president at Norddeutsche Landesbank in New York. "I don't think it's a given there will be a repo rate cut."

HEADLINE: Bankruptcy Fears Take Big Toll On Broadway Stores' Shares

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Shares in Broadway Stores Inc. lost nearly half their value today amid speculation that the department store company might have to sell assets or seek protection under the bankruptcy laws.
Several credit companies have refused to guarantee payment to companies that supply Broadway Stores, and several suppliers, including Jones Apparel Group Inc., Guess and Esprit de Corp., have stopped shipping merchandise to the company. 
 Broadway Stores, formerly Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., operates 82 stores under the Weinstocks, Emporium and Broadway names.
 "There is a lot of competition here and they don't have a niche," said Sanford Paganucci, an analyst with Collins & Company. "Management is floundering."
 Broadway Stores' shares fell $1.375 today, or 46 percent, to $1.625 on the New York Stock Exchange. On Friday, the stock declined 14 percent. The company's shares traded as high as $12.125 on Nov. 21.
 The Standard & Poor's Corporation placed the company's $144 million in debt on Creditwatch today with negative implications.
Broadway Stores said on Friday that it was exploring alternatives for financing its business. The company has been in talks to sell its Emporium and Weinstocks stores in Northern California to the May Department Stores Company.
 Broadway Stores' president, David Dworkin, said in Friday's statement that he knew of no defaults by the company on loan agreements.
 The company did not return phone calls today.
 In February 1991, the company, then known as Carter Hawley Hale, obtained court protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws.It emerged in October 1992 as Broadway Stores after a restructuring by the real estate magnate Sam Zell's Zell/Chilmark Fund, with Mr. Zell holding 54 percent.
 Broadway Stores recorded a profit for 1992, but the slumping California economy, stiff competition and a lack of identity with shoppers caused it to post losses for the two most recent fiscal years.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
An American Tempest at Fund Created for Russia

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Two years ago, President Clinton and Congress joined hands to create two investment funds that were to be the primary tools for pumping American money into Russia's ravaged economy and teaching the American way of doing business.
But the lessons the two funds have been offering lately are surely not ones the Americans intended: about board room fights, wounded egos, invective and angry resignations. And some people say the ultimate lesson may be that the formula for success on Wall Street does not always work in public and nonprofit operations. 
 The trouble erupted after the two funds were merged in May, and A. Robert Towbin, the 59-year-old investment banker who was chief executive of the fund for small businesses, was not named chief executive of the merged fund.
Mr. Towbin, who became a Wall Street star in the 1970's and 80's doing initial public offerings for Intel and Compaq, was so angry at being passed over in favor of a 35-year-old former investment banker that he quit his job as vice chairman of the merged fund and began a campaign of invective against the man responsible for passing him over: former Secretary of the Treasury W. Michael Blumenthal, the chairman of the merged fund.
Mr. Blumenthal passed over Mr. Towbin largely because members of Mr. Towbin's board, Federal officials and some lawmakers, who provide the money for the fund, were frustrated that Mr. Towbin's Russian-American Enterprise Fund was investing in Russia by the thimbleful when they thought a flood of investment was urgently needed.
Mr. Towbin responded that he was the victim of impossibly high expectations and that his critics failed to appreciate how hard it is to do business in Russia.
He was especially galled that the job he sought was given to Austin Beutner, who had worked with Mr. Blumenthal on the other fund.
In January 1994, Mr. Towbin had taken the job as chief executive of the small-business fund because, he said, the time was right to give something back to society. After more than a quarter-century in investment banking, he had his 94-foot-yacht, his country house in Provence and his million-dollar-a-year job.
He spent much of the year running around Russia, and with each passing week, grew more convinced that he was doing the right thing, providing desperately needed seed money and his own investment-banking expertise so that entrepreneurs could take root in the land of Lenin.
His fund, which had $340 million to invest, had a varied portfolio: $8 million went to a supermarket chain in the Russian Far East, $700,000 to a jeans maker in Nizhny Novgorod and $5.6 million to a plywood manufacturer.
Seventeen months after Mr. Towbin took the helm, the Clinton Administration decided to merge Mr. Towbin's small-business fund with the $100 million Government-sponsored Fund for Large Enterprises -- a merger that had Mr. Towbin's blessing because it was expected to cut overhead by more than $2 million a year.
Little did he suspect that Mr. Blumenthal, the chairman of the fund for large businesses and later of the merged fund, would not pick him as chief executive of the consolidated fund. Instead Mr. Blumenthal chose Mr. Beutner, a former investment banker with the Blackstone Group.
Mr. Blumenthal's effort to soothe Mr. Towbin by offering him the vice chairman's job only stoked his anger. "They threw me a bone," said Mr. Towbin, a proud man accustomed to getting his way. "I'm angry because it was done in such a Machiavellian way. I don't understand why this happened because I didn't do anything wrong. I told him I'm going to fight this."
First, he urged Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott, who oversees Russia policy, and the Agency for International Development to overrule Mr. Blumenthal, but they refused. Then he started his letter-writing campaign, which included a letter to President Clinton.
Mr. Blumenthal, who has made plenty of personnel decisions as Treasury Secretary and as chairman of the Bendix Corporation and of Unisys, appears stunned by Mr. Towbin's outrage. He said he sees it as a case of sour grapes.
"I'm obviously a little surprised he feels so sad," Mr. Blumenthal said. "I'm not surprised that he thinks he would have been the better man."
Mr. Towbin, he continued, "is a good man and did a fine job."
"At the same time Mr. Beutner did an equally good job," he said. "All things considered, I decided Mr. Beutner was the right choice."
Mr. Blumenthal said that he had canvassed the fund's board and officials in Washington and they indicated support for choosing Mr. Beutner over Mr. Towbin. "It was not a decision that I imposed," he said. "The new board of the merged fund unanimously concurred." The Russian members of the board agreed because they thought the move would speed up the flow of money.
Some board members of the Russian-American Enterprise Fund were less charitable about Mr. Towbin's performance, unhappy that in his nearly 18 months at the helm, he had invested only $30 million in Russia of the $340 million promised in a period of just over three years.
"Bob worked his backside off, but things weren't going fast enough," said Sharon Tennison, a board member who is president of the Center for Citizen Initiatives, a San Francisco-based group promoting business in the former Soviet bloc. "He wanted to operate the fund like a Wall Street fund, but Russia isn't Wall Street. You have to be willing to take larger risks."
About one-fourth of the enterprise fund's 24-member board regularly complained about Mr. Towbin, faulting him for micromanaging, for not having enough offices outside Moscow, for doing too little for very small businesses, and for building a staff of 54 employees when so little money was flowing to Russia.
Mr. Towbin is an affable, square-jawed man with shaggy white hair, who takes an almost parental pride in describing investments like the $280,000 he put into a 40-employee skirt manufacturer in Podolsk, south of Moscow, where the fund taught computer skills and Western accounting methods.
"I could have always gotten money out the door faster, but I was worried I would look like a fool a year from now," he said. "I was worried people would say that I dumped all this money down the drain and the people you invested in ran away with 100 Mercedes-Benzes. There would have been hell to pay in Washington."
His most important defender is E. Gerald Corrigan, former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, who served as chairman of the Russian-American Enterprise Fund until he resigned in April.
"I at times shared the frustration of wanting things to go faster," Mr. Corrigan said. "but realistically what Bob and the whole staff did in a short time frame was heroic, extraordinary. Some people might say our due diligence was too conservative. My answer to that is, so be it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A merger of American funds set up to invest in Russia has become embroiled in a dispute after A. Robert Towbin was passed over for chief executive of the fund. "I don't understand why this happened because I didn't do anything wrong," said Mr. Towbin, shown at his country house in Provence. (George Gobet/Agence France-Presse, for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: I.B.M. and Toshiba Expected To Announce a $1 Billion Plant

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Joining a multibillion-dollar international rush to increase production of computer memory chips, I.B.M. and the Toshiba Corporation were expected to announce plans today to invest more than $1 billion in a new plant in northern Virginia, people familiar with the announcement said.
The two companies, which already conduct joint semiconductor research in East Fishkill, N.Y., and have a joint venture that produces flat-panel color screens in Japan, would split the cost of the new plant, which is expected to come on line in 1997, according to those familiar with the deal. The new plant would produce the latest generation of dynamic random-access-memory chips, which are mostly used in personal computers. 
 I.B.M. and Toshiba spokesmen declined to comment on the expected announcement, as did state officials in Virginia. But a press advisory issued by Gov. George F. Allen said yesterday that the Governor would be attending a "historic economic development announcement" today in Manassas, outside Washington. The statement said the announcement would concern a project that could be the "largest single economic development" in the state's history.
I.B.M. has an industrial site in Manassas it had been trying to sell. Now, said those familiar with the plans, I.B.M. and Toshiba would build the new semiconductor plant there.
Because chip-making operations are so expensive to build and the yen is so strong compared with the dollar, many Japanese manufacturers have joined with partners in the United States.
I.B.M. makes memory chips in Burlington, Vt., and in France. Speaking to financial analysts last month, Jerome B. York, I.B.M.'s chief financial officer, said the company was currently selling all the chips it was making. Asked about the company's capital spending plans, Mr. York said I.B.M. "may decide to push capacity up to a point where we might need another foundry."
But he expressed reservations about covering the cost of a new plant, which he estimated to be $1.5 billion.
The demand for memory chips has surged in recent years, driven mostly by rising sales of personal computers. Industry analysts expect the demand to continue growing as memory chips are used in an increasing number of products, from telephones to toys.
"We don't see supply catching up to demand until about 1997," said Mario A. Morales, an analyst at Dataquest, a market research firm in San Jose, Calif.

HEADLINE: Florida Insurers Still Face A Gap in Disaster Coverage

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
As Florida residents sigh with relief over the mildness of Hurricane Erin, insurers are alarmed at the holes that remain in the financial safety net created by the state after Hurricane Andrew in 1992.
Bankers in New York are near completion of two credit agreements totaling $2.5 billion that would help insurers pay claims after a big storm. But those agreements are not enough to cover the losses possible from the most severe storms. 
 "The insurance companies are still on the hook, and they don't like it," said Sean Mooney, chief economist at the Insurance Information Institute. "The insurance system is just not built to handle the once-in-a-100-year event with $50 billion or $100 billion of losses," he said, noting that disasters of that size could put even the largest companies out of business.
Hurricane Andrew in 1992 caused about $16 billion of insurance losses and led to the failure of a half-dozen insurance companies.
Since then, insurers have tried to reduce their business in the riskiest parts of the state, particularly coastal areas. At the same time they have pushed -- unsuccessfully so far -- for Federal legislation to lend insurers money after a giant catastrophe.
To accommodate homeowners who are unwanted as policyholders by private insurers, Florida created the Joint Underwriting Associaton, which is now the state's third-largest home insurer, with 730,000 customers. But with only $200 million of cash, the association wants access to bank loans to pay claims quickly after a big storm. It has negotiated a $1.5 billion line of credit from J. P. Morgan & Company.
The association is paying 45-hundredths of a percentage point, or about $6.8 million a year, to keep the bank line available. In addition, any loan it takes will carry an interest rate of 1.25 to 1.75 percentage points more than the cost of bank deposits in the wholesale market.
Eric Altman, a managing director at J. P. Morgan, said that such a price was "orders of magnitude cheaper than the cost of reinsurance" for a similar amount. Money to repay the loans would come from an assessment on insurers in the first year, followed in subsequent years by assessments on its customers.
A similar $1 billion line of credit for the Florida Windstorm Underwriting Association, which provides hurricane insurance in some risky counties, is being arranged by Chase Manhattan Bank.
Another part of the state's safety net is its Catastrophe Trust Fund, which now collects about $425 million annually from insurers. Earlier this year, the fund received a key ruling from the Internal Revenue Service that it would not have to pay tax on money it earns from investments. Assuming no big claims this year, the fund expects to have nearly $1 billion on hand at the end of 1995.
"Every year that we have no claims we get stronger," said Jack Nicholson, chief operating officer of the catastrophe fund. Insurers pay for the first $3 billion of losses, with the catastrophe fund paying about 80 percent of additional losses. To pay those losses it would use its reserve fund, plus about $4 billion of bonds that it might issue. The bonds would be backed by an emergency 4 percent assessment it could charge on premiums for most kinds of property or liability insurance in the state.
Estimating probabilities of infrequent events is always risky, but Mr. Nicholson said the fund could now cover the $10 billion of residential losses from another storm similar to Andrew judged to be a catastrophe that occurs once every 30 years.
But the fund is still short of covering losses from a catastrophe that might occur once in a 100 years. It is estimated such a storm would cause about $18 billion of residential losses, with another $11 billion of losses on commercial property.
