SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1639 words

HEADLINE: Welfare Rules Created for Cities Cause Trouble in the Countryside

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: FRIENDSHIP, N.Y.

 BODY:
This region of cornfields and shale-encrusted hills near the Pennsylvania border once seeped with wealth in the form of crude oil. Now the very same hills conceal pockets of poverty and welfare dependency.
In this town where oil barons lived in splendor 100 years ago, today an estimated 1 in 6 households is on welfare and 1 in 4 is poor, about the same percentages as in Brooklyn. 
 Yet amid this year's vigorous push in Albany to change the state's welfare rules, there was little discussion of the problems that afflict the rural poor. The debate focused almost entirely on one thing: reducing welfare costs in big cities.
But the way poor people here tell it, in tightening the rules, the Legislature created hurdles that are far higher for country people than for the urban poor. Paradoxically, upstate Republicans whose main goal was to curb what they considered runaway welfare fraud and abuse in New York City were the ones who championed those changes.
In one major revision, able-bodied adults will start losing their welfare benefits this summer if they cannot demonstrate that they have got in touch with five different employers a week, with no repeats in a month.
But in many mountain towns, welfare recipients might not find 20 employers within a 30-square mile area. So meeting the rule could prove impossible, for here, unlike in New York City, one of the biggest challenges for people trying to get off welfare is transportation.
"That's an onerous requirement for some of our folks, because of a lack of job openings and the lack of means to travel," said Joan Sinclair, director of social services for Allegany County.
New rules enacted into law this year will also impose tougher penalties on welfare recipients who miss even one day of their public work programs, known as workfare. One unexcused absence can lead to a 90-day suspension of benefits; four such absences can cause expulsion from welfare.
Welfare workers and recipients said those penalties, too, are likely to fall more heavily on rural people who, because of undependable transportation, are more apt to miss work, or appointments at welfare offices.
"It stinks," said Sharon DeBarge, a welfare recipient. "What are us people in rural areas supposed to do, if you don't have a license, or you don't have a vehicle?"
In Allegany County there are no public buses. Throughout the region, welfare recipients typically can't afford dependable cars, much less insurance. Those who do have good cars have to sell them: state rules say welfare recipients cannot own vehicles worth over $1,500.
"You don't have reliable transportation at that price," said Anne Erickson of the Greater Upstate Law Project, which lobbies for the rural poor in Albany. "In New York City, that's not going to be a problem. How many people in New York City own cars?"
Even welfare recipients who can keep their cars say that can be a mixed blessing. The cost of upkeep, insurance and gasoline for driving long distances can eat away at welfare checks.
Gertrude Riffle, 60, a welfare recipient who lives in a trailer park in Addison with her mentally retarded son, said that maintaining her 11-year old Pontiac Bonneville was one of her major expenses. "It always needs repairs," she said. "So I'm just getting by."
These problems can have devastating effects. Susan Lewis spent years refiling job applications along her town's four-block main street because those employers were the only ones she could reach on foot.
"You get embarrassed because you're letting people know you're still not working, week after week," she said. State social service officials argued that five job applications a week is not an excessive number for rural residents. "We believe there are a lot of jobs out there," said John Fredericks of the State Department of Social Services, in his office in Albany.
State officials have contended that tougher work programs in rural areas have reduced welfare rolls. But it remains unclear whether the people quitting welfare have found jobs or simply vanished from the state's view.
Senator Joseph Holland, chairman of the Senate Social Services Committee and an advocate of tougher welfare rules, said he did not think the new regulations would have a harsher impact on rural residents. But Senator Holland, a Rockland County Republican, acknowledged that the effort to tighten the rules was done with city, not rural, recipients in mind because "people think welfare is better controlled upstate."
He also said there is bipartisan agreement among legislators from outside New York City that more must be done to reduce welfare spending.
"I guess the people in need come to major cities because more services are there, so they have a different philosophy," the Senator said. "We are not separated by parties on this issue. We are separated by upstate and downstate."
In dozens of interviews, welfare recipients in Allegany and Steuben counties said they wanted to work but couldn't find accessible jobs.
Dan Barber lives in Belmont, a village of 1,000 people, one stoplight and a handful of stores. Though Belmont is the seat of Allegany County, Mr. Barber can visit all of its businesses in a day or two. Then he must go elsewhere to fulfill the job-search obligations.
Because he can't afford a car, Mr. Barber, 25, does his job canvassing by foot, sometimes hitching rides. On Fridays, his day off from a county workfare program, he rises at 3 A.M. to travel 30 miles to Olean, a city of 18,000, where he scans want ads for minimum-wage jobs at grocery stores and fast-food restaurants. He is worried that he won't be able to reach five employers a week, as the new welfare rules require.
Inevitably, the subject of transportation arises in job interviews. The typical exchange has become depressingly familiar, said Mr. Barber, who is single and has been on welfare since 1991 when he severely injured his foot in a work accident.
"They ask how I got there, I tell them I walked," he said. "After that, the interview doesn't go any farther."
David DeBarge lives in a three-bedroom trailer home on a wind-swept bluff overlooking Addison, population 2,700, with his wife and three children.
Last March, he found full-time work as a machine operator in a metal stamping plant in Elmira, 40 miles away. His driver's license had been suspended three times since 1991, and he could not afford the $500 needed to reinstate it. So he relied on two co-workers for transportation, an arrangement that worked well for a few months.
Earning $5 an hour and working full time, he managed to pull his family off welfare. "I was scared to death," he said of the decision to exchange a steady public assistance check for the vagaries of private employment. "But you've got to take that leap sooner or later."
But then in June, he lost one ride after arguing with the driver. The next month, a second ride stopped traveling to Addison. With no buses available during his night shift, he stopped going to work. His bosses told him they would hire someone else to fill his job.
Now Mr. DeBarge, a tall, coarse-voiced man of 33 with tattoo-covered arms, is debating whether to reapply for welfare for his family. If he does, they may have to wait three months for their first check. Then he will face the same transportation problems as he tries to meet the rule requiring five job contacts a week. "I'm a recovered alcoholic," he said. "Now I know why people relapse."
In Albany, the welfare debate has pitted urban Democrats against upstate Republicans, who contend that cities are sponges for tax dollars.
Statistics from the Department of Social Services show that New York City, with 40 percent of the state's residents, receives 72 percent of its welfare spending, over $2 billion this year.
But a recent study commissioned by the Republican-led Senate found that in several poverty indicators, the state's rural areas were losing ground to its metropolitan regions. Rural areas have higher unemployment rates, lower per-capita income and a smaller percentage of adults with college educations, according to the report by the New York State Commission on Rural Resources.
Moreover, between 1950 and 1990, most rural areas experienced faster growth in the number of families living in poverty, the report found. It concluded that a continuing decline in manufacturing jobs had left rural areas with low-paying service jobs that rarely provided benefits like health insurance.
Allegany County regularly ranks near the bottom of the state's 62 counties. It has the third lowest per-capita income. The 1990 Census found that it had the fifth highest percentage of families living in poverty: 15 percent of its 55,000 residents, lower than the Bronx, Brooklyn and Manhattan, but significantly higher than Queens and Staten Island. That same year, 10 percent of Allegany County's households received public assistance, just below Manhattan's 11 percent.
In Allegany County, registered Republicans outnumber Democrats by more than 2 to 1. Several welfare recipients who are Republicans said they thought Republican lawmakers had overlooked the possible damage that sharp cutbacks in welfare might cause.
"You'll start seeing things here that you only expect to see in New York City," said Susan Lewis, who spent several years on welfare.
Ms. Lewis, 28, is one of the success stories of the welfare system. In late 1989, her boyfriend was laid off, and she went on welfare.
In 1992, the county placed her in a workfare program, training her in secretarial skills. Her break came late last year, when she was hired from a pool of 30 applicants for a receptionist's job at a home health-care concern. She earns less than $5 an hour and receives no health benefits, but with her boyfriend's income, it is enough.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

International A3-9
 
SERBIAN REFUGEES TRAPPED
Thousands of Serbian refugees were trapped as they fled Croatia, caught in fighting between a conquering Croatian army and fleeing Serbian rebel forces. A1
 
WELCOME LULL IN BIHAC
Since the outbreak of the war in Bosnia three years ago, Bihac has been blockaded by Serbian forces. Now some relief has come. A1

President Clinton is dispatching emissaries to Europe to discuss new ideas for diplomatic initiatives in the Balkans. A7

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS: TV SPORTS;
Hello, Sydney? This Is Going to Be Big, Really Big

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir 

 BODY:
NBC swept its rivals away on Monday by paying $1.27 billion for the television rights to the 2000 Summer Olympics and the 2002 Winter Olympics, while Universal was reported to be paying Sylvester Stallone $60 million for three films.
Coincidence or trend? Trend. Entertainment companies want blockbuster programming, worldwide stars and global amusements to make more piles of money. 
 And here's an interesting coincidence. Last Monday, Fox Network executives flew to Montreal to see Dick Pound, chief of the International Olympic Committee's television committee. They made a $701 million bid for the 2000 Summer Games in Sydney, Australia, homeland of Rupert Murdoch, whose News Corporation owns Fox.
Murdoch's offer was big enough to be pre-emptive. But it would not be.
The next day, Bob Wright, NBC's president, and Dick Ebersol, the president of NBC Sports, began skull sessions about their Sydney bid. By Wednesday, Wright and Ebersol had conceived the idea of packaging a $715 million Sydney offer with a $555 million bid for the 2002 Winter Games in Salt Lake City.
By Friday, in Montreal, NBC had wrapped up its deal with the I.O.C., having imposed a strict deadline and a confidentiality requirement on Pound & Company
That left Fox Sydney-less. Fox may not have practiced safe bidding. It is believed not to have imposed deadlines or confidentiality on the I.O.C.
Could someone have leaked Fox's bid to NBC? "Absolutely, categorically, unbelievably untrue," Ebersol said. "The beauty of making sports bids is in the guesswork and in the risk."
Pound refused to discuss Fox's bid, but said cryptically: "When you're in a position to get two pre-emptive bids, you don't shop them around."
Pound was in a pickle. If the I.O.C. didn't accept NBC's bid by Friday -- limited time, and limited time only! -- the network vowed not to revisit a package deal. If that happened, NBC then might not have offered more than $620 million for Sydney, and the Salt Lake bidding may have been put off until 1997.
Perhaps Pound could have told NBC and Fox that he appreciated their eagerness, but he wanted them to await the auction for Sydney scheduled for next month. Unlikely. That auction was for one Olympics; the I.O.C. would have been foolish to resist NBC's $1.27 billion simply to follow past bidding protocol.
Why say no to NBC, a network the I.O.C. is cozy with after two Summer Olympic telecasts and a third coming next year? The I.O.C. was comfortable enough with NBC to refuse any chance of continuing with CBS, which, after the 1998 Winter Games in Nagano, Japan, will have spent $913 million on three Winter Olympics.
Ebersol has crafted many creative deals (not all succeed, like The Baseball Network), but packaging both Olympics in one may be his best.
He guaranteed big-event sports at NBC through 2002, and provided financial stability for the Sydney and Salt Lake Olympic committees.
The Salt Lake organizers had predicted the rights would yield $400 million. Waiting two years may have yielded more than $555 million. "But it's less important to have a few more dollars than certainty in planning," Ebersol said.
Pound wanted to wait when the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games -- hobbled by slow sponsorship sales and needing money to start construction -- pressed Pound to auction television rights in July 1993, eight months earlier than Pound had planned. Pound wanted all bidders to bask longer in a roaring economy for advertising sales. "If we waited, we could have gotten more," he said.
While people paid to wonder about such things wonder whether NBC can make its risk pay off, Ebersol vows to break even. He has support from a man he feuded with about soaring rights fees: Neal Pilson, the former president of CBS Sports.
"You're talking about numbers that are within the capability of General Electric to absorb," Ebersol said, referring to NBC's parent company. "But it's time to stop evaluating every sports deal on a dollar-by-dollar basis. NBC's presence at places like Atlanta, Barcelona and Wimbledon is used for NBC's and G.E.'s corporate purposes. G.E. is a $50 billion company. Does it matter if they make $10 million or lose $50 million?"
 
A Good Investment
 In 1979, Getty Oil paid Bill Rasmussen, ESPN's founder, $43,000 for an option to buy 85 percent of the cable sports network. Now, ESPN has given birth to ESPN2 and is valued at between $3 billion and $5 billion -- a sizable chunk of the $19 billion the Walt Disney Company is paying to acquire Capital Cities/ABC, which owns 80 percent of ESPN.
Rasmussen was paid by ESPN through 1980, then cashed out, with family members and other investors, for $36 million in 1984 when ABC bought ESPN.
"What ESPN is worth now astounds me," he said. "I'm amazed at the appetite for TV sports. It's staggering. In 1980, sports fanatics knew us, but we were barely in six million homes when I left. I get a lot of reflected enjoyment watching it now. It's like a baby grown up."
Rasmussen now runs a Naples, Fla., company that installs computerized energy, security and lighting controls in residences. "I don't even have to get out of my chair to see who's at my door," he said.
Great. Another Rasmussen company that encourages couch potato behavior.
 "You're talking about numbers that are within the capability of General Electric to absorb. But it's time to stop evaluating every sports deal on a dollar-by-dollar basis. NBC's presence at places like Atlanta, Barcelona and Wimbledon is used for NBC's and G.E.'s corporate purposes. G.E. is a $50 billion company. Does it matter if they make $10 million or lose $50 million?"

HEADLINE: The Condos Are Eating Our History

BYLINE: By Geraldine Brooks; Geraldine Brooks is author of "Nine Parts of Desire: The Hidden World of Islamic Women."

DATELINE: WATERFORD, Va.

 BODY:
The backhoes arrived a few weeks ago on the farm near my home, where Washington's sprawl finally surrenders to a wide hazy view of the Blue Ridge Mountains.
The backhoes and the little piles of earth mean a developer is testing the land to see how many houses it can carry. Next year, the hay bales won't be there, lit up by the afternoon sun. The hedgerow with its tangle of blackberries and bishop's lace will have been bulldozed for site access. And the thread -- the fine, frail thread that binds here and now to there and then -- will have been frayed just a little bit closer to breaking point. 
 It's considered elitist to lament those backhoes, just as it is to oppose a Disney theme park or a Wal-Mart. People need houses, after all. They even need malls. And for sure the struggling cattle farmers here are entitled to a profit on their land after years of eking a bare living from it. But to me it's far more elitist to feel an inalienable right to change a landscape that has a long history, to feel that our needs -- now, this minute -- count for more than the needs of future generations to know America as it was.
The city kids who come to our town's annual fair tell me the amazement in their eyes when they tour my old house. I show them the Civil War belt buckle dug up in the garden and the trap door in the kitchen ceiling, where the children of the house used to be hoisted on their parents' shoulders to sleep in the small, stove-warmed crawl space.
The property-rights movement says I'm entitled to put dry wall over that trap door if I feel like it or even to tear the house down. To me, that's elitism. We have owned this house less than two years; to my mind, that conveys very few rights to a structure that has stood for almost two centuries. Even if we own it for 20 years, I will still see myself as just one in a line of its custodians, carrying this little piece of America's heritage safely into the future.
Waterford, settled by Quakers in 1733, has history written into the stones of buildings much older than mine. There are houses that stood when Virginia was a colony, whose pacifist Quaker inhabitants abhorred the Revolutionary War. When Virginia was a rebel state, some Quakers fought for the Union because the evil of slavery outweighed the evil of battle. The church still has bullet marks in the brick from a skirmish. Confederate and Union dead lie side by side in the village graveyard.
The one-room schoolhouse built just after the Civil War to educate the African-American children still functions as a school. Third and fourth graders who visit the place experience what it was like to be educated in the segregated slate-and-pencil world of the 19th century.
And yet what makes this village most special is its link with the surrounding farmland. One step out of Williamsburg's colonial center and you're hard upon the neon 1990's. But walk the Water Meadow behind Waterford and you can gaze for 360 degrees on a village among farms that looks like America looked way back when. What is preserved here isn't the grand and the exceptional like Monticello or Mount Vernon but the domain of ordinary lives.
If the march of the condos continues -- and with a million acres of American farmland disappearing each year there's no reason to think it won't -- Waterford and its history will become just a collection of quaint houses, hemmed in by sprawl, robbed of history.
Can't America afford to keep even a few places as they were? Surely it makes as much sense to compensate farmers with public funds for not developing their land as to compensate then for not growing too many soybeans. If the worry is taxes, we will pay them anyway when the condos are built, because the extra revenue from a bigger population in rural areas never, ever covers the cost of providing the new services it demands.
Even setting aside our duty to history and to the future, this place is worth keeping on economic grounds alone. There is a growing hunger in us for a taste of the world's older, quieter places. Waterford, too, can be a field of dreams: if you don't build it, they will come.
Already, for one weekend every October our tiny village -- a general store, a post office, a population of 250 -- is host to 30,000 at its annual fair. We give each a ticket that reads: "America's heritage belongs to everyone." If only it were true.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Frenzy for Netscape Sends Stock Skyward
 Netscape Communications, an Internet software company, made one of the most stunning debuts in Wall Street history, jumping $30.25 a share to close at $58.25, more than double its offering price of $28. And even though only 5.75 million shares were available, volume reached almost 14 million, as some shares traded hands more than once. 
 Netscape shares opened at $71 and soon surged as high as $74.75 before falling back. The rush to commercialize the Internet has created an investor frenzy not seen in the high-tech industry since the early days of the personal computer. [Page A1.]
 James L. Barksdale has just received roughly $135 million for seven months as Netscape's chief executive, thanks to stock options. [D5.]
 
Clinton Will Back F.D.A.
 In Declaring Nicotine a Drug President Clinton has decided to let the F.D.A. begin the process of declaring the nicotine in cigarettes an addictive drug, clearing the way for the most significant regulations in tobacco industry history. Administration officials said the White House was still debating what new restrictions should be imposed. [A1.]
 
German Repurchase Rate Lowered
 The Bundesbank accepted a rate as low as 4.45 percent for 14-day securities repurchase agreements, down from 4.5 percent a week ago. Analysts said they did not expect the bank's policy-making council to announce an easing of monetary policy today. [D3.]
 
Host Marriott to Spin Off Unit
 Host Marriott said it would spin off to shareholders its concessions unit, which runs highway and airport restaurants. The company said it expected the stock market to place higher values on the separated businesses. [D2.]
 
Striking Journalists Threatened
 The Detroit Free Press is threatening to start permanently replacing journalists, who have been on strike a month, if they do not return to work today. [D7.]
 
Boston Bank Lending Found Fairer
 A study has found that banks in Boston have greatly improved their records in lending to minorities and residents of low-income neighborhoods, six years after a series of studies portrayed Boston as rife with racial discrimination in lending. [D2.]
 
Hungarian Buses in U.S.
 A company in Hungary is making buses in Budapest, having them completed in Alabama and selling them to several American cities. Behind this success is the First Hungary Fund, a big institutional investment fund. [D3.]
 
Car Sales Drop in Mexico
 Since the peso crisis, many Mexicans have been unable to buy cars. As a result, new car sales in Mexico have fallen by 70 percent in the first half of the year. [D3.]
 
Westinghouse Chief Visits CBS Unit
 Seeking to establish rapport with the CBS News division, Michael H. Jordan, the chairman of Westinghouse, visited the studios of both the CBS Evening News and 60 Minutes for the first time since announcing the pending $5.4 billion purchase of CBS. [D7.]
 
Lexus to Promote Used Cars
 With thousands of used Lexuses coming off their leases, the company will begin running next month a 30-minute infomercial to convince customers that the used cars are a good deal. The company estimates that as many as 60 percent of used Lexuses could be former leased cars within years. Advertising. [D7.]
 
British Telecom in MCI Talks
 MCI said British Telecommunications was considering buying a stake in its new on-line venture with the News Corporation. [D8.]

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 818 words

HEADLINE: Revival of Economic Growth Is Scant So Far, the Fed Reports

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
While the sluggish American economy may be poised for a rebound, the much-anticipated return to higher rates of economic growth in the second half of the year has not yet happened, the Federal Reserve said in a report issued today.
Although the report does not specifically address interest-rate policy, its slightly pessimistic tone about growth, coupled with the playing down of inflation risks, suggests that the central bank will have room to cut rates further later this year. But most economists expect Fed policy makers to leave short-term interest rates unchanged at their next meeting on Aug. 22, waiting for more data to become available in September. 
 The economy "is expanding, but at a slow rate," said Richard B. Berner, chief economist at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "Having eased cautiously once, if the Fed continues to see inflation subsiding, they may ease again -- I wouldn't think in August."
At their last meeting on July 6, Fed officials shaved one-quarter of a percentage point from one of the interest rates they control.
At a breakfast meeting with reporters today, Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin expressed confidence that the economy would be in better shape a year from now, when the Presidential election campaign will be in full swing. "The most likely set of conditions a year from now is probably solid growth, moderate inflation," he said.
Mr. Rubin also predicted that unemployment late next summer would be around 5.6 or 5.8 percent. It was 5.7 percent last month.
The Fed's experts were less enthusiastic, though, about the economy's current health. Today's report, prepared for the Aug. 22 rate-setting meeting, was cautious in tone about economic activity in the 12 regional districts into which the Federal Reserve divides the country.
"Most districts continue to report economic expansion, although in some areas the rate of expansion has moderated recently," the report said. "The upper Midwest, Southeast and West continue to expand. Other areas are experiencing little or no growth."
The national economy grew at a paltry annual rate of one-half of 1 percent during the second quarter, the Commerce Department announced nearly two weeks ago. Most private economists predict slightly faster growth this quarter, followed by a return to a growth rate of around 2.5 percent by the fourth quarter.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, and Alan S. Blinder, the Fed's vice chairman, have attributed the economy's weakness this summer to a move by companies to sell off part of their big inventories of goods before ordering more output from their factories. Today's study suggested that this pattern could be coming to an end, laying the groundwork for stronger growth in the months ahead.
"Orders are up in some districts, and inventories generally are considered to be at acceptable levels," said the report, commonly known as the beige book because of the color of its cover.
The report also repeated the recent theme of senior Fed officials that inflation seems to be slowing but has not been extinguished. "Nearly all districts note that price pressures remain on materials and supplies, with reports of increasing prices generally outnumbering reports of flat or declining prices," the document said. "Over all, though, the rate of increases appears to be moderating."
The Federal Reserve Banks of Boston, Dallas and St. Louis reported slowing growth in their regions, while the Federal Reserve Banks of New York, Richmond, Philadelphia and Minneapolis reported steady or mixed signs of economic strength in their nearby states. The Fed regional banks in Atlanta, Chicago, Cleveland, Kansas City and San Francisco noted strong or strengthening economies.
Some of the states now prospering or recovering, notably California, were among those hardest hit by the recession in the early 1990's. At the same time, the economy in the Midwest appears strong despite an overall loss in manufacturing jobs in July reported by the Labor Department last Friday.
As a result, the regional economies of the United States seem to be converging around a more moderate pace of growth, said David Kelly, a senior economist at Lehman Brothers. "In general, there is no one region of the country going down the tubes at the moment, and that's important," he said. "Right now, it's a slower pace but a tighter pack, and that probably leaves the economy" at less risk of a recession.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said that in its region, announcements of large job gains in June and July were balanced by announced job losses at other companies. Retail sales rose moderately in June in the region, and the midtown Manhattan commercial real estate market improved as vacancy rates edged down.
The regional bank's district consists of the state of New York, 12 counties in northern New Jersey and Fairfield County in Connecticut.

HEADLINE: At K.K.R., the Glory Days Are Past

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. In the late 1980's, the name became synonymous with corporate gtakeovers and all the glory and terror they implied. Representatives of some of America's largest companies jetted into New York to seek an audience at the firm. Some came to seek its help in buying control of companies from their shareholders, and the $30.6 billion buyout of R.J.R. Nabisco in 1989 made Kohlber, Kravis the king of the huge deal. Others came merely to urge the firm to leave their company alone. The firm's name partners became celebrities of sorts, symbols of the pressure on American managers to make their companies more profitable or yield to someone who would.
 How times have changed. 
 Kohlberg, Kravis in now scrambling even to find much smaller and apparently less profitable transactions, and sometimes being passed over then. And annual returns from its investments, which some times ran close to 50 percent in the late 1970's and early 1980's, are now bouncing around the teens - lower than returns at some lesser-known firms and this year, even below the gains of broad stock market gauges like the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
 Kohlberg, Kravis's acquisition of the Brunu's Inc. supermarket chain last spring illustrates the deal maker's more humble existence these days.
 The firm pursued Bruno's, rather than the other way around. Indeed, Bruno's turned to Kohlberg, Kravis only after talks with another firm had fallen through. And rather than granting an audience to Bruno's executives in New York, two Kohlber, Kravis partners - Paul E. Raether and Jamie Greene - flew to the company's headquarters in Birmingham, Ala, to see them.
 The deal they struck was smaller, and will probably be less profitable to Kohlberg, Kravis and its investors, than earlier deals by the firm.
 What happened? To some extent, Kohlberg, Kravis is a victim of its own success. Many companies heeded its warnings and those of others, and overhualed themselves, leaving fewer dinosaurs vulnerable to a takeover.
 "Pay off debt, getting rid of divisions that are not up to snuff - companies can do that for themselves now," said Steven N. Kaplan, a professor of finance at the University of Chicago's graduate school of business. "It's very hard for a leveraged buyout of a large public company to add values as it could 5 or 10 years ago."
And when companies do seek a buyout, it often involves a less attractive deal for Kohlberg, Kravis and its investors.
In a typical Kohlberg, Kravis deal, known as a leveraged buyout, the firm acquires a company from its shareholders mostly with money lent by banks and with high-yield, or junk, bonds. The firm owns most of the company's stock; the company's management owns the rest. As the bonds and bank loans are paid off, and as the company improves its performance by cutting costs and reorganizing its business, the value of the company's stock rises dramatically, paving the way for a very lucrative sale. .
In the 1980's, buyouts generally involved more borrowing than they do today, meaning that there was proportionately less stock. That meant that the value of each share of stock could rise dramatically. By contrast, the higher proportion of stock these days means less profit potential.
Meanwhile, competition has gotten tougher. In the last decade, the number of buyout firms like Kohlberg, Kravis has grown to 214 with $93 billion under management, from 40 with $7 billion under management, according to Venture Economics Information Service, a Boston company that follows the business.
All this competition means that Kohlberg, Kravis must offer companies more attractive terms to do a deal -- in short, lower its fees and cede some of its potential profits.
Executives at Kohlberg, Kravis acknowledged that its returns were not what they used to be, but they said the firm was making the right moves to adjust to a more difficult economic environment. They noted that the leveraged-buyout business was cyclical, with the current bull market in stocks making buyouts both more expensive and often less attractive compared with other investments.
But the executives said that Kohlberg, Kravis was taking the long view. They said that the stock market might have a good year like the current one, but cannot offer the sustained annual returns of more than 40 percent that a good company buyout can. The executives also emphasized the conservative approach of the firm, its vast experience, its ability to adapt, its skill in ferreting out deals and its consistent investment of $400 million a year in equity since 1991 despite the volatility in the markets.
And Kohlberg, Kravis's defenders say the firm is showing sparks of its old inventiveness, shopping in Canada and Europe and delving further into an acquisition strategy called leveraged buildup. This involves setting up a management team in an industry with growth potential, then building a company through acquisitions. For example, the firm hired three former Macmillan Group executives in Feb. 1989 to create K-III Communications Corporation to expand into the media and publishing businesses.
Analysts say the firm is sufficiently confident that it is planning to approach investors in the coming months for a new buyout fund, its seventh since Kohlberg, Kravis was founded in 1976. The firm declined to comment on that report.
Even so, many investors are shying away from Kohlberg, Kravis, citing high fees and high risks given the current returns.
Kohlberg, Kravis officials declined to disclose the firm's returns. But some other buyout firms such as Clayton Dubilier & Rice and Forstmann Little & Company have returns that in some years are well above, and may even be double, those at Kohlberg, Kravis, analysts said.
Kohlberg, Kravis calculates its returns by determining a current value for its investments and then comparing that with the value of the original investment, then subtracting fees and interest costs. In cases where a company in which the firm invested is sold, the increase in value is easy to calculate; the valuation of a company in which the firm still holds a stake involves more guesswork.
Part of the drag on returns was the RJR Nabisco takeover, hailed in 1989 as a bold stroke. It has knocked down Kohlberg, Kravis's overall returns by a full 10 percentage points since its inception, analysts said. Kohlberg, Kravis shed the last of its RJR Nabisco investment last March, swapping its remaining $4 billion stake in the tobacco and food conglomerate for ownership of Borden Inc., the food company.
RJR Nabisco "wasn't a rewarding investment for the original investors," said David J. Adelman, an analyst with Dean Witter, Discover.
Kohlberg, Kravis is also lagging when it comes to the diversity of its staff. It doesn't have a single woman professional, and there is little, if any, ethnic diversity among its managerial staff. In its recent recruitment of a handful of executives, Kohlberg Kravis just was not able to find women who met its requirements, according to one executive at the firm.
None of this is to say that Kohlberg, Kravis is dead on its feet. While not involved in any of this year's megamergers in the entertainment, health care, banking or railroad industries, it has spent more than $2 billion on acquisitions.
Applying assets from a fund it set up in 1993, it bought Canadian General Insurance Group Ltd. in January for about $160 million, and Neway Anchorlok International Inc., a maker of brakes and suspension systems, in February for $105 million. It acquired Bruno's in April and bought Reliance Comm/Tec, a telecommunications equipment supplier, from Rockwell International Inc., in June for $475 million. Last month, it paid $340 million for the Medco Behavioral Care Corporation, a specialty managed care unit of Merck & Company.
"The level of activity has definitely accelerated recently," said Mr. Raether, who joined Kohlberg, Kravis in 1980. The firm now has about $7.8 billion in equity investments in 21 companies, he said. With offices in New York and San Francisco, the firm has recently hired five associates and four analysts, increasing its staff to more than 70.
Insiders at Kohlberg, Kravis, and advisers working with the firm, said two of the founding partners, Henry R. Kravis and George R. Roberts, who are cousins and both 51 years old, remained in charge. (Jerome S. Kohlberg Jr. left the firm in 1987.) These people deny speculation that Mr. Kravis has slowed down, saying he attends important meetings, works hard and keeps informed of the firm's affairs.
The two partners have played an important role in the firm's overseas forays. In Europe last year, Kohlberg, Kravis backed Ian A. Martin, a former deputy chairman of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the big food and beverage company, helping him to set up the Glenisla Group, which is looking at prospects for buyouts and buildups, but has yet to announce a deal.
Jon R. Vanderploeg, who oversees investments for the State of Wisconsin Investment Board, praised the firm's team as exceptional, adding, "They are as good as it gets." Still, the board did not invest in Kohlberg, Kravis's 1993 fund, its most recent.
John B. Fewel Jr., senior equities investment officer for Oregon, which has invested in Kohlberg, Kravis funds since 1984, added: "Our annual returns from inception to date have averaged about 20 percent overall, with realized returns in excess of 40 percent. The returns have been quite attractive."
Other investors, with more funds from which to choose, have put pressure on the firm to reduce its management and investment-banking fees. "The investing institutions have gotten a lot smarter in terms of the due diligence they're doing about fees and charges," said Jesse E. Reyes, a director of Venture Economics, the Boston research firm.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Selling the family silver cheaply just to pay for tonight's dinner.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
NOTICE: Going out of business. Debt-ridden Government seeks buyers for dams, power plants, irrigation canals. No unreasonable offer refused.
Well, it may not be quite that bad. But in their search for gimmicks to balance the budget, both Congress and the White House are contemplating the sale of California's Gargantuan Federal water system for pennies on the dollar. For those who have spent years struggling to balance the interests of farmers, urban water districts and the state's heavily stressed wildlife, it couldn't be a worse idea. 
 "If the rules were fair, we wouldn't oppose it," said Thomas Graff, senior attorney for the Environmental Defense Fund in California. "But this would be a rip-off of the taxpayer and a rape of the environment."
The Central Valley Project, a crazy quilt of reservoirs, dams and canals that bring water from the mountains of Northern California to the arid valleys in the middle of the state, was designed during the New Deal and largely completed in the 1950's. The project transformed California into the nation's premier producer of farm crops. But it is also a textbook example of the temptation to waste inherent in public works dominated by private interests.
The water is a great bargain for those lucky enough to get in on the deal. Under the terms of the Congressionally mandated pact, local irrigation districts control the water, paying only maintenance costs plus interest-free, bite-size installments on the initial investment. "You'd like to buy your house that way," said Robert Reischauer, former director of the Congressional Budget Office.
But it is not just the sweetheart aspects of the financing that offend economists and environmentalists. Indeed, the implicit subsidy is perhaps the least of their objections.
Super-cheap water has led to its profligate use. The most dramatic waste is seen in the spread of low-value crops to the desert -- alfalfa for cattle feed, for example -- while California's coastal cities scrounge for drinking water from drought to drought. Environmentalists are even more concerned about the damage to rivers and estuaries by dams and reservoirs, as well as the concentration of toxic chemicals from irrigation runoff water.
In 1992 Mr. Graff's Environmental Defense Fund helped broker a legislative compromise with more than a little assistance from senior Congressional Democrats.
Farmers, facing the end of their contracts for Federal water, got long-term renewals along with the right to sell limited amounts of their allotments to urban water districts for whatever the market would bear. In return they agreed to pay somewhat higher rates, with the extra cash going into a fund for protecting the regional environment. The deal also included formal set-asides of water for sustaining wildlife habitats during droughts.
But with the fall of the Democratic majority in Congress and the new push to sell off Federal assets to balance the budget, the agribusiness interests that dominate the Central Valley now see an opportunity to renegotiate the terms.
Some 60 water districts -- mostly those serving farmers in the San Joaquin Valley -- have formed the Central Valley Project Authority, which is offering to buy the water system outright. Smith Barney, commissioned by the farmers to estimate its value, came up with the figure of $826 million. This number, the investment bankers calculate, is the lump-sum equivalent of the $2.1 billion in remaining construction costs that water users would otherwise be obliged to pay over the next 35 years.
The farmers' enthusiasm for the bargain basement deal is understandable, since estimates of the replacement cost of the system run as high as $15 billion. "It would capitalize their subsidy for all time," Mr. Reischauer explained.
So is the Environmental Defense Fund's dismay. If Washington loses leverage over the Central Valley Project, wildlife may lose its priority access to water. And the danger is more than theoretical: Mr. Graff points out that Smith Barney is assuming there will be far more water available to sell than others are projecting.
More puzzling, perhaps, is the willingness of both the Clinton Administration and responsible conservatives in Congress to count revenues from the proposed sale against the deficit. In fact, Mr. Reischauer notes, the exchange would be a wash: if the $826 million were used to reduce the national debt, the reduction in future interest liabilities would equal the reduction in future payments from the farmers.
But in the Government's Alice-in-Wonderland accounting system, the only thing that matters is today's cash. Thus the $826 million would allow Washington to support programs that might otherwise end up being cut. The deal would thus be equivalent to selling the family silverware to pay for tonight's dinner.
The environmentalists recognize they can't win this battle alone. Instead they are hoping that divisions among the farmers themselves will derail the deal. Agribusinesses in the northern Sacramento Valley are worried that San Joaquin farmers to the south will hog the spoils. And with Washington in a panic to balance the budget, those opposed to the transfer cannot afford to be picky in choosing allies.

HEADLINE: CLINTON TO SEEK NEW RESTRICTIONS ON YOUNG SMOKERS

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
President Clinton has decided to let the Food and Drug Administration begin the process of declaring the nicotine in tobacco an addictive drug, a step that would clear the way for the most significant Government regulations in the history of the tobacco industry.
Clinton Administration officials said the President's decision stemmed from his judgment that the F.D.A. had successfully made a scientific and legal case for the addictive nature of nicotine. 
 They said the White House was still reviewing precisely what new restrictions the agency should try to impose, but Mr. Clinton is to announce at least some of them on Thursday.
These early proposals, intended to curb teen-age smoking, will include restrictions on vending machine sales and on advertising that reaches children. They specifically avoid any restrictions on adult smoking, Administration officials said.
Still, the F.D.A.'s action would amount to a landmark change in the Government's approach to cigarettes. For the first time, the Government would be asserting jurisdiction over the product itself as opposed to cigarette advertising, whose regulation by the Federal Trade Commission already bars cigarette commercials on television and requires the industry's print ads to carry a warning about the hazards of smoking.
Indeed, the new move would open the door to future regulation that might someday bring an outright ban on cigarettes, although the F.D.A. has insisted that it has no such current intent.
The agency's assertion of jurisdiction over tobacco, and any proposed restrictions that result, will be subject to the usual Federal regulatory process: publication of the proposals, a period of public comment and then final adoption. This process generally takes only a few months, but in the case of tobacco years of legal and legislative wrangling appear likely.
In a glimpse of the battle that will surely ensue, Brennan Dawson, a spokesman for the industry's Tobacco Institute, said the tobacco companies might well go to court and would certainly appeal to Congress.
"The F.D.A. does not have jurisdiction and should not be regulating tobacco products," Ms. Dawson said. "That would lead down the road to prohibition."
Ms. Dawson also said that to avoid regulation, the industry, which has long professed opposition to teen-age smoking, was willing to take steps to help curb it, perhaps by keeping vending machines out of grocery stores and other places where children have access.
Under the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act, the F.D.A. has the power to classify as a drug under its jurisdiction any commercial substance that is marketed with the intent to affect the structure or the function of the human body. The heart of the debate is thus whether nicotine, which has a powerful effect on the body, is being used by the industry as a major element in the marketing of cigarettes.
In any case, the law provides that the agency's assertion of authority can be challenged in court. And Congress may write laws to steer the agency's action if enough votes can be garnered in both houses to overcome a Presidential veto.
Tobacco-state lawmakers have already promised a bitter fight over any effort to regulate the industry. Last week, for instance, Representative Charlie Rose, Democrat of North Carolina, said that if the Government and the industry could not reach a voluntary agreement curbing youths' access to cigarettes, "some Republicans here are licking their chops for that one -- they want to go head to head with the White House."
As Administration officials discussed the new plans today, Mr. Clinton was in Charlotte, N.C., where, in a speech centering on family values, he touched briefly on the dangers of teen-age smoking.
But he did not disclose his support for the F.D.A's new role. That was due in part to the urging of North Carolina politicians, whose constituencies include many tobacco workers and executives and who had implored the President not to make the proposals the focus of his remarks.
In his speech, to the Progressive National Baptist Convention, Mr. Clinton called smoking one of the greatest threats to young people, listing it with violence, teen-age pregnancy and illegal drugs. He said curbing tobacco use among young people would be "the cheapest, easiest, quickest thing you could ever do to change the whole dynamic of health care in America."
The President said that he recognized the importance of tobacco to the economy of North Carolina and other Southern states but that recent increases in smoking among teen-agers were too pronounced and dangerous to ignore.
"Every single day," he said, "3,000 young people become regular smokers, and nearly 1,000 of them will die prematurely as a result."
The President said that "there are some things we can do at the governmental level," but he added: "No matter what you do with the law, people have to change inside. And somebody has to help them change inside. And we have to do it in an organized, disciplined way."
Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, said the President might try to work with Congress to embody new tobacco regulations in law. But he made clear that Mr. Clinton had squarely rejected the voluntary approach, suggested by some members of Congress, in which cigarette makers would undertake an anti-smoking public relations campaign or help states enforce existing laws, now often loosely applied, against sales to minors.
Instead, White House aides suggested, the President would be willing to force Congress to overturn new regulations if it wanted to, on the political ground that defending the tobacco industry is a losing proposition among voters nationally. Mr. Clinton's political support in many Southern states -- like North Carolina, which he lost narrowly in 1992 -- is already shaky for a host of other reasons anyway.
Mr. Clinton mentioned smoking only at the tail end of his 50-minute speech, in which he largely reiterated themes he had sounded in recent weeks about the importance of family values. Back in Washington, Presidential advisers were concerned that this might be interpreted as a softening of his resolve against teen-age smoking, and so Mr. McCurry announced that Mr. Clinton intended to deliver details on Thursday.
White House aides acknowledged that North Carolina officials, whom they would not identify by name, had urged the President not to go into detail today, in part because the local media attention to his visit would have forced them to answer questions on smoking all day.
The first step in the President's action -- permitting the F.D.A. to assert legal jurisdiction over the nicotine in cigarettes -- is a historic one that previous Commissioners of Food and Drugs have considered in previous Administrations but always rejected. Several elements in the political and scientific mix have changed since then, however.
One was President George Bush's appointment of Dr. David A. Kessler as Food and Drug Commissioner. Dr. Kessler is a pediatrician who is an expert on food and drug law.
Even as Dr. Kessler has pushed for regulation, volumes of internal tobacco company papers have been made public, and many more have become available to the Food and Drug Administration, showing that tobacco companies carried out extensive research into nicotine's pleasurable and dependence-producing effects.
Most important, a wave of anti-tobacco sentiment has swept the country in recent years, resulting in enactment of hundreds of local antismoking ordinances.

HEADLINE: Boston Banks Lend More To Minorities, Study Finds

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Six years after a series of studies portrayed Boston as rife with racial discrimination in lending, banks there have greatly improved their records in lending to minorities and residents of low-income neighborhoods, a study released today finds.
The study, by James T. Campen, an associate professor of economics at the University of Massachusetts at Boston, was financed by a grant from the Massachusetts Community and Banking Council, a group of banks and community groups. The Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, which produced critical studies in 1989 and 1992, cautiously endorsed today's report. 
 "We've reviewed the study and found the methodology to be straightforward and the conclusions to be sound," said James E. Mahoney, the vice president and secretary of the regional Federal Reserve bank.
Willie M. Jones Jr., a community activist and member of the council sponsoring the study, said local banks had made great progress in hiring bilingual loan officers and in approving more home mortgage applications in low-income neighborhoods.
"They've done some things that are for real," said Mr. Jones, who is a director of the Roxbury/North Dorchester Neighborhood Revitalization Corporation, a nonprofit housing development group in Boston. "Is that to say they've figured it out? I'd say the jury is out."
One prominent member of the Massachusetts Community and Banking Council is the Fleet Financial Group, a big banking company that is buying another New England banking company, the Shawmut National Corporation. Some community activists have contended that the merger may limit the availability of loans in low-income neighborhoods, and have persuaded the Federal Reserve to extend its usual deadlines for public comment and to hold public hearings in New England later this month before deciding whether to approve the deal. Thomas L. Lavelle, a spokesman for Fleet Financial, welcomed today's study. "It's certainly a trend that we applaud, and are glad to be a part of," he said.
Mr. Campen's study found black applicants received 20.1 percent of the home mortgages approved in Boston in 1993, up from 16.2 percent in 1990. By comparison, 23.8 percent of Boston's residents are black, the study said.
The percentage of black applicants denied mortgages plunged in the same period, to 17.5 percent from 32.7 percent, while the percentage of white applicants denied mortgages fell less sharply, to 11.7 percent from 16.4 percent, Mr. Campen said. National figures also show a narrowing of the gap in mortgage denial rates, but not so dramatically.
For Hispanic home buyers, the improvement has been less pronounced. Their share of approved mortgages edged up to 5.7 percent from 5.1 percent, and remained well below their 10.8 percent proportion of the population, the study found.
Mr. Campen said that the overall improvement in bank lending to minorities and residents of low-income neighborhoods reflected pressure from community activists, lawmakers and regulators. "Banks have responded in a positive way, rather than being defensive," he added. The Boston Fed's studies inspired some of the pressure.
Today's study was less comprehensive than the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston's controversial 1992 study, for which researchers obtained the loan files for more than 3,000 mortgage applicants and evaluated them based on more than 40 criteria. That study found that even after the credit histories and other financial details of applicants were taken into account, black and Hispanic applicants were less likely to be approved.
The Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago produced a study this summer, based on the same data from 1990, concluding that banks did not distinguish between white and minority applicants with good credit histories but that minority applicants with bad credit histories were less likely to be approved than white applicants with similar backgrounds.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexican Peso Fall Leads To Auto-Sales Standstill

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

 BODY:
In the aftermath of the peso crisis, Mexico has turned into an incredible shrinking market for new-car sales, and world auto companies are scrambling to adjust.
Mexicans are not buying cars. The peso's slide cut deeply into their buying power while interest rates on car loans hover around 46 percent. In the first half of this year, new vehicle sales dipped by 70 percent from the corresponding period in 1994. 
 The scene at dealerships across Mexico is the same: Auto lots are full and sales offices are empty. Volkswagen has been the worst hit; its sales crashed by 85 percent. The venerable Volkswagen Beetle is still the most popular model in Mexico, but mainly among the working-class Mexicans who have suffered the most in the slump.
Before the peso collapsed last December, the five major auto makers in Mexico -- Chrysler, Ford, General Motors, Nissan and Volkswagen -- had expected a thriving market there to give a small lift to profits.
Now those companies are looking for ways to minimize losses. They are increasing exports from Mexico where they can, while taking advantage of cheaper labor costs after the peso devaluation and fewer restrictions since the 1994 North American Free Trade Agreement. They are propping up their dealers and cutting costs, hunkering down to wait for a return to growth.
So far this year, auto exports from Mexico are up 25 percent. But this does not represent a dramatic shift. Ford was the only auto maker that managed to increase production in Mexico. Ford had planned before the peso fell to build some of its new Contour and Mercury Mystique models at its plant near Mexico City for the more friendly market in the United States.
Volkswagen's exports also surged. But VW was well placed to step up export production because it already builds in Mexico all the Jetta sedans and Golf compacts it sells in the United States. The company decided in February to take thousands of Jettas and Golfs it had hoped to sell in Mexico and ship them north of the border..
"It was pretty effortless," said Maria Leonhauser, a spokeswoman for Volkswagen of America.
Other companies had less flexibility.
"We were aiming to take advantage of the higher growth in Mexico with more sales there," James D. Donlon, a Chrysler vice president, said. Just this year, Chrysler began to make the stylish Dodge Stratus for the Mexican market. Chrysler had decided to reorganize production to build this model for the American market, but it was tricky and time-consuming to get the right parts, Mr. Donlon said. Chrysler is relying on the brisk American sales of its Mexican-made pickup trucks to shore up its operations there.
General Motors was also focused on building and selling cars in Mexico, according to Robert W. Hendry, vice president for North American operations. Now G.M.'s strategy is to battle for the biggest share of a withered market and hang on until sales come back.
"We are still very bullish on Mexico," Mr. Hendry said. "The growth was set back a few years, but the basics are still there."
In Mexico, auto makers are trying to save their desperate dealers from going under, and some are providing more generous help than anything they have done in the United States. Chrysler, which has lost 20 of its 150 dealers this year, is extending credit to its dealers well below Mexican loan rates "on an individualized basis," Mr. Donlon said.
Ford has lost only one of its 136 dealers by providing them with cars to sell on credit for as long as five months, Ford executives said. The dealers pay the company only after selling a car.
"How do we do it?" said Carlos Hernandez, Ford's spokesman in Mexico. "It's costing us money. But we built up that distributor network over many years and we don't want to lose them."
The big companies are leaning hard on their parts suppliers in Mexico to renegotiate contracts for price cuts that reflect lower labor costs.
"In the new world order, the companies are not bashful about going to the suppliers and saying there's been kind of a windfall here, pal," Mr. Donlon, the Chrysler official, said. Most suppliers are "playing ball," he said, adding that a handful who have resisted "will find themselves over time with other long-term relationships."
Exports of car parts from Mexico to the United States took a jump as well. Small Mexican companies not tied to global manufacturing networks are the beneficiaries, especially those that moved quickly into the surging market for replacement parts.
The American parts maker Delphi Automotive Systems, a unit of General Motors, is one of the largest private employers in Mexico, with 45,000 workers. But J. T. Battenberg, the Delphi president, said he was not rushing to realign production to make more parts for export from Mexico.
"We don't view Mexico as Mexico per se," Mr. Battenberg said. "We have operations in 32 countries around the world. We don't just move in and out of Mexico, because it's such an integrated piece of our global network." A cluster of dashboard wires Delphi strings together in Mexico is tied in the assembly stream to sophisticated instruments it makes in the United States. So it does not work for Delphi to accelerate production in Mexico alone.
"For the short term you ride the bumps," said Gary Corrigan, a spokesman for the Dana Corporation in Toledo, Ohio, which makes auto parts in Mexico with two big Mexican partners. "For the medium term you begin to look at exporting, but only to help American plants that are stretched. The goal is not to have a negative impact on employment in your companies in the States."
Some of the biggest losers in the industry are American workers who were looking forward to thousands of new job opportunities stemming from a rise in American exports to Mexico as a result of the free trade agreement, according to Robert E. Scott, an economist at the University of Maryland. American car imports to Mexico have ground to a virtual halt. Mr. Scott estimates 45,000 jobs that would have been there for American auto workers did not materialize because of the peso's decline.
Analysts expect it will be at least three years before the vehicle market rebounds. This year, in the first quarter alone Nissan reported unspecified losses as a result of the peso devaluation, which industry analysts estimated at $300 million. Dana announced losses of $15 million because of peso loans. But manufacturers have remained optimistic about the free trade accord and Mexico.
"This is just a disruption," said James G. O'Connor, executive director of Ford's export operations. "We are a long-term player in Mexico, and we think the long-term outlook remains strong."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A technician at the Ford Motor factory in Cuautitlan, Mexico, installs electronic equipment in the engine bay of a Mercury Mystique. Since the peso crisis, many Mexicans have been unable to buy cars, so auto makers are trying to increase exports. Only Ford has been able to raise its output in Mexico. (Sergio Dorantes for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ebbs Against the Mark After Half-Step on German Rates

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar drifted lower against the German mark yesterday in languid trading as dealers scaled back expectations for cuts in key German interest rates.
But the currency remained well supported against the Japanese yen after the Treasury's auction of 10-year notes, the second leg of the Government's record $42.5 billion quarterly refunding, attracted better than expected demand from investors. 
In late New York trading, the dollar was at 91.63 yen, up from 91.49 yen on Tuesday. It was at 1.4063 German marks, down slightly from 1.4082.
Although the dollar had a rather muted response to the auction of $13 billion in notes, analysts said the favorable outcome helped remove a negative factor for the currency, after a disappointing three-year note sale on Tuesday. Many said the market was on hold in anticipation of today's auction of $11.5 billion in benchmark 30-year Treasury bonds.
Traders had hoped that the auction would draw foreign investors who would have to exchange their currency for dollars to buy American assets. In particular, the market is looking for participation by Japanese institutions after Tokyo's move last week to change regulations to encourage overseas investment.
"The dollar has a firmer tone, but we are not roaring away here," said Dave Glowacki, senior trader at NBD Bank in Detroit. "We have had one not-so-good auction and one good one. So now, the market is just waiting to see what the final auction is going to show."
Traders said the dollar had also been bolstered against the yen by the aggressive buying of hedge funds.
But few were betting on dollar gains against the mark. The German central bank trimmed its 14-day money market rate yesterday, but analysts said it was likely to delay cuts in the key discount and Lombard rates.
"About 75 percent of people were expecting the Bundesbank to cut rates," said Bruce English, vice president at ABN-Amro Bank, "and that had given the market the incentive to buy dollars and sell marks. But we aren't seeing that anymore, and we've come off a bit." Still, Mr. English said, the market was wary of selling the currency too heavily.
Against some other currencies, the dollar was slightly lower yesterday, at 1.1635 Swiss francs, compared with 1.1670 on Tuesday. The British pound traded at $1.5987, down from $1.6023. The Canadian dollar sold for 73.58 United cents, compared with 73.66 cents on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Panel Denounces Council Over Deal With Pathmark

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
The City Planning Commission yesterday voted to denounce a deal the City Council struck with Pathmark Stores last month to build a large supermarket in Springfield Gardens, Queens, in which the company agreed to donate more than $400,000 to other merchants and to youth groups in the area.
The commission's view was bolstered by a letter from the city's Corporation Counsel, which calls the deal an illegal tax on Pathmark because the $400,000 fund has no connection to the zoning changes Pathmark wants from the city. The Mayor appears prepared to veto the deal if it goes forward. 
 Last month, Councilwoman Juanita E. Watkins, a Democrat, brokered the deal under which Pathmark would donate $400,000, a sum that would be distributed over 20 years to merchants who would be Pathmark's competitors.
These merchants had expressed concern that the huge supermarket would damage their businesses. Ms. Watkins represents that area, and without her approval it seemed unlikely that the Council would have approved the zoning change Pathmark needed to build the store.
Under the arrangement, the money would be used to renovate facades of stores in the community, for example, and make other improvements. Community groups would also be eligible for money to pay for projects like youth programs. A seven-member advisory panel controlled by Ms. Watkins would administer the fund through a community organization, which has yet to be named.
But several Planning Commission members referred to the arrangement as "extortion" -- particularly because the $400,000 would be distributed by a task force controlled by Ms. Watkins and not by a city agency.
Ms. Watkins stood by the deal, saying she hoped the City Council would still vote to approve the arrangement at its meeting next Thursday. Yesterday, the Planning Commission voted almost unanimously, with 10 votes for approval and 1 abstention, to send a letter urging the Council to reject the modifications Ms. Watkins negotiated -- changes that were approved last month by the Council's Land Use Committee.
The Planning Commission's move is merely advisory, but the city's Corporation Counsel, Paul M. Crotty, said the city would sue to stop the deal if the City Council approves it.
"We've made that very clear," Mr. Crotty said. "And based on what the Mayor has said about these kinds of arrangements, the Mayor would veto it."
Last week, when the Mayor gave his final approval for a Pathmark store to be built in East Harlem, he said he opposed any deals requiring businesses to create economic development funds to assist other local businesses.
"That's inappropriate," Mr. Giuliani said. "There's no reason to exact additional taxes from businesses that want to do business in this city. That's a way to discourage business." Without mentioning Ms. Watkins by name, he said arrangements like the one she negotiated "should be part of the past of New York City, not the future, where businesses are expected to make side payments and side deals."
David Parmet, a spokesman for the City Council, said the Council had received the commission's letter and added, "We understand the objections, and we're taking them under consideration."
Ms. Watkins said she did not know how the Council would vote on the proposed deal, an agreement that was all but assured approval before the actions of the Planning Commission and the Corporation Counsel.
"Anything is possible at this point in time," she said. "I have eight days before the vote, and a lot can happen in eight days."
Planning Commission members said they objected to Ms. Watkins's arrangement with Pathmark because it was negotiated as a condition for the Council's approval of Pathmark's request to build the 65,000-square-foot commercial building in an area zoned for industrial uses.
"This was bad policy," said Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the Planning Commission. "It was inappropriate, and it's something that shouldn't be done in the future." He said similar land-use requests involving proposed Caldor and Kmart stores in the city were scheduled to come before the commission and the Council in coming months.
Mr. Rose said that commission members were sympathetic to the Council's concerns that a large Pathmark supermarket could hurt small businesses in the community.
"But there are ways of addressing the Council's concerns without trying to use the routine land-use review process as a way of squeezing funds out of individual stores that are trying to invest in the city," he said. He noted that the Planning Commission had studied the economic impact of a large supermarket in Springfield Gardens and had determined that it would not have any negative impact.
Pathmark officials declined to take any position on the controversy. "We just hope the issue can be resolved between the Council and the Mayor's office," said Stan Sorkin, a spokesman for Pathmark Stores, based in Woodbridge, N.J.
Calling the deal extortion, Alexander Garvin, a member of the Planning Commission, said the increased project costs would eventually be passed on to customers through higher supermarket prices.
He said other undesirable outcomes included "influence peddling" and the possibility that the deal would scare away other potential developers.
"When government demands amenities not related to a specific development," Mr. Garvin said, "the perception will be that no developer can be certain a project can be approved, even when it complies with zoning requirements."
Other commissioners, however, took less strident stands.
Still, Ms. Watkins was clearly shaken by the accusations. She denied having any hidden agenda when she made the agreement with Pathmark. "It is the epitome of arrogance on the part of certain commissioners to have assumed that there was some ill-begotten gain or some self-serving means," she said.
"There is no harm in disagreeing with people," she added. "But I do have distinct distaste and displeasure for people who cannot disagree without being disagreeable, ornery and ugly about it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Councilwoman Juanita E. Watkins brokered a deal in which Pathmark agreed to donate money to other merchants and to youth groups. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Stocks End Day Mixed, With Dow Retreating by 21.83

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed yesterday, as blue chips faltered in response to a weakening in the bond market. But once more, technology issues bounced ahead.
Though the Treasury Department's auction of 10-year notes had better-than-expected results, there was little follow-through and prices slipped. The 30-year Treasury bond dipped 12/32 and its yield rose to 6.91 percent, from 6.88 percent on Tuesday. 
 "It was a kind of blah stock market," said Peter J. Anderson, senior vice president of American Express Financial Advisers. "I suspect we're setting some sort of top."
In such a setting, the attention of many investors was focused on the first day of trading in Netscape, which was issued at twice its original offering price and yesterday zoomed 30 1/4, to 58 1/4. That surge marked one of the market's most stunning initial public offerings in recent years.
"We were all ga-ga over the Netscape deal," Mr. Anderson said. "We're in a speculative phase, particularly in the I.P.O. and O.T.C. markets."
The Dow Jones industrial average closed near its low of the day at 4,671.49, down 21.83 points. The Philip Morris Companies, one of the best-known stocks in this average, dropped 1 3/8, to 73 1/2, amid reports that President Clinton planned to support Food and Drug Administration efforts to declare nicotine a drug and make the sale of cigarettes to minors subject to new regulation.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also finished down, easing 0.68 point, to 559.71. But the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index gained 7.98 points, to 1,005.10.
Technology issues were the market leaders, stimulated by yesterday's Justice Department announcement that it would take no antitrust action against the Microsoft Corporation before the Aug. 24 introduction of its Microsoft Network on-line service. Microsoft shares jumped 3, to 96 1/2, and was followed by shares of such companies as the Intel Corporation, up 1 3/8, to 66 1/8; the Compaq Computer Corporation, up 1 7/8, to 52, and the Oracle Corporation, up 1 1/16 , to 41.
Drug stocks also advanced in a growth-oriented marketplace. Among them, shares of Pfizer Inc. increased 3/4, to 50 1/8; Merck & Company, 7/8, to 51 1/8, and Schering-Plough, 3/8, to 47 1/8.
Cyclical issues, whose earnings typically rise and fall in keeping with interest rates and the economy, wound up lower. Alcoa shares dropped 3/4, to 56 3/4; those of the International Paper Company, 1/2, to 84 3/4, Caterpillar Inc., 1 1/8, to 65, and the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, 1/2, to 42 7/8. The Morgan Stanley index of cyclical stocks declined 2.63 points, to 348.34.
The regional Bell telephone companies were lower because of profit taking after sharp rises earlier resulting from Congressional action on telecommunications deregulation. Shares of U S West Inc. fell 1 1/8, to 43, and those of the BellSouth Corporation fell 1/2, to 66 1/2.
Another sector that weakened yesterday was the retail stocks, with some analysts indicating concern that profits will continue to sink. Shares of the Dayton Hudson Corporation closed at 75 5/8, down 1; Sears, Roebuck & Company closed at 1/4, down 32 1/2, and Home Depot Inc. closed at 42 3/8, down 1 1/8.
Declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange edged above advancing stocks, 1,166 to 1,036. Big Board volume was almost at Tuesday's level, with 303.4 million shares traded, compared with 306.1 million shares the previous day.
