HEADLINE: China's Anti-Graft Drive Grows; So Does Graft

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Aug. 9

 BODY:
On a rainy Sunday morning this week, 10 rusting luxury cars were lined up in a parking lot outside Beijing's Municipal Library and auctioned off. The presiding official, Yang Baojing, called it a shining moment in China's fight against corruption.
The cars, Mr. Yang said, were confiscated from senior officials in a display of the leadership's determination to rein in excesses in the upper ranks of the Communist Party, which long ago lost its reputation for purity. 
 Yet the auction was probably more an ordinary money-making procedure masquerading as government virtue than an indication of any zeal in cracking down on corruption. Nearly all the cars, three of them Mercedes-Benzes, had over 100,000 miles on their odometers, and each had seen better days.
Despite what Mr. Yang said, they appeared to be cars that senior officials -- complying with a new regulation that officials use domestically produced cars -- would be eager to trade in for a new Chinese-made Audi, the current favorite among the leadership.
If the anti-corruption campaign is netting bigger fish this year than ever before, Chinese officials and Western businessmen say, it is more an indication of corruption's growing pervasiveness than of any official determination to alter the situation that allows graft to flourish.
"The network of gift-giving and favors involves the families of almost every senior leader," a mid-level Chinese official said. "So anyone who tries to move against them immediately runs into resistance."
Traditionally, those disciplined for corruption have been people who run afoul of officialdom, while those who preserve connections with ranking officials go unpunished no matter how bad their crime. Since investigators and court officials take instructions from party officials, no prosecution can proceed without approval from the senior authorities, either at a local or central level.
With an economy growing at breakneck speed and officials involved in many stages of business ventures, corruption has accelerated greatly in the anything-goes economic atmosphere in recent years, the official said.
Small examples abound. A Chinese chief representative of an American company in Beijing complained that she ran into corrupt practices every week. Getting a telephone installed, having an operating license approved and even registering her office all involve cash payoffs, the executive said.
"It's everywhere," the executive said. "I hate it. It's getting worse and worse."
Last week the authorities announced that more than 47,000 officials had been disciplined on corruption charges in the first half of this year, an increase of 7.8 percent over the same period last year. Of those punished, official news reports said, more than 1,801 were division chiefs or magistrates or higher, a 44 percent increase.
Large cases are more common, too. In July, investigators publicized the outline of the largest corruption scandal yet in 46 years of Communist Party rule, a case involving central Government as well as provincial officials.
A well-connected woman in Wuxi, 100 miles west of Shanghai, bilked Government officials and private investors of more than $380 million over five years in a pyramid scheme built on imaginary investments, an official account said.
The woman, Deng Bin, 57, was accused of running an operation that bribed officials in dozens of cities to invest in her company, Xinxing Industrial Corporation, sometimes offering profits in advance. The operation even reached into Beijing's Municipal State Security Bureau, where a senior official lured high-ranking customers into the scheme, before it collapsed last summer when the Wuxi authorities arrested Ms. Deng. She now faces the death penalty.
An even more explosive corruption case came to light in April when the Deputy Mayor of Beijing, Wang Baosen, was found dead in a ravine in Huairou, 35 miles north of Beijing, apparently a suicide.
Mr. Wang was later accused of embezzling $37 million, but a second Chinese official said investigators might find even more by the time they finish looking into a series of Beijing construction projects under Mr. Wang's control that apparently involved huge payoffs to staff at the Beijing Municipal Communist Party Committee, headed by a Politburo member, Chen Xitong.
"It's hard to separate corruption from politics in this case," the official said. "No one doubts that Chen Xitong was dirty, but if only he and the people around him are charged, it will look very political."
Mr. Chen has been a rival of the Communist Party chief, Jiang Zemin, since the latter won his post in 1989, and is said to have complained in meetings that he was better suited for China's top position than Mr. Jiang.
Mr. Chen's arrest, announced in early July, aroused speculation that Mr. Jiang would open a far-reaching crackdown on corruption, both to clear out political enemies and to earn respect from ordinary Chinese, who almost uniformly express disgust with the level of graft that has spread throughout Chinese society. Yet no more officials have been charged.
It is not clear why Mr. Wang chose to kill himself in Huairou, where the nongovernmental forum of the United Nations Conference on Women is being held next month. But a popular theory in Beijing is that he chose Huairou because he had arranged several villas for senior Chinese leaders there, and wanted to send a signal that if he was blamed for a huge corruption scandal, his superiors had indirect complicity as well.

HEADLINE: More in U.S. Are in Prisons, Report Says

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

 BODY:
The number of Americans under the control of the criminal justice system reached 5 million last year, including a record 1.5 million inmates in Federal and state prisons and local jails and 3.5 million convicted criminals on probation and parole, the Justice Department said today in the most comprehensive report ever done on the scope of law-enforcement network.
If the current trend continues -- as law-enforcement experts and criminologists interviewed today predicted it would -- the number of Americans behind bars or on probation or parole will soon approach the six million students enrolled full-time in four-year colleges and universities nationwide; within a decade the number of people behind bars will exceed the entire New York City population, currently about 7.3 million. 
 During 1994, the number of inmates in Federal, state and local prisons increased by more than 1,600 a week, and the number of people incarcerated at year's end had tripled since 1980, according to the study, by the Bureau of Justice Statistics, a research arm of the Justice Department.
There are wide divergences among experts on how fast the prison population will grow, with estimates depending both on the crime rate and changes in legislation. This year, for instance, the Republicans' Contract With America calls for providing possibly billions of dollars in Federal financing for state prison construction if states lengthen the required amount of time inmates serve to at least 85 percent of their sentences, a provision that Florida recently met.
Criminologists and politicians today offered conflicting opinions about whether the large increase in the number of Americans behind bars had had any effect on the crime rate. The Federal Bureau of Investigation reported in May that the rate of violent and serious crimes had dropped 3 percent in 1994, the third consecutive year of decline. Some cities, including New York, have reported a significant decrease in homicide.
Representative Bill McCollum, the Florida Republican who is chairman of the House subcommittee on crime, called today's report "encouraging" and said it showed that Congress's efforts to stop crime by lengthening prison sentences and building more prisons were beginning to work.
"If you can get these violent criminals to serve more time, you will inevitably reduce the violent crime rate," Mr. McCollum said. "Anyone who is locked up will not commit a crime."
Alfred Blumstein, a criminologist at Carnegie Mellon University, acknowledged that the increase in imprisonment clearly removed some criminals from the streets and meant that fewer murders would be committed. But he said that since 1985 there had been only a 10 percent reduction in the homicide rate among adults over the age of 24, a disproportionately small gain when measured against the vast increase in the number of prisoners.
"We should think very hard about the trade-off" between the tripling in the prison population and the relatively small decrease in crime, Professor Blumstein said.
Today's report found that there were 95,034 people in Federal prisons at the end of 1994, with 958,704 in state prisons. The total represented an overall increase of 9 percent compared with 1993, which was the second largest yearly increase on record.
Allen J. Beck, an author of the report, said there were another 483,717 people locked up in city and county jails at the end of 1994. Most inmates in local jails at any given time are awaiting trial or have been sentenced to terms of a year or less.
There were widespread variations by region in rates of incarceration, the report found. Southern states had the highest per capita rate of incarceration, 451 per 100,000 residents, while the Northeast had the lowest rate, 285 per 100,000 residents. During 1994, Texas led the nation in the growth of its state prison population with an increase of 28 percent, followed by Georgia with a 20 percent increase.
The report offered conflicting evidence about whether many of those being arrested are simply drug users instead of serious, violent criminals, as some critics of America's crime policy have charged. The study showed that between 1980 and 1993, the number of people imprisoned for violent offenses grew by 221,200 nationwide, while those convicted on drug charges increased by 167,000.
But at the same time the report found that from 1980 to 1993 the percentage of drug offenders in state prisons rose to 26 percent from 8 percent, while the proportion of drug offenders in Federal prisons soared to 60 percent from 25 percent.
John J. DiIulio Jr., professor of politics and public affairs at Princeton University, said that the report had overlooked an important development: that violent criminals are gradually being made to serve a greater proportion of their sentences. In 1988, he said, violent offenders served only 43 percent of their sentences, compared with 51 percent today. "This is good news and will account for tens of millions of serious crimes averted," Professor DiIulio said.
But Jerome G. Miller, the director of the National Center on Institutions and Alternatives, said that today's report was discouraging because it showed that "the percentage of Americans going in and out of jails is phenomenal" and that "as you go down the socio-economic scale the percentage gets much higher." America, Mr. Miller asserted, is relying too heavily on imprisonment as a way to stop crime, and the criminal justice system is turning the majority of impoverished minorities in the inner cities into criminals.
Almost three quarters of the new admissions to prisons are now black or Hispanic, Mr. Miller said, and if present trends continue, he asserted, by 2010, "we will have the absolute majority of all African-American males between age 18 and 40 in prisons and camps."
Today's report, though not addressing the racial breakdown of new admissions to prison, confirms that between 1980 and 1993 the proportion of inmates in state and Federal prisons who were black rose to 50.8 percent from 46.5 percent, while the proportion of prisoners of Hispanic descent almost doubled to 14.3 percent from 7.7 percent.
"The effects of relying so heavily on the criminal justice system have not been looked at," Mr. Miller said, "but it explains a lot of things." When so many poor families have a father, brother, uncle or son who has been arrested at one time or another, Mr. Miller said, "It makes it very hard to organize them against the criminal element."

HEADLINE: Spy Photos Indicate Mass Grave At Serb-Held Town, U.S. Says

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
The United States said today that it had spy photographs that it planned to make public of what appears to be a mass grave outside the Bosnian town of Srebrenica, where thousands of Muslim men and boys have been missing since they were rounded up after Bosnian Serbs seized the area last month.
The photographs, from spy satellites and U-2 planes, coupled with interviews with Muslim refugees who fled after Srebrenica's capture, provide the most compelling circumstantial evidence that Serbian troops executed at least several hundred military-age men and boys as part of an ethnic-cleansing campaign, Administration officials said. 
 "We've got some evidence from sensitive sources that tend to corroborate accounts of atrocities against the Bosnian men and boys who were prevented from leaving Srebrenica," David T. Johnson, a State Department spokesman, said today.
The chief United States delegate to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, plans to present the evidence to the Security Council on Thursday. News organizations have reported refugees' grisly accounts of murders, rapes and other atrocities from Srebrenica. What are new are the reconnaissance photographs and a tip from a witness who knew of the mass graves, Administration officials said.
According to one American official who has seen the photographs, one shows hundreds and perhaps thousands of Muslim men and boys in a field near a soccer stadium about 5 miles north of Srebrenica. Another photo taken several days later shows a large area of freshly dug earth, consistent with the appearance of known mass graves, near the stadium, which is empty.
The International Red Cross has said at least 6,000 people are unaccounted for since the fall of Srebrenica. One senior American official said the graves in the aerial photographs could hold "many hundreds" of bodies. It is unclear how many of the other missing people are in hiding, dead or in refugee camps.
The timing of the Administration's disclosure of the photos, which Mr. Clinton discussed with his national security advisers on Monday, coincided with a new American plan to broker peace in the Balkans. Anthony Lake, the President's national security adviser, arrived in London today to begin talks with European allies.
One senior Administration official acknowledged that the photos "put some pressure on the Serbs and shows people we are watching them."
"People have to know what's going on," the official added. "We don't want people to think we're sitting on evidence."
The Administration said Assistant Secretary of State John Shattuck had gathered evidence of Serb atrocities during a visit to central and northeastern Bosnia last week.
Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, said Mr. Shattuck "was presented with evidence of egregious human rights violations committed by Bosnian Serb forces in the aftermath of their attack on Srebrenica and Zepa."
"The Assistant Secretary heard eyewitness accounts of mass executions, beatings, rape and other flagrant violations of human rights and international humanitarian law," Mr. McCurry said, adding that the evidence would be turned over to the war crimes tribunal in The Hague.
The Central Intelligence Agency's Deputy Director for Intelligence, John Gannon, told a Senate hearing today that American intelligence had found a clear pattern of "ethnic cleansing" by the Bosnian Serbs since 1992.
He said that a C.I.A. analysis showed that more than 3,000 settlements, mainly in Serb-controlled areas of Bosnia, have been burned or destroyed and that up to 90 percent of non-Serbs will have no homes to return to.
As Administration officials in Washington discussed the reconnaissance photos, Mr. Lake and senior Defense and State Department officials prepared for talks with European allies on a new peace proposal for the Balkans.
American officials disclosed new details of the plan, which one top aide described as "a series of sticks and carrots" for the Bosnian Serbs and the Bosnian Muslims.
While Washington still favors a plan that gives the Muslim-controlled Bosnian Government 51 percent of the territory, the new proposal would give the Serbs the last remaining eastern Government enclave, Gorazde, in exchange for more valuable territory around Sarajevo.
To entice the warring parties to settle, the plan would lift economic sanctions against the Bosnian Serbs and promise a "mini-Marshall plan" of post-war economic aid to the Bosnian Muslims, an American official said. The United States and other Western nations would also help the Government build a military strong enough to defend its new borders.
If the deal falls through and the allies blame the Serbs, the plan calls for lifting the arms embargo against the Bosnian Government and launching air strikes against Serbian targets. If the Muslims are blamed for any failure, the United Nations peacekeeping forces would withdraw and leave the Muslims to their own devices.
If the new American peace effort succeeds, several thousand United States troops would be committed to a heavily armed NATO force to guarantee the plan, Administration officials said.
This planning has been in place for nearly two years, but until recently has not been much of an issue. But Croatia's successful military offensive against the Serbs and a split within the leadership of the Bosnian Serbs has presented an opportunity for a diplomatic settlement and forced the Pentagon to refine details on how to enforce it.
There are still several hurdles to clear before peace breaks out in the Balkans. Some Administration officials voiced skepticism that any deal was imminent. The European allies have to agree on the details. More important, the Serbs and Muslims must concur, which is far from certain.
"It has to be pursued in number of capitals," a senior Administration official said.
But if a durable peace is negotiated and Congress agrees to send troops, American forces would join a large NATO force to monitor Bosnian borders. Until the recent Croatian military offensive, NATO planners had estimated it would take as many as 35,000 NATO troops -- half of them American -- to enforce a Bosnia peace plan.
Pentagon officials said today that the loss of two eastern enclaves to the Serbs and the Croatian advances would mean there would be less territory to monitor and fewer troops, but they declined to say how many might now be required.
"Under the old plan, NATO would have done disarming and collecting heavy weapons," said a senior Pentagon planner. "This new initiative has much more limited tasks, like separating factions and providing some sort of protective envelope for the Bosnian Muslims."
The Pentagon official said the Administration "hasn't crystallized around any numbers, but it will be a smaller force with fewer missions."
"It all depends on how they the draw the map, where they put forces and what tasks would be assigned to them," the official added.
American officials say any NATO military involvement in Bosnia would most likely be measured in months, not years. "We are looking more to a Haiti model," a senior Administration official said.

HEADLINE: Severe Water Crisis Ahead for Poorest Nations in Next 2 Decades

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 9

 BODY:
In many of the world's poorest countries, a combination of industrialization without pollution controls, persistent population growth and the continued subsidizing of the cost of water for farmers is hastening the onset of a severe water crisis over the next decade or two, a World Bank study reported this week.
The report said 80 countries with 40 percent of the world's population already have water shortages that could cripple agriculture and industry. 
 "We already have 40 percent of the world's population living on rivers shared by more than one country," Ismail Serageldin, the World Bank's vice president for Environmentally Sustainable Development, said in an interview this week. "Many of the wars in this century were about oil, but wars of the next century will be over water."
Water supplies are increasingly contaminated in many regions, adding to the threat of disease. About 95 percent of the world's urban areas dump raw sewage into rivers and other bodies of water, the report said. Dirty water may be killing 10 million or more people every year and causing untold economic damage.
"Over the next 10 years, $600 billion to $800 billion will be needed for water projects in developing countries," said Mr. Serageldin, who is Egyptian. The World Bank, the largest spender on such projects, will be able to muster only $30 billion to $40 billion, he added.
The most dangerous situation is in the Middle East and North Africa, the report said. From 1960 to 2025, if present trends in population growth and water use continue, the water supply per capita will have fallen from 3,430 cubic meters to 667 cubic meters in that region. That would be an 80 percent drop in the renewable water supply in a lifetime.
In the industrial world, pressure from environmentalists is putting the largest strain on supplies. The report noted that in California, the fish and wildlife habitats, wetlands and recreational waters in lakes and rivers now use 45 percent of total resources, compared with 42 percent for agriculture.
Another recent report, produced for the International Food Policy and Research Institute in Washington, noted that California had introduced successful "water marketing" programs in problem years, during which farmers were given incentives to conserve water and sell the excess to cities.
Chile has also introduced water marketing programs, according to the same study. A Chilean farmer who can cut water use by less than a third on about 80 acres can earn up to $10,000 in extra income without reducing crop yields.
At the World Bank, Mr. Serageldin said developing countries should be encouraged to manage water resources more effectively from the grass roots up. He said pilot projects in Mexico and Pakistan had proved that incentives and powers delegated to local associations -- neighborhoods, farming cooperatives and other small-scale groups -- paid large dividends in conservation.
At the same time, the practice of providing cheap water through subsidies will have to be curtailed, Mr. Seralgedin said. Cheap water not only encourages waste but also takes pressure off governments to develop alternate supplies.
Mr. Serageldin said that in the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu, for example, the Government was still subsidizing well-drilling although the ground-water levels were falling every year. In the Punjab region, the heart of India's "green revolution," the once-rich agricultural land could begin turning to desert within two decades.

HEADLINE: Dole Courts Conservatives With Changes On Welfare

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Senator Bob Dole said today that he was picking up additional Republican support for his bill to overhaul the nation's welfare system, would call it up again soon after Labor Day and would probably tack it onto sweeping legislation to balance the Federal budget.
While Democrats celebrated their success in forcing the majority leader to postpone action on welfare, Mr. Dole, the front-running candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1996, was negotiating today with conservative Republicans, hoping to attract their support with tougher measures to discourage out-of-wedlock births. 
 Mr. Dole said today that he had deferred action on the bill so he could "find enough Republican support" to pass the bill next month, either as a free-standing piece of legislation or as a part of an omnibus spending bill.
In an interview today, Ralph Reed, executive director of the Christian Coalition, said, "The Senate Republican leadership failed to fully appreciate the significance and centrality of the religious conservative constituency in this debate, and the depth of its commitment on the issue."
Senator John Ashcroft, Republican of Missouri, spoke for many conservatives and a few liberals when he said today, "Illegitimacy is a threat to the survival of our nation and our culture."
Mr. Ashcroft and Mr. Reed endorsed a bill sponsored by one of Mr. Dole's rivals for the nomination, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas. It would offer a bonus to states that reduce out-of-wedlock births and would prohibit states from increasing welfare checks for women who have additional children while receiving welfare.
But if Mr. Dole mollifies the conservatives, he risks alienating moderate Republicans who are demanding other changes in his bill, like more money for child care. They also want to encourage states to continue spending their own money on welfare, at current levels, as a condition of getting Federal welfare aid.
Rahm I. Emanuel, a White House aide coordinating strategy on welfare, said he was distressed to see Mr. Dole trying to placate the conservatives. "There is a potential bipartisan agreement to be found here," Mr. Emanuel said. "But every time Dole plays Presidential politics with welfare reform, it gets stalled."
Senator Carol Moseley-Braun, Democrat of Illinois, said: "I am delighted that the Republicans are squabbling among themselves and we've delayed consideration of this legislation. The best antidote to the majority leader's punitive, Draconian proposal is sunshine. Let the American people see what's in the bill."
In the stylized combat now common on Capitol Hill, senators today held three news conferences to debate welfare. At 11 A.M., the Democrats attacked the Republicans. Then at 1 P.M., the Republicans counterattacked. At 3 P.M., the Democrats hit back, saying Mr. Dole had misrepresented the Democratic proposals offered as an alternative to his bill.
Democrats denounced Mr. Dole's bill on the ground that it would require parents who receive welfare to take jobs without providing any guarantee of child care. The Democrats maintain that the Federal Government should require states to guarantee child care, for children under the age of 13, if parents are on welfare and need such care so they can take jobs.
The Democrats, like the Republicans, said they intended to impose a five-year limit on welfare payments to any family. But the Republicans said that the Democrats' time limit was virtually meaningless because their bill would explicitly exempt any family that "resides in an area with an unemployment rate exceeding 7.5 percent." As a result, Mr. Dole said, people in cities like New York, Detroit, Los Angeles and Washington could continue receiving welfare year after year, generation after generation.
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, defended the proposed exception. "If you live in an area of high unemployment, exceeding 7.5 percent," he said, "you're exempt. You must work, but we are just saying that we won't throw you out in the street if it's likely that there are no jobs where you live."
After Mr. Daschle finished firing his salvos at the Republicans, Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, offered a cease-fire. "I promise not to trash their bill if they promise to quit trashing ours," said Mr. Breaux, and he proposed "high-level negotiations between the two parties."
Mr. Dole said that President Clinton "talked to me privately about working out something on welfare reform" a few weeks ago, but he gave no details.

HEADLINE: Timber Industry Ally Wields Power in Senate

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Senator Frank H. Murkowski has long been an advocate for the timber industry in his home state of Alaska. As the new chairman of the Senate's Natural Resources Committee, he is in a position of influence over the nation's forests unimaginable for a Republican when the Democrats controlled Congress.
Mr. Murkowski has seized the opportunity to introduce legislation that would increase logging in the Tongass National Forest, the vast expanse of islands and lush valleys that covers most of the Alaska Panhandle. The bill would also give a financial lift to a company in which Mr. Murkowski has a personal financial interest: the Ketchikan Pulp Company. 
 To help push the legislation through, Mr. Murkowski has hired as a Senate aide the former chief lobbyist for the timber industry, Mark E. Rey, who now heads the staff of the subcommittee on forests.
The atmosphere in Washington has seldom been more favorable toward business. Some critics said today that Mr. Murkowski's bill provided a clear example of the heightened influence of business interests in the drafting and passage of legislation.
Mr. Rey, the former vice president of the American Forest Products Association, sat next to Mr. Murkowski today at what was to have been a hearing on the legislation. Mr. Murkowski had downgraded the session to a "workshop" late Tuesday night after the Governor of Alaska, Tony Knowles, a Democrat, issued a statement denouncing the bill. Because the session was not an official hearing, no record will be made of either the statements of support or the angry denunciations of opponents, who were furious that they had flown in from Alaska for an event that turned out to have little significance.
Whether Mr. Murkowski will be able to push the legislation through in the face of formidable opposition not only from the Governor's office but from some local officials, fishermen and others worried about wildlife and pollution from some in his home state was unclear today.
He seemed to have underestimated the strength of the opposition or overestimated his newly acquired power. And his personal and political ties to the timber industry have provided his opponents with the ammunition to raise a thicket of ethical questions.
"Obviously, this is a direct conflict of interest and we recommend that he put a distance between himself and this legislation," said Bart Koehler, the executive director of the Southeast Alaska Conservation Council. "He shouldn't be working on legislation that directly benefits this pulp mill."
Mr. Murkowski declined to discuss his stock holdings today when he was asked about the matter by a reporter.
Financial disclosure statements filed with the Senate show that on May 1, 1992, Mr. Murkowski bought $1,001 to $15,000 worth of stock in the Louisiana Pacific Corporation, which owns Ketchikan Pulp, now the only timber processer in the area. That stock is now worth $15,001 to $50,000, according to Mr. Murkowski's latest filing.
The Tongass bill, sponsored by Mr. Murkowski and Alaska's other Senator, Ted Stevens, would require the United States Forest Service to provide enough timber to support 2,400 jobs in southeast Alaska, where the state's timber industry is centered. Employment in the industry has fallen to about 1,500 since 1990, when comprehensive legislation on management of the Tongass was passed.
The Murkowski-Stevens proposal is highly unusual because it would force the Forest Service to put jobs ahead of all other considerations, including pollution and wildlife concerns. If enacted, the proposal would make the Tongass the only national forest where jobs were the pre-eminent consideration.
Mr. Murkowski said today that he had canceled the hearing on the bill because it was clear that there was widespread misunderstanding about what the legislation would do.
Mr. Murkowski has apparently violated no Senate rules or broken any laws in relation to the Tongass issue and his finances. He has publicly disclosed his personal holdings on his annual statements to the Senate each year. He also has reported holdings of more than $1 million in the First Bank of Ketchikan, whose overall health is dependent on the area's economy.
"Even if it is not illegal, senators should consider it unethical if they fail to recuse themselves from doing anything but voting on issues that affect their personal assets," said Michael Calabrese, the director of Public Citizen's Congress Watch.
"In an era when we have widely held and diversified stock funds, I see no reason why members should have large individual stock holdings," Mr. Calabrese said. Those who do should refrain from acting on issues that could affect their stocks, he added.
More troubling to some is an apparent increase in the involvement of business interests in the drafting of legislation. Such influence has been a fact of life to some degree since Congress passed its first law.
"It seems to be happening much more commonly and brazenly," Mr. Calabrese said. Not only are members of the new majority turning to the lobbyisyts to write the legislation, but also hiring lobbyists directly on staff to shepherd it through."
The practice has come to be known as the "reverse revolving door."
Mr. Rey said his background with the timber industry was irrelevant to his new job in the Senate. He said his appointment to the committee staff was "no more or less appropriate" than the Clinton Administration's appointment of George Frampton, the former head of the Wilderness Society as Assistant Secretary of the Interior.
"We were hired to be public servants," Mr. Rey said, "and that is what we are.
"I am no longer representing the timber industry, and there will be some things that I will do in discharging the public trust that they won't like. I have an open door and an open mind."

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
N.B.A. Owners Settled Rather Than Risk More

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
When he announced the deadline-beating deal between the National Basketball Association and its union, Commissioner David Stern said the agreement was riskier for the owners than the first deal the two sides made in vain in June.
The economic risks Stern sees for the owners, though, would appear to be potentially less damaging than other risks they would face without an agreement. If the league and the union can sell the six-year agreement to a majority of their players, it would kill decertification and antitrust litigation, two roads fraught with uncertainties larger than New York potholes in the winter. 
 The deal isn't the one Stern and the N.B.A. owners wanted, but it at least has plunged people active in the decertification movement into a wait-and-see posture. Arn Tellem and Marc Fleisher, two active agents in the effort to decertify the union, said yesterday that they will reserve judgment on the agreement until they see the details.
"Everyone at this point has an open mind," Tellem said by telephone from Los Angeles. "I'm not going to prejudge it in any way. I think that's how my players are. They're hoping it's a good deal. If it turns out to be a deal that the players feel positive about, my sense is decertification will go away."
N.B.A. negotiators did not press for some of their demands in a four-hour bargaining session Tuesday night, the first since talks broke off Thursday, because they wanted to make a deal, end their six-week lockout of the players and insure the playing of the coming season.
"We're confident that sometime in December or January we could make a much better deal than we made last night," said Russ Granik, the league's deputy commissioner and chief negotiator. "But we know what damage would be done to the business."
League officials had said repeatedly they would not lift the lockout and start the season without an agreement. The union leadership obviously took them at their word. But the dissident players would have forged ahead with decertification and with the antitrust lawsuit scheduled for an initial hearing in Federal court in Minneapolis Sept. 6.
Now, if the majority of players like the agreement, they will vote to maintain the union as their collective bargaining representative. Without decertification, the lawsuit almost certainly would die because court decisions have favored ongoing bargaining relationships between leagues and unions.
"It's wise for the league to have taken this tact," said a lawyer who works the union side of the labor fence. "First of all, they're a much more sympathetic defendant in a lawsuit, and they have a second shot at the players. The litigation route, for all their bravado about how players are getting bad legal advice, was not without very significant legal risk to them."
The league, the lawyer added, faced the risk of treble damages over the lockout. "Stern made a judgment," the lawyer said. " 'I'll sweeten the deal a little bit to end this so I don't subject myself to treble damages, the loss of revenue, public relations damage to the sport and legal fees.' "
While Stern emphasized the importance of playing the season and continuing the league's record of never having lost a game to labor strife, he said: "I didn't want to face the risk of what decertification would bring. What we need to be, players and owners, is successful. This is not about who's either stronger or more right."
Dissident players and their agents were vehemently critical of the June 21 deal, which the player representatives subsequently rejected by refusing to vote on ratification. They were uncharacteristically reserved in their reaction to the second agreement because they hadn't seen the details.
Fleisher said if the deal is good for the players, "we're all going to applaud the improvements in it." If, on the other hand, it's viewed as a bad deal, "the players will fight for decertification."
Tellem said he would evaluate the agreement on one primary issue: Is the payroll cap a hard cap? "If veterans have no ability to move from one team to another because of the cap," he said, "then I will recommend to my players that they oppose it."
After talking with some players, the agent said, he found that the issue on everyone's mind is "how will this affect free agency."
Keith Askins of the Miami Heat is not on the level of Michael Jordan and Patrick Ewing, who have led the decertification movement.
"I don't know what Patrick or Michael want out of the deal," he said yesterday, "but for me, being one of the blue collar, middle class workers in this league, I think it's a good deal. I think it benefits everybody."
Askins said he had spoken to a teammate, Bimbo Coles, and reported that "he also likes the deal."
Simon Gourdine, the union's executive director, did not return a telephone call seeking comment on his plans for a players' vote on the agreement. Charles Smith of the Knicks, a union vice president, said he did not know if Gourdine planned to have a vote before the decertification vote Aug. 30 and Sept. 7.
"We plan on getting information out to the guys and see what happens from there," Smith said.
None of the players, though, has seen all of the details because they haven't been circulated.
The league eliminated the luxury tax that appeared in the June 21 agreement and agreed to three items the union leadership said the players wanted:
*A $1 million exception for teams over the payroll cap to sign free agents (a team can use the exception three times in the six-year life of the agreement but not two years in a row).
*Restoration of the exception that allows a team to replace an injured player at 50 percent of the player's salary, though only up to the league average.
*Addition of a modified Larry Bird exception for players competing two seasons with the same team (salary increase in the first year of a new contract would be the greater of the average salary or a 75 percent raise for a player already above the average).
The league dropped its demand for the minimum payroll to be 60 percent of the payroll cap, leaving it at the 75 percent ratio included in the June 21 agreement, down from 80 percent in the expired agreement.
The league reduced its previous position on adjustments to the cap if the collective payroll exceeds the players' percentage of the league's basketball related income. After the first three years of the agreement, if the teams exceed 50.13 percent of the income, the cap would be adjusted downward the following season up to $500,000 a team.
As an alternative, the owners could reopen the agreement after three years.

HEADLINE: SENIOR ARMY AIDES TO IRAQ PRESIDENT DEFECT TO JORDAN

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Two of Saddam Hussein's sons-in-law who were among the Iraqi leader's closest aides have defected to Jordan with their wives and a number of senior army officers, Jordanian officials said today.
The defections represented the hardest internal blow yet to the iron rule of President Hussein. 
 The defectors include Lieut. Gen. Hussein Kamel, the husband of President Hussein's eldest daughter, Raghad. General Kamel oversaw Iraq's buildup of missiles and chemical and biological weapons, and Iraq's nuclear research program.
Another defector is Hussein Kamel's brother, Col. Saddam Kamel, who is married to President Hussein's daughter Rana. Colonel Kamel was in charge of Iraq's special forces.
The Kamels are also cousins of President Hussein and members of the sprawling clan that forms Iraq's inner governing circle.
The defections underline serious and growing divisions among the sons, brothers, cousins and close relatives of the President who have come to rule Iraq since its defeat in the Persian Gulf war in 1991.
[President Clinton pledged that the United States would protect Jordan against any retaliation from Iraq, and he praised the King of Jordan for granting political asylum to the members of Saddam Hussein's family. Page A10.]
An Iraqi opposition figure said today that the defectors left Iraq on the pretext of an official visit to Bulgaria, which began with a 14-hour drive from Baghdad to Amman, apparently to take an onward flight. But it is not clear how such a large party escaped detection on the highway to Jordan, the sole land link that Iraq is permitted under United Nations sanctions.
Jordanian officials said the defectors fled on Tuesday, arriving here that night, and immediately requested political asylum, which King Hussein promptly granted at an audience in his palace.
"Two daughters of President Saddam Hussein and their husbands, Hussein and Saddam Kamel, met with King Hussein on Tuesday and made a personal plea for asylum, which was granted to them immediately," Jordan's Foreign Minister, Abdul-Karim al-Kabariti, said today.
[American officials in Washington said the defectors included some of Saddam Hussein's grandchildren.]
An Iraqi opposition figure, speaking here on condition of anonymity, said today that a third son-in-law of President Hussein, Maj. Ezzedine Mohammed Hassan, who is married to Hala, another daughter of the Iraqi President, had also defected, but this could not be verified.
Mr. Hussein has been very circumspect about his private life and little is known about his family. He is known to have two sons, Uday and Qosay, and the three daughters, of whom Raghad is the eldest.
Iraq made no comment today's on the defections. But the Government press agency did note that General Kamel had been dismissed this week as head of military industrialization.
And President Hussein sent his elder son, Uday, to Amman, where he met with King Hussein today, apparently to attempt a reconciliation or to find ways to limit the damage from the defections. In announcing the meeting, Jordanian television said that it was brief and that Uday Hussein had left to return to Iraq.
In announcing the defections, the Jordanian Government made a point of saying the Iraqis would have the protection of King Hussein, who is unrelated to the Iraqi President but who sided with Baghdad in the gulf war. In the past three years, King Hussein has distanced himself from Iraq, criticizing the Government's human rights record and calling for democracy.
The Foreign Minister, Mr. Kabariti, said he did not know the official reason for Uday Hussein's visit. But other officials expressed skepticism about the chance of reversing the defections or of getting much cooperation from King Hussein regarding sending the return of the defectors.
The whereabouts of the defectors was kept secret, but a large fleet of Mercedes Benzes with Iraqi license plates were seen this afternoon outside a Government guest palace.
The Iraqi press agency's announcement of the dismissal of General Kamel followed widespread reports of serious clashes with President Hussein's two sons. The President has allowed his sons' authority to displace that of other relatives in the ruling circle.
Uday Hussein has spread his role to all matters of policy, economy and administration; Qosay Hussein has taken over security services. The brothers are widely referred to in Iraq as the "Number 2" and "Number 3" in the Government.
In addition to the brothers, Mr. Kabariti said, "a large number of army officers was also granted asylum." In what appeared to be a warning to Iraq to refrain from any attempts to interfere, he added that Jordan had guaranteed the safety of all the Iraqis.
In the past, Iraq has sent agents to intimidate, monitor and sometimes attack defectors here. In 1992 a nuclear scientist who defected was assassinated on an Amman street.
About 30,000 Iraqis live in Amman. Many who fled for political reasons are Sunni Muslim technocrats, scientists and administrators who once formed the backbone of support for the Iraqi Government.
In recent months, despite high fees for exit visas, the flow of Iraqi refugees to Jordan, especially Sunni Muslims, has increased. Jordan allows Iraqis to enter without obtaining visas in advance.
"It seems the inner circle is deteriorating," said Kamel Abu Jaber, a former Jordanian Foreign Minister. "It's obvious the leadership is cracking."
Earlier this year, there were open clashes among the wider circle of supporters that has always formed the base of support for President Hussein's rule, particularly among Sunni Muslims and clans affiliated with his family. This group, which numbers in the hundreds of thousands, was the main source of staff members for sensitive positions in the army and intelligence and security services.
In May and June, after the execution of army officers from two major clans, the Dulaimis and the Jabours, military members of these tribes rebelled, demanding compensation and going so far as to mount small armed mutinies. President Hussein responded by ordering the arrest and dismissal of hundreds of men from these clans, further damaging his ties to an important component of his power base.
President Hussein has shown an increasingly unsteady hand in dealing with such rebellions, which have become more frequent as the economy has deteriorated under pressure of United Nations sanctions.
In a speech some weeks ago, President Hussein compared himself to the captain of a ship of mutineers, and vowed to deal ruthlessly with anyone challenging his authority. Last week he offered amnesty to political dissenters, but the opposition immediately dismissed the move as a ruse.
Some Iraqi opposition figures said today that General Kamel was such an important figure in Iraq that should he mount a political threat to President Hussein, the threat would be serious. But others maintained that General Kamel is widely hated in Iraq, and that he commanded no power base except among technocrats, who would be unable to mount a significant rebellion against President Hussein.
Furthermore, as a senior Jordanian official noted tonight, it is far from clear whether the Kamels or the daughters of President Hussein could ever cooperate with either the Shiite Muslims or the Kurds who actively oppose the Baghdad Government, or with Western powers that are trying to bring down President Hussein.
General Kamel could be of vital assistance to a United Nations team that is dismantling Iraq's weapons of mass destruction. But Rolf Ekeus of Sweden, chairman of the team, today deflected questions about whether he would meet with General Kamel.

LENGTH: 1025 words

HEADLINE: Newark Lures New Teachers By Hundreds

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Colleen Johnson had tried several times to get a teaching job in Newark's public schools, but before the state takeover last month, she had always been turned away.
"When you went to personnel you were told they were not accepting applications and they never advertised," Ms. Johnson said. "I always wanted to teach in Newark but I didn't know anyone, so I never made it." 
 She was not alone. Applicants had become so discouraged that the new state administrators who took over the troubled Newark public schools last month were not entirely sure how many candidates would show up for a one-day job fair aimed at filling the district's 130 teaching vacancies.
They were nearly swamped by the turnout today. Lines started to form around 7 A.M., two hours before the doors opened at the Rafael Hernandez Elementary School; by the end of the day, 1,400 teaching candidates had showed up. As the wait for a 20-minute interview stretched past four hours, state officials were on the phone begging the printers to rush them more applications and volunteers brought in to read brief application essays were instead pressed into service interviewing candidates.
Applicants hung on without benefit of lunch or even coffee, some pointing out that any jobs, much less jobs with a salary range of $31,000 to $69,000, were hard to come by in a city with an unemployment rate over 13 percent. Others said that they thought the takeover would allow them to do something good for children for the first time and that the wide-open application process showed a new leadership intent on ridding the system of the nepotism and cronyism that state officials have charged plague the schools here.
"This is the first year of the takeover so I want to be involved with the changes from the start," said Joseph McMorris, 26, an applicant who now heads the English Department at East Harlem Performing Arts, a Manhattan junior high school.
Dr. Beverly L. Hall, who took over as acting superintendent in Newark on July 17, toured the school today to inspect the application process, stopping at about half a dozen of the 60 tables in the library and the gymnasium where interviews were being conducted.
"This is unbelievable," said Dr. Hall, after joking that she was there to sign up. Dr. Hall said that the job fair was initially intended to speed up the process of finding enough teachers for school to start on time Sept. 11, but the fact that many excellent candidates were discovered meant that the emphasis had shifted somewhat.
"That is going to be the challenge, narrowing it down to the best, but it is good to have a choice," she said, noting that the job fair had attracted candidates from as far away as Washington, D.C. and Massachusetts.
Those to get positions will be called within two weeks, and an additional pool will be put on a waiting list to fill vacancies throughout the year, said Dr. Barbara Anderson, an assistant state Commissioner of Education who is part of the takeover team.
The takeover was the culmination of a 10-year monitoring process that showed an administration more interested in free cars and other trappings of office than in improving the low test scores and decaying buildings. Newark is New Jersey's largest district with 82 schools, 47,500 students and a budget of more than $540 million.
The people conducting the interviews said that the best candidates were those who answered the questions directly and brought a little spark to their responses. Questions included how they might react to teaching in an urban setting like Newark and how they would discipline unruly children.
Some impressed the interviewers by showing up with lesson plans or telling them about their own studies toward higher degrees. Those who were not likely to make it spoke in monotones or said things like they would discipline children by writing a report on them.
"A guy like that would not survive in Newark," said Houston Stevens, the head of the P.T.A. at University High School and one of about 60 parents participating in the interviews.
Newark parents said they were encouraged that the state administrators asked them to participate, with one parent sitting at each table along with an employee from the school district and one from the State Department of Education.
Sitting at one table, Ellen Blount said that while the two professionals focused on each candidate's credentials, she tried to figure out what parents would think about handing a child to the person.
Aside from listing their credentials and work experience, the applicants were asked to write a 100-word essay on one of two topics. The first was why they should be selected to work in the Newark public schools, the other was what kind of working relationship they would have with parents, administrators and other teachers.
One man said he would bring "energy, passion and creativity" to the job while on the second topic, another man wrote that giving any one group too much control over a child's education "tilts the equation to a rocky end."
"We want them to write a little from the heart instead of pat answers," said Barbara Scott, a senior Newark administrator who read essays for about 20 minutes before being switched to interviews because of the crush. She said about one in five were rejected for sentences that went on for half a page, wrong tenses or sentence fragments. Such mistakes were grounds for automatic disqualification, administrators said.
Applicants said the competition for teaching jobs in northern New Jersey is fierce, so despite the delays and crowds they were happy that everyone seemed to be getting an equal shot. There are 4,400 teaching jobs in Newark out of a total district staff of 8,000.
Joseph Del Grosso, president of the Newark Teachers Union, said he was surprised and pleased by the heavy turnout.
"In the past the procedure was that if you knew a board member you could get a job," said Mr. Del Grosso, a 26-year veteran of the Newark schools who became head of the union last June. "Before it was a political screening and not an educational screening. This opens up the process."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Frederick D. Johnson being interviewed by a screening panel at Newark's public schools job fair yesterday. Interviewers from the state, which has taken over the district, were swamped by people hoping to fill the city's 130 teaching vacancies. (Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times)
